 the practical usefulness of the national forest reserve to the mining grazing irrigation and other interest of the region in which the reserve lie have lead to a widespread demand by the people of the west for their protection and extension the forest reserve will inevitably be of still great use in the future than in the past addition should be make to they whenever practicable and their usefulness should be increase by a thoroughly business like management

 at present the protection of the forest reserve rest with the general land office the mapping and description of their timber with the united states geological survey and the preparation of plan for their conservative use with the bureau of forestry which be also charge with the general advancement of practical forestry in the united states these various function should be unite in the bureau of forestry to which they properly belong the present diffusion of responsibility be bad from every standpoint it prevent that effective co operation between the government and the man who utilize the resource of the reserve without which the interest of both must suffer the scientific bureaus generally should be put under the department of agriculture the president should have by law the power of transfer land for use as forest reserve to the department of agriculture he already have such power in the case of land need by the departments of war and the navy

 the wise administration of the forest reserve will be not less helpful to the interest which depend on water than to those which depend on wood and grass the water supply itself depend upon the forest in the arid region it be water not land which measure production the western half of the united states would sustain a population great than that of our whole country to day if the water that now run to waste be save and use for irrigation the forest and water problem be perhaps the most vital internal question of the united states

 certain of the forest reserve should also be make preserve for the wild forest creature all of the reserve should be well protect from fire many of they need special protection because of the great injury do by live stock above all by sheep the increase in deer elk and other animal in the yellowstone park show what may be expect when other mountain forest be properly protect by law and properly guard some of these area have be so denuded of surface vegetation by overgraze that the ground breeding bird include grouse and quail and many mammal include deer have be exterminate or drive away at the same time the water store capacity of the surface have be decrease or destroy thus promote flood in time of rain and diminish the flow of stream between rain

 in case where natural condition have be restore for a few year vegetation have again carpet the ground bird and deer be come back and hundred of person especially from the immediate neighborhood come each summer to enjoy the privilege of camping some at least of the forest reserve should afford perpetual protection to the native fauna and flora safe haven of refuge to our rapidly diminish wild animal of the large kind and free camping ground for the ever increase number of man and woman who have learn to find rest health and recreation in the splendid forest and flower clothe meadow of our mountain the forest reserve should be set apart forever for the use and benefit of our people as a whole and not sacrifice to the shortsighted greed of a few

 the forest be natural reservoir by restrain the stream in flood and replenish they in drought they make possible the use of water otherwise waste they prevent the soil from washing and so protect the storage reservoir from fill up with silt forest conservation be therefore an essential condition of water conservation

 the forest alone can not however fully regulate and conserve the water of the arid region great storage work be necessary to equalize the flow of stream and to save the flood water their construction have be conclusively show to be an undertaking too vast for private effort nor can it be well accomplish by the individual states act alone far reach interstate problem be involve and the resource of single states would often be inadequate it be properly a national function at least in some of its feature it be as right for the national government to make the stream and river of the arid region useful by engineer work for water storage as to make useful the river and harbor of the humid region by engineering work of another kind the storing of the flood in reservoir at the headwater of our river be but an enlargement of our present policy of river control under which levee be build on the low reach of the same stream

 the government should construct and maintain these reservoir as it do other public work where their purpose be to regulate the flow of stream the water should be turn freely into the channel in the dry season to take the same course under the same law as the natural flow

 the reclamation of the unsettled arid public land present a different problem here it be not enough to regulate the flow of stream the object of the government be to dispose of the land to settler who will build home upon it to accomplish this object water must be bring within their reach

 the pioneer settler on the arid public domain choose their home along stream from which they could themselves divert the water to reclaim their holding such opportunity be practically go there remain however vast area of public land which can be make available for homestead settlement but only by reservoir and main line canal impracticable for private enterprise these irrigation work should be build by the national government the land reclaim by they should be reserve by the government for actual settler and the cost of construction should so far as possible be repay by the land reclaim the distribution of the water the division of the stream among irrigator should be leave to the settler themselves in conformity with state law and without interference with those law or with vested fight the policy of the national government should be to aid irrigation in the several states and territories in such manner as will enable the people in the local community to help themselves and as will stimulate need reform in the state law and regulation govern irrigation

 the reclamation and settlement of the arid land will enrich every portion of our country just as the settlement of the ohio and mississippi valley bring prosperity to the atlantic states the increase demand for manufacture article will stimulate industrial production while wide home market and the trade of asia will consume the large food supply and effectually prevent western competition with eastern agriculture indeed the product of irrigation will be consume chiefly in upbuilde local center of mining and other industry which would otherwise not come into existence at all our people as a whole will profit for successful home making be but another name for the upbuilding of the nation

 the necessary foundation have already be lay for the inauguration of the policy just describe it would be unwise to begin by do too much for a great deal will doubtless be learn both as to what can and what can not be safely attempt by the early effort which must of necessity be partly experimental in character at the very beginning the government should make clear beyond shadow of doubt its intention to pursue this policy on line of the broad public interest no reservoir or canal should ever be build to satisfy selfish personal or local interest but only in accordance with the advice of train expert after long investigation have show the locality where all the condition combine to make the work most need and fraught with the great usefulness to the community as a whole there should be no extravagance and the believer in the need of irrigation will most benefit their cause by see to it that it be free from the least taint of excessive or reckless expenditure of the public money

 whatever the nation do for the extension of irrigation should harmonize with and tend to improve the condition of those now live on irrigated land we be not at the starting point of this development over two hundred million of private capital have already be expend in the construction of irrigation work and many million acre of arid land reclaim a high degree of enterprise and ability have be show in the work itself but as much can not be say in reference to the law relate thereto the security and value of the home create depend largely on the stability of title to water but the majority of these rest on the uncertain foundation of court decision render in ordinary suit at law with a few creditable exception the arid states have fail to provide for the certain and just division of stream in time of scarcity lax and uncertain law have make it possible to establish right to water in excess of actual use or necessity and many stream have already pass into private ownership or a control equivalent to ownership

 whoever control a stream practically control the land it render productive and the doctrine of private ownership of water apart from land can not prevail without cause endure wrong the recognition of such ownership which have be permit to grow up in the arid region should give way to a more enlightened and large recognition of the right of the public in the control and disposal of the public water supply law found upon condition obtain in humid region where water be too abundant to justify hoard it have no proper application in a dry country

 in the arid states the only right to water which should be recognize be that of use in irrigation this right should attach to the land reclaim and be inseparable therefrom grant perpetual water right to other than user without compensation to the public be open to all the objection which apply to give away perpetual franchise to the public utility of city a few of the western states have already recognize this and have incorporate in their constitution the doctrine of perpetual state ownership of water

 the benefit which have follow the unaided development of the past justify the nation&#39;s aid and co operation in the more difficult and important work yet to be accomplish law so vitally affect home as those which control the water supply will only be effective when they have the sanction of the irrigator reform can only be final and satisfactory when they come through the enlightenment of the people most concerned the large development which national aid insure should however awaken in every arid state the determination to make its irrigation system equal in justice and effectiveness that of any country in the civilized world nothing could be more unwise than for isolated community to continue to learn everything experimentally instead of profit by what be already know elsewhere we be deal with a new and momentous question in the pregnant year while institution be form and what we do will affect not only the present but future generation

 our aim should be not simply to reclaim the large area of land and provide home for the large number of people but to create for this new industry the well possible social and industrial condition and this require that we not only understand the exist situation but avail ourselves of the good experience of the time in the solution of its problem a careful study should be make both by the nation and the states of the irrigation law and condition here and abroad ultimately it will probably be necessary for the nation to co operate with the several arid states in proportion as these states by their legislation and administration show themselves fit to receive it

 in hawaii our aim must be to develop the territory on the traditional american line we do not wish a region of large estate till by cheap labor we wish a healthy american community of man who themselves till the farm they own all our legislation for the island should be shape with this end in view the well being of the average home maker must afford the true test of the healthy development of the island the land policy should as nearly as possible be model on our homestead system

 it be a pleasure to say that it be hardly more necessary to report as to puerto rico than as to any state or territory within our continental limit the island be thrive as never before and it be be administer efficiently and honestly its people be now enjoy liberty and order under the protection of the united states and upon this fact we congratulate they and ourselves their material welfare must be as carefully and jealously consider as the welfare of any other portion of our country we have give they the great gift of free access for their product to the market of the united states i ask the attention of the congress to the need of legislation concern the public land of puerto rico

 in cuba such progress have be make toward put the independent government of the island upon a firm footing that before the present session of the congress close this will be an accomplished fact cuba will then start as her own mistress and to the beautiful queen of the antilles as she unfold this new page of her destiny we extend our heartiest greeting and good wish elsewhere i have discuss the question of reciprocity in the case of cuba however there be weighty reason of morality and of national interest why the policy should be hold to have a peculiar application and i most earnestly ask your attention to the wisdom indeed to the vital need of provide for a substantial reduction in the tariff duty on cuban import into the united states cuba have in her constitution affirm what we desire that she should stand in international matter in close and more friendly relation with we than with any other power and we be bind by every consideration of honor and expediency to pass commercial measure in the interest of her material well being

 in the philippines our problem be large they be very rich tropical island inhabit by many vary tribe represent widely different stage of progress toward civilization our earnest effort be to help these people upward along the stony and difficult path that lead to self government we hope to make our administration of the island honorable to our nation by make it of the high benefit to the filipinos themselves and as an earnest of what we intend to do we point to what we have do already a great measure of material prosperity and of governmental honesty and efficiency have be attain in the philippines than ever before in their history

 it be no light task for a nation to achieve the temperamental quality without which the institution of free government be but an empty mockery our people be now successfully govern themselves because for more than a thousand year they have be slowly fit themselves sometimes consciously sometimes unconsciously toward this end what have take we thirty generation to achieve we can not expect to have another race accomplish out of hand especially when large portion of that race start very far behind the point which our ancestor have reach even thirty generation ago in deal with the philippine people we must show both patience and strength forbearance and steadfast resolution our aim be high we do not desire to do for the islander merely what have elsewhere be do for tropic people by even the good foreign government we hope to do for they what have never before be do for any people of the tropic to make they fit for self government after the fashion of the really free nation

 history may safely be challenge to show a single instance in which a masterful race such as our having be force by the exigency of war to take possession of an alien land have behave to its inhabitant with the disinterested zeal for their progress that our people have show in the philippines to leave the island at this time would mean that they would fall into a welter of murderous anarchy such desertion of duty on our part would be a crime against humanity the character of governor taft and of his associate and subordinate be a proof if such be need of the sincerity of our effort to give the islander a constantly increase measure of self government exactly as fast as they show themselves fit to exercise it since the civil government be establish not an appointment have be make in the island with any reference to consideration of political influence or to aught else save the fitness of the man and the need of the service

 in our anxiety for the welfare and progress of the philippines may be that here and there we have go too rapidly in give they local self government it be on this side that our error if any have be commit no competent observer sincerely desirous of find out the fact and influence only by a desire for the welfare of the native can assert that we have not go far enough we have go to the very verge of safety in hasten the process to have take a single step far or fast in advance would have be folly and weakness and might well have be crime we be extremely anxious that the native shall show the power of govern themselves we be anxious first for their sake and next because it relieve we of a great burden there need not be the slight fear of our not continue to give they all the liberty for which they be fit

 the only fear be test in our overanxiety we give they a degree of independence for which they be unfit thereby invite reaction and disaster as fast as there be any reasonable hope that in a give district the people can govern themselves self government have be give in that district there be not a locality fit for self government which have not receive it but it may well be that in certain case it will have to be withdraw because the inhabitant show themselves unfit to exercise it such instance have already occur in other word there be not the slight chance of our fail to show a sufficiently humanitarian spirit the danger come in the opposite direction

 there be still trouble ahead in the island the insurrection have become an affair of local bandit and marauder who deserve no high regard than the brigand of portion of the old world encouragement direct or indirect to these insurrector stand on the same footing as encouragement to hostile indians in the day when we still have indian war exactly as our aim be to give to the indian who remain peaceful the full and amplest consideration but to have it understand that we will show no weakness if he go on the warpath so we must make it evident unless we be false to our own tradition and to the demand of civilization and humanity that while we will do everything in our power for the filipino who be peaceful we will take the stern measure with the filipino who follow the path of the insurrecto and the ladrone

 the heartiest praise be due to large number of the native of the island for their steadfast loyalty the macabebes have be conspicuous for their courage and devotion to the flag i recommend that the secretary of war be empower to take some systematic action in the way of aid those of these man who be crippled in the service and the family of those who be kill

 the time have come when there should be additional legislation for the philippines nothing well can be do for the island than to introduce industrial enterprise nothing would benefit they so much as throw they open to industrial development the connection between idleness and mischief be proverbial and the opportunity to do remunerative work be one of the sure preventative of war of course no business man will go into the philippines unless it be to his interest to do so and it be immensely to the interest of the island that he should go in it be therefore necessary that the congress should pass law by which the resource of the island can be develop so that franchise for limited term of year can be grant to company do business in they and every encouragement be give to the incoming of business man of every kind

 not to permit this be to do a wrong to the philippines the franchise must be grant and the business permit only under regulation which will guarantee the island against any kind of improper exploitation but the vast natural wealth of the island must be develop and the capital willing to develop it must be give the opportunity the field must be throw open to individual enterprise which have be the real factor in the development of every region over which our flag have fly it be urgently necessary to enact suitable law deal with general transportation mining banking currency homestead and the use and ownership of the land and timber these law will give free play to industrial enterprise and the commercial development which will surely follow will accord to the people of the island the good proof of the sincerity of our desire to aid they

 i call your attention most earnestly to the cry need of a cable to hawaii and the philippines to be continue from the philippines to point in asia we should not defer a day long than necessary the construction of such a cable it be demand not merely for commercial but for political and military consideration

 either the congress should immediately provide for the construction of a government cable or else an arrangement should be make by which like advantage to those accrue from a government cable may be secure to the government by contract with a private cable company

 no single great material work which remain to be undertake on this continent be of such consequence to the american people as the building of a canal across the isthmus connect north and south america its importance to the nation be by no mean limit merely to its material effect upon our business prosperity and yet with view to these effect alone it would be to the last degree important for we immediately to begin it while its beneficial effect would perhaps be most mark upon the pacific coast and the gulf and south atlantic states it would also greatly benefit other section it be emphatically a work which it be for the interest of the entire country to begin and complete as soon as possible it be one of those great work which only a great nation can undertake with prospect of success and which when do be not only permanent asset in the nation&#39;s material interest but stand monument to its constructive ability

 i be glad to be able to announce to you that our negotiation on this subject with great britain conduct on both side in a spirit of friendliness and mutual good will and respect have result in my be able to lay before the senate a treaty which if ratify will enable we to begin preparation for an isthmian canal at any time and which guarantee to this nation every right that it have ever ask in connection with the canal in this treaty the old clayton bulwer treaty so long recognize as inadequate to supply the base for the construction and maintenance of a necessarily american ship canal be abrogate it specifically provide that the united states alone shall do the work of building and assume the responsibility of safeguard the canal and shall regulate its neutral use by all nation on term of equality without the guaranty or interference of any outside nation from any quarter the sign treaty will at once be lay before the senate and if approve the congress can then proceed to give effect to the advantage it secure we by provide for the building of the canal

 the true end of every great and free people should be self respect peace and this nation most earnestly desire sincere and cordial friendship with all other over the entire world of recent year war between the great civilized power have become less and less frequent war with barbarous or semi barbarous people come in an entirely different category be merely a most regrettable but necessary international police duty which must be perform for the sake of the welfare of mankind peace can only be keep with certainty where both side wish to keep it but more and more the civilized people be realize the wicked folly of war and be attain that condition of just and intelligent regard for the right of other which will in the end as we hope and believe make world wide peace possible the peace conference at the hague give definite expression to this hope and belief and mark a stride toward their attainment

 this same peace conference acquiesce in our statement of the monroe doctrine as compatible with the purpose and aim of the conference

 the monroe doctrine should be the cardinal feature of the foreign policy of all the nation of the two americas as it be of the united states just seventy eight year have pass since president monroe in his annual message announce that the american continent be henceforth not to be consider as subject for future colonization by any european power in other word the monroe doctrine be a declaration that there must be no territorial aggrandizement by any non american power at the expense of any american power on american soil it be in no wise intend as hostile to any nation in the old world still less be it intend to give cover to any aggression by one new world power at the expense of any other it be simply a step and a long step toward assure the universal peace of the world by secure the possibility of permanent peace on this hemisphere

 during the past century other influence have establish the permanence and independence of the small state of europe through the monroe doctrine we hope to be able to safeguard like independence and secure like permanence for the less among the new world nation

 this doctrine have nothing to do with the commercial relation of any american power save that it in truth allow each of they to form such as it desire in other word it be really a guaranty of the commercial independence of the americas we do not ask under this doctrine for any exclusive commercial dealing with any other american state we do not guarantee any state against punishment if it misconduct itself provide that punishment do not take the form of the acquisition of territory by any non american power

 our attitude in cuba be a sufficient guaranty of our own good faith we have not the slight desire to secure any territory at the expense of any of our neighbor we wish to work with they hand in hand so that all of we may be uplifted together and we rejoice over the good fortune of any of they we gladly hail their material prosperity and political stability and be concerned and alarm if any of they fall into industrial or political chaos we do not wish to see any old world military power grow up on this continent or to be compel to become a military power ourselves the people of the americas can prosper good if leave to work out their own salvation in their own way

 the work of upbuilde the navy must be steadily continue no one point of our policy foreign or domestic be more important than this to the honor and material welfare and above all to the peace of our nation in the future whether we desire it or not we must henceforth recognize that we have international duty no less than international right even if our flag be haul down in the philippines and puerto rico even if we decide not to build the isthmian canal we should need a thoroughly train navy of adequate size or else be prepare definitely and for all time to abandon the idea that our nation be among those whose son go down to the sea in ship unless our commerce be always to be carry in foreign bottom we must have war craft to protect it

 inasmuch however as the american people have no thought of abandon the path upon which they have enter and especially in view of the fact that the building of the isthmian canal be fast become one of the matter which the whole people be unite in demand it be imperative that our navy should be put and keep in the high state of efficiency and should be make to answer to our grow need so far from be in any way a provocation to war an adequate and highly train navy be the good guaranty against war the cheap and most effective peace insurance the cost of build and maintain such a navy represent the very light premium for insure peace which this nation can possibly pay

 probably no other great nation in the world be so anxious for peace as we be there be not a single civilized power which have anything whatever to fear from aggressiveness on our part all we want be peace and toward this end we wish to be able to secure the same respect for our right from other which we be eager and anxious to extend to their right in return to insure fair treatment to we commercially and to guarantee the safety of the american people

 our people intend to abide by the monroe doctrine and to insist upon it as the one sure mean of secure the peace of the western hemisphere the navy offer we the only mean of make our insistence upon the monroe doctrine anything but a subject of derision to whatever nation choose to disregard it we desire the peace which come as of right to the just man arm not the peace grant on term of ignominy to the craven and the weakling

 it be not possible to improvise a navy after war break out the ship must be build and the man train long in advance some auxiliary vessel can be turn into makeshift which will do in default of any well for the minor work and a proportion of raw man can be mix with the highly train their shortcoming be make good by the skill of their fellow but the efficient fight force of the navy when pit against an equal opponent will be find almost exclusively in the war ship that have be regularly build and in the officer and man who through year of faithful performance of sea duty have be train to handle their formidable but complex and delicate weapon with the high efficiency in the late war with spain the ship that deal the decisive blow at manila and santiago have be launch from two to fourteen year and they be able to do as they do because the man in the con tower the gun turret and the engine room have through long year of practice at sea learn how to do their duty

 our present navy be begin in 1882 at that period our navy consist of a collection of antiquated wooden ship already almost as out of place against modern war vessel as the galley of alcibiades and hamilcar certainly as the ship of tromp and blake nor at that time do we have man fit to handle a modern man of war under the wise legislation of the congress and the successful administration of a succession of patriotic secretary of the navy belong to both political party the work of upbuilde the navy go on and ship equal to any in the world of their kind be continually add and what be even more important these ship be exercise at sea singly and in squadron until the man aboard they be able to get the good possible service out of they the result be see in the short war with spain which be decide with such rapidity because of the infinitely great preparedness of our navy than of the spanish navy

 while award the full honor to the man who actually command and man the ship which destroy the spanish sea force in the philippines and in cuba we must not forget that an equal meed of praise belong to those without whom neither blow could have be strike the congressman who vote year in advance the money to lay down the ship to build the gun to buy the armor plate the department official and the business man and wage worker who furnish what the congress have authorize the secretary of the navy who ask for and expend the appropriation and finally the officer who in fair weather and foul on actual sea service train and discipline the crew of the ship when there be no war in sight all be entitle to a full share in the glory of manila and santiago and the respect accord by every true american to those who work such signal triumph for our country it be forethought and preparation which secure we the overwhelming triumph of 1898 if we fail to show forethought and preparation now there may come a time when disaster will befall we instead of triumph and should this time come the fault will rest primarily not upon those whom the accident of event put in supreme command at the moment but upon those who have fail to prepare in advance

 there should be no cessation in the work of complete our navy so far ingenuity have be wholly unable to devise a substitute for the great war craft whose hammer gun beat out the mastery of the high sea it be unsafe and unwise not to provide this year for several additional battle ship and heavy armored cruiser with auxiliary and light craft in proportion for the exact number and character i refer you to the report of the secretary of the navy but there be something we need even more than additional ship and this be additional officer and man to provide battle ship and cruiser and then lie they up with the expectation of leave they unmanned until they be need in actual war would be bad than folly it would be a crime against the nation

 to send any war ship against a competent enemy unless those aboard it have be train by year of actual sea service include incessant gunnery practice would be to invite not merely disaster but the bitter shame and humiliation four thousand additional seaman and one thousand additional marine should be provide and an increase in the officer should be provide by make a large addition to the class at annapolis there be one small matter which should be mention in connection with annapolis the pretentious and unmeaning title of naval cadet should be abolish the title of midshipman full of historic association should be restore

 even in time of peace a war ship should be use until it wear out for only so can it be keep fit to respond to any emergency the officer and man alike should be keep as much as possible on blue water for it be there only they can learn their duty as they should be learn the big vessel should be manoeuvre in squadron contain not merely battle ship but the necessary proportion of cruiser and scout the torpedo boat should be handle by the young officer in such manner as will well fit the latter to take responsibility and meet the emergency of actual warfare

 every detail ashore which can be perform by a civilian should be so perform the officer be keep for his special duty in the sea service above all gunnery practice should be unceasing it be important to have our navy of adequate size but it be even more important that ship for ship it should equal in efficiency any navy in the world this be possible only with highly drill crew and officer and this in turn imperatively demand continuous and progressive instruction in target practice ship handling squadron tactic and general discipline our ship must be assemble in squadron actively cruise away from harbor and never long at anchor the result wear upon engine and hull must be endure a battle ship wear out in long training of officer and man be well pay for by the result while on the other hand no matter in how excellent condition it be useless if the crew be not expert

 we now have seventeen battle ship appropriate for of which nine be complete and have be commission for actual service the remain eight will be ready in from two to four year but it will take at least that time to recruit and train the man to fight they it be of vast concern that we have train crew ready for the vessel by the time they be commission good ship and good gun be simply good weapon and the good weapon be useless save in the hand of man who know how to fight with they the man must be train and drill under a thorough and well plan system of progressive instruction while the recruiting must be carry on with still great vigor every effort must be make to exalt the main function of the officer the command of man the lead graduate of the naval academy should be assign to the combatant branch the line and marine

 many of the essential of success be already recognize by the general board which as the central office of a grow staff be move steadily toward a proper war efficiency and a proper efficiency of the whole navy under the secretary this general board by foster the creation of a general staff be provide for the official and then the general recognition of our altered condition as a nation and of the true meaning of a great war fleet which mean be first the good man and second the good ship the naval militia force be state organization and be train for coast service and in event of war they will constitute the inner line of defense they should receive hearty encouragement from the general government

 but in addition we should at once provide for a national naval reserve organize and train under the direction of the navy department and subject to the call of the chief executive whenever war become imminent it should be a real auxiliary to the naval seagoe peace establishment and offer material to be draw on at once for man our ship in time of war it should be compose of graduate of the naval academy graduate of the naval militia officer and crew of coast line steamer longshore schooner fishing vessel and steam yacht together with the coast population about such center as lifesave station and light house

 the american people must either build and maintain an adequate navy or else make up their mind definitely to accept a secondary position in international affair not merely in political but in commercial matter it have be well say that there be no surer way of court national disaster than to be opulent aggressive and unarmed

 it be not necessary to increase our army beyond its present size at this time but it be necessary to keep it at the high point of efficiency the individual unit who as officer and enlisted man compose this army be we have good reason to believe at least as efficient as those of any other army in the entire world it be our duty to see that their training be of a kind to insure the high possible expression of power to these unit when act in combination

 the condition of modern war be such as to make an infinitely heavy demand than ever before upon the individual character and capacity of the officer and the enlisted man and to make it far more difficult for man to act together with effect at present the fighting must be do in extended order which mean that each man must act for himself and at the same time act in combination with other with whom he be no long in the old fashioned elbow to elbow touch under such condition a few man of the high excellence be worth more than many man without the special skill which be only find as the result of special training apply to man of exceptional physique and morale but nowadays the most valuable fighting man and the most difficult to perfect be the rifleman who be also a skillful and daring rider

 the proportion of our cavalry regiment have wisely be increase the american cavalryman train to manoeuvre and fight with equal facility on foot and on horseback be the good type of soldier for general purpose now to be find in the world the ideal cavalryman of the present day be a man who can fight on foot as effectively as the good infantryman and who be in addition unsurpasse in the care and management of his horse and in his ability to fight on horseback

 a general staff should be create as for the present staff and supply department they should be fill by detail from the line the man so detailed return after a while to their line duty it be very undesirable to have the senior grade of the army compose of man who have come to fill the position by the mere fact of seniority a system should be adopt by which there shall be an elimination grade by grade of those who seem unfit to render the good service in the next grade justice to the veteran of the civil war who be still in the army would seem to require that in the matter of retirement they be give by law the same privilege accord to their comrade in the navy

 the process of elimination of the least fit should be conduct in a manner that would render it practically impossible to apply political or social pressure on behalf of any candidate so that each man may be judge purely on his own merit pressure for the promotion of civil official for political reason be bad enough but it be tenfold bad where apply on behalf of officer of the army or navy every promotion and every detail under the war department must be make solely with regard to the good of the service and to the capacity and merit of the man himself no pressure political social or personal of any kind will be permit to exercise the least effect in any question of promotion or detail and if there be reason to believe that such pressure be exercise at the instigation of the officer concern it will be hold to militate against he in our army we can not afford to have reward or duty distribute save on the simple ground that those who by their own merit be entitle to the reward get they and that those who be peculiarly fit to do the duty be choose to perform they

 every effort should be make to bring the army to a constantly increase state of efficiency when on actual service no work save that directly in the line of such service should be require the paper work in the army as in the navy should be greatly reduce what be need be prove power of command and capacity to work well in the field constant care be necessary to prevent dry rot in the transportation and commissary department

 our army be so small and so much scatter that it be very difficult to give the high officer as well as the low officer and the enlisted man a chance to practice manoeuvre in mass and on a comparatively large scale in time of need no amount of individual excellence would avail against the paralysis which would follow inability to work as a coherent whole under skillful and daring leadership the congress should provide mean whereby it will be possible to have field exercise by at least a division of regular and if possible also a division of national guardsman once a year these exercise might take the form of field manoeuvre or if on the gulf coast or the pacific or atlantic sea- board or in the region of the great lakes the army corps when assemble could be march from some inland point to some point on the water there embark disembark after a couple of days&#39 journey at some other point and again march inland only by actual handling and provide for man in masse while they be march camping embarking and disembarking will it be possible to train the high officer to perform their duty well and smoothly

 a great debt be owe from the public to the man of the army and navy they should be so treat as to enable they to reach the high point of efficiency so that they may be able to respond instantly to any demand make upon they to sustain the interest of the nation and the honor of the flag the individual american enlisted man be probably on the whole a more formidable fighting man than the regular of any other army every consideration should be show he and in return the high standard of usefulness should be exact from he it be well worth while for the congress to consider whether the pay of enlisted man upon second and subsequent enlistment should not be increase to correspond with the increase value of the veteran soldier

 much good have already come from the act reorganize the army pass early in the present year the three prime reform all of they of literally inestimable value be first the substitution of four year detail from the line for permanent appointment in the so call staff division second the establishment of a corps of artillery with a chief at the head third the establishment of a maximum and minimum limit for the army it would be difficult to overestimate the improvement in the efficiency of our army which these three reform be make and have in part already effect

 the reorganization provide for by the act have be substantially accomplish the improved condition in the philippines have enable the war department materially to reduce the military charge upon our revenue and to arrange the number of soldier so as to bring this number much near to the minimum than to the maximum limit establish by law there be however need of supplementary legislation thorough military education must be provide and in addition to the regular the advantage of this education should be give to the officer of the national guard and other in civil life who desire intelligently to fit themselves for possible military duty the officer should be give the chance to perfect themselves by study in the high branch of this art at west point the education should be of the kind most apt to turn out man who be good in actual field service too much stress should not be lay on mathematic nor should proficiency therein be hold to establish the right of entry to a corps d&#39;elite the typical american officer of the good kind need not be a good mathematician but he must be able to master himself to control other and to show boldness and fertility of resource in every emergency

 action should be take in reference to the militia and to the raising of volunteer force our militia law be obsolete and worthless the organization and armament of the national guard of the several states which be treat as militia in the appropriation by the congress should be make identical with those provide for the regular force the obligation and duty of the guard in time of war should be carefully define and a system establish by law under which the method of procedure of raise volunteer force should be prescribe in advance it be utterly impossible in the excitement and haste of impend war to do this satisfactorily if the arrangement have not be make long beforehand provision should be make for utilize in the first volunteer organization call out the training of those citizen who have already have experience under arm and especially for the selection in advance of the officer of any force which may be raise for careful selection of the kind necessary be impossible after the outbreak of war

 that the army be not at all a mere instrument of destruction have be show during the last three year in the philippines cuba and puerto rico it have prove itself a great constructive force a most potent implement for the upbuilding of a peaceful civilization

 no other citizen deserve so well of the republic as the veteran the survivor of those who save the union they do the one deed which if left undo would have mean that all else in our history go for nothing but for their steadfast prowess in the great crisis of our history all our annal would be meaningless and our great experiment in popular freedom and self government a gloomy failure moreover they not only leave we a united nation but they leave we also as a heritage the memory of the mighty deed by which the nation be keep united we be now indeed one nation one in fact as well as in name we be unite in our devotion to the flag which be the symbol of national greatness and unity and the very completeness of our union enable we all in every part of the country to glory in the valor show alike by the son of the north and the son of the south in the time that try men&#39;s soul

 the man who in the last three year have do so well in the east and the west indies and on the mainland of asia have show that this remembrance be not lose in any serious crisis the united states must rely for the great mass of its fight man upon the volunteer soldiery who do not make a permanent profession of the military career and whenever such a crisis arise the deathless memory of the civil war will give to americans the lift of lofty purpose which come to those whose father have stand valiantly in the forefront of the battle

 the merit system of make appointment be in its essence as democratic and american as the common school system itself it simply mean that in clerical and other position where the duty be entirely non political all applicant should have a fair field and no favor each stand on his merit as he be able to show they by practical test write competitive examination offer the only available mean in many case for apply this system in other case as where laborer be employ a system of registration undoubtedly can be widely extend there be of course place where the write competitive examination can not be apply and other where it offer by no mean an ideal solution but where under exist political condition it be though an imperfect mean yet the good present mean of get satisfactory result

 wherever the condition have permit the application of the merit system in its full and widest sense the gain to the government have be immense the navy yard and postal service illustrate probably well than any other branch of the government the great gain in economy efficiency and honesty due to the enforcement of this principle

 i recommend the passage of a law which will extend the classified service to the district of columbia or will at least enable the president thus to extend it in my judgment all law provide for the temporary employment of clerk should hereafter contain a provision that they be select under the civil service law

 it be important to have this system obtain at home but it be even more important to have it apply rigidly in our insular possession not an office should be fill in the philippines or puerto rico with any regard to the man&#39;s partisan affiliation or service with any regard to the political social or personal influence which he may have at his command in short heed should be pay to absolutely nothing save the man&#39;s own character and capacity and the need of the service

 the administration of these island should be as wholly free from the suspicion of partisan politic as the administration of the army and navy all that we ask from the public servant in the philippines or puerto rico be that he reflect honor on his country by the way in which he make that country&#39; rule a benefit to the people who have come under it this be all that we should ask and we can not afford to be content with less

 the merit system be simply one method of secure honest and efficient administration of the government and in the long run the sole justification of any type of government lie in its proving itself both honest and efficient

 the consular service be now organize under the provision of a law pass in 1856 which be entirely inadequate to exist condition the interest show by so many commercial body throughout the country in the reorganization of the service be heartily commend to your attention several bill provide for a new consular service have in recent year be submit to the congress they be base upon the just principle that appointment to the service should be make only after a practical test of the applicant&#39; fitness that promotion should be govern by trustworthiness adaptability and zeal in the performance of duty and that the tenure of office should be unaffected by partisan consideration

 the remarkable growth of the postal service be show in the fact that its revenue have double and its expenditure have nearly double within twelve year its progressive development compels constantly increase outlay but in this period of business energy and prosperity its receipt grow so much fast than its expense that the annual deficit have be steadily reduce from $ 11,411,779 in 1897 to $ 3,923,727 in 1901 among recent postal advance the success of rural free delivery wherever establish have be so marked and actual experience have make its benefit so plain that the demand for its extension be general and urgent

 it be just that the great agricultural population should share in the improvement of the service the number of rural route now in operation be 6,009 practically all establish within three year and there be 6,000 application await action it be expect that the number in operation at the close of the current fiscal year will reach 8,600 the mail will then be daily carry to the door of 5,700,000 of our people who have heretofore be dependent upon distant office and one third of all that portion of the country which be adapt to it will be cover by this kind of service

 the general term of the settlement of the question grow out of the antiforeign uprising in china of 1900 having be formulate in a joint note address to china by the representative of the injure power in december last be promptly accept by the chinese government after protract conference the plenipotentiary of the several power be able to sign a final protocol with the chinese plenipotentiary on the 7th of last september set forth the measure take by china in compliance with the demand of the joint note and express their satisfaction therewith it will be lay before the congress with a report of the plenipotentiary on behalf of the united states mr. william woodville rockhill to whom high praise be due for the tact good judgment and energy he have display in perform an exceptionally difficult and delicate task

 the agreement reach dispose in a manner satisfactory to the power of the various ground of complaint and will contribute materially to well future relation between china and the power reparation have be make by china for the murder of foreigner during the uprising and punishment have be inflict on the official however high in rank recognize as responsible for or having participate in the outbreak official examination have be forbid for a period of five year in all city in which foreigner have be murder or cruelly treat and edict have be issue make all official directly responsible for the future safety of foreigner and for the suppression of violence against they

 provision have be make for insure the future safety of the foreign representative in peking by set aside for their exclusive use a quarter of the city which the power can make defensible and in which they can if necessary maintain permanent military guard by dismantle the military work between the capital and the sea and by allow the temporary maintenance of foreign military post along this line an edict have be issue by the emperor of china prohibit for two year the importation of arm and ammunition into china china have agree to pay adequate indemnity to the state society and individual for the loss sustain by they and for the expense of the military expedition send by the various power to protect life and restore order

 under the provision of the joint note of december 1900 china have agree to revise the treaty of commerce and navigation and to take such other step for the purpose of facilitate foreign trade as the foreign power may decide to be need

 the chinese government have agree to participate financially in the work of better the water approach to shanghai and to tientsin the center of foreign trade in central and northern china and an international conservancy board in which the chinese government be largely represent have be provide for the improvement of the shanghai river and the control of its navigation in the same line of commercial advantage a revision of the present tariff on import have be assent to for the purpose of substitute specific for ad valorem duty and an expert have be send abroad on the part of the united states to assist in this work a list of article to remain free of duty include flour cereal and rice gold and silver coin and bullion have also be agree upon in the settlement

 during these trouble our government have unswervingly advocate moderation and have materially aid in bring about an adjustment which tend to enhance the welfare of china and to lead to a more beneficial intercourse between the empire and the modern world while in the critical period of revolt and massacre we do our full share in safe guard life and property restore order and vindicate the national interest and honor it behoove we to continue in these path do what lie in our power to foster feeling of good will and leave no effort untried to work out the great policy of full and fair intercourse between china and the nation on a footing of equal right and advantage to all we advocate the open door with all that it imply not merely the procurement of enlarge commercial opportunity on the coast but access to the interior by the waterway with which china have be so extraordinarily favor only by bring the people of china into peaceful and friendly community of trade with all the people of the earth can the work now auspiciously begin be carry to fruition in the attainment of this purpose we necessarily claim parity of treatment under the convention throughout the empire for our trade and our citizen with those of all other power
