 to the senate and house of representatives
 i deem it important before the adjournment of the present session of congress to call attention to the follow expression in the message which in the discharge of the duty impose upon i by the constitution i send to congress on the first tuesday of december last
 elsewhere i have discuss the question of reciprocity in the case of cuba however there be weighty reason of morality and of national interest why the policy should be hold to have a peculiar application and i most earnestly ask your attention to the wisdom indeed to the vital need of provide for a substantial reduction in the tariff duty on cuban import into the united states cuba have in her constitution affirm what we desire that she should stand in international matter in close and more friendly relation with we than with any other power and we be bind by every consideration of honor and expediency to pass commercial measure in the interest of her material well be
 this recommendation be merely give practical effect to president mckinley&#39;s word when in his message of december 5 1898 and december 5 1899 he write
 it be important that our relation with this people of cuba shall be of the most friendly character and our commercial relation close and reciprocal we have accept a trust the fulfillment of which call for the stern integrity of purpose and the exercise of the high wisdom the new cuba yet to arise from the ashe of the past must need be bind to we by tie of singular intimacy and strength if its endure welfare be to be assure the great blessing which can come to cuba be the restoration of her agricultural and industrial prosperity
 yesterday june 12 i receive by cable from the american minister in cuba a most earnest appeal from president palms for legislative relief before it be too late and his country financially ruin
 the granting of reciprocity with cuba be a proposition which stand entirely alone the reason for it far outweigh those for grant reciprocity with any other nation and be entirely consistent with preserve intact the protective system under which this country have thrive so marvelously the present tariff law be design to promote the adoption of such a reciprocity treaty and expressly provide for a reduction not to exceed 20 per cent upon good come from a particular country leave the tariff rate on the same article unchanged as regard all other country objection have be make to the granting of the reduction on the ground that the substantial benefit would not go to the agricultural producer of sugar but would inure to the american sugar refiner in my judgment provision can and should be make which will guarantee we against this possibility without having recourse to a measure of doubtful policy such as a bounty in the form of a rebate
 the question as to which if any of the different schedule of the tariff ought most properly to be revise do not enter into this matter in any way or shape we be concern with get a friendly reciprocal arrangement with cuba this arrangement apply to all the article that cuba grow or produce it be not in our power to determine what these article shall be and any discussion of the tariff as it affect special schedule or country other than cuba be wholly aside from the subject matter to which i call your attention
 some of our citizen oppose the lowering of the tariff on cuban product just as three year ago they oppose the admission of the hawaiian islands lest free trade with they might ruin certain of our interest here in the actual event their fear prove baseless as regard hawaii and their apprehension as to the damage to any industry of our own because of the propose measure of reciprocity with cuba seem to i equally baseless in my judgment no american industry will be hurt and many american industry will be benefit by the propose action it be to our advantage as a nation that the grow cuban market should be control by american producer
 the event follow the war with spain and the prospective building of the isthmian canal render it certain that we must take in the future a far great interest than hitherto in what happen throughout the west indies central america and the adjacent coast and water we expect cuba to treat we on an exceptional footing politically and we should put she in the same exceptional position economically the propose action be in line with the course we have pursue as regard all the island with which we have be bring into relation of vary intimacy by the spanish war puerto rico and hawaii have be include within our tariff line to their great benefit as well as ours and without any of the fear detriment to our own industry the philippines which stand in a different relation have be grant substantial tariff concession
 cuba be an independent republic but a republic which have assume certain special obligation as regard her international position in compliance with our request i ask for her certain special economic concession in return these economic concession to benefit we as well as she there be few bright page in american history than the page which tell of our dealing with cuba during the past four year on her behalf we wage a war of which the mainspring be generous indignation against oppression and we have keep faith absolutely it be earnestly to be hope that we will complete in the same spirit the record so well begun and show in our dealing with cuba that steady continuity of policy which it be essential for our nation to establish in foreign affair if we desire to play well our part as a world power
 we be a wealthy and powerful nation cuba be a young republic still weak who owe to we her birth whose whole future whose very life must depend on our attitude toward she i ask that we help she as she struggle upward along the painful and difficult road of self- govern independence i ask this aid for she because she be weak because she need it because we have already aid she i ask that open handed help of a kind which a serf respect people can accept be give to cuba for the very reason that we have give she such help in the past our soldier fight to give her freedom and for three year our representative civil and military have toil unceasingly face disease of a peculiarly sinister and fatal type with patient and uncomplaine fortitude to teach she how to use aright her new freedom never in history have any alien country be thus administer with such high integrity of purpose such wise judgment and such single minded devotion to the country&#39; interest now i ask that the cubans be give all possible chance to use to the good advantage the freedom of which americans have such right to be proud and for which so many american life have be sacrifice

to the senate and house of representatives

 we still continue in a period of unbounded prosperity this prosperity be not the creature of law but undoubtedly the law under which we work have be instrumental in create the condition which make it possible and by unwise legislation it would be easy enough to destroy it there will undoubtedly be period of depression the wave will recede but the tide will advance this nation be seat on a continent flank by two great ocean it be compose of man the descendant of pioneer or in a sense pioneer themselves of man winnow out from among the nation of the old world by the energy boldness and love of adventure find in their own eager heart such a nation so place will surely wrest success from fortune

 as a people we have play a large part in the world and we be bent upon make our future even large than the past in particular the event of the last four year have definitely decide that for woe or for weal our place must be great among the nation we may either fall greatly or succeed greatly but we can not avoid the endeavor from which either great failure or great success must come even if we would we can not play a small part if we should try all that would follow would be that we should play a large part ignobly and shamefully

 but our people the son of the man of the civil war the son of the man who have iron in their blood rejoice in the present and face the future high of heart and resolute of will ours be not the creed of the weakling and the coward ours be the gospel of hope and of triumphant endeavor we do not shrink from the struggle before we there be many problem for we to face at the outset of the twentieth century grave problem abroad and still graver at home but we know that we can solve they and solve they well provide only that we bring to the solution the quality of head and heart which be show by the man who in the day of washington round this government and in the day of lincoln preserve it

 no country have ever occupy a high plane of material well being than our at the present moment this well being be due to no sudden or accidental cause but to the play of the economic force in this country for over a century to our law our sustained and continuous policy above all to the high individual average of our citizenship great fortune have be win by those who have take the lead in this phenomenal industrial development and most of these fortune have be win not by do evil but as an incident to action which have benefit the community as a whole never before have material well being be so widely diffused among our people great fortune have be accumulate and yet in the aggregate these fortune be small indeed when compare to the wealth of the people as a whole the plain people be well off than they have ever be before the insurance company which be practically mutual benefit society especially helpful to man of moderate mean represent accumulation of capital which be among the large in this country there be more deposit in the saving bank more owner of farm more well pay wage worker in this country now than ever before in our history of course when the condition have favor the growth of so much that be good they have also favor somewhat the growth of what be evil it be eminently necessary that we should endeavor to cut out this evil but let we keep a due sense of proportion let we not in fix our gaze upon the less evil forget the great good the evil be real and some of they be menacing but they be the outgrowth not of misery or decadence but of prosperity of the progress of our gigantic industrial development this industrial development must not be check but side by side with it should go such progressive regulation as will diminish the evil we should fail in our duty if we do not try to remedy the evil but we shall succeed only if we proceed patiently with practical common sense as well as resolution separate the good from the bad and hold on to the former while endeavor to get rid of the latter

 in my message to the present congress at its first session i discuss at length the question of the regulation of those big corporation commonly do an interstate business often with some tendency to monopoly which be popularly know as trust the experience of the past year have emphasize in my opinion the desirability of the step i then propose a fundamental requisite of social efficiency be a high standard of individual energy and excellence but this be in no wise inconsistent with power to act in combination for aim which can not so well be achieve by the individual act alone a fundamental base of civilization be the inviolability of property but this be in no wise inconsistent with the right of society to regulate the exercise of the artificial power which it confer upon the owner of property under the name of corporate franchise in such a way as to prevent the misuse of these power corporation and especially combination of corporation should be manage under public regulation experience have show that under our system of government the necessary supervision can not be obtain by state action it must therefore be achieve by national action our aim be not to do away with corporation on the contrary these big aggregation be an inevitable development of modern industrialism and the effort to destroy they would be futile unless accomplish in way that would work the utmost mischief to the entire body politic we can do nothing of good in the way of regulate and supervise these corporation until we fix clearly in our mind that we be not attack the corporation but endeavor to do away with any evil in they we be not hostile to they we be merely determined that they shall be so handle as to subserve the public good we draw the line against misconduct not against wealth the capitalist who alone or in conjunction with his fellow perform some great industrial feat by which he win money be a welldoer not a wrongdoer provide only he work in proper and legitimate line we wish to favor such a man when he do well we wish to supervise and control his action only to prevent he from do ill publicity can do no harm to the honest corporation and we need not be over tender about spare the dishonest corporation

 in curb and regulate the combination of capital which be or may become injurious to the public we must be careful not to stop the great enterprise which have legitimately reduce the cost of production not to abandon the place which our country have win in the leadership of the international industrial world not to strike down wealth with the result of close factory and mine of turn the wage worker idle in the street and leave the farmer without a market for what he grow insistence upon the impossible mean delay in achieve the possible exactly as on the other hand the stubborn defense alike of what be good and what be bad in the exist system the resolute effort to obstruct any attempt at betterment betray blindness to the historic truth that wise evolution be the sure safeguard against revolution

 no more important subject can come before the congress than this of the regulation of interstate business this country can not afford to sit supine on the plea that under our peculiar system of government we be helpless in the presence of the new condition and unable to grapple with they or to cut out whatever of evil have arise in connection with they the power of the congress to regulate interstate commerce be an absolute and unqualified grant and without limitation other than those prescribe by the constitution the congress have constitutional authority to make all law necessary and proper for execute this power and i be satisfied that this power have not be exhaust by any legislation now on the statute book it be evident therefore that evil restrictive of commercial freedom and entail restraint upon national commerce fall within the regulative power of the congress and that a wise and reasonable law would be a necessary and proper exercise of congressional authority to the end that such evil should be eradicate

 i believe that monopoly unjust discrimination which prevent or cripple competition fraudulent overcapitalization and other evil in trust organization and practice which injuriously affect interstate trade can be prevent under the power of the congress to regulate commerce with foreign nation and among the several states through regulation and requirement operate directly upon such commerce the instrumentality thereof and those engage therein

 i earnestly recommend this subject to the consideration of the congress with a view to the passage of a law reasonable in its provision and effective in its operation upon which the question can be finally adjudicate that now raise doubt as to the necessity of constitutional amendment if it prove impossible to accomplish the purpose above set forth by such a law then assuredly we should not shrink from amend the constitution so as to secure beyond peradventure the power seek

 the congress have not heretofore make any appropriation for the well enforcement of the antitrust law as it now stand very much have be do by the department of justice in secure the enforcement of this law but much more could be do if the congress would make a special appropriation for this purpose to be expend under the direction of the attorney general

 one proposition advocate have be the reduction of the tariff as a means of reach the evil of the trust which fall within the category i have describe not merely would this be wholly ineffective but the diversion of our effort in such a direction would mean the abandonment of all intelligent attempt to do away with these evil many of the large corporation many of those which should certainly be include in any proper scheme of regulation would not be affect in the slight degree by a change in the tariff save as such change interfere with the general prosperity of the country the only relation of the tariff to big corporation as a whole be that the tariff make manufacture profitable and the tariff remedy propose would be in effect simply to make manufacture unprofitable to remove the tariff as a punitive measure direct against trust would inevitably result in ruin to the weak competitor who be struggle against they our aim should be not by unwise tariff change to give foreign product the advantage over domestic product but by proper regulation to give domestic competition a fair chance and this end can not be reach by any tariff change which would affect unfavorably all domestic competitor good and bad alike the question of regulation of the trust stand apart from the question of tariff revision

 stability of economic policy must always be the prime economic need of this country this stability should not be fossilization the country have acquiesce in the wisdom of the protective tariff principle it be exceedingly undesirable that this system should be destroy or that there should be violent and radical change therein our past experience show that great prosperity in this country have always come under a protective tariff and that the country can not prosper under fitful tariff change at short interval moreover if the tariff law as a whole work well and if business have prosper under they and be prosper it be well to endure for a time slight inconvenience and inequality in some schedule than to upset business by too quick and too radical change it be most earnestly to be wish that we could treat the tariff from the standpoint solely of our business need it be perhaps too much to hope that partisanship may be entirely exclude from consideration of the subject but at least it can be make secondary to the business interest of the country that be to the interest of our people as a whole unquestionably these business interest will well be serve if together with fixity of principle as regard the tariff we combine a system which will permit we from time to time to make the necessary reapplication of the principle to the shift national need we must take scrupulous care that the reapplication shall be make in such a way that it will not amount to a dislocation of our system the mere threat of which not to speak of the performance would produce paralysis in the business energy of the community the first consideration in make these change would of course be to preserve the principle which underlie our whole tariff system that is the principle of put american business interest at least on a full equality with interest abroad and of always allow a sufficient rate of duty to more than cover the difference between the labor cost here and abroad the well being of the wage worker like the well being of the tiller of the soil should be treat as an essential in shape our whole economic policy there must never be any change which will jeopardize the standard of comfort the standard of wage of the american wage worker

 one way in which the readjustment seek can be reach be by reciprocity treaty it be greatly to be desire that such treaty may be adopt they can be use to widen our market and to give a great field for the activity of our producer on the one hand and on the other hand to secure in practical shape the lowering of duty when they be no long need for protection among our own people or when the minimum of damage do may be disregard for the sake of the maximum of good accomplished if it prove impossible to ratify the pende treaty and if there seem to be no warrant for the endeavor to execute other or to amend the pende treaty so that they can be ratify then the same end to secure reciprocity should be meet by direct legislation

 wherever the tariff condition be such that a need change can not with advantage be make by the application of the reciprocity idea then it can be make outright by a lowering of duty on a give product if possible such change should be make only after the full consideration by practical expert who should approach the subject from a business standpoint have in view both the particular interest affect and the commercial well being of the people as a whole the machinery for provide such careful investigation can readily be supply the executive department have already at its disposal method of collect fact and figure and if the congress desire additional consideration to that which will be give the subject by its own committee then a commission of business expert can be appoint whose duty it should be to recommend action by the congress after a deliberate and scientific examination of the various schedule as they be affect by the change and change condition the unhurried and unbiased report of this commission would show what change should be make in the various schedule and how far these change could go without also change the great prosperity which this country be now enjoy or upset its fix economic policy

 the case in which the tariff can produce a monopoly be so few as to constitute an inconsiderable factor in the question but of course if in any case it be find that a give rate of duty do promote a monopoly which work ill no protectionist would object to such reduction of the duty as would equalize competition

 in my judgment the tariff on anthracite coal should be remove and anthracite put actually where it now be nominally on the free list this would have no effect at all save in crisis but in crisis it might be of service to the people

 interest rate be a potent factor in business activity and in order that these rate may be equalize to meet the vary need of the season and of widely separate community and to prevent the recurrence of financial stringency which injuriously affect legitimate business it be necessary that there should be an element of elasticity in our monetary system bank be the natural servant of commerce and upon they should be place as far as practicable the burden of furnish and maintain a circulation adequate to supply the need of our diversify industry and of our domestic and foreign commerce and the issue of this should be so regulated that a sufficient supply should be always available for the business interest of the country

 it would be both unwise and unnecessary at this time to attempt to reconstruct our financial system which have be the growth of a century but some additional legislation be i think desirable the mere outline of any plan sufficiently comprehensive to meet these requirement would transgress the appropriate limit of this communication it be suggest however that all future legislation on the subject should be with the view of encourage the use of such instrumentality as will automatically supply every legitimate demand of productive industry and of commerce not only in the amount but in the character of circulation and of make all kind of money interchangeable and at the will of the holder convertible into the establish gold standard

 i again call your attention to the need of pass a proper immigration law cover the point outline in my message to you at the first session of the present congress substantially such a bill have already pass the house

 how to secure fair treatment alike for labor and for capital how to hold in check the unscrupulous man whether employer or employee without weaken individual initiative without hamper and cramp the industrial development of the country be a problem fraught with great difficulty and one which it be of the high importance to solve on line of sanity and far sight common sense as well as of devotion to the right this be an era of federation and combination exactly as business man find they must often work through corporation and as it be a constant tendency of these corporation to grow large so it be often necessary for labor man to work in federation and these have become important factor of modern industrial life both kind of federation capitalistic and labor can do much good and as a necessary corollary they can both do evil opposition to each kind of organization should take the form of opposition to whatever be bad in the conduct of any give corporation or union not of attack upon corporation as such nor upon union as such for some of the most far reach beneficent work for our people have be accomplish through both corporation and union each must refrain from arbitrary or tyrannous interference with the right of other organized capital and organized labor alike should remember that in the long run the interest of each must be bring into harmony with the interest of the general public and the conduct of each must conform to the fundamental rule of obedience to the law of individual freedom and of justice and fair deal toward all each should remember that in addition to power it must strive after the realization of healthy lofty and generous ideal every employer every wage worker must be guarantee his liberty and his right to do as he like with his property or his labor so long as he do not infringe upon the right of other it be of the high importance that employer and employee alike should endeavor to appreciate each the viewpoint of the other and the sure disaster that will come upon both in the long run if either grow to take as habitual an attitude of sour hostility and distrust toward the other few people deserve well of the country than those representative both of capital and labor and there be many such who work continually to bring about a good understanding of this kind base upon wisdom and upon broad and kindly sympathy between employer and employ above all we need to remember that any kind of class animosity in the political world be if possible even more wicked even more destructive to national welfare than sectional race or religious animosity we can get good government only upon condition that we keep true to the principle upon which this nation be found and judge each man not as a part of a class but upon his individual merit all that we have a right to ask of any man rich or poor whatever his creed his occupation his birthplace or his residence be that he shall act well and honorably by his neighbor and by his country we be neither for the rich man as such nor for the poor man as such we be for the upright man rich or poor so far as the constitutional power of the national government touch these matter of general and vital moment to the nation they should be exercise in conformity with the principle above set forth

 it be earnestly hope that a secretary of commerce may be create with a seat in the cabinet the rapid multiplication of question affect labor and capital the growth and complexity of the organization through which both labor and capital now find expression the steady tendency toward the employment of capital in huge corporation and the wonderful stride of this country toward leadership in the international business world justify an urgent demand for the creation of such a position substantially all the lead commercial body in this country have unite in request its creation it be desirable that some such measure as that which have already pass the senate be enact into law the creation of such a department would in itself be an advance toward deal with and exercise supervision over the whole subject of the great corporation do an interstate business and with this end in view the congress should endow the department with large power which could be increase as experience might show the need

 i hope soon to submit to the senate a reciprocity treaty with cuba on may 20 last the united states keep its promise to the island by formally vacate cuban soil and turn cuba over to those whom her own people have choose as the first official of the new republic

 cuba lie at our door and whatever affect she for good or for ill affect we also so much have our people feel this that in the platt amendment we definitely take the ground that cuba must hereafter have close political relation with we than with any other power thus in a sense cuba have become a part of our international political system this make it necessary that in return she should be give some of the benefit of become part of our economic system it be from our own standpoint a short sighted and mischievous policy to fail to recognize this need moreover it be unworthy of a mighty and generous nation itself the great and most successful republic in history to refuse to stretch out a help hand to a young and weak sister republic just enter upon its career of independence we should always fearlessly insist upon our right in the face of the strong and we should with ungrudge hand do our generous duty by the weak i urge the adoption of reciprocity with cuba not only because it be eminently for our own interest to control the cuban market and by every mean to foster our supremacy in the tropical land and water south of we but also because we of of the giant republic of the north should make all our sister nation of the american continent feel that whenever they will permit it we desire to show ourselves disinterestedly and effectively their friend

 a convention with great britain have be conclude which will be at once lay before the senate for ratification provide for reciprocal trade arrangement between the united states and newfoundland on substantially the line of the convention formerly negotiate by the secretary of state mr. blaine i believe reciprocal trade relation will be greatly to the advantage of both country

 as civilization grow warfare become less and less the normal condition of foreign relation the last century have see a marked diminution of war between civilized power war with uncivilized power be largely mere matter of international police duty essential for the welfare of the world wherever possible arbitration or some similar method should be employ in lieu of war to settle difficulty between civilized nation although as yet the world have not progress sufficiently to render it possible or necessarily desirable to invoke arbitration in every case the formation of the international tribunal which sit at the hague be an event of good oman from which great consequence for the welfare of all mankind may flow it be far well where possible to invoke such a permanent tribunal than to create special arbitrator for a give purpose

 it be a matter of sincere congratulation to our country that the united states and mexico should have be the first to use the good office of the hague court this be do last summer with most satisfactory result in the case of a claim at issue between we and our sister republic it be earnestly to be hope that this first case will serve as a precedent for other in which not only the united states but foreign nation may take advantage of the machinery already in existence at the hague

 i commend to the favorable consideration of the congress the hawaiian fire claim which be the subject of careful investigation during the last session

 the congress have wisely provide that we shall build at once an isthmian canal if possible at panama the attorney general report that we can undoubtedly acquire good title from the french panama canal company negotiation be now pende with colombia to secure her assent to our build the canal this canal will be one of the great engineering feat of the twentieth century a great engineering feat than have yet be accomplish during the history of mankind the work should be carry out as a continue policy without regard to change of administration and it should be begin under circumstance which will make it a matter of pride for all administration to continue the policy

 the canal will be of great benefit to america and of importance to all the world it will be of advantage to we industrially and also as improve our military position it will be of advantage to the country of tropical america it be earnestly to be hope that all of these country will do as some of they have already do with signal success and will invite to their shore commerce and improve their material condition by recognize that stability and order be the prerequisite of successful development no independent nation in america need have the slight fear of aggression from the united states it behove each one to maintain order within its own border and to discharge its just obligation to foreigner when this be do they can rest assure that be they strong or weak they have nothing to dread from outside interference more and more the increase interdependence and complexity of international political and economic relation render it incumbent on all civilized and orderly power to insist on the proper policing of the world

 during the fall of 1901 a communication be address to the secretary of state ask whether permission would be grant by the president to a corporation to lay a cable from a point on the california coast to the philippine islands by way of hawaii a statement of condition or term upon which such corporation would undertake to lay and operate a cable be volunteer

 inasmuch as the congress be shortly to convene and pacific cable legislation have be the subject of consideration by the congress for several year it seem to i wise to defer action upon the application until the congress have first an opportunity to act the congress adjourn without take any action leave the matter in exactly the same condition in which it stand when the congress convene

 meanwhile it appear that the commercial pacific cable company have promptly proceed with preparation for lay its cable it also make application to the president for access to and use of sounding take by the u. s. s. nero for the purpose of discover a practicable route for a trans pacific cable the company urge that with access to these sounding it could complete its cable much soon than if it be require to take sounding upon its own account pende consideration of this subject it appear important and desirable to attach certain condition to the permission to examine and use the sounding if it should be grant

 in consequence of this solicitation of the cable company certain condition be formulate upon which the president be willing to allow access to these sounding and to consent to the landing and laying of the cable subject to any alteration or addition thereto impose by the congress this be deem proper especially as it be clear that a cable connection of some kind with china a foreign country be a part of the company&#39;s plan this course be moreover in accordance with a line of precedent include president grant&#39;s action in the case of the first french cable explain to the congress in his annual message of december 1875 and the instance occur in 1879 of the second french cable from brest to st. pierre with a branch to cape cod

 these condition prescribe among other thing a maximum rate for commercial message and that the company should construct a line from the philippine islands to china there be at present as be well know a british line from manila to hongkong

 the representative of the cable company keep these condition long under consideration continue in the meantime to prepare for lay the cable they have however at length accede to they and an all american line between our pacific coast and the chinese empire by way of honolulu and the philippine islands be thus provide for and be expect within a few month to be ready for business

 among the condition be one reserve the power of the congress to modify or repeal any or all of they a copy of the condition be herewith transmit

 of porto rico it be only necessary to say that the prosperity of the island and the wisdom with which it have be govern have be such as to make it serve as an example of all that be good in insular administration

 on july 4 last on the one hundred and twenty sixth anniversary of the declaration of our independence peace and amnesty be promulgate in the philippine islands some trouble have since from time to time threaten with the mohammedan moros but with the late insurrectionary filipinos the war have entirely cease civil government have now be introduce not only do each filipino enjoy such right to life liberty and the pursuit of happiness as he have never before know during the record history of the island but the people take as a whole now enjoy a measure of self government great than that grant to any other orientals by any foreign power and great than that enjoy by any other orientals under their own government save the japanese alone we have not go too far in grant these right of liberty and self government but we have certainly go to the limit that in the interest of the philippine people themselves it be wise or just to go to hurry matter to go fast than we be now go would entail calamity on the people of the island no policy ever enter into by the american people have vindicate itself in more signal manner than the policy of hold the philippines the triumph of our arm above all the triumph of our law and principle have come soon than we have any right to expect too much praise can not be give to the army for what it have do in the philippines both in warfare and from an administrative standpoint in prepare the way for civil government and similar credit belong to the civil authority for the way in which they have plant the seed of self government in the ground thus make ready for they the courage the unflinche endurance the high soldierly efficiency and the general kind heartedness and humanity of our troop have be strikingly manifest there now remain only some fifteen thousand troop in the island all tell over one hundred thousand have be send there of course there have be individual instance of wrongdoing among they they war under fearful difficulty of climate and surrounding and under the strain of the terrible provocation which they continually receive from their foe occasional instance of cruel retaliation occur every effort have be make to prevent such cruelty and finally these effort have be completely successful every effort have also be make to detect and punish the wrongdoer after make all allowance for these misdeed it remain true that few indeed have be the instance in which war have be wage by a civilized power against semicivilized or barbarous force where there have be so little wrongdoing by the victor as in the philippine islands on the other hand the amount of difficult important and beneficent work which have be do be well nigh incalculable

 take the work of the army and the civil authority together it may be question whether anywhere else in modern time the world have see a well example of real constructive statesmanship than our people have give in the philippine islands high praise should also be give those filipinos in the aggregate very numerous who have accept the new condition and join with our representative to work with hearty good will for the welfare of the island

 the army have be reduce to the minimum allow by law it be very small for the size of the nation and most certainly should be keep at the high point of efficiency the senior officer be give scant chance under ordinary condition to exercise command commensurate with their rank under circumstance which would fit they to do their duty in time of actual war a system of maneuver our army in body of some little size have be begin and should be steadily continue without such maneuver it be folly to expect that in the event of hostility with any serious foe even a small army corp could be handle to advantage both our officer and enlisted man be such that we can take hearty pride in they no well material can be find but they must be thoroughly train both as individual and in the mass the marksmanship of the man must receive special attention in the circumstance of modern warfare the man must act far more on his own individual responsibility than ever before and the high individual efficiency of the unit be of the utmost importance formerly this unit be the regiment it be now not the regiment not even the troop or company it be the individual soldier every effort must be make to develop every workmanlike and soldierly quality in both the officer and the enlisted man

 i urgently call your attention to the need of pass a bill provide for a general staff and for the reorganization of the supply department on the line of the bill propose by the secretary of war last year when the young officer enter the army from west point they probably stand above their compeer in any other military service every effort should be make by training by reward of merit by scrutiny into their career and capacity to keep they of the same high relative excellence throughout their career the measure provide for the reorganization of the militia system and for secure the high efficiency in the national guard which have already pass the house should receive prompt attention and action it be of great importance that the relation of the national guard to the militia and volunteer force of the united states should be define and that in place of our present obsolete law a practical and efficient system should be adopt

 provision should be make to enable the secretary of war to keep cavalry and artillery horse wear out in long performance of duty such horse fetch but a trifle when sell and rather than turn they out to the misery await they when thus dispose of it would be well to employ they at light work around the post and when necessary to put they painlessly to death

 for the first time in our history naval maneuver on a large scale be be hold under the immediate command of the admiral of the navy constantly increase attention be be pay to the gunnery of the navy but it be yet far from what it should be i earnestly urge that the increase ask for by the secretary of the navy in the appropriation for improve the markmanship be grant in battle the only shot that count be the shot that hit it be necessary to provide ample fund for practice with the great gun in time of peace these fund must provide not only for the purchase of projectile but for allowance for prize to encourage the gun crew and especially the gun pointer and for perfect an intelligent system under which alone it be possible to get good practice

 there should be no halt in the work of build up the navy provide every year additional fighting craft we be a very rich country vast in extent of territory and great in population a country moreover which have an army diminutive indeed when compare with that of any other first class power we have deliberately make our own certain foreign policy which demand the possession of a first class navy the isthmian canal will greatly increase the efficiency of our navy if the navy be of sufficient size but if we have an inadequate navy then the building of the canal would be merely give a hostage to any power of superior strength the monroe doctrine should be treat as the cardinal feature of american foreign policy but it would be bad than idle to assert it unless we intend to back it up and it can be back up only by a thoroughly good navy a good navy be not a provocative of war it be the sure guaranty of peace

 each individual unit of our navy should be the most efficient of its kind as regard both material and personnel that be to be find in the world i call your special attention to the need of provide for the manning of the ship serious trouble threaten we if we can not do well than we be now do as regard secure the service of a sufficient number of the high type of sailorman of sea mechanic the veteran seaman of our war ship be of as high a type as can be find in any navy which ride the water of the world they be unsurpasse in daring in resolution in readiness in thorough knowledge of their profession they deserve every consideration that can be show they but there be not enough of they it be no more possible to improvise a crew than it be possible to improvise a war ship to build the fine ship with the deadly battery and to send it afloat with a raw crew no matter how brave they be individually would be to insure disaster if a foe of average capacity be encounter neither ship nor man can be improvise when war have begin

 we need a thousand additional officer in order to properly man the ship now provide for and under construction the class at the naval school at annapolis should be greatly enlarge at the same time that we thus add the officer where we need they we should facilitate the retirement of those at the head of the list whose usefulness have become impaired promotion must be foster if the service be to be keep efficient

 the lamentable scarcity of officer and the large number of recruit and of unskilled man necessarily put aboard the new vessel as they have be commission have throw upon our officer and especially on the lieutenant and junior grade unusual labor and fatigue and have gravely strain their power of endurance nor be there sign of any immediate let up in this strain it must continue for some time long until more officer be graduate from annapolis and until the recruit become trained and skillful in their duty in these difficulty incident upon the development of our war fleet the conduct of all our officer have be creditable to the service and the lieutenant and junior grade in particular have display an ability and a steadfast cheerfulness which entitle they to the ungrudge thank of all who realize the disheartening trial and fatigue to which they be of necessity subject

 there be not a cloud on the horizon at present there seem not the slight chance of trouble with a foreign power we most earnestly hope that this state of thing may continue and the way to insure its continuance be to provide for a thoroughly efficient navy the refusal to maintain such a navy would invite trouble and if trouble come would insure disaster fatuous self complacency or vanity or short sightedness in refuse to prepare for danger be both foolish and wicked in such a nation as our and past experience have show that such fatuity in refuse to recognize or prepare for any crisis in advance be usually succeed by a mad panic of hysterical fear once the crisis have actually arrive

 the striking increase in the revenue of the post office department show clearly the prosperity of our people and the increase activity of the business of the country

 the receipt of the post office department for the fiscal year end june 30 last amount to $ 121,848,047.26 an increase of $ 10,216,853.87 over the precede year the large increase know in the history of the postal service the magnitude of this increase will well appear from the fact that the entire postal receipt for the year 1860 amount to but $ 8,518,067

 rural free delivery service be no long in the experimental stage it have become a fix policy the result follow its introduction have fully justify the congress in the large appropriation make for its establishment and extension the average yearly increase in post office receipt in the rural district of the country be about two per cent we be now able by actual result to show that where rural free delivery service have be establish to such an extent as to enable we to make comparison the yearly increase have be upward of ten per cent

 on november 1 1902 11,650 rural free delivery route have be establish and be in operation cover about one third of the territory of the united states available for rural free delivery service there be now await the action of the department petition and application for the establishment of 10,748 additional route this show conclusively the want which the establishment of the service have meet and the need of far extend it as rapidly as possible it be justify both by the financial result and by the practical benefit to our rural population it bring the man who live on the soil into close relation with the active business world it keep the farmer in daily touch with the market it be a potential educational force it enhance the value of farm property make farm life far pleasanter and less isolated and will do much to check the undesirable current from country to city

 it be to be hope that the congress will make liberal appropriation for the continuance of the service already establish and for its further extension

 few subject of more importance have be take up by the congress in recent year than the inauguration of the system of nationally aid irrigation for the arid region of the far west a good beginning therein have be make now that this policy of national irrigation have be adopt the need of thorough and scientific forest protection will grow more rapidly than ever throughout the public land states

 legislation should be provide for the protection of the game and the wild creature generally on the forest reserve the senseless slaughter of game which can by judicious protection be permanently preserve on our national reserve for the people as a whole should be stop at once it be for instance a serious count against our national good sense to permit the present practice of butcher off such a stately and beautiful creature as the elk for its antler or tusk

 so far as they be available for agriculture and to whatever extent they may be reclaim under the national irrigation law the remain public land should be hold rigidly for the home builder the settler who live on his land and for no one else in their actual use the desert land law the timber and stone law and the commutation clause of the homestead law have be so pervert from the intention with which they be enact as to permit the acquisition of large area of the public domain for other than actual settler and the consequent prevention of settlement moreover the approach exhaustion of the public range have of late lead to much discussion as to the good manner of use these public land in the west which be suitable chiefly or only for graze the sound and steady development of the west depend upon the building up of home therein much of our prosperity as a nation have be due to the operation of the homestead law on the other hand we should recognize the fact that in the graze region the man who correspond to the homesteader may be unable to settle permanently if only allow to use the same amount of pasture land that his brother the homesteader be allow to use of arable land one hundred and sixty acre of fairly rich and well water soil or a much small amount of irrigated land may keep a family in plenty whereas no one could get a living from one hundred and sixty acre of dry pasture land capable of support at the outside only one head of cattle to every ten acre in the past great tract of the public domain have be fence in by person have no title thereto in direct defiance of the law forbid the maintenance or construction of any such unlawful inclosure of public land for various reason there have be little interference with such inclosure in the past but ample notice have now be give the trespasser and all the resource at the command of the government will hereafter be use to put a stop to such trespassing

 in view of the capital importance of these matter i commend they to the earnest consideration of the congress and if the congress find difficulty in deal with they from lack of thorough knowledge of the subject i recommend that provision be make for a commission of expert specially to investigate and report upon the complicated question involve

 i especially urge upon the congress the need of wise legislation for alaska it be not to our credit as a nation that alaska which have be ours for thirty five year should still have as poor a system of law as be the case no country have a more valuable possession-- in mineral wealth in fishery fur forest and also in land available for certain kind of farming and stockgrowing it be a territory of great size and varied resource well fit to support a large permanent population alaska need a good land law and such provision for homestead and pre emption as will encourage permanent settlement we should shape legislation with a view not to the exploiting and abandon of the territory but to the building up of home therein the land law should be liberal in type so as to hold out inducement to the actual settler whom we most desire to see take possession of the country the forest of alaska should be protect and as a secondary but still important matter the game also and at the same time it be imperative that the settler should be allow to cut timber under proper regulation for their own use law should be enact to protect the alaskan salmon fishery against the greed which would destroy they they should be preserve as a permanent industry and food supply their management and control should be turn over to the commission of fish and fishery alaska should have a delegate in the congress it would be well if a congressional committee could visit alaska and investigate its need on the ground

 in deal with the indians our aim should be their ultimate absorption into the body of our people but in many case this absorption must and should be very slow in portion of the indian territory the mixture of blood have go on at the same time with progress in wealth and education so that there be plenty of man with vary degree of purity of indian blood who be absolutely indistinguishable in point of social political and economic ability from their white associate there be other tribe which have as yet make no perceptible advance toward such equality to try to force such tribe too fast be to prevent their go forward at all moreover the tribe live under widely different condition where a tribe have make considerable advance and live on fertile farming soil it be possible to allot the member land in severalty much as be the case with white settler there be other tribe where such a course be not desirable on the arid prairie land the effort should be to induce the indians to lead pastoral rather than agricultural life and to permit they to settle in village rather than to force they into isolation

 the large indian school situate remote from any indian reservation do a special and peculiar work of great importance but excellent though these be an immense amount of additional work must be do on the reservation themselves among the old and above all among the young indians

 the first and most important step toward the absorption of the indian be to teach he to earn his living yet it be not necessarily to be assume that in each community all indians must become either tiller of the soil or stock raiser their industry may properly be diversify and those who show special desire or adaptability for industrial or even commercial pursuit should be encourage so far as practicable to follow out each his own bent

 every effort should be make to develop the indian along the line of natural aptitude and to encourage the exist native industry peculiar to certain tribe such as the various kind of basket weaving canoe building smith work and blanket work above all the indian boy and girl should be give confident command of colloquial english and should ordinarily be prepare for a vigorous struggle with the condition under which their people live rather than for immediate absorption into some more highly developed community

 the official who represent the government in deal with the indians work under hard condition and also under condition which render it easy to do wrong and very difficult to detect wrong consequently they should be amply pay on the one hand and on the other hand a particularly high standard of conduct should be demand from they and where misconduct can be prove the punishment should be exemplary

 in no department of governmental work in recent year have there be great success than in that of give scientific aid to the farming population thereby show they how most efficiently to help themselves there be no need of insist upon its importance for the welfare of the farmer be fundamentally necessary to the welfare of the republic as a whole in addition to such work as quarantine against animal and vegetable plague and war against they when here introduce much efficient help have be render to the farmer by the introduction of new plant specially fit for cultivation under the peculiar condition exist in different portion of the country new cereal have be establish in the semi arid west for instance the practicability of produce the good type of macaroni wheat in region of an annual rainfall of only ten inch or thereabout have be conclusively demonstrate through the introduction of new rice in louisiana and texas the production of rice in this country have be make to about equal the home demand in the south west the possibility of regrasse overstock range land have be demonstrate in the north many new forage crop have be introduce while in the east it have be show that some of our choicest fruit can be store and ship in such a way as to find a profitable market abroad

 i again recommend to the favorable consideration of the congress the plan of the smithsonian institution for make the museum under its charge worthy of the nation and for preserve at the national capital not only record of the vanish race of man but of the animal of this continent which like the buffalo will soon become extinct unless specimen from which their representative may be renew be seek in their native region and maintain there in safety

 the district of columbia be the only part of our territory in which the national government exercise local or municipal function and where in consequence the government have a free hand in reference to certain type of social and economic legislation which must be essentially local or municipal in their character the government should see to it for instance that the hygienic and sanitary legislation affect washington be of a high character the evil of slum dwelling whether in the shape of crowded and congested tenement house district or of the back alley type should never be permit to grow up in washington the city should be a model in every respect for all the city of the country the charitable and correctional system of the district should receive consideration at the hand of the congress to the end that they may embody the result of the most advanced thought in these field moreover while washington be not a great industrial city there be some industrialism here and our labor legislation while it would not be important in itself might be make a model for the rest of the nation we should pass for instance a wise employer&#39;s liability act for the district of columbia and we need such an act in our navy yard railroad company in the district ought to be require by law to block their frog

 the safety appliance law for the well protection of the life and limb of railway employee which be pass in 1893 go into full effect on august 1 1901 it have result in avert thousand of casualty experience show however the necessity of additional legislation to perfect this law a bill to provide for this pass the senate at the last session it be to be hope that some such measure may now be enact into law

 there be a grow tendency to provide for the publication of masse of document for which there be no public demand and for the printing of which there be no real necessity large number of volume be turn out by the government print press for which there be no justification nothing should be print by any of the departments unless it contain something of permanent value and the congress could with advantage cut down very materially on all the printing which it have now become customary to provide the excessive cost of government printing be a strong argument against the position of those who be incline on abstract ground to advocate the government&#39;s do any work which can with propriety be leave in private hand

 gratifying progress have be make during the year in the extension of the merit system of make appointment in the government service it should be extend by law to the district of columbia it be much to be desire that our consular system be establish by law on a basis provide for appointment and promotion only in consequence of prove fitness

 through a wise provision of the congress at its last session the white house which have become disfigure by incongruous addition and change have now be restore to what it be plan to be by washington in make the restoration the utmost care have be exercise to come as near as possible to the early plan and to supplement these plan by a careful study of such building as that of the university of virginia which be build by jefferson the white house be the property of the nation and so far as be compatible with live therein it should be keep as it originally be for the same reason that we keep mount vernon as it originally be the stately simplicity of its architecture be an expression of the character of the period in which it be build and be in accord with the purpose it be design to serve it be a good thing to preserve such building as historic monument which keep alive our sense of continuity with the nation&#39;s past

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas by the resolution of the senate of march 19 1903 the approval by congress of the reciprocal commercial convention between the united states and the republic of cuba sign at havana on december 11 1902 be necessary before the say convention shall take effect
 and whereas it be important to the public interest of the united states that the say convention shall become operative as early as may be
 now therefore i theodore roosevelt president of the united states of america by virtue of the power vest in i by the constitution do hereby proclaim and declare that an extraordinary occasion require the convening of both houses of the congress of the united states at their respective chambers in the city of washington on the 9th day of november next at 12 o&#39;clock noon to the end that they may consider and determine whether the approval of the congress shall be give to the said convention
 all person entitle to act as member of the 58th congress be require to take notice of this proclamation
 give under my hand and the seal of the united states at washington the 20th day of october in the year of our lord one thousand nine hundred and three and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and twenty eighth

 theodore roosevelt
 by the president
 john hay
 secretary of state
to the senate and house of representatives
 it be require by the resolution of the senate of march 1903 that the approval of congress shall be give to the reciprocal commercial convention between the united states and cuba sign december 11 1902 before the same shall take effect i transmit herewith the text of the say convention as amend by the senate
 theodore roosevelt
 the president of the united states of america and the president of the republic of cuba animate by the desire to strengthen the bond of friendship between the two country and to facilitate their commercial intercourse by improve the condition of trade between they have resolve to enter into a convention for that purpose and have appoint their respective plenipotentiaries to wit
 the president of the united states of america the honorable general tasker h. bliss
 the president of the republic of cuba the honorable carlos de zaldo y beurmann secretary of state and justice and the honorable jose&#39 m. garcia y montes secretary of the treasury
 who after an exchange of their full power find to be in good and due form have in consideration of and in compensation for the respective concession and engagement make by each to the other as hereinafter recite agree and do hereby agree upon the following articles for the regulation and government of their reciprocal trade namely
 article i.
 during the term of this convention all article of merchandise be the product of the soil or industry of the united states which be now import into the republic of cuba free of duty and all article of merchandise be the product of the soil or industry of the republic of cuba which be now import into the united states free of duty shall continue to be so admit by the respective country free of duty
 article ii
 during the term of this convention all article of merchandise not include in the foregoing article i and be the product of the soil or industry of the republic of cuba import into the united states shall be admit at a reduction of twenty per centum of the rate of duty thereon as provide by the tariff act of the united states approve july 24 1897 or as may be provide by any tariff law of the united states subsequently enact
 article iii
 during the term of this convention all article of merchandise not include in the foregoing article i and not hereinafter enumerate be the product of the soil or industry of the united states import into the republic of cuba shall be admit at a reduction of twenty per centum of the rate of duty thereon as now provide or as may hereafter be provide in the customs tariff of say republic of cuba
 article iv
 during the term of this convention the follow article of merchandise as enumerate and describe in the exist customs tariff of the republic of cuba be the product of the soil or industry of the united states import into cuba shall be admit at the follow respective reduction of the rate of duty thereon as now provide or as may hereafter be provide in the customs tariff of the republic of cuba
 schedule a.
 to be admit at a reduction of twenty five 25 per centum
 machinery and apparatus of copper or its alloy or machine and apparatus in which copper or its alloy enter as the component of chief value cast iron wrought iron and steel and manufacture thereof article of crystal and glass except window glass ship and water bear vessel of all kind of iron or steel whisky and brandy fish salt pickled smoke or marinated fish or shell fish preserve in oil or otherwise in tin article of pottery or earthenware now classify under paragraphs 21 and 22 of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba
 schedule b.
 to be admit at a reduction of thirty 30 per centum
 butter flour of wheat corn flour of corn or corn meal chemical and pharmaceutical product and simple drug malt liquor in bottle non alcoholic beverage cider mineral water color and dye window glass complete or partly make up article of hemp flax pit jute henequen ramie and other vegetable fiber now classify under the paragraph of group 2 class v of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba musical instrument writing and printing paper except for newspaper cotton and manufacture thereof except knit good see schedule c all article of cutlery boot shoe and slipper now classify under paragraphs 197 and 198 of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba gold and silver plate ware drawing photograph engraving lithograph chromolithograph oleograph etc print from stone zinc aluminium or other material use as label flap band and wrapper for tobacco or other purpose and all the other paper except paper for cigarette and except map and chart pasteboard and manufacture thereof now classify under paragraphs 157 to 164 inclusive of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba common or ordinary soap now classify under paragraph 105 letter a and b of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba vegetable pickle or preserve in any manner all wine except those now classify under paragraph 279 a of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba
 schedule c.
 to be admit at a reduction of forty 40 per centum
 manufacture of cotton knit and all manufacture of cotton not include in the precede schedule cheese fruit preserve paper pulp perfumery and essence article of pottery and earthenware now classify under paragraph 20 of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba porcelain soap other than common now classify under paragraph 105 of the customs tariff of the republic of cuba umbrella and parasol dextrine and glucose watch wool and manufacture thereof silk and manufacture thereof rice cattle
 article v.
 it be understand and agree that the law and regulation adopt or that may be adopt by the united states and by the republic of cuba to protect their revenue and prevent fraud in the declaration and proof that the article of merchandise to which this convention may apply be the product or manufacture of the united states and the republic of cuba respectively shall not impose any additional charge or fee therefor on the article import except the consular fee establish or which may be establish by either of the two country for issue shipping document which fee shall not be high than those charge on the shipment of similar merchandise from any other nation whatsoever
 article vi
 it be agree that the tobacco in any form of the united states or of any of its insular possession shall not enjoy the benefit of any concession or rebate of duty when import into the republic of cuba
 article vii
 it be agree that similar article of both country shall receive equal treatment on their importation into the port of the united states and of the republic of cuba respectively
 article viii
 the rate of duty herein grant by the united states to the republic of cuba be and shall continue during the term of this convention preferential in respect to all like import from other country and in return for say preferential rate of duty grant to the republic of cuba by the united states it be agree that the concession herein grant on the part of the say republic of cuba to the product of the united states shall likewise be and shall continue during the term of this convention preferential in respect to all like import from other country provide that while this convention be in force no sugar import from the republic of cuba and be the product of the soil or industry of the republic of cuba shall be admit into the united states at a reduction of duty great than twenty per centum of the rate of duty thereon as provide by the tariff act of the united states approve july 24 1897 and no sugar the product of any other foreign country shall be admit by treaty or convention into the united states while this convention be in force at a low rate of duty than that provide by the tariff act of the united states approve july 24 1897
 article ix
 in order to maintain the mutual advantage grant in the present convention by the united states to the republic of cuba and by the republic of cuba to the united states it be understand and agree that any tax or charge that may be impose by the national or local authority of either of the two country upon the article of merchandise embrace in the provision of this convention subsequent to importation and prior to their entering into consumption in the respective country shall be impose and collect without discrimination upon like article whensoever import
 article x.
 it be hereby understand and agree that in case of change in the tariff of either country which deprive the other of the advantage which be represent by the percentage herein agree upon on the actual rate of the tariff now in force the country so deprive of this protection reserve the right to terminate its obligation under this convention after six months&#39 notice to the other of its intention to arrest the operation thereof
 and it be far understand and agree that if at any time during the term of this convention after the expiration of the first year the protection herein grant to the product and manufacture of the united states on the basis of the actual rate of the tariff of the republic of cuba now in force should appear to the government of the say republic to be excessive in view of a new tariff law that may be adopt by it after this convention become operative then the say republic of cuba may reopen negotiation with a view to secure such modification as may appear proper to both contracting party
 article xi
 the present convention shall be ratify by the appropriate authority of the respective country and the ratification shall be exchange at washington district of columbia united states of america as soon as may be before the thirty first day of january 1903 and the convention shall go into effect on the tenth day after the exchange of ratification and shall continue in force for the term of five 5 year from the date of go into effect and from year to year thereafter until the expiration of one year from the day when either of the contracting party shall give notice to the other of its intention to terminate the same
 this convention shall not take effect until the same shall have be approve by the congress
 in witness whereof we the respective plenipotentiaries have sign the same in duplicate in english and spanish and have affix our respective seal at havana cuba this eleventh day of december in the year one thousand nine hundred and two
 tasker h. bliss
 carlos de zaldo
 jose m. garcia montes
 to the senate and house of representatives
 i have convene the congress that it may consider the legislation necessary to put into operation the commercial treaty with cuba which be ratify by the senate at its last session and subsequently by the cuban government i deem such legislation demand not only by our interest but by our honor we can not with propriety abandon the course upon which we have so wisely embark when the acceptance of the platt amendment be require from cuba by the action of the congress of the united states this government thereby definitely commit itself to the policy of treat cuba as occupy a unique position as regard this country it be provide that when the island become a free and independent republic she should stand in such close relation with we as in certain respect to come within our system of international policy and it necessarily follow that she must also to a certain degree become include within the line of our economic policy situate as cuba be it would not be possible for this country to permit the strategic abuse of the island by any foreign military power it be for this reason that certain limitation have be impose upon her financial policy and that naval station have be concede by she to the united states the negotiation as to the detail of these naval station be on the eve of completion they be so situated as to prevent any idea that there be the intention ever to use they against cuba or otherwise than for the protection of cuba from the assault of foreign foe and for the well safeguarding of american interest in the water south of we
 these interest have be largely increase by the consequence of the war with spain and will be still far increase by the building of the isthmian canal they be both military and economic the granting to we by cuba of the naval station above allude to be of the utmost importance from a military standpoint and be proof of the good faith with which cuba be treat we cuba have make great progress since her independence be establish she have advance steadily in every way she already stand high among her sister republic of the new world she be loyally observe her obligation to we and she be entitle to like treatment by we
 the treaty submit to you for approval secure to the united states economic advantage as great as those give to cuba not an american interest be sacrifice by the treaty a large cuban market be secure to our producer it be a market which lie at our door which be already large which be capable of great expansion and which be especially important to the development of our export trade it would be indeed shortsighted for we to refuse to take advantage of such an opportunity and to force cuba into make arrangement with other country to our disadvantage
 this reciprocity treaty stand by itself it be demand on consideration of broad national policy as well as by our economic interest it will do harm to no industry it will benefit many industry it be in the interest of our people as a whole both because of its importance from the broad standpoint of international policy and because economically it intimately concern we to develop and secure the rich cuban market for our farmer artisan merchant and manufacturer finally it be desirable as a guaranty of the good faith of our nation towards her young sister republic to the south whose welfare must ever be closely bind with ours we give her liberty we be knit to she by the memory of the blood and the courage of our soldier who fight for she in war by the memory of the wisdom and integrity of our administrator who serve she in peace and who start she so well on the difficult path of self government we must help she onward and upward and in help she we shall help ourselves
 the foregoing consideration cause the negotiation of the treaty with cuba and its ratification by the senate they now with equal force support the legislation by the congress which by the term of the treaty be necessary to render it operative a failure to enact such legislation would come perilously near a repudiation of the pledge faith of the nation
 i transmit herewith the treaty as amend by the senate and ratify by the cuban government

to the house of representatives
 in response to a resolution of the house of representatives of november 9 1903 request the president to communicate to the house if not in his judgment incompatible with the interest of the public service all correspondence and other official document relate to the recent revolution on the isthmus of panama i transmit herewith copy of the paper call for
 theodore roosevelt

 respectfully submit
 john hay

 the people of panama have by an apparently unanimous movement dissolve their political connection with the republic of colombia and resume their independence and having adopt a government of their own republican in form with which the government of the united states of america have enter into relation the president of the united states in accordance with the tie of friendship which have so long and so happily exist between the respective nation most earnestly commend to the government of colombia and of panama the peaceful and equitable settlement of all question at issue between they he hold that he be bind not merely by treaty obligation but by the interest of civilization to see that the peaceable traffic of the world across the isthmus of panama shall not long be disturb by a constant succession of unnecessary and wasteful civil war
