 foreign relations
 telegram translation
 new york november 7 1903
 receive 1:40 p.m.
 his excellency john hay secretary of state
 i have the privilege and the honor of notify you that the government of the republic of panama have be pleased to designate i as its envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary near the government of the united states in select for its first representative at washington a veteran servant and champion of the panama canal my government have evidently seek to show that it consider a loyal and earnest devotion to the success of that most heroic conception of human genius as both a solemn duty and the essential purpose of its existence i congratulate myself sir that my first official duty should be to respectfully request you to convey to his excellency the president of the united states on behalf of the people of panama an expression of the grateful sense of their obligation to his government in extend her generous hand so spontaneously to her latest bear the mother of the american nations be prosecute her noble mission as the liberator and the educator of the people in spread her protect wing over the territory of our republic the american eagle have sanctify it it have rescue it from the barbarism of unnecessary and wasteful civil war to consecrate it to the destiny assign to it by providence the service of humanity and the progress of civilization
 philippe bunau varilla

 beaupre bogota
 the people of panama have by an apparently unanimous movement dissolve their political connection with the republic of colombia and resume their independence and having adopt a government of their own republican in form with which the government of the united states of america have enter into relation the president of the united states in accordance with the tie of friendship which have so long and so happily exist between the respective nation most earnestly commend to the government of colombia and panama the peaceful and equitable settlement of all question at issue between they he hold that he be bind not merely by treaty obligation but by the interest of civilization to see that the peaceable traffic of the world across the isthmus of panama shall not long be disturb by a constant succession of unnecessary and wasteful civil war
 hay
 dr. herran to mr. hay
 translation
 legation of colombia washington d.c. november 6 1903
 excellency i acknowledge the reception of your excellency&#39; note of the 6th instant inclose a copy of the telegram send on the same day to the legation of the united states at bogota by the department of state
 in that telegram your excellency refer to the relation already enter into by the government of the united states of america with the colombian rebel who on the evening of the 3rd usurp the power in the capital of the colombian department of panama and imprison the lawful civil and military authority
 your excellency will undoubtedly receive the reply of the colombian government through the same channel that be use to forward the notice of which your excellency be pleased to send i a copy but in the meanwhile i be discharge a duty by lodge in advance with your excellency in the name of my government a solemn protest against the attitude assume in the department of panama by the government of the united states to the injury of colombia&#39;s right and in disaccord with the stipulation of article 35 of the still exist treaty of 1846 1848 between colombia and the united states of america
 i reiterate etc
 thomas herran

 mr. loomis to mr. varilla
 department of state
 washington november 12 1903
 sir i have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your note of the 11th instant in which you advise i that the republic of panama lass appoint you to fill near this government the post of envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary with full power to negotiate
 you far ask that this information may be communicate to the president and that he will kindly fix a date at which you may present your letter of credence
 in reply i have the honor to say that the president will be pleased to receive you for the purpose mention to morrow friday at 9:30 a.m.
 if you will be good enough to call at this department shortly before the hour mention the secretary of state will be pleased to accompany you to the white house
 accept etc
 francis b. loomis acting secretary
 remarks make by the minister of panama
 mr president in accord to the minister plenipotentiary of the republic of panama the honor of present to you his letter of credence you admit into the family of nation the weak and the last bear of the republic of the new world
 it owe its existence to the outburst of the indignant grief which stir the heart of the citizen of the isthmus on behold the despotic action which seek to forbid their country from fulfil the destiny vouchsafe to it by providence
 in consecrate its right to exist mr. president you put an end to what appear to be the interminable controversy as to the rival waterway and you definitely inaugurate the era of the achievement of the panama canal
 from this time forth the determination of the fate of the canal depend upon two element alone now bring face to face singularly unlike as regard their authority and power but wholly equal in their common and ardent desire to see at last the accomplishment of the heroic enterprise for pierce the mountain barrier of the andes
 the highway from europe to asia follow the pathway of the sun be now to be realize
 the early attempt to find such a way unexpectedly result in the great of all historic achievement the discovery of america century have since roll by but the pathway seek have hitherto remain in the realm of dream to day mr. president in response to your summon it become a reality
 the president&#39;s reply to the remarks make by senor bunau varilla on the occasion of the presentation of his letter of credence
 mr minister i be much gratified to receive the letter whereby you be accredit to the government of the united states in the capacity of envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of the republic of panama
 in accordance with its long establish rule this government have take cognizance of the act of the ancient territory of panama in reassert the right of self control and see in the recent event on the isthmus an unopposed expression of the will of the people of panama and the confirmation of their declare independence by the institution of a de facto government republican in form and spirit and alike able and resolve to discharge the obligation pertain to sovereignty we have enter into relation with the new republic it be fitting that we should do so now as we do nearly a century ago when the latin people of america proclaim the right of popular government and it be equally fitting that the united states should now as then be the first to stretch out the hand of fellowship and to observe toward the new bear state the rule of equal intercourse that regulate the relation of sovereignty toward one another
 i feel that i express the wish of my countryman in assure you and through you the people of the republic of panama of our earnest hope and desire that stability and prosperity shall attend the new state and that in harmony with the united states it may be the providential instrument of untold benefit to the civilized world through the opening of a highway of universal commerce across its exceptionally favor territory
 for yourself mr. minister i wish success in the discharge of the important mission to which you have be call
 navy department
 washington november 12 1903
 sir in accordance with the resolution of the house of representatives of the 9th instant call for all correspondence and other official document relate to the recent revolution on the isthmus of panama i have the honor to transmit herewith all such matter on file in the navy department
 very respectfully
 william h. moody secretary

to the senate
 i transmit for the advice and consent of the senate to its ratification a convention between the united states of america and the republic of panama for the construction of a ship canal etc to connect the water of the atlantic and pacific ocean sign on november 18 1903
 i also inclose a report from the secretary of state submit the convention for my consideration
 theodore roosevelt
 department of state
 washington november 19 1903
 the president
 the undersigned secretary of state have the honor to lay before the president for his consideration and if his judgment approve thereof for submission to the senate with a view to receive the advice and consent of that body to its ratification a convention between the united states of america and the republic of panama for the construction of a ship canal etc to connect the water of the atlantic and pacific ocean sign by the respective plenipotentiary of the two country on november 18 1903
 respectfully submit
 john hay
 isthmian canal convention
 the united states of america and the republic of panama be desirous to insure the construction of a ship canal across the isthmus of panama to connect the atlantic and pacific ocean and the congress of the united states of america having pass an act approve june 28 1902 in furtherance of that object by which the president of the united states be authorize to acquire within a reasonable time the control of the necessary territory of the republic of colombia and the sovereignty of such territory be actually vest in the republic of panama the high contracting party have resolve for that purpose to conclude a convention and have accordingly appoint as their plenipotentiaries--
 the president of the united states of america john hay secretary of state and
 the government of the republic of panama philippe bunau varilla envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of the republic of panama thereunto specially empower by say government who after communicate with each other their respective full power find to be in good and due form have agree upon and conclude the following article
 article i.
 the united states guarantee and will maintain the independence of the republic of panama
 article ii
 the republic of panama grant to the united states in perpetuity the use occupation and control of a zone of land and land under water for the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of say canal of the width of 10 mile extend to the distance of 5 mile on each side of the center line of the route of the canal to be construct the say zone begin in the caribbean sea 3 marine mile from mean low water mark and extend to and across the isthmus of panama into the pacific ocean to a distance of 3 marine mile from mean low water mark with the proviso that the city of panama and colon and the harbor adjacent to say city which be include within the boundary of the zone above describe shall not be include within this grant
 the republic of panama further grant to the united states in perpetuity the use occupation and control of any other land and water outside of the zone above describe which may be necessary and convenient for the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the say canal or of any auxiliary canal or other work necessary and convenient for the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the say enterprise
 the republic of panama further grant in like manner to the united states in perpetuity all island within the limit of the zone above describe and in addition thereto the group of small island in the bay of panama name perico naos culebra and flamenco
 article iii
 the republic of panama grant to the united states all the right power and authority within the zone mention and describe in article ii of this agreement and within the limit of all auxiliary land and water mention and describe in say article ii which the united states would possess and exercise if it be the sovereign of the territory within which say land and water be locate to the entire exclusion of the exercise by the republic of panama of any sovereign right power or authority
 article iv
 as right subsidiary to the above grant the republic of panama grant in perpetuity to the united states the right to use the river stream lake and other body of water within its limit for navigation the supply of water or water power or other purpose so far as the use of say river stream lake and body of water and the water thereof may be necessary and convenient for the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the said canal
 article v.
 the republic of panama grant to the united states in perpetuity a monopoly for the construction maintenance and operation of any system of communication by mean of canal or railroad across its territory between the caribbean sea and the pacific ocean
 article vi
 the grant herein contain shall in no manner invalidate the title or right of private land holder or owner of private property in the say zone or in or to any of the land or water grant to the united states by the provision of any article of this treaty nor shall they interfere with the right of way over the public road pass through the say zone or over any of the say land or water unless say right of way or private right shall conflict with right herein grant to the united states in which case the right of the united states shall be superior
 all damage cause to the owner of private land or private property of any kind by reason of the grant contain in this treaty or by reason of the operation of the united states its agent or employee or by reason of the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the say canal or of the work of sanitation and protection herein provide for shall be appraise and settle by a joint commission appoint by the government of the united states and of the republic of panama whose decision as to such damage shall be final and whose award as to such damage shall be pay solely by the united states no part of the work on say canal or the panama railroad or on any auxiliary work relate thereto and authorize by the term of this treaty shall be prevent delay or impede by or pende such proceeding to ascertain such damage the appraisal of say private land and private property and the assessment of damage to they shall be base upon their value before the date of this convention
 article vii
 the republic of panama grant to the united states within the limit of the city of panama and colon and their adjacent harbor and within the territory adjacent thereto the right to acquire by purchase or by the exercise of the right of eminent domain any land building water right or other property necessary and convenient for the construction maintenance operation and protection of the canal and of any work of sanitation such as the collection and disposition of sewage and the distribution of water in the say city of panama and colon which in the discretion of the united states may be necessary and convenient for the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the say canal and railroad
 all such work of sanitation collection and disposition of sewage and distribution of water in the city of panama and colon shall be make at the expense of the united states and the government of the united states its agent or nominee shall be authorize to impose and collect water rate and sewerage rate which shall be sufficient to provide for the payment of interest and the amortization of the principal of the cost of say work within a period of fifty year and upon the expiration of say term of fifty year the system of sewer and waterworks shall revert to and become the property of the city of panama and colon respectively and the use of the water shall be free to the inhabitant of panama and colon except to the extent that water rate may be necessary for the operation and maintenance of say system of sewer and water
 the republic of panama agree that the city of panama and colon shall comply in perpetuity with the sanitary ordinance whether of a preventive or curative character prescribe by the united states and in case the government of panama be unable or fail in its duty to enforce this compliance by the city of panama and colon with the sanitary ordinance of the united states the republic of panama grant to the united states the right and authority to enforce the same
 the same right and authority be grant to the united states for the maintenance of public order in the city of panama and colon and the territory and harbor adjacent thereto in case the republic of panama should not be in the judgment of the united states able to maintain such order
 article viii
 the republic of panama grant to the united states all right which it now have or hereafter may acquire to the property of the new panama canal company and the panama railroad company as a result of the transfer of sovereignty from the republic of colombia to the republic of panama over the isthmus of panama and authorize the new panama canal company to sell and transfer to the united states its right privilege property and concession as well as the panama railroad and all the share or part of the share of that company but the public land situate outside of the zone describe in article ii of this treaty now include in the concession to both say enterprise and not require in the construction or operation of the canal shall revert to the republic of panama except any property now own by or in the possession of say company within panama or colon or the port or terminal thereof
 article ix
 the united states agree that the port at either entrance of the canal and the water thereof and the republic of panama agree that the town of panama and colon shall be free for all time so that there shall not be impose or collect custom house toll tonnage anchorage light house wharf pilot or quarantine due or any other charge or taxis of any kind upon any vessel use or pass through the canal or belong to or employ by the united states directly or indirectly in connection with the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the main canal or auxiliary work or upon the cargo officer crew or passenger of any such vessel except such toll and charge as may be impose by the united states for the use of the canal and other work and except toll and charge impose by the republic of panama upon merchandise destine to be introduce for the consumption of the rest of the republic of panama and upon vessel touch at the port of colon and panama and which do not cross the canal
 the government of the republic of panama shall have the right to establish in such port and in the town of panama and colon such house and guard as it may be necessary to collect duty on importation destine to other portion of panama and to prevent contraband trade the united states shall have the right to make use of the town and harbor of panama and colon as place of anchorage and for make repair for loading unloading depositing or transshipping cargo either in transit or destine for the service of the canal and for other work pertain to the canal
 article x.
 the republic of panama agree that there shall not be impose any taxis national municipal departmental or of any other class upon the canal the railway and auxiliary work tug and other vessel employ in the service of the canal storehouse workshop office quarter for laborer factory of all kind warehouse wharf machinery and other work property and effect appertain to the canal or railroad and auxiliary work or their officer or employee situate within the city of panama and colon and that there shall not be impose contribution or charge of a personal character of any kind upon officer employee laborer and other individual in the service of the canal and railroad and auxiliary work
 article xi
 the united states agree that the official dispatch of the government of the republic of panama shall be transmit over any telegraph and telephone line establish for canal purpose and use for public and private business at rate not high than those require from official in the service of the united states
 article xii
 the government of the republic of panama shall permit the immigration and free access to the land and workshop of the canal and its auxiliary work of all employee and workman of whatever nationality under contract to work upon or seek employment upon or in any wise connect with the say canal and its auxiliary work with their respective family and all such person shall be free and exempt from the military service of the republic of panama
 article xiii
 the united states may import at any time into the say zone and auxiliary land free of custom duty impost taxis or other charge and without any restriction any and all vessel dredge engine car machinery tool explosive material supply and other article necessary and convenient in the construction maintenance operation sanitation and protection of the canal and auxiliary work and all provision medicine clothing supply and other thing necessary and convenient for the officer employee workman and laborer in the service and employ of the united states and for their family if any such article be dispose of for use outside of the zone and auxiliary land grant to the united states and within the territory of the republic they shall be subject to the same import or other duty as like article import under the law of the republic of panama
 article xiv
 as the price or compensation for the right power and privilege grant in this convention by the republic of panama to the united states the government of the united states agree to pay to the republic of panama the sum of $ 10,000,000 in gold coin of the united states on the exchange of the ratification of this convention and also an annual payment during the life of this convention of $ 250,000 in like gold coin begin nine year after the date aforesaid
 the provision of this article shall be in addition to all other benefit assure to the republic of panama under this convention
 but no delay or difference of opinion under this article or any other provision of this treaty shall affect or interrupt the full operation and effect of this convention in all other respect
 article xv
 the joint commission refer to in article vi shall be establish as follow
 the president of the united states shall nominate two person and the president of the republic of panama shall nominate two person and they shall proceed to a decision but in case of disagreement of the commission by reason of their be equally divide in conclusion an umpire shall be appoint by the two government who shall render the decision in the event of the death absence or incapacity of a commissioner or umpire or of his omitting decline or cease to act his place shall be fill by the appointment of another person in the manner above indicate all decision by a majority of the commission or by the umpire shall be final
 article xvi
 the two government shall make adequate provision by future agreement for the pursuit capture imprisonment detention and delivery within say zone and auxiliary land to the authority of the republic of panama of person charge with the commitment of crime felony or misdemeanor without say zone and for the pursuit capture imprisonment detention and delivery without say zone to the authority of the united states of person charge with the commitment of crime felony and misdemeanor within say zone and auxiliary land
 article xvii
 the republic of panama grant to the united states the use of all the port of the republic open to commerce as place of refuge for any vessel employ in the canal enterprise and for all vessel pass or bind to pass through the canal which may be in distress and be drive to seek refuge in say port such vessel shall be exempt from anchorage and tonnage due on the part of the republic of panama
 article xviii
 the canal when construct and the entrance thereto shall be neutral in perpetuity and shall be open upon the term provide for by section i of article iii of and in conformity with all the stipulation of the treaty enter into by the government of the united states and great britain on november 18 1901
 article xix
 the government of the republic of panama shall have the right to transport over the canal its vessel and its troop and munition of war in such vessel at all time without pay charge of any kind the exemption be to be extend to the auxiliary railway for the transportation of person in the service of the republic of panama or of the police force charge with the preservation of public order outside of say zone as well as to their baggage munition of war and supply
 article xx
 if by virtue of any exist treaty in relation to the territory of the isthmus of panama whereof the obligation shall descend or be assume by the republic of panama there may be any privilege or concession in favor of the government or the citizen and subject of a third power relative to an interoceanic mean of communication which in any of its term may be incompatible with the term of the present convention the republic of panama agree to cancel or modify such treaty in due form for which purpose it shall give to the say third power the requisite notification within the term of four month from the date of the present convention and in case the exist treaty contain no clause permit its modification or annulment the republic of panama agree to procure its modification or annulment in such form that there shall not exist any conflict with the stipulation of the present convention
 article xxi
 the right and privilege grant by the republic of panama to the united states in the precede article be understand to be free of all anterior debt lien trust or liability or concession or privilege to other government corporation syndicate or individual and consequently if there should arise any claim on account of the present concession and privilege or otherwise the claimant shall resort to the government of the republic of panama and not to the united states for any indemnity or compromise which may be require
 article xxii
 the republic of panama renounce and grant to the united states the participation to which it might be entitle in the future earning of the canal under article xv of the concessionary contract with lucien n. b. wyse now own by the new panama canal company and any and all other right or claim of a pecuniary nature arise under or relate to say concession or arise under or relate to the concession to the panama railroad company or any extension or modification thereof and it likewise renounce confirm and grant to the united states now and hereafter all the right and property reserve in the say concession which otherwise would belong to panama at or before the expiration of the term of ninety nine year of the concession grant to or hold by the above mention party and company and all right title and interest which it now have or may hereafter have in and to the land canal work property and right hold by the say company under say concession or otherwise and acquire or to be acquire by the united states from or through the new panama canal company include any property and right which might or may in the future either by lapse of time forfeiture or otherwise revert to the republic of panama under any contract or concession with say wyse the universal panama canal company the panama railroad company and the new panama canal company
 the aforesaid right and property shall be and be free and release from any present or revisionary interest in or claim of panama and the title of the united states thereto upon consummation of the contemplated purchase by the united states from the new panama canal company shall be absolute so far as concern the republic of panama except always the right of the republic specifically secure under this treaty
 article xxiii
 if it should become necessary at any time to employ armed force for the safety or protection of the canal or of the ship that make use of the same or the railway and auxiliary work the united states shall have the right at all time and in its discretion to use its police and its land and naval force or to establish fortification for these purpose
 article xxiv
 no change either in the government or in the law and treaty of the republic of panama shall without the consent of the united states affect any right of the united states under the present convention or under any treaty stipulation between the two country that now exist or may hereafter exist touch the subject matter of this convention
 if the republic of panama shall hereafter enter as a constituent into any other government or into any union or confederation of state so as to merge her sovereignty or independence in such government union or confederation the right of the united states under this convention shall not be in any respect lessen or impair
 article xxv
 for the well performance of the engagement of this convention and to the end of the efficient protection of the canal and the preservation of its neutrality the government of the republic of panama will sell or lease to the united states land adequate and necessary for naval or coaling station on the pacific coast and on the western caribbean coast of the republic at certain point to be agree upon with the president of the united states
 article xxvi
 this convention when sign by the plenipotentiary of the contracting party shall be ratify by the respective government and the ratification shall be exchange at washington at the early date possible
 in faith whereof the respective plenipotentiary have sign the present convention in duplicate and have hereunto affix their respective seal
 do at the city of washington the 18th day of november in the year of our lord 1903
 john hay
 p. bunau varilla

not design to restrict or control the full liberty of legitimate business action but to secure exact and authentic information which will aid the executive in enforce exist law and which will enable united states we have repeatedly exercise this control by intervene in the course of domestic dissension and by protect the territory from foreign invasion in 1853 mr. everett assure the peruvian minister that we should not hesitate to maintain the neutrality of the isthmus in the case of war between peru and colombia in 1864 colombia which have always be vigilant to avail itself of its privilege confer by the treaty express its expectation that in the event of war between peru and spain the united states would carry into effect the guaranty of neutrality there have be few administration of the state department in which this treaty have not either by the one side or the other be use as a basis of more or less important demand it be say by mr. fish in 1871 that the department of state have reason to believe that an attack upon colombian sovereignty on the isthmus have on several occasion be avert by warn from this government in 1886 when colombia be under the menace of hostility from italy in the cerruti case mr. bayard express the serious concern that the united states could not but feel that a european power should resort to force against a sister republic of this hemisphere as to the sovereign and uninterrupted use of a part of whose territory we be guarantor under the solemn faith of a treaty the above recital of fact establishe beyond question first that the united states have for over half a century patiently and in good faith carry out its obligation under the treaty of 1846 second that when for the first time it become possible for colombia to do anything in requital of the service thus repeatedly render to it for fifty seven year by the united states the colombian government peremptorily and offensively refuse thus to do its part even though to do so would have be to its advantage and immeasurably to the advantage of the state of panama at that time under its jurisdiction third that throughout this period revolution riot and factional disturbance of every kind have occur one after the other in almost uninterrupted succession some of they last for month and even for year while the central government be unable to put they down or to make peace with the rebel fourth that these disturbance instead of show any sign of abate have tend to grow more numerous and more serious in the immediate past fifth that the control of colombia over the isthmus of panama could not be maintain without the armed intervention and assistance of the united states in other word the government of colombia though wholly unable to maintain order on the isthmus have nevertheless decline to ratify a treaty the conclusion of which open the only chance to secure its own stability and to guarantee permanent peace on and the construction of a canal across the isthmus under such circumstance the government of the united states would have be guilty of folly and weakness amount in their sum to a crime against the nation have it act otherwise than it do when the revolution of november 3 last take place in panama this great enterprise of build the interoceanic canal can not be hold up to gratify the whim or out of respect to the governmental impotence or to the even more sinister and evil political peculiarity of people who though they dwell afar off yet against the wish of the actual dweller on the isthmus assert an unreal supremacy over the territory the possession of a territory fraught with such peculiar capacity as the isthmus in question carry with it obligation to mankind the course of event have show that this canal can not be build by private enterprise or by any other nation than our own therefore it must be build by the united states every effort have be make by the government of the united states to persuade colombia to follow a course which be essentially not only to our interest and to the interest of the world but to the interest of colombia itself these effort have fail and colombia by her persistence in repulse the advance that have be make have force we for the sake of our own honor and of the interest and well being not merely of our own people but of the people of the isthmus of panama and the people of the civilized country of the world to take decisive step to bring to an end a condition of affair which have become intolerable the new republic of panama immediately offer to negotiate a treaty with we this treaty i herewith submit by it our interest be well safeguard than in the treaty with colombia which be ratify by the senate at its last session it be well in its term than the treaty offer to we by the republics of nicaragua and costa rica at last the right to begin this great undertaking be make available panama have do her part all that remain be for the american congress to do its part and forthwith this republic will enter upon the execution of a project colossal in its size and of well nigh incalculable possibility for the good of this country and the nation of mankind by the provision of the treaty the united states guarantee and will maintain the independence of the republic of panama there be grant to the united states in perpetuity the use occupation and control of a strip ten mile wide and extend three nautical mile into the sea at either terminal with all land lie outside of the zone necessary for the construction of the canal or for its auxiliary work and with the island in the bay of panama the city of panama and colon be not embrace in the canal zone but the united states assume their sanitation and in case of need the maintenance of order therein the united states enjoy within the grant limit all the right power and authority which it would possess be it the sovereign of the territory to the exclusion of the exercise of sovereign right by the republic all railway and canal property right belong to panama and need for the canal pass to the united states include any property of the respective company in the city of panama and colon the work property and personnel of the canal and railway be exempt from taxation as well in the city of panama and colon as in the canal zone and its dependency free immigration of the personnel and importation of supply for the construction and operation of the canal be grant provision be make for the use of military force and the building of fortification by the united states for the protection of the transit in other detail particularly as to the acquisition of the interest of the new panama canal company and the panama railway by the united states and the condemnation of private property for the use of the canal the stipulation of the hay herran treaty be closely follow while the compensation to be give for these enlarge grant remain the same be ten million of dollar payable on exchange of ratification and begin nine year from that date an annual payment of $ 250,000 during the life of the convention
by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas a state of war unhappily exist between japan on the one side and russia on the other side
 and whereas the united states be on term of friendship and amity with both the contend power and with the person inhabit their several dominion
 and whereas there be citizen of the united states reside within the territory or dominion of each of the say belligerent and carry on commerce trade or other business or pursuit therein protect by the faith of treaty
 and whereas there be subject of each of the say belligerent reside within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states and carry on commerce trade or other business or pursuit therein
 and whereas the law of the united states without interfere with the free expression of opinion and sympathy or with the open manufacture or sale of arm or munition of war nevertheless impose upon all person who may be within their territory and jurisdiction the duty of an impartial neutrality during the existence of the contest
 and whereas it be the duty of a neutral government not to permit or suffer the making of its water subservient to the purpose of war
 now therefore i theodore roosevelt president of the united states of america in order to preserve the neutrality of the united states and of their citizen and of person within their territory and jurisdiction and to enforce their law and in order that all person be warn of the general tenor of the law and treaty of the united states in this behalf and of the law of nation may thus be prevent from an unintentional violation of the same do hereby declare and proclaim that by the act pass on the 20th day of april a. d. 1818 commonly know as the neutrality law the follow act be forbid to be do under severe penalty within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states to wit
 1 accept and exercise a commission to serve either of the say belligerent by land or by sea against the other belligerent
 2 enlist or enter into the service of either of the say belligerent as a soldier or as a marine or seaman on board of any vessel of war letter of marque or privateer
 3 hire or retain another person to enlist or enter himself in the service of either of the say belligerent as a soldier or as a marine or seaman on board of any vessel of war letter of marque or privateer
 4 hire another person to go beyond the limit or jurisdiction of the united states with intent to be enlist as aforesaid
 5 hire another person to go beyond the limit of the united states with intent to be enter into service as aforesaid
 6 retain another person to go beyond the limit of the united states with intent to be enlist as aforesaid
 7 retain another person to go beyond the limit of the united states with intent to be enter into service as aforesaid but the say act be not to be construe to extend to a citizen or subject of either belligerent who be transiently within the united states shall on board of any vessel of war which at the time of its arrival within the united states be fit and equip as such vessel of war enlist or enter himself or hire or retain another subject or citizen of the same belligerent who be transiently within the united states to enlist or enter himself to serve such belligerent on board such vessel of war if the united states shall then be at peace with such belligerent
 8 fit out and arm or attempt to fit out and arm or procure to be fit out and arm or knowingly be concern in the furnish fit out or arming of any ship or vessel with intent that such ship or vessel shall be employ in the service of either of the say belligerent
 9 issue or deliver a commission within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states for any ship or vessel to the intent that she may be employ as aforesaid
 10 increase or augment or procure to be increase or augmented or knowingly be concern in increase or augment the force of any ship of war cruiser or other armed vessel which at the time of her arrival within the united states be a ship of war cruiser or armed vessel in the service of either of the say belligerent or belong to the subject of either by add to the number of gun of such vessel or by change those on board of she for gun of a large caliber or by the addition thereto of any equipment solely applicable to war
 11 begin or set on foot or provide or prepare the mean for any military expedition or enterprise to be carry on from the territory or jurisdiction of the united states against the territory or dominion of either of the say belligerent
 and i do hereby further declare and proclaim that any frequenting and use of the water within the territorial jurisdiction of the united states by the armed vessel of either belligerent whether public ship or privateer for the purpose of prepare for hostile operation or as post of observation upon the ship of war or privateer or merchant vessel of the other belligerent lying within or be about to enter the jurisdiction of the united states must be regard as unfriendly and offensive and in violation of that neutrality which it be the determination of this government to observe and to the end that the hazard and inconvenience of such apprehended practice may be avoid i far proclaim and declare that from and after the fifteenth day of february instant and during the continuance of the present hostility between japan and russia no ship of war or privateer of either belligerent shall be permit to make use of any port harbor roadstead or water subject to the jurisdiction of the united states from which a vessel of the other belligerent whether the same shall be a ship of war a privateer or a merchant ship shall have previously depart until after the expiration of at least twenty four hour from the departure of such last mention vessel beyond the jurisdiction of the united states if any ship of war or privateer of either belligerent shall after the time this notification take effect enter any port harbor roadstead or water of the united states such vessel shall be require to depart and to put to sea within twenty four hour after her entrance into such port harbor roadstead or water except in case of stress of weather or of she require provision or thing necessary for the subsistence of her crew or for repair in either of which case the authority of the port or of the near port as the case may be shall require she to put to sea as soon as possible after the expiration of such period of twenty four hour without permit she to take in supply beyond what may be necessary for her immediate use and no such vessel which may have be permit to remain within the water of the united states for the purpose of repair shall continue within such port harbor roadstead or water for a long period than twenty four hour after her necessary repair shall have be complete unless within such twenty four hour a vessel whether ship of war privateer or merchant ship of the other belligerent shall have depart therefrom in which case the time limit for the departure of such ship of war or privateer shall be extend so far as may be necessary to secure an interval of not less than twenty four hour between such departure and that of any ship of war privateer or merchant ship of the other belligerent which may have previously quit the same port harbor roadstead or water no ship of war or privateer of either belligerent shall be detain in any port harbor roadstead or water of the united states more than twenty four hour by reason of the successive departure from such port harbor roadstead or water of more than one vessel of the other belligerent but if there be several vessel of each or either of the two belligerent in the same port harbor roadstead or water the order of their departure therefrom shall be so arrange as to afford the opportunity of leave alternately to the vessel of the respective belligerent and to cause the least detention consistent with the object of this proclamation no ship of war or privateer of either belligerent shall be permit while in any port harbor roadstead or water within the jurisdiction of the united states to take in any supply except provision and such other thing as may be requisite for the subsistence of her crew and except so much coal only as may be sufficient to carry such vessel if without any sail power to the near port of her own country or in case the vessel be rig to go under sail and may also be propel by steam power then with half the quantity of coal which she would be entitle to receive if dependent upon steam alone and no coal shall be again supply to any such ship of war or privateer in the same or any other port harbor roadstead or water of the united states without special permission until after the expiration of three month from the time when such coal may have be last supply to she within the water of the united states unless such ship of war or privateer shall since last thus supply have enter a port of the government to which she belong
 and i far declare and proclaim that by the first article of the convention as to right of neutral at sea which be conclude between the united states of america and his majesty the emperor of all the russias on the 22nd day of july a. d. 1854 the follow principle be recognize as permanent and immutable to wit
 1 that free ship make free good that be to say that the effect or good belong to subject or citizen of a power or state at war be free from capture and confiscation when find on board of neutral vessel with the exception of article contraband of war
 2 that the property of neutral on board an enemy&#39;s vessel be not subject to confiscation unless the same be contraband of war
 and i do far declare and proclaim that the statute of the united states and the law of nation alike require that no person within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states shall take part directly or indirectly in the said war but shall remain at peace with each of the say belligerent and shall maintain a strict and impartial neutrality and that whatever privilege shall be accord to one belligerent within the port of the united states shall be in like manner accord to the other
 and i do hereby enjoin all the good citizen of the united states and all person reside or be within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states to observe the law thereof and to commit no act contrary to the provision of the say statute or in violation of the law of nation in that behalf
 and i do hereby warn all citizen of the united states and all person reside or be within their territory or jurisdiction that while the free and full expression of sympathy in public and private be not restrict by the law of the united states military force in aid of either belligerent can not lawfully be originate or organize within their jurisdiction and that while all person may lawfully and without restriction by reason of the aforesaid state of war manufacture and sell within the united states arm and munition of war and other article ordinarily know as contraband of war yet they can not carry such article upon the high sea for the use or service of either belligerent nor can they transport soldier and officer of either or attempt to break any blockade which may be lawfully establish and maintain during the war without incur the risk of hostile capture and the penalty denounce by the law of nation in that behalf
 and i do hereby give notice that all citizen of the united states and other who may claim the protection of this government who may misconduct themselves in the premise will do so at their peril and that they can in no wise obtain any protection from the government of the united states against the consequence of their misconduct
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 11th day of february in the year of our lord one thousand nine hundred and four and of the independence of the united states the one hundred and twenty eighth

 theodore roosevelt
 by the president
 john hay
 secretary of state
to the senate and house of representatives the nation continue to enjoy noteworthy prosperity such prosperity be of course primarily due to the high individual average of our citizenship take together with our great natural resource but an important factor therein be the working of our long continue governmental policy the people have emphatically express their approval of the principle underlie these policy and their desire that these principle be keep substantially unchanged although of course apply in a progressive spirit to meet change condition the enlargement of scope of the function of the national government require by our development as a nation involve of course increase of expense and the period of prosperity through which the country be pass justifie expenditure for permanent improvement far great than would be wise in hard time battle ship and fort public building and improve waterway be investment which should be make when we have the money but abundant revenue and a large surplus always invite extravagance and constant care should be take to guard against unnecessary increase of the ordinary expense of government the cost of do government business should be regulate with the same rigid scrutiny as the cost of do a private business in the vast and complicated mechanism of our modern civilized life the dominant note be the note of industralism and the relation of capital and labor and especially of organized capital and organized labor to each other and to the public at large come second in importance only to the intimate question of family life our peculiar form of government with its sharp division of authority between the nation and the several states have be on the whole far more advantageous to our development than a more strongly centralized government but it be undoubtedly responsible for much of the difficulty of meeting with adequate legislation the new problem present by the total change in industrial condition on this continent during the last half century in actual practice it have prove exceedingly difficult and in many case impossible to get unanimity of wise action among the various states on these subject from the very nature of the case this be especially true of the law affect the employment of capital in huge masse with regard to labor the problem be no less important but it be simple as long as the states retain the primary control of the police power the circumstance must be altogether extreme which require interference by the federal authority whether in the way of safeguard the right of labor or in the way of see that wrong be not do by unruly person who shield themselves behind the name of labor if there be resistance to the federal court interference with the mail or interstate commerce or molestation of federal property or if the state authority in some crisis which they be unable to face call for help then the federal government may interfere but though such interference may be cause by a condition of thing arise out of trouble connect with some question of labor the interference itself simply take the form of restore order without regard to the question which have cause the breach of order for to keep order be a primary duty and in a time of disorder and violence all other question sink into abeyance until order have be restore in the district of columbia and in the territories the federal law cover the entire field of government but the labor question be only acute in populous center of commerce manufacture or mining nevertheless both in the enactment and in the enforcement of law the federal government within its restricted sphere should set an example to the state government especially in a matter so vital as this affect labor i believe that under modern industrial condition it be often necessary and even where not necessary it be yet often wise that there should be organization of labor in order well to secure the right of the individual wage worker all encouragement should be give to any such organization so long as it be conduct with a due and decent regard for the right of other there be in this country some labor union which have habitually and other labor union which have often be among the most effective agent in work for good citizenship and for uplift the condition of those whose welfare should be close to our heart but when any labor union seek improper end or seek to achieve proper end by improper mean all good citizen and more especially all honorable public servant must oppose the wrongdoing as resolutely as they would oppose the wrongdoing of any great corporation of course any violence brutality or corruption should not for one moment be tolerate wage worker have an entire right to organize and by all peaceful and honorable mean to endeavor to persuade their fellow to join with they in organization they have a legal right which accord to circumstance may or may not be a moral right to refuse to work in company with man who decline to join their organization they have under no circumstance the right to commit violence upon these whether capitalist or wage worker who refuse to support their organization or who side with those with whom they be at odd for mob rule be intolerable in any form the wage worker be peculiarly entitle to the protection and the encouragement of the law from the very nature of their occupation railroad man for instance be liable to be maim in do the legitimate work of their profession unless the railroad company be require by law to make ample provision for their safety the administration have be zealous in enforce the exist law for this purpose that law should be amend and strengthen wherever the national government have power there should be a stringent employer 's liability law which should apply to the government itself where the government be an employer of labor in my message to the fifty seventh congress at its second session i urge the passage of an employer 's liability law for the district of columbia i now renew that recommendation and far recommend that the congress appoint a commission to make a comprehensive study of employer 's liability with the view of extend the provision of a great and constitutional law to all employment within the scope of federal power the government have recognize heroism upon the water and bestow medal of honor upon those person who by extreme and heroic daring have endanger their life in saving or endeavor to save live from the peril of the sea in the water over which the united states have jurisdiction or upon an american vessel this recognition should be extend to cover case of conspicuous bravery and self sacrifice in the saving of life in private employment under the jurisdiction of the united states and particularly in the land commerce of the nation the ever increase casualty list upon our railroad be a matter of grave public concern and urgently call for action by the congress in the matter of speed and comfort of railway travel our railroad give at least as good service as those of any other nation and there be no reason why this service should not also be as safe as human ingenuity can make it many of our lead road have be foremost in the adoption of the most approve safeguard for the protection of traveler and employee yet the list of clearly avoidable accident continue unduly large the passage of a law require the adoption of a block signal system have be propose to the congress i earnestly concur in that recommendation and would also point out to the congress the urgent need of legislation in the interest of the public safety limit the hour of labor for railroad employee in train service upon railroad engage in interstate commerce and provide that only trained and experienced person be employ in position of responsibility connect with the operation of train of course nothing can ever prevent accident cause by human weakness or misconduct and there should be drastic punishment for any railroad employee whether officer or man who by issuance of wrong order or by disobedience of order cause disaster the law of 1901 require interstate railroad to make monthly report of all accident to passenger and employee on duty should also be amend so as to empower the government to make a personal investigation through proper officer of all accident involve loss of life which seem to require investigation with a requirement that the result of such investigation be make public the safety appliance law as amend by the act of march 2 1903 have prove beneficial to railway employee and in order that its provision may be properly carry out the force of inspector provide for by appropriation should be largely increase this service be analogous to the steamboat inspection service and deal with even more important interest it have pass the experimental stage and demonstrate its utility and should receive generous recognition by the congress there be no objection to employee of the government form or belong to union but the government can neither discriminate for nor discriminate against nonunion man who be in its employment or who seek to be employ under it moreover it be a very grave impropriety for government employee to band themselves together for the purpose of extort improperly high salary from the government especially be this true of those within the classified service the letter carrier both municipal and rural be as a whole an excellent body of public servant they should be amply pay but their payment must be obtain by argue their claim fairly and honorably before the congress and not by band together for the defeat of those congressman who refuse to give promise which they can not in conscience give the administration have already take step to prevent and punish abuse of this nature but it will be wise for the congress to supplement this action by legislation much can be do by the government in labor matter merely by give publicity to certain condition the bureau of labor have do excellent work of this kind in many different direction i shall shortly lay before you in a special message the full report of the investigation of the bureau of labor into the colorado mining strike as this be a strike in which certain very evil force which be more or less at work everywhere under the condition of modern industrialism become startlingly prominent it be greatly to be wish that the department of commerce and labor through the labor bureau should compile and arrange for the congress a list of the labor law of the various states and should be give the mean to investigate and report to the congress upon the labor condition in the manufacturing and mining region throughout the country both as to wage as to hour of labor as to the labor of woman and child and as to the effect in the various labor center of immigration from abroad in this investigation especial attention should be pay to the condition of child labor and child labor legislation in the several states such an investigation must necessarily take into account many of the problem with which this question of child labor be connect these problem can be actually meet in most case only by the states themselves but the lack of proper legislation in one state in such a matter as child labor often render it excessively difficult to establish protective restriction upon the work in another state have the same industry so that the bad tend to drag down the well for this reason it would be well for the nation at least to endeavor to secure comprehensive information as to the condition of labor of child in the different state such investigation and publication by the national government would tend toward the securing of approximately uniform legislation of the proper character among the several states when we come to deal with great corporation the need for the government to act directly be far great than in the case of labor because great corporation can become such only by engage in interstate commerce and interstate commerce be peculiarly the field of the general government it be an absurdity to expect to eliminate the abuse in great corporation by state action it be difficult to be patient with an argument that such matter should be leave to the states because more than one state pursue the policy of create on easy term corporation which be never operate within that state at all but in other states whose law they ignore the national government alone can deal adequately with these great corporation to try to deal with they in an intemperate destructive or demagogic spirit would in all probability mean that nothing whatever would be accomplish and with absolute certainty that if anything be accomplish it would be of a harmful nature the american people need to continue to show the very quality that they have show that is moderation good sense the earnest desire to avoid do any damage and yet the quiet determination to proceed step by step without halt and without hurry in eliminate or at least in minimize whatever of mischief or evil there be to interstate commerce in the conduct of great corporation they be act in no spirit of hostility to wealth either individual or corporate they be not against the rich man any more than against the poor man on the contrary they be friendly alike toward rich man and toward poor man provide only that each act in a spirit of justice and decency toward his fellow great corporation be necessary and only man of great and singular mental power can manage such corporation successfully and such man must have great reward but these corporation should be manage with due regard to the interest of the public as a whole where this can be do under the present law it must be do where these law come short other should be enact to supplement they yet we must never forget the determine factor in every kind of work of head or hand must be the man 's own good sense courage and kindliness more important than any legislation be the gradual growth of a feeling of responsibility and forbearance among capitalist and wage worker alike a feeling of respect on the part of each man for the right of other a feeling of broad community of interest not merely of capitalist among themselves and of wage worker among themselves but of capitalist and wage worker in their relation to each other and of both in their relation to their fellow who with they make up the body politic there be many captain of industry many labor leader who realize this a recent speech by the president of one of our great railroad system to the employee of that system contain sound common sense it rim in part as follows:"it be my belief we can well serve each other well understand the man as well as his business when meeting face to face exchange view and realize from personal contact we serve but one interest that of our mutual prosperity "serious misunderstanding can not occur where personal good will exist and opportunity for personal explanation be present "in my early business life i have experience with man of affair of a character to make i desire to avoid create a like feeling of resentment to myself and the interest in my charge should fortune ever place i in authority and i be solicitous of a measure of confidence on the part of the public and our employee that i shall hope may be warrant by the fairness and good fellowship i intend shall prevail in our relationship "but do not feel i be disposed to grant unreasonable request spend the money of our company unnecessarily or without value receive nor expect the day of mistake be disappear or that cause for complaint will not continually occur simply to correct such abuse as may be discover to well condition as fast as reasonably may be expect constantly strive with vary success for that improvement we all desire to convince you there be a force at work in the right direction all the time make progress be the disposition with which i have come among you ask your good will and encouragement "the day have go by when a corporation can be handle successfully in defiance of the public will even though that will be unreasonable and wrong a public may be lead but not drive and i prefer to go with it and shape or modify in a measure its opinion rather than be sweep from my bearing with loss to myself and the interest in my charge "violent prejudice exist towards corporate activity and capital today much of it found in reason more in apprehension and a large measure be due to the personal trait of arbitrary unreasonable incompetent and offensive man in position of authority the accomplishment of result by indirection the endeavor to thwart the intention if not the express letter of the law the will of the people a disregard of the right of other a disposition to withhold what be due to force by main strength or inactivity a result not justify depend upon the weakness of the claimant and his indisposition to become involved in litigation have create a sentiment harmful in the extreme and a disposition to consider anything fair that give gain to the individual at the expense of the company "if corporation be to continue to do the world 's work as they be well fit to these quality in their representative that have result in the present prejudice against they must be relegate to the background the corporation must come out into the open and see and be see they must take the public into their confidence and ask for what they want and no more and be prepared to explain satisfactorily what advantage will accrue to the public if they be give their desire for they be permit to exist not that they may make money solely but that they may effectively serve those from whom they derive their power "publicity and not secrecy will win hereafter and law be construe by their intent and not by their letter otherwise public utility will be own and operate by the public which create they even though the service be less efficient and the result less satisfactory from a financial standpoint "the bureau of corporations have make careful preliminary investigation of many important corporation it will make a special report on the beef industry the policy of the bureau be to accomplish the purpose of its creation by co operation not antagonism by make constructive legislation not destructive prosecution the immediate object of its inquiry by conservative investigation of law and fact and by refusal to issue incomplete and hence necessarily inaccurate report its policy be thus one of open inquiry into and not attack upon business the bureau have be able to gain not only the confidence but well still the cooperation of man engage in legitimate business the bureau offer to the congress the mean of get at the cost of production of our various great staple of commerce of necessity the careful investigation of special corporation will afford the commissioner knowledge of certain business fact the publication of which might be an improper infringement of private right the method of make public the result of these investigation afford under the law a means for the protection of private right the congress will have all fact except such as would give to another corporation information which would injure the legitimate business of a competitor and destroy the incentive for individual superiority and thrift the bureau have also make exhaustive examination into the legal condition under which corporate business be carry on in the various states into all judicial decision on the subject and into the various system of corporate taxation in use i call special attention to the report of the chief of the bureau and i earnestly ask that the congress carefully consider the report and recommendation of the commissioner on this subject the business of insurance vitally affect the great mass of the people of the united states and be national and not local in its application it involve a multitude of transaction among the people of the different states and between american company and foreign government i urge that the congress carefully consider whether the power of the bureau of corporations can not constitutionally be extend to cover interstate transaction in insurance above all else we must strive to keep the highway of commerce open to all on equal term and to do this it be necessary to put a complete stop to all rebate whether the shipper or the railroad be to blame make no difference the rebate must be stop the abuse of the private car and private terminal track and side track system must be stop and the legislation of the fifty eighth congress which declare it to be unlawful for any person or corporation to offer gram give solicit accept or receive any rebate concession or discrimination in respect of the transportation of any property in interstate or foreign commerce whereby such property shall by any device whatever be transport at a less rate than that name in the tariff publish by the carrier must be enforce for some time after the enactment of the act to regulate commerce it remain a mooted question whether that act confer upon the interstate commerce commission the power after it have find a challenge rate to be unreasonable to declare what thereafter should prima facie be the reasonable maximum rate for the transportation in dispute the supreme court finally resolve that question in the negative so that as to the senate and house of representatives the people of this country continue to enjoy great prosperity undoubtedly there will be ebb and flow in such prosperity and this ebb and flow will be feel more or less by all member of the community both by the deserving and the undeserving against the wrath of the lord the wisdom of man can not avail in time of flood or drought human ingenuity can but partially repair the disaster a general failure of crop would hurt all of we again if the folly of man mar the general well being then those who be innocent of the folly will have to pay part of the penalty incur by those who be guilty of the folly a panic bring on by the speculative folly of part of the business community would hurt the whole business community but such stoppage of welfare though it might be severe would not be last in the long run the one vital factor in the permanent prosperity of the country be the high individual character of the average american worker the average american citizen no matter whether his work be mental or manual whether he be farmer or wage worker business man or professional man in our industrial and social system the interest of all man be so closely intertwine that in the immense majority of case a straight deal man who by his efficiency by his ingenuity and industry benefit himself must also benefit other normally the man of great productive capacity who become rich by guide the labor of many other man do so by enable they to produce more than they could produce without his guidance and both he and they share in the benefit which come also to the public at large the superficial fact that the sharing may be unequal must never blind we to the underlying fact that there be this sharing and that the benefit come in some degree to each man concern normally the wage worker the man of small mean and the average consumer as well as the average producer be all alike help by make condition such that the man of exceptional business ability receive an exceptional reward for his ability something can be do by legislation to help the general prosperity but no such help of a permanently beneficial character can be give to the less able and less fortunate save as the result of a policy which shall inure to the advantage of all industrious and efficient people who act decently and this be only another way of say that any benefit which come to the less able and less fortunate must of necessity come even more to the more able and more fortunate if therefore the less fortunate man be move by envy of his more fortunate brother to strike at the condition under which they have both though unequally prosper the result will assuredly be that while danger may come to the one strike at it will visit with an even heavy load the one who strike the blow take as a whole we must all go up or down together yet while not merely admit but insist upon this it be also true that where there be no governmental restraint or supervision some of the exceptional man use their energy not in way that be for the common good but in way which tell against this common good the fortune amass through corporate organization be now so large and vest such power in those that wield they as to make it a matter of necessity to give to the sovereign that be to the government which represent the people as a whole some effective power of supervision over their corporate use in order to insure a healthy social and industrial life every big corporation should be hold responsible by and be accountable to some sovereign strong enough to control its conduct i be in no sense hostile to corporation this be an age of combination and any effort to prevent all combination will be not only useless but in the end vicious because of the contempt for law which the failure to enforce law inevitably produce we should moreover recognize in cordial and ample fashion the immense good effect by corporate agency in a country such as ours and the wealth of intellect energy and fidelity devote to their service and therefore normally to the service of the public by their officer and director the corporation have come to stay just as the trade union have come to stay each can do and have do great good each should be favor so long as it do good but each should be sharply check where it act against law and justice so long as the finance of the nation be keep upon an honest basis no other question of internal economy with which the congress have the power to deal begin to approach in importance the matter of endeavor to secure proper industrial condition under which the individual and especially the great corporation do an interstate business be to act the maker of our national constitution provide especially that the regulation of interstate commerce should come within the sphere of the general government the argument in favor of their take this stand be even then overwhelming but they be far strong today in view of the enormous development of great business agency usually corporate in form experience have show conclusively that it be useless to try to get any adequate regulation and supervision of these great corporation by state action such regulation and supervision can only be effectively exercise by a sovereign whose jurisdiction be coextensive with the field of work of the corporation that be by the national government i believe that this regulation and supervision can be obtain by the enactment of law by the congress if this prove impossible it will certainly be necessary ultimately to confer in full form such power upon the national government by a proper amendment of the constitution it would obviously be unwise to endeavor to secure such an amendment until it be certain that the result can not be obtain under the constitution as it now be the law of the congress and of the several states hitherto as pass upon by the court have result more often in show that the states have no power in position of subject without a sovereign neither any state government nor the national government have effective control over they our steady aim should be by legislation cautiously and carefully undertake but resolutely persevere in to assert the sovereignty of the national government by affirmative action this be only in form an innovation in substance it be merely a restoration for from the early time such regulation of industrial activity have be recognize in the action of the lawmaking body and all that i propose be to meet the change condition in such manner as will prevent the commonwealth abdicate the power it have always possess not only in this country but also in england before and since this country become a separate nation it have be a misfortune that the national law part in their prohibition confound what should be allow and what should not be allow it be generally useless to try to prohibit all restraint on competition whether this restraint be reasonable or unreasonable and where it be not useless it be generally hurtful event have show that it be not possible adequately to secure the enforcement of any law of this kind by incessant appeal to the court the department of justice have for the last four year devote more attention to the enforcement of the anti trust legislation than to anything else much have be accomplish particularly marked have be the moral effect of the prosecution but it be increasingly evident that there will be a very insufficient beneficial result in the way of economic change the successful prosecution of one device to evade the law immediately develop another device to accomplish the same purpose what be need be not sweep prohibition of every arrangement good or bad which may tend to restrict competition but such adequate supervision and regulation as will prevent any restriction of competition from be to the detriment of the public as well as such supervision and regulation as will prevent other abuse in no way connect with restriction of competition of these abuse perhaps the chief although by no mean the only one be overcapitalization generally itself the result of dishonest promotion because of the myriad evil it bring in its train for such overcapitalization often mean an inflation that invite business panic it always conceal the true relation of the profit earn to the capital actually invest the government undertake any work which can with propriety be leave in private hand but neither do i believe in the government flinching from oversee any work when it become evident that abuse be sure to obtain therein unless there be governmental supervision it be not my province to indicate the exact term of the law which should be enact but i call the attention of the congress to certain exist condition with which it be desirable to deal in my judgment the most important provision which such law should contain be that confer upon some competent administrative body the power to decide upon the case be bring before it whether a give rate prescribe by a railroad be reasonable and just and if it be find to be unreasonable and unjust then after full investigation of the complaint to prescribe the limit of rate beyond which it shall not be lawful to go the maximum reasonable rate as it be commonly call this decision to go into effect within a reasonable time and to obtain from thence onward subject to review by the court it sometimes happen at present not that a rate be too high but that a favored shipper be give too low a rate in such case the commission would have the
