i call your attention to the fact that my proposal be not to give the commission power to initiate or originate rate generally but to regulate a rate already fix or originate by the road upon complaint and after investigation a heavy penalty should be exact from any corporation which fail to respect an order of the commission i regard this power to establish a maximum rate as be essential simple we can get justice and right deal only if we put as of paramount importance the principle of treat a man on his worth as a man rather than with reference to his social position his occupation or the class to which he belong there be selfish and brutal man in all rank of life if they be capitalist their selfishness and brutality may take the form of hard indifference to suffering greedy side in the mass be both wicked and foolish in the past the most direful among the influence which have bring about the downfall of republic have ever be the growth of the class spirit the growth of the spirit which tend to make a man subordinate the welfare of the public as a whole to the welfare of the particular class to which he belong the substitution of loyalty to a class for loyalty to the nation this inevitably bring about a tendency to treat each man not on his merit as an individual but on his position as belong to a certain class in the community if such a spirit grow up in this republic it will ultimately prove fatal to we as in the past it have prove fatal to every community in which it have become dominant unless we continue to keep a quick and lively sense of the great fundamental truth that our concern be with the individual worth of the individual man this government can not permanently hold the place which it have achieve among the nation the vital line of cleavage among our people do not correspond and indeed run at right angle to the line of cleavage which divide occupation from occupation which divide wage worker from capitalist farmer from banker man of small mean from man of large mean man who live in the town from man who live in the country for the vital line of cleavage be the line which divide the honest man who try to do well by his neighbor from the dishonest man who do ill by his neighbor in other word the standard we should establish be the standard of conduct not the standard of occupation of mean or of social position it be the man 's moral quality his attitude toward the great question which concern all humanity his cleanliness of life his power to do his duty toward himself and toward other which really count and if we substitute for the standard of personal judgment which treat each man accord to his merit another standard in accordance with which all man of one class be favor and all man of another class discriminate against we shall do irreparable damage to the body politic i believe that our people be too sane too self respect too fit for self government ever to adopt such an attitude this government be not and never shall be government by a plutocracy this government be not and never shall be government by a mob it shall continue to be in the future what it have be in the past a government base on the theory that each man rich or poor be to be treat simply and solely on his worth as a man that all his personal and property right be to be safeguard and that he be neither to wrong other nor to suffer wrong from other the noblest of all form of government be self government but it be also the most difficult we who possess this priceless boon and who desire to hand it on to our child and our child 's child should ever bear in mind the thought so finely express by burke man be qualified for civil liberty in exact proportion to their disposition to put moral chain upon their own appetite in proportion as they be disposed to listen to the counsel of the wise and good in preference to the flattery of knave society can not exist unless a control power upon will and appetite be place somewhere and the less of it there be within the more there must be without it be ordain in the eternal constitution of thing that man of intemperate mind can not be free their reduce to 25 per cent of the present rate under the dingley act that after july 1 1909 the tariff upon tobacco and sugar produce in the philippine islands be entirely remove and that free trade to the senate and house of representatives
 i inclose herewith the annual report of the isthmian canal commission the annual report of the panama railroad company and the secretary of war&#39;s letter transmit the same together with certain paper
 the work on the isthmus be be admirably do and great progress have be make especially during the last nine month the plant be be make ready and the organization perfect the first work to be do be the work of sanitation the necessary preliminary to the work of actual construction and this have be push forward with the utmost energy and mean in a short while i shall lay before you the recommendation of the commission and of the board of consult engineer as to the proper plan to be adopt for the canal itself together with my own recommendation thereon all the work so far have be do not only with the utmost expedition but in the most careful and thorough manner and what have be accomplish give we good reason to believe that the canal will be dig in a short time than have be anticipate and at an expenditure within the estimate amount all our citizen have a right to congratulate themselves upon the high standard of efficiency and integrity which have be hitherto maintain by the representative of the government in do this great work if this high standard of efficiency and integrity can be maintain in the future at the same level which it have now reach the construction of the panama canal will be one of the feat to which the people of this republic will look back with the high pride
 from time to time various publication have be make and from time to time in the future various similar publication doubtless will be make purport to give an account of jobbery or immorality or inefficiency or misery as obtain on the isthmus i have carefully examine into each of these accusation which seem worthy of attention in every instance the accusation have prove to be without foundation in any shape or form they spring from several source sometimes they take the shape of statement by irresponsible investigator of a sensational habit of mind incapable of observe or repeat with accuracy what they see and desirous of obtain notoriety by widespread slander more often they originate with or be give currency by individual with a personal grievance the sensation monger both those who stay at home and those who visit the isthmus may ground their accusation on false statement by some engineer who having apply for service on the commission and be refuse such service now endeavor to discredit his successful competitor or by some lessee or owner of real estate who have seek action or inaction by the commission to increase the value of his lot and be bitter because the commission can not be use for such purpose or on the tale of disappointed bidder for contract or of office holder who have prove incompetent or who have be suspect of corruption and dismiss or who have be overcome by panic and have flee from the isthmus every specific charge relate to jobbery to immorality or to inefficiency from whatever source it have come have be immediately investigate and in no single instance have the statement of these sensation monger and the interested complainant behind they prove true the only discredit inhering in these false accusation be to those who originate and give they currency and who to the extent of their ability thereby hamper and obstruct the completion of the great work in which both the honor and the interest of america be so deeply involved it matter not whether those guilty of these false accusation utter they in mere wanton recklessness and folly or in spirit of sinister malice to gratify some personal or political grudge
 any attempt to cut down the salary of the official of the isthmian commission or of their subordinate who be do important work would be ruinous from the standpoint of accomplish the work effectively to quote the word of one of the good observer on the isthmus demoralization of the service be certain if the reward for successful endeavor be a reduction of pay we be undertake in panama a gigantic task the large piece of engineering ever do the employment of the man engage thereon be only temporary and yet it will require the high order of ability if it be to be do economically honestly and efficiently to attempt to secure man to do this work on insufficient salary would amount to put a premium upon inefficiency and corruption man fit for the work will not undertake it unless they be well pay in the end the man who do undertake it will be leave to seek other employment with as their chief reward the reputation they achieve their work be infinitely more difficult than any private work both because of the peculiar condition of the tropical land in which it be lay and because it be impossible to free they from the peculiar limitation inseparably connect with government employment while it be unfortunately true that man engage in public work no matter how devoted and disintereste their service must expect to be make the object of misrepresentation and attack at well therefore the position be not attractive in proportion to their importance and among the man fit to do the task only those with a genuine sense of public spirit and eager to do the great work for the work&#39;s sake can be obtain and such man can not be keep if they be to be treat with niggardliness and parsimony in addition to the certainty that false accusation will continually be bring against they
 i repeat that the work on the isthmus have be do and be be do admirably the organization be good the mistake be extraordinarily few and these few have be of practically no consequence the zeal intelligence and efficient public service of the isthmian commission and its subordinate have be noteworthy i court the full most exhaustive and most search investigation of any act of theirs and if any one of they be ever show to have do wrong his punishment shall be exemplary but i ask that they be decently pay and that their hand be uphold as long as they act decently on any other condition we shall not be able to get man of the right type to do the work and this mean that on any other condition we shall insure if not failure at least delay scandal and inefficiency in the task of dig the giant canal

to the senate and house of representatives
 i transmit herewith the report of mr. james bronson reynolds and commissioner charles p. neill the special committee whom i appoint to investigate into the condition in the stock yard of chicago and report thereon to i this report be of a preliminary nature i submit it to you now because it show the urgent need of immediate action by the congress in the direction of provide a drastic and thoroughgoing inspection by the federal government of all stockyard and pack house and of their product so far as the latter enter into interstate or foreign commerce the condition show by even this short inspection to exist in the chicago stock yard be revolt it be imperatively necessary in the interest of health and of decency that they should be radically change under the exist law it be wholly impossible to secure satisfactory result
 when my attention be first direct to this matter an investigation be make under the bureau of animal industry of the department of agriculture when the preliminary statement of this investigation be bring to my attention they show such defect in the law and such wholly unexpected condition that i deem it well to have a further immediate investigation by man not connect with the bureau and accordingly appoint messrs. reynolds and neill it be impossible under exist law that satisfactory work should be do by the bureau of animal industry i be now however examine the way in which the work actually be do
 before i have receive the report of messrs. reynolds and neill i have direct that label place upon any package of meat food product should state only that the carcass of the animal from which the meat be take have be inspect at the time of slaughter if inspection of meat food product at all stage of preparation be not secure by the passage of the legislation recommend i shall feel compel to order that inspection label and certificate on can product shall not be use hereafter
 the report show that the stock yard and pack house be not keep even reasonably clean and that the method of handle and prepare food product be uncleanly and dangerous to health under exist law the national government have no power to enforce inspection of the many form of prepare meat food product that be daily go from the packing house into interstate commerce owe to an inadequate appropriation the department of agriculture be not even able to place inspector in all establishment desire they the present law prohibit the shipment of uninspected meat to foreign country but there be no provision forbid the shipment of uninspected meat in interstate commerce and thus the avenue of interstate commerce be leave open to traffic in diseased or spoiled meat
 if as have be allege on seemingly good authority further evil exist such as the improper use of chemical and dye the government lack power to remedy they
 a law be need which will enable the inspector of the general government to inspect and supervise from the hoof to the can the preparation of the meat food product the evil seem to be much less in the sale of dress carcase than in the sale of canned and other prepared product and very much less as regard product send abroad than as regard those use at home
 in my judgment the expense of the inspection should be pay by a fee levy on each animal slaughter if this be not do the whole purpose of the law can at any time be defeat through an insufficient appropriation and whenever there be no particular public interest in the subject it would be not only easy but natural thus to make the appropriation insufficient if it be not for this consideration i should favor the government pay for the inspection
 the alarm express in certain quarter concern this feature should be allay by a realization of the fact that in no case under such a law will the cost of inspection exceed 8 cent per head
 i call special attention to the fact that this report be preliminary and that the investigation be still unfinished it be not yet possible to report on the allege abuse in the use of deleterious chemical compound in connection with canning and preserve meat product nor on the alleged doctoring in this fashion of tainted meat and of product return to the packer as having grow unsalable or unusable from age or from other reason grave allegation be make in reference to abuse of this nature
 let i repeat that under the present law there be practically no method of stop these abuse if they should be discover to exist legislation be need in order to prevent the possibility of all abuse in the future if no legislation be pass then the excellent result accomplish by the work of this special committee will endure only so long as the memory of the committee&#39; work be fresh and a recrudescence of the abuse be absolutely certain
 i urge the immediate enactment into law of provision which will enable the department of agriculture adequately to inspect the meat and meat food product enter into interstate commerce and to supervise the method of prepare the same and to prescribe the sanitary condition under which the work shall be perform i therefore commend to your favorable consideration and urge the enactment of substantially the provision know as senate amendment no 29 to the act make appropriation for the department of agriculture for the fiscal year end june 30 1907 as pass by the senate this amendment be commonly know as the beveridge amendment

defendant 's demurrer while in another jurisdiction an indictment for conspiracy to obtain rebate have be sustain by the court conviction obtain under it and two defendant sentence to imprisonment the two case refer to may not be in real conflict with each other but it be unfortunate that there should even be an apparent conflict at present there be no way by which the government can cause such a conflict when it occur to be solve by an appeal to a high court and the wheel of justice be block without any real decision of the question i can not too strongly urge the passage of the bill in question a failure to pass it will result in seriously hamper the government in its effort to obtain justice especially against wealthy individual or corporation who do wrong and may also prevent the government from obtain justice for wage worker who be not themselves able effectively to contest a case where the judgment of an inferior court have be against they i have specifically in view a recent decision by a district judge leave railway employee without remedy for violation of a certain so call labor statute it seem an absurdity to permit a single district judge against what may be the judgment of the immense majority of his colleague on the bench to declare a law solemnly enact by the congress to be unconstitutional and then to deny to the government the right to have the supreme court definitely decide the question it be well to recollect that the real efficiency of the law often depend not upon the passage of act as to which there be great public excitement but upon the passage of act of this nature as to which there be not much public excitement because there be little public understanding of their importance while the interested party be keenly alive to the desirability of defeat they the importance of enact into law the particular bill in question be far increase by the fact that the government have now definitely begin a policy of resort to the criminal law in those trust and interstate commerce case where such a course offer a reasonable chance of success at first as be proper every effort be make to enforce these law by civil proceeding but it have become increasingly evident that the action of the government in finally decide in certain case to undertake criminal proceeding be justifiable and tho there have be some conspicuous failure in these case we have have many success which have undoubtedly have a deterrent effect upon evil doer whether the penalty inflict be in the shape of fine or imprisonment and penalty of both kind have already be inflict by the court of course where the judge can see his way to inflict the penalty of imprisonment the deterrent effect of the punishment on other offender be increase but sufficiently heavy fine accomplish much judge holt of the new york district court in a recent decision admirably state the need for treat with just severity offender of this kind his opinion run in part as follows:'the government 's evidence to establish the defendant 's guilt be clear conclusive and undisputed the case be a flagrant one the transaction which take place under this illegal contract be very large the amount of rebate return be considerable and the amount of the rebate itself be large amount to more than one fifth of the entire tariff charge for the transportation of merchandise from this city to detroit it be not too much to say in my opinion that if this business be carry on for a considerable time on that basis that be if this discrimination in favor of this particular shipper be make with an 18 instead of a 23 cent rate and the tariff rate be maintain as against their competitor the result might be and not improbably would be that their competitor would be drive out of business this crime be one which in its nature be deliberate and premeditate i think over a fortnight elapse between the date of palmer 's letter request the reduce rate and the answer of the railroad company decide to grant it and then for month afterwards this business be carry on and these claim for rebate submit month after month and check in payment of they draw month after month such a violation of the law in my opinion in its essential nature be a very much more heinous act than the ordinary common vulgar crime which come before criminal court constantly for punishment and which arise from sudden passion or temptation this crime in this case be commit by man of education and of large business experience whose stand in the community be such that they might have be expect to set an example of obedience to law upon the maintenance of which alone in this country the security of their property depend it be commit on behalf of a great railroad corporation which like other railroad corporation have receive gratuitously from the state large and valuable privilege for the public 's convenience and its own which perform quasi public function and which be charge with the high obligation in the transaction of its business to treat the citizen of this country alike and not to carry on its business with unjust discrimination between different citizen or different class of citizen this crime in its nature be one usually do with secrecy and proof of which it be very difficult to obtain the interstate commerce act be past in 1887 nearly twenty year ago ever since that time complaint of the granting of rebate by railroad have be common urgent and insistent and altho the congress have repeatedly past legislation endeavor to put a stop to this evil the difficulty of obtain proof upon which to bring prosecution in these case be so great that this be the first case that have ever be bring in this court and as i be form this case and one recently bring in i be force to the conclusion in a case in which the proof be so clear and the fact be so flagrant it be the duty of the court to fix a penalty which shall in some degree be commensurate with the the case be set forth with singular clearness and good temper by judge w. h. taft when a united states circuit judge eleven year ago in 1895:"the opportunity freely and publicly to criticize judicial action be of vastly more importance to the body politic than the immunity of court and judge from unjust aspersion and attack nothing tend more to render judge careful in their decision and anxiously solicitous to do exact justice than the consciousness that every act of theirs be to be subject to the intelligent scrutiny and candid criticism of their fellow man such criticism be beneficial in proportion as it be fair dispassionate discriminating and base on a knowledge of sound legal principle the comment make by learn text writer and by the acute editor of the various law review upon judicial decision be therefore highly useful such critic constitute more or less impartial tribunal of professional opinion before which each judgment be make to stand or fall on its merit and thus exert a strong influence to secure uniformity of decision but non professional criticism also be by no mean without its use even if accompany as it often be by a direct attack upon the judicial fairness and motive of the occupant of the bench for if the law be but the essence of common sense the protest of many average man may evidence a defect in a judicial conclusion tho base on the nice legal reasoning and profoundest learning the two important element of moral character in a judge be an earnest desire to reach a just conclusion and courage to enforce it in so far as fear of public comment do not affect the courage of a judge but only spur he on to search his conscience and to reach the result which approve itself to his inmost heart such comment serve a useful purpose there be few man whether they be judge for life or for a short term who do not prefer to earn and hold the respect of all and who can not be reach and make to pause and deliberate by hostile public criticism in the case of judge have a life tenure indeed their very independence make the right freely to comment on their decision of great importance because it be the only practical and available instrument for trade the destruction of the pribilof islands fur seal by pelagic sealing still continue the herd which accord to the survey make in 1874 by direction of the congress number 4,700,000 and which accord to the survey of both american and canadian commissioner in 1891 amount to 1,000,000 have now be reduce to about 180,000 this result have be bring about by canadian and some other sealing vessel kill the female seal while in the water during their annual pilgrimage to and from the south or in search of food as a rule the female seal when kill be pregnant and also have an unweaned pup on land so that for each skin take by pelagic sealing as a rule three life be destroy the mother the unborn offspring and the nursing pup which be leave to starve to death no damage whatever be do to the herd by the carefully regulate kill on land the custom of pelagic sealing be solely responsible for all of the present evil and be alike indefensible from the economic standpoint and from the standpoint of humanity in 1896 over 16,000 young seal be find dead from starvation on the pribilof islands in 1897 it be estimate that since pelagic sealing begin upward of 400,000 adult female seal have be kill at sea and over 300,000 young seal have die of starvation as the result the revolt barbarity of such a practise as well as the wasteful destruction which it involve need no demonstration and be its own condemnation the bering sea tribunal which sit in paris in 1893 and which decide against the claim of the united states to exclusive jurisdiction in the water of bering sea and to a property right in the fur seal when outside of the three mile limit determine also upon certain regulation which the tribunal consider sufficient for the proper protection and preservation of the fur seal in or habitually resort to the bering sea the tribunal by its regulation establish a close season from the 1st of may to the 31st of july and exclude all killing in the water within 60 mile around the pribilof islands they also provide that the regulation which they have determine upon with a view to the protection and preservation of the seal should be submit every five year to new examination so as to enable both interested government to consider whether in the light of past experience there be occasion for any modification thereof the regulation have prove plainly inadequate to accomplish the object of protection and preservation of the fur seal and for a long time this government have be try in vain to secure from great britain such revision and modification of the regulation as be contemplate and provide for by the award of the tribunal of paris the process of destruction have be accelerate during recent year by the appearance of a number of japanese vessel engage in pelagic sealing as these vessel have not be bind even by the inadequate limitation prescribe by the tribunal of paris they have pay no attention either to the close season or to the sixty before they be beat off by the very meager and insufficiently armed guard they succeed in kill several hundred seal and carry off the skin of most of they nearly all the seal kill be female and the nothing could be more instructive than a rational study of the war of 1812 as it be tell for instance by captain mahan there be only one way in which that war could have be avoid if during the precede annapolis already turn out excellent officer we do not need to have these school make more scholastic on the contrary we should never lose sight of the fact that the aim of each school be to turn out a man who shall be above everything else a fight man in the army in particular it be not necessary that either the cavalry or infantry officer should have special mathematical ability probably in both school the good part of the education be the high standard of character and of professional morale which it confer but in both service there be urgent need for the establishment of a principle of selection which will eliminate man after a certain age if they can not be promote from the subordinate rank and which will bring into the high rank few man and these at an early age this principle of selection will be object to by good man of mediocre capacity who be fit to do well while young in the low position but who be not fit to do well when at an advanced age they come into position of command and of great responsibility but the desire of these man to be promote to position which they be not competent to fill should not weigh against the interest of the navy and the country at present our man especially in the navy be keep far too long in the junior grade and then at much too advanced an age be put quickly thru the senior grade often not attain to these senior grade until they be too old to be of real use in they and if they be of real use be put thru they so quickly that little benefit to the navy come from their having be in they at all the navy have one great advantage over the army in the fact that the officer of high rank be actually train in the continual performance of their duty that be in the management of the battle ship and armored cruiser gather into fleet this be not true of the army officer who rarely have correspond chance to exercise command over troop under service condition the conduct of the spanish war show the lamentable loss of life the useless extravagance and the inefficiency certain to result if during peace the high official of the war and navy departments be praise and reward only if they save money at no matter what cost to the efficiency of the service and if the high officer be give no chance whatever to exercise and practise command for year prior to the spanish war the secretaries of war be praise chiefly if they practise economy which economy especially in connection with the quartermaster commissary and medical department be directly responsible for most of the mismanagement that occur in the war itself and parenthetically be it observe that the very people who clamor for the misdirect economy in the first place be foremost to denounce the mismanagement loss and suffering which be primarily due to this same misdirect economy and to the lack of preparation it involve there should soon be an increase in the number of man for our coast defense these man should be of the right type and properly train and there should therefore be an increase of pay for certain skilled grade especially in the coast artillery money should be appropriate to permit troop to be mass in body and exercise in maneuver particularly in marching such exercise during the summer just past have be of incalculable benefit to the army and should under no circumstance be discontinue if on these practise marche and in these maneuver elderly officer prove unable to bear the strain they should be retire at once for the fact be conclusive as to their unfitness for war that be for the only purpose because of which they should be allow to stay in the service it be a real misfortune to have score of small company or regimental post scatter thruout the country the army should be gather in a few brigade or division post and the general should be practise in handle the man in masse neglect to provide for all of this mean to incur the risk of future disaster and disgrace the readiness and efficiency of both the army and navy in deal with the recent sudden crisis in cuba illustrate afresh their value to the nation this readiness and efficiency would have be very much less have it not be for the existence of the general staff in the army and the general board in the navy both be essential to the proper development and use of our military force afloat and ashore the troop that be send to cuba be handle flawlessly it be the swift mobilization and dispatch of troop over sea ever accomplish by our government the expedition land completely equipped and ready for immediate service several of its organization hardly remain in havana over night before split up into detachment and go to their several post it be a fine demonstration of the value and efficiency of the general staff similarly it be owe in large part to the general board that the navy be able at the outset to meet the cuban crisis with such instant efficiency ship after ship appear on the short notice at any threatened point while the marine corps in particular performed indispensable service the army and navy war colleges be of incalculable value to the two service and they cooperate with constantly increase efficiency and importance the congress have most wisely provide for a national board for the promotion of rifle practise excellent result have already come from this law but it do not go far enough our regular army be so small that in any great war we should have to trust mainly to volunteer and in such event these volunteer should already know how to shoot for if a soldier have the fighting edge and ability to take care of himself in the open his efficiency on the line of battle be almost directly proportionate to excellence in marksmanship we should establish shoot gallery in all the large public and military school should maintain national target range in different part of the country and should in every way encourage the formation of rifle club thruout all part of the land the little republic of switzerland offer we an excellent example in all matter connect with build up an efficient citizen soldiery
to the senate and house of representatives
 on november 21st i visit the island of porto rico land at ponce cross by the old spanish road by cayey to san juan and return next morning over the new american road from arecibo to ponce the scenery be wonderfully beautiful especially among the mountain of the interior which constitute a veritable tropic switzerland i could not embark at san juan because the harbor have not be dredge out and can not receive an american battleship i do not think this fact creditable to we as a nation and i earnestly hope that immediate provision will be make for dredge san juan harbor
 i doubt whether our people as a whole realize the beauty and fertility of porto rico and the progress that have be make under its admirable government we have just cause for pride in the character of our representative who have administer the tropic island which come under our flag as a result of the war with spain and of no one of they be this more true than of porto rico it would be impossible to wish a more faithful a more efficient and a more disintereste public service than that now be render in the island of porto rico by those in control of the insular government
 i stop at a dozen town all tell and one of the notable feature in every town be the gathering of the school child the work that have be do in porto rico for education have be noteworthy the main emphasis as be eminently wise and proper have be put upon primary education but in addition to this there be a normal school an agricultural school three industrial and three high school every effort be be make to secure not only the benefit of elementary education to all the porto ricans of the next generation but also as far as mean will permit to train they so that the industrial agricultural and commercial opportunity of the island can be utilize to the good possible advantage it be evident at a glance that the teacher both americans and native porto ricans be devoted to their work take the great pride in it and be endeavor to train their pupil not only in mind but in what count for far more than mind in citizenship that is in character
 i be very much strike by the excellent character both of the insular police and of the porto rican regiment they be both of they body that reflect credit upon the american administration of the island the insular police be under the local porto rican government the porto rican regiment of troop must be appropriate for by the congress i earnestly hope that this body will be keep permanent there should certainly be troop in the island and it be wise that these troop should be themselves native porto ricans it would be from every standpoint a mistake not to perpetuate this regiment
 in traverse the island even the most cursory survey leave the beholder strike with the evident rapid growth in the culture both of the sugar cane and tobacco the fruit industry be also grow last year be the most prosperous year that the island have ever know before or since the american occupation the total of export and import of the island be forty five million of dollar as against eighteen million in 1901 this be the large in the island&#39; history prior to the american occupation the great trade for any one year be that of 1896 when it reach nearly $ 23,000,000 last year therefore there be double the trade that there be in the most prosperous year under the spanish regime there be 210,273 ton of sugar export last year of the value of $ 14,186,319 $ 3,555,163 of tobacco and 28,290,322 pound of coffee of the value of $ 3,181,102 unfortunately what use to be porto rico&#39;s prime cup coffee have not share this prosperity it have never recover from the disaster of the hurricane and moreover the benefit of throw open our market to it have not compensate for the loss inflict by the closing of the market to it abroad i call your attention to the accompany memorial on this subject of the board of trade of san juan and i earnestly hope that some measure will be take for the benefit of the excellent and high grade porto rican coffee
 in addition to delegation from the board of trade and chamber of commerce of san juan i also receive delegation from the porto rican federation of labor and from the coffee growers&#39 association
 there be a matter to which i wish to call your special attention and that be the desirability of confer full american citizenship upon the people of porto rico i most earnestly hope that this will be do i can not see how any harm can possibly result from it and it seem to i a matter of right and justice to the people of porto rico they be loyal they be glad to be under our flag they be make rapid progress along the path of orderly liberty surely we should show our appreciation of they our pride in what they have do and our pleasure in extend recognition for what have thus be do by grant they full american citizenship
 under the wise administration of the present governor and council marked progress have be make in the difficult matter of grant to the people of the island the large measure of self government that can with safety be give at the present time it would have be a very serious mistake to have go any fast than we have already go in this direction the porto ricans have complete and absolute autonomy in all their municipal government the only power over they possess by the insular government be that of remove corrupt or incompetent municipal official this power have never be exercise save on the clear proof of corruption or of incompetence such as to jeopardize the interest of the people of the island and under such circumstance it have be fearlessly use to the immense benefit of the people it be not a power with which it would be safe for the sake of the island itself to dispense at present the low house be absolutely elective while the upper house be appointive this scheme be work well no injustice of any kind result from it and great benefit to the island and it should certainly not be change at this time the machinery of the election be administer entirely by the porto rican people themselves the governor and council keep only such supervision as be necessary in order to insure an orderly election any protest as to electoral fraud be settle in the court
 here again it would not be safe to make any change in the present system the election this year be absolutely orderly unaccompanie by any disturbance and no protest have be make against the management of the election although three contest be threaten where the majority be very small and error be claim the contest of course to be settle in the court in short the governor and council be co operate with all of the most enlightened and most patriotic of the people of porto rico in educate the citizen of the island in the principle of orderly liberty they be provide a government base upon each citizen&#39;s self respect and the mutual respect of all citizen that be base upon a rigid observance of the principle of justice and honesty it have not be easy to instill into the mind of the people unaccustomed to the exercise of freedom the two basic principle of our american system the principle that the majority must rule and the principle that the minority have right which must not be disregard or trample upon yet real progress have be make in have these principle accept as elementary as the foundation of successful self government
 i transmit herewith the report of the governor of porto rico send to the president through the secretary of state
 all the insular government should be place in one bureau either in the department of war or the department of state it be a mistake not so to arrange our handling of these island at washington as to be able to take advantage of the experience gain in one when deal with the problem that from time to time arise in another
 in conclusion let i express my admiration for the work do by the congress when it enact the law under which the island be now be administer after see the island personally and after five years&#39 experience in connection with its administration it be but fair to those who devise this law to say that it would be well nigh impossible to have devise any other which in the actual working would have accomplish well result

to the senate and house of representatives
 in the month of november i visit the isthmus of panama go over the canal zone with considerable care and also visit the city of panama and colon which be not in the zone or under the united states flag but as to which the united states government through its agent exercise control for certain sanitary purpose
 the u. s. s. louisiana on which i be anchor off colon about half past two on wednesday afternoon november 14 i come aboard she after my stay on shore at about half past 9 on saturday evening november 17 on wednesday afternoon and evening i receive the president of panama and his suite and see member of the canal commission and various other gentleman perfect the arrangement for my visit so that every hour that i be ashore could be employ to advantage i be three day ashore not a sufficient length of time to allow of an exhaustive investigation of the minutia of the work of any single department still less to pass judgment on the engineering problem but enough to enable i to get a clear idea of the salient feature of the great work and of the progress that have be make as regard the sanitation of the zone colon and panama the caring for and housing of the employee and the actual digging of the canal the zone be a narrow strip of land and it can be inspect much as one can inspect 50 or 60 mile of a great railroad at the point where it rim through mountain or overcome other national obstacle
 i choose the month of november for my visit partly because it be the rainy month of the year the month in which the work go forward at the great disadvantage and one of the two month which the medical department of the french canal company find most unhealthy
 immediately after anchor on the afternoon of wednesday there be a violent storm of wind and rain from that time we do not again see the sun until saturday morning the rain continue almost steadily but vary from a fine drizzle to a torrential downpour during that time in fifteen minute at cristobal 1.05 inch of rain fall from 1 to 3 a. m. november 16 3.2 inch fall for the twenty four hour end noon november 16 4.68 inch fall and for the six day end noon november 16 10.24 inch fall the changes rise in flood to a great height than it have attain during the last fifteen year tear out the track in one place it would have be impossible to see the work go on under more unfavorable weather condition on saturday november 17 the sun shine now and then for a few minute although the day be generally overcast and there be heavy shower at interval
 on thursday morning we land at about half past seven and go slowly over the line of the panama railway end with an expedition in a tug at the pacific entrance of the canal out to the island where the dredging for the canal will cease we take our dinner at one of the eat house furnish by the commission for the use of the government employee no warning of our come be give i inspect the ancon hospital go through various ward both for white patient and for colored patient i inspect portion of the constabulary zone police examine the man individually i also examine certain of the school and see the school child both white and color speak with certain of the teacher in the afternoon of this day i be formally receive in panama by president amador who together with the government and all the people of panama treat i with the most considerate courtesy for which i hereby extend my most earnest thank i be drive through panama and in a public square be formally receive and welcome by the president and other member of the government and in the evening i attend a dinner give by the president and a reception which be also a government function i also drive through the street of panama for the purpose of observe what have be do we sleep at the hotel tivoli at ancon which be on a hill directly outside of the city of panama but in the zone
 on friday morning we leave the hotel at 7 o&#39;clock and spend the entire day go through the culebra cut the spot in which most work will have to be do in any event we watch the different steam shovel work we see the drilling and blasting we see many of the dirt train of the two different type use both carry the earth away from the steam shovel and deposit it on the dump some of the dump be run out in the jungle merely to get rid of the earth while in other case they be be use for double track the railway and in prepare to build the great dams i visit many of the different village inspect thoroughly many different building the local receiving hospital the house in which the unmarried white workman live those in which the unmarried colored workman live also the quarter of the white marry employee and of the married colored employee as well as the commissary store the bath house the water closet the cook shed for the colored laborer and the government canteen or hotel at which most of the white employee take their meal i go through the machine shop during the day i talk with score of different man superintendent and head of department division and bureau steam shovel man machinist conductor engineer clerk wife of the american employee health officer colored laborer colored attendant and manager of the commissary store where food be sell to the colored laborer wife of the colored employee who be marry in the evening i have an interview with the british consul mr. mallet a gentleman who for many year have well and honorably represent the british government on the isthmus of panama and who have a peculiar relation to our work because the bulk of the colored laborer come from the british west indies i also see the french consul mr. gey a gentleman of equally long service and honorable record i see the lieutenant the chief executive and administrative officer under the engineering and sanitary department i also see and have long talk with two deputation one of machinist and one represent the railway man of the dirt train listen to what they have to say as to the rate of pay and various other matter and go over as much in detail as possible all the different question they bring up as to some matter i be able to meet their wish as to other i feel that what they request could not be do consistently with my duty to the united states government as a whole as to yet other i reserve judgment
 on saturday morning we start at 8 o&#39;clock from the hotel we go through the culebra cut stop off to see the marine and also to investigate certain town one of white employee as to which in certain respect complaint have be make to i and another town where i want to see certain house of the colored employee we go over the site of the propose gatun dam have on the first day inspect the site of the propose la boca and sosa dam we go out on a little toy railway to the reservoir which have be build to supply the people of colon with water for their house there we take lunch at the engineers&#39 mess we then go through the store and shop of cristobal inspect carefully the house of both the white and colored employee married and unmarried together with the other building we then go to colon and see the fire department at work in four minute from the signal the engine have come down to front street and twenty one 2 1/2 inch hose pipe be raise stream of water about 75 foot high we ride about colon through the various street pave unpaved and in process of pave look at the ditch sewer curb and the light i then go over the colon hospital in order to compare it with the temporary town or field receive hospital which i have already see and inspect i also inspect some of the dwelling of the employee in the evening i attend a reception give by the american employee on the isthmus which take place on one of the dock in colon and from there go aboard the louisiana
 each day from twelve to eighteen hour be spend in go over and inspect all there be to be see and in examine various employee throughout my trip i be accompany by the surgeon general of the navy dr. rixey by the chairman of the isthmian canal commission mr. shonts by chief engineer stevens by dr. gorgas the chief sanitary officer of the commission by mr. bishop the secretary of the commission by mr. ripley the principal assistant engineer by mr. jackson smith who have have practical charge of collect and handle the labor force by mr. bierd general manager of the railway and by mr. rogers the general counsel of the commission and many other official join we from time to time
 at the outset i wish to pay a tribute to the amount of work do by the french canal company under very difficult circumstance many of the building they put up be excellent and be still in use though naturally the house be now get out of repair and be be use as dwelling only until other house can be build and much of the work they do in the culebra cut and some of the work they do in dig have be of direct and real benefit this country have never make a well investment than the $ 40,000,000 which it pay to the french company for work and betterment include especially the panama railroad
 an inspection on the ground at the height of the rainy season serve to convince i of the wisdom of congress in refuse to adopt either a high level or a sea level canal there seem to be a universal agreement among all people competent to judge that the panama route the one actually choose be much superior to both the nicaragua and darien route
 the wisdom of the canal management have be show in nothing more clearly than in the way in which the foundation of the work have be lay to have yield to the natural impatience of ill inform outsider and begin all kind of experiment in work prior to a thorough sanitation of the isthmus and to a fairly satisfactory work out of the problem of get and keep a sufficient labor supply would have be disastrous the various preliminary measure have to be take first and these could not be take so as to allow we to begin the real work of construction prior to january 1 of the present year it then become necessary to have the type of the canal decide and the only delay have be the necessary delay until the 29th day of june the date when the congress definitely and wisely settle that we should have an 85 foot level canal immediately after that the work begin in hard earnest and have be continue with increase vigor ever since and it will continue so to progress in the future when the contract be let the condition will be such as to insure a constantly increase amount of performance
 the first great problem to be solve upon the solution of which the success of the rest of the work depend be the problem of sanitation this be from the outset under the direction of dr. w. c. gorgas who be to be make a full member of the commission it must be remember that his work be not mere sanitation as the term be understand in our ordinary municipal work throughout the zone and in the two city of panama and colon in addition to the sanitation work proper he have have to do all the work that the marine hospital service do as regard the nation that the health department officer do in the various state and city and that colonel waring do in new york when he clean its street the result have be astounding the isthmus have be a by word for deadly unhealthfulness now after two year of our occupation the condition as regard sickness and the death rate compare favorably with reasonably healthy locality in the united states especial care have be devote to minimize the risk due to the presence of those specie of mosquito which have be find to propagate malarial and yellow fever in all the settlement the little temporary town or city compose of the white and black employee which grow up here and there in the tropic jungle as the need of the work dictate the utmost care be exercise to keep the condition healthy everywhere be to be see the drainage ditch which in remove the water have remove the breed place of the mosquito while the whole jungle be cut away for a considerable space around the habitation thus destroy the place in which the mosquito take shelter these drainage ditch and clearing be in evidence in every settlement and together with the invariable presence of mosquito screen around the piazzas and of mosquito door to the house not to speak of the careful fumigation that have go on in all infected house doubtless explain the extraordinary absence of mosquito as a matter of fact but a single mosquito and this not of the dangerous specie be see by any member of our party during my three day on the isthmus equal care be take by the inspector of the health department to secure cleanliness in the house and proper hygienic condition of every kind i inspect between twenty and thirty water closet both those use by the white employee and those use by the colored laborer in almost every case i find the condition perfect in but one case do i find they really bad in this case affect a settlement of unmarried white employee i find they very bad indeed but the building be all inherit from the french company and be be use temporarily while other building be in the course of construction and right near the defective water closet a new and excellent closet with a good sewer pipe be in process of construction and nearly finish nevertheless this do not excuse the fact that the bad condition have be allow to prevail temporary accommodation even if only such as soldier use when camp in the field should have be provide order to this effect be issue i append the report of dr. gorgas on the incident i be strike however by the fact that in this instance as in almost every other where a complaint be make which prove to have any justification whatever it appear that step have already be take to remedy the evil complain of and that the trouble be mainly due to the extreme difficulty and often impossibility of provide in every place for the constant increase in the number of employee generally the provision be make in advance but it be not possible that this should always be the case when it be not there ensue a period of time during which the condition be unsatisfactory until a remedy can be provide but i never find a case where the remedy be not be provide as speedily as possible
 i inspect the large hospital at ancon and colon which be excellent example of what tropical hospital should be i also inspect the receive hospital in various settlement i go through a number of the ward in which the colored man be treat a number of those in which the white man be treat americans and spaniards both white man and black man be treat exactly alike and their treatment be as good as that which could be obtain in our first class hospital at home all the patient that i see with one or two exception be laborer or other employee on the canal work and railway most of they be color man of the ordinary laborer stamp not only be the man carefully care for whenever they apply for care but so far as practicable a watch be keep to see that if they need it they be send to the hospital whether they desire to go or not from no responsible source do any complaint come to i as to the management of the hospital service although occasionally a very ignorant west india negro when he be first bring into the hospital become frightened by the ordinary hospital routine
 just at present the health showing on the isthmus be remarkably good so much well than in most section of the united states that i do not believe that it can possibly continue at quite its present average thus early in the present year a band of several hundred spaniards be bring to the isthmus as laborer and addition to their number have be make from time to time yet since their arrival in february last but one of those spaniards thus bring over to work on the canal have die of disease and he of typhoid fever two other be kill one in a railroad accident and one by a dynamite explosion there have be for the last six month a well nigh steady decline in the death rate for the population of the zone this be largely due to the decrease in death from pneumonia which have be the most fatal disease on the isthmus in october there be ninety nine death of every kind among the employee of the isthmus there be then on the roll 5,500 white seven eighth of they be americans of these white but two die of disease and as it happen neither man be an american of the 6,000 white americans include some 1,200 woman and child not a single death have occur in the past three month whereas in an average city in the united states the number of death for a similar number of people in that time would have be about thirty from disease this very remarkable showing can not of course permanently obtain but it certainly go to prove that if good care be take the isthmus be not a particularly unhealthy place in october of the 19,000 negro on the roll 86 die from disease pneumonia be the most destructive disease and malarial fever come second the difficulty of exercise a thorough supervision over the colored laborer be of course great than be the case among the white and they be also less competent to take care of themselves which account for the fact that their death rate be so much high than that of the white in spite of the fact that they have be use to similar climatic condition even among the colored employee it will be see that the death rate be not high
 in panama and colon the death rate have also be greatly reduce this be directly due to the vigorous work of the special brigade of employee who have be inspect house where the stegomyia mosquito be to be find and destroy its larvae and breed place and do similar work in exterminate the malarial mosquito in short in perform all kind of hygienic labor a little over a year ago all kind of mosquito include the two fatal specie be numerous about the culebra cut in this cut during last october every room of every house be carefully examine and only two mosquito neither of they of the two fatal specie be find unfaltere energy in inspection and in disinfect and in the work of drain and of clearing brush be responsible for the change i append dr. gorgas&#39;s report on the health condition also a letter from surgeon general rixey to dr. gorgas the surgeon general report to i that the hygienic condition on the isthmus be about as good as for instance those in the norfolk navy yard
 corozal some four mile from la boca be formerly one of the most unsanitary place on the isthmus probably the most unsanitary there be a marsh with a pond in the middle dr. gorgas have both the marsh and pond drain and the brush clear off so that now when i go over the ground it appear like a smooth meadow intersect by drainage ditch the breeding place and shelter spot of the dangerous mosquito have be completely destroy the result be that corozal for the last six month like la boca which formerly also have a very unsanitary record show one of the good sick rate in the zone have less than 1 per cent a week admit to the hospital at corozal there be a big hotel fill with employee of the isthmian canal commission some of they with their wife and family yet this healthy and attractive spot be stigmatize as a hog wallow by one of the least scrupulous and most foolish of the professional scandal monger who from time to time have write about the commission&#39;s work
 the sanitation work in the city of panama and colon have be just as important as in the zone itself and in many respect much more difficult because it be necessary to deal with the already exist population which naturally have scant sympathy with revolutionary change the value of which they be for a long time not able to perceive in colon the population consist largely of colored laborer who having come over from the west indies to work on the canal abandon the work and either take to the brush or lie idle in colon itself thus people colon with the least desirable among the import laborer for the good and steady man of course continue at the work yet astonishing progress have be make in both city in panama 90 per cent of the street that be to be pave at all be already pave with an excellent brick pavement lay in heavy concrete a few of the street be still in process of pave the sewer and water service in the city be of the most modern hygienic type some of the service having just be complete
 in colon the condition be peculiar and it be as regard colon that most of the very bitter complaint have be make colon be build on a low coral island cover at more or less shallow depth with vegetable accumulation or mold which afford sustenance and strength to many variety of low lie tropical plant one half of the surface of the island be cover with water at high tide the average height of the land be 1 1/2 foot above low tide the slight undulation furnish shallow natural reservoir or fresh water breeding place for every variety of mosquito and the ground tend to be low in the middle when the town be originally build no attempt be make to fill the low ground either in the street or on the building site so that the entire surface be practically a quagmire when the quagmire become impassable certain of the street be crudely improve by fill especially bad mud hole with soft rock or other material in september 1905 a systematic effort be begin to formulate a general plan for the proper sanitation of the city in february last temporary relief measure be take while in july the prosecution of the work be begin in good earnest the result be already visible in the sewering drain gutter and pave of the street some four month will be require before the work of sewerage and street improvement will be complete but the progress already make be very marked ditch have be dig through the town connect the salt water on both side and into these the pond which have serve as breed place for the mosquito be drain these ditch have answer their purpose for they be probably the chief cause of the astonishing diminution in the number of mosquito more ditch of the kind be be construct
 it be not practicable with the force at the commission&#39;s disposal and in view of the need that the force should be use in the large town of panama to begin this work before early last winter water main be then lay in the town and water be furnish to the people early in march from a temporary reservoir this reservoir prove to be of insufficient capacity before the end of the dry season and the shortage be make up by haul water over the panama railroad so that there be at all time an ample supply of the very good water since that time the new reservoir back of mount hope have be practically complete i visit this reservoir it be a lake over a mile long and half a mile broad it now carry some 500,000,000 gallon of first class water i forward herewith a photograph of this lake together with certain other photograph of what i see while i be on the isthmus nothing but a cataclysm will hereafter render it necessary in the dry season to haul water for the use of colon and cristobal
 one of the most amusing as well as dishonest attack make upon the commission be in connection with this reservoir the writer in question usually confine himself to vague general mendacity but in this case he specifically state that there be no water in the vicinity fit for a reservoir i drink it and it be excellent and that this particular reservoir would never hold water anyway accompany this message as i have say above be a photograph of the reservoir as i myself see it and as it have be in existence ever since the article in question be publish with typical american humor the engineering corps still at work at the reservoir have christen a large boat which be now use on the reservoir by the name of the individual who thus deny the possibility of the reservoir&#39; existence
 i ride through the street of colon see they at the height of the rainy season after two day of almost unexampled downpour when they be at their very bad take as a whole they be undoubtedly very bad as bad as pennsylvania avenue in washington before grant&#39;s administration front street be already in thoroughly satisfactory shape however some of the side street be also in good condition in other the change in the street be rapidly go on through three fourth of the town it be now possible to walk even during the period of tremendous rain in low shoe without wet one&#39;s foot owe to the rapidity with which the surface water be carry away in the ditch in the remain one fourth of the street the mud be very deep about as deep as in the ordinary street of a low lie prairie river town of the same size in the united states during early spring all man to whom i speak be a unit in say that the condition of the colon street be 100 per cent well than a year ago the most superficial examination of the town show the progress that have be make and be be make in macadamize the street complaint be make to i by an entirely reputable man as to the character of some of the material use for repair certain street on investigation the complaint prove well rounded but it also appear that the use of the material in question have be abandon the commission after having try it in one or two street find it not appropriate
 the result of the investigation of this honest complaint be typical of what occur when i investigate most of the other honest complaint make to i that is where the complaint be not make wantonly or maliciously they almost always prove due to failure to appreciate the fact that time be necessary in the creation and completion of this titanic work in a tropic wilderness it be impossible to avoid some mistake in build a giant canal through jungle cover mountain and swamp while at the same time sanitate tropic city and provide for the feeding and general care of from twenty to thirty thousand worker the complaint bring to i either of insufficient provision in care for some of the laborer or of failure to finish the pavement of colon or of failure to supply water or of failure to build wooden sidewalk for the use of the laborer in the rainy season on investigation prove almost without exception to be due merely to the utter inability of the commission to do everything at once
 for instance it be imperative that panama which have the high death rate and where the chance of a yellow fever epidemic be strong should be care for first yet most of the complaint as to the delay in take care of colon be due to the inability or unwillingness to appreciate this simple fact again as the thousand of laborer be bring over and house it be not always possible at the outset to supply wooden walk and bath house because other more vital necessity have to be meet and in consequence while most of the settlement have good bath house and to a large extent at least wooden walk there be plenty of settlement where wooden walk have not yet be lay down and i visit one where the bath house have not be provide but in this very settlement the frame of the bath house be already up and in every case the utmost effort be be make to provide the wooden walk of course in some of the new camp tent be use pende the building of house where possible i think detach house would be preferable to the semi detached house now in general use
 care and forethought have be exercise by the commission and nothing have reflect more credit upon they than their refusal either to go ahead too fast or to be deter by the fear of criticism from not go ahead fast enough it be curious to note the fact that many of the most severe critic of the commission criticize they for precisely opposite reason some complain bitterly that the work be not in a more advanced condition while the other complain that it have be rush with such haste that there have be insufficient preparation for the hygiene and comfort of the employee as a matter of fact neither criticism be just it would have be impossible to go quick than the commission have go for such quickness would have mean insufficient preparation on the other hand to refuse to do anything until every possible future contingency have be meet would have cause wholly unwarranted delay the right course to follow be exactly the course which have be follow every reasonable preparation be make in advance the hygienic condition in especial be make as nearly perfect as possible while on the other hand there have be no timid refusal to push forward the work because of inability to anticipate every possible emergency for of course many defect can only be show by the working of the system in actual practice
 in addition to attend to the health of the employee it be of course necessary to provide for police the zone this be do by a police force which at present number over 200 man under captain shanton about one fifth of the man be white and the other black in different place i question some twenty or thirty of these man take they at random they be a fine set physically and in discipline with one exception all the white man i question have serve in the american army usually in the philippines and belong to the good type of american soldier without exception the black policeman whom i question have serve either in the british army or in the jamaica or barbados police they be evidently content and be do their work well where possible the policeman be use to control people of their own color but in any emergency no hesitation be feel in use they indiscriminately
 inasmuch as so many both of the white and colored employee have bring their family with they school have be establish the school service be under mr. o&#39;connor for the white pupil white american teacher be employ for the colored pupil there be also some white american teacher one spanish teacher and one colored american teacher most of they be color teacher from jamaica barbados and st. lucia the schoolroom be good and it be a pleasant thing to see the pride that the teacher be take in their work and their pupil
 there seem to i to be too many saloon in the zone but the new high license law which go into effect on january 1 next will probably close four fifth of they resolute and successful effort be be make to minimize and control the sale of liquor
 the car on the passenger train on the isthmus be divide into first and second class the difference be mark in the price of ticket as a rule second class passenger be color and first class passenger white but in every train which i see there be a number of white second class passenger and on two of they there be color first class passenger
 next in importance to the problem of sanitation and indeed now of equal importance be the problem of securing and care for the mechanic laborer and other employee who actually do the work on the canal and the railroad this great task have be under the control of mr. jackson smith and on the whole have be well do at present there be some 6,000 white employee and some 19,000 colored employee on the isthmus i go over the different place where the different kind of employee be work i think i see representative of every type both at their work and in their home and i converse with probably a couple of hundred of they all tell choose they at random from every class and include those who come especially to present certain grievance i find that those who do not come specifically to present grievance almost invariably express far great content and satisfaction with the condition than do those who call to make complaint
 nearly 5,000 of the white employee have come from the united states no man can see these young vigorous man energetically do their duty without a thrill of pride in they as americans they represent on the average a high class doubtless to congress the wage pay they will seem high but as a matter of fact the only general complaint which i find have any real basis among the complaint make to i upon the isthmus be that owe to the peculiar surrounding the cost of living and the distance from home the wage be really not as high as they should be in fact almost every man i speak to feel that he ought to be receive more money a view however which the average man who stay at home in the united states probably likewise hold as regard himself i append figure of the wage pay so that the congress can judge the matter for itself later i shall confer on the subject with certain representative labor man here in the united states as well as go over with mr. stevens the comparative wage pay on the zone and at home and i may then communicate my finding to the canal committee of the two houses
 the white americans be employ some of they in office work but the majority in handle the great steam shovel as engineer and conductor on the dirt train as machinist in the great repair shop as carpenter and time keeper superintendent and foreman of division and of gang and so on and so on many of they have bring down their wife and family and the child when not in school be run about and behave precisely as the american small boy and small girl behave at home the bachelor among the employee live sometimes in small separate house sometimes in large house quarter be furnish free to all the man married and unmarried usually the bachelor sleep two in a room as they would do in this country i find a few case where three be in a room and i be tell of although i do not see large room in which four be sleep for it be not possible in what be really a vast system of construction camp always to provide in advance as ample house room as the commission intend later to give in one case where the house be an old french house with a leak in the roof i do not think the accommodation be good but in every other case among the score of house i enter at random the accommodation be good every room be neat and clean usually have book magazine and small ornament and in short just such a room as a self respect craftsman would be glad to live in at home the quarter for the married people be even well doubtless there must be here and there a married couple who with or without reason be not content with their house on the isthmus but i never happen to strike such a couple the wife of the steam shovel man engineer machinist and carpenter into whose house i go all with one accord express their pleasure in their home life and surrounding indeed i do not think they could have do
