american housewife and helpmeet who have give to the home life that touch of attractiveness which of course the bachelor quarter neither have nor could have
 the housewife purchase their supply directly or through their husband from the commissary store of the commission all to whom i speak agree that the supply be excellent and all but two state that there be no complaint to be make these two complain that the price be excessive as compare to the price in the states on investigation i do not feel that this complaint be well found the married man eat at home the unmarried man sometimes eat at private boarding house or private mess but more often judge by the answer of those whom i question at the government canteen or hotel where the meal cost 30 cent to each employee this 30 cent meal strike i as be as good a meal as we get in the united states at the ordinary hotel in which a 50 cent meal be provide three fourth of the man whom i question state that the meal furnish at these government hotel be good the remain one fourth that they be not good i myself take dinner at the la boca government hotel no warning whatever having be give of my coming there be two room as generally in these hotel in one the employee be allow to dine without their coat while in the other they have to put they on the 30 cent meal include soup native beef which be good mashed potato pea beet chili con carne plum pudding tea coffee each man have as much of each dish as he desire on the table there be a bottle of liquid quinine tonic which two third of the guest as i be inform use every day there be neat tablecloth and napkin the man who be take the meal at or about the same time include railroad man machinist shipwright and member of the office force the room be clean comfortable and airy with mosquito screen around the outer piazza i be inform by some of those present that this hotel and also the other similar hotel be every saturday night turn into clubhouse where the american official the school teacher and various employee appear bring their wife there be dance and singing there be a piano in the room which i be inform be use for the music on these occasion my meal be excellent and two newspaper correspondent who have be on the isthmus several day inform i that it be precisely like the meal they have be get elsewhere at other government hotel one of the employee be a cousin of one of the secret service man who be with i and he state that the meal have always be good but that after a time he grow tired of they because they seem so much alike
 i come to the conclusion that speak generally there be no warrant for complaint about the food doubtless it grow monotonous after awhile any man accustom to handle large masse of man know that some of they even though otherwise very good man be sure to grumble about something and usually about their food schoolboy college boy and boarder in boarding house make similar complaint so do soldier and sailor on this very trip on one of the warship a seaman come to complain to the second watch officer about the quality of the cocoa at the seaman&#39;s mess say that it be not sweet enough it be point out to he that there be sugar on the table and he could always put it in to which he respond that that be the cook&#39;s business and not his i think that the complaint as to the food on the isthmus have but little more foundation than that of the sailor in question moreover i be give to understand that one real cause of complaint be that at the government hotel no liquor be serve and some of the drinking man therefore refuse to go to they the number of man use the government hotel be steadily increase
 of the nineteen or twenty thousand day laborer employ on the canal a few hundred be spaniards these do excellent work their foreman tell i that they do twice as well as the west india laborer they keep healthy and no difficulty be experience with they in any way some italian laborer be also employ in connection with the drilling as might be expect with labor as high price as at present in the united states it have not so far prove practicable to get any ordinary laborer from the united states the american wage worker on the isthmus be the highly pay skilled mechanic of the type mention previously a steady effort be be make to secure italians and especially to procure more spaniards because of the very satisfactory result that have come from their employment and their number will be increase as far as possible it have not prove possible however to get they in anything like the number need for the work and from present appearance we shall in the main have to rely for the ordinary unskilled work partly upon colored laborer from the west indies partly upon chinese labor it certainly ought to be unnecessary to point out that the american workingman in the united states have no concern whatever in the question as to whether the rough work on the isthmus which be perform by alien in any event be do by alien from one country with a black skin or by alien from another country with a yellow skin our business be to dig the canal as efficiently and as quickly as possible provide always that nothing be do that be inhumane to any laborer and nothing that interfere with the wage of or lower the standard of living of our own workman have in view this principle i have arrange to try several thousand chinese laborer this be desirable both because we must try to find out what laborer be most efficient and furthermore because we should not leave ourselves at the mercy of any one type of foreign labor at present the great bulk of the unskilled labor on the isthmus be do by west india negro chiefly from jamaica barbados and the other english possession one of the governor of the land in question have show an unfriendly disposition to our work and have throw obstacle in the way of our get the labor need and it be highly undesirable to give any outsider the impression however ill found that they be indispensable and can dictate term to we
 the west india laborer be fairly but only fairly satisfactory some of the man do very well indeed the well class who be to be find as foreman as skilled mechanic as policeman be good man and many of the ordinary day laborer be also good but thousand of those who be bring over under contract at our expense go off into the jungle to live or loaf around colon or work so badly after the first three or four day as to cause a serious diminution of the amount of labor perform on friday and saturday of each week i question many of these jamaica laborer as to the condition of their work and what if any change they wish i receive many complaint from they but as regard most of these complaint they themselves contradict one another in all case where the complaint be as to their treatment by any individual it prove on examination that this individual be himself a west india man of color either a policeman a storekeeper or an assistant storekeeper doubtless there must be many complaint against americans but those to whom i speak do not happen to make any such complaint to i there be no complaint of the housing i see but one set of quarter for color laborer which i think poor and this be in an old french house the barrack for unmarried man be roomy well ventilate and clean with canvas bunk for each man and a kind of false attic at the top where the trunk and other belonging of the different man be keep the clothe be hang on clothesline nothing be allow to be keep on the floor in each of these big room there be table and lamp and usually a few book or paper and in almost every room there be a bible the book be the property of the laborer themselves the cleanliness of the quarter be secure by daily inspection the quarter for the married negro laborer be good they be neatly keep and in almost every case the man live in they whose wife or daughter do the cooking for they be far well satisfied and of a high grade than the ordinary bachelor negro not only be the quarter in which these negro laborer be live much superior to those in which i be inform they live at home but they be much superior to the hut to be see in the jungle of panama itself beside the railroad track in which the low class of native panamans live as well as the negro workman when they leave the employ of the canal and go into the jungle a single glance at the two set of building be enough to show the great superiority in point of comfort cleanliness and healthfulness of the government house as compare with the native house
 the negro generally do their own cooking the bachelor cook in shed provide by the government and use their own pot in the different camp there be a wide variation in the character of these cooking shed in some where the camp be complete the kitchen or cooking shed as well as the bathroom and water closet be all in excellent trim while there be board sidewalk lead from building to building in other camp the kitchen or cook shed have not be floor and the sidewalk have not be put down while in one camp the bath house be not yet up in each case however every effort be be make to hurry on the construction and i do not believe that the delay have be great than be inevitable in such work the laborer be accustomed to do their own cooking but there be much complaint especially among the bachelor as to the quantity and some as to the quality of the food they get from the commissary department especially as regard yam on the other hand the married man and their wife and the more advanced among the bachelor almost invariably express themselves as entirely satisfied with their treatment at the commissary store except that they state that they generally could not get yam there and have to purchase they outside the chief complaint be that the price be too high it be unavoidable that the price should be high than in their own home and after careful investigation i come to the conclusion that the chief trouble lie in the fact that the yam plantain and the like be rather perishable food and be very bulky compare to the amount of nourishment they contain so that it be costly to import they in large quantity and difficult to keep they nevertheless i feel that an effort should be make to secure they a more ample supply of their favorite food and so directed and i believe that ultimately the government must itself feed they i be have this matter look into
 the superintendent have immediate charge of one gang of man at the colon reservoir state that he endeavor to get they to substitute bean and other nourishing food for the stringy watery yam because the man keep their strength and health well on the more nourishing food inasmuch however as they be accustom to yams it be difficult to get they to eat the more strengthen food and some time elapse before they grow accustomed to it at this reservoir there have be a curious experience it be off in the jungle by itself at the end of a couple of mile of a little toy railroad in order to get the laborer there they be give free food and of course free lodging and yet it prove difficult to keep they because they wish to be where they could reach the dramshop and place of amusement
 i be strike by the superior comfort and respectability of the life of the married man it would in my opinion be a most admirable thing if a much large number of the man have their wife for with their advent all complaint about the food and cooking be almost sure to cease
 i have an interview with mr. mallet the british consul to find out if there be any just cause for complaint as to the treatment of the west india negro he inform i most emphatically that there be not and authorize i to give his statement publicity he say that not only be the condition of the laborer far well than have be the case under the old french company but that year by year the condition be improve under our own regime he state that complaint be continually bring to he and that he always investigate they and that for the last six month he have fail to find a single complaint of a serious nature that contain any justification whatever
 one of the great need at present be to provide amusement both for the white man and the black the young men&#39;s christian association be try to do good work and should be in every way encouraged but the government should do the main work i have specifically call the attention of the commission to this matter and something have be accomplish already anything do for the welfare of the man add to their efficiency and money devote to that purpose be therefore properly to be consider as spend in build the canal it be imperatively necessary to provide ample recreation and amusement if the man be to be keep well and healthy i call the special attention of congress to this need
 this gathering distribute and care for the great force of laborer be one of the giant feature of the work that friction will from time to time occur in connection therewith be inevitable the astonishing thing be that the work have be perform so well and that the machinery run so smoothly from my own experience i be able to say that more care have be exercise in housing feeding and generally pay heed to the need of the skilled mechanic and ordinary laborer in the work on this canal than be the case in the construction of new railroad or in any other similar private or public work in the united states proper and it be the testimony of all people competent to speak that on no other similar work anywhere in the tropics indeed as far as i know anywhere else have there be such forethought and such success achieve in provide for the need of the man who do the work
 i have now deal with the hygienic condition which make it possible to employ a great force of laborer and with the task of gathering housing and feed these laborer there remain to consider the actual work which have to be do the work because of which these laborer be gather together the work of construct the canal this be under the direct control of the chief engineer mr. stevens who have already show admirable result and whom we can safely trust to achieve similar result in the future
 our people find on the isthmus a certain amount of old french material and equipment which could be use some of it in addition could be sell as scrap iron some could be use for furnish the foundation for fill in for much no possible use could be devise that would not cost more than it would bring in
 the work be now go on with a vigor and efficiency pleasant to witness the three big problem of the canal be the la boca dams the gatun dam and the culebra cut the culebra cut must be make anyhow but of course change as to the dams or at least as to the lock adjacent to the dams may still occur the la boca dam offer no particular problem the bottom material be so good that there be a practical certainty not merely as to what can be achieve but as to the time of achievement the gatun dam offer the most serious problem which we have to solve and yet the able man on the isthmus believe that this problem be certain of solution along the line propose although of course it necessitate great toil energy and intelligence and although equally of course there will be some little risk in connection with the work the risk arise from the fact that some of the material near the bottom be not so good as could be desire if the huge earth dam now contemplate be throw across from one foothill to the other we will have what be practically a low broad mountain ridge behind which will rise the inland lake this artificial mountain will probably show less seepage that is will have great restraining capacity than the average natural mountain range the exact locality of the lock at this dam as at the other dams be now be determine in april next secretary taft with three of the able engineer of the country messrs. noble stearns and ripley will visit the isthmus and the three engineer will make the final and conclusive examination as to the exact site for each lock meanwhile the work be go ahead without a break
 the culebra cut do not offer such great risk that is the damage liable to occur from occasional land slip will not represent what may be call major disaster the work will merely call for intelligence perseverance and executive capacity it be however the work upon which most labor will have to be spend the dam will be compose of the earth take out of the cut and very possibly the building of the lock and dam will take even long than the cutting in culebra itself
 the main work be now be do in the culebra cut it be strike and impressive to see the huge steam shovel in full play the dumping train carry away the rock and earth they dislodge the implement of french excavating machinery which often stand a little way from the line of work though of excellent construction look like the veri toy when compare with these new steam shovel just as the french dumping car seem like toy car when compare with the long train of huge car dump by steam plow which be now in use this represent the enormous advance that have be make in machinery during the past quarter of a century no doubt a quarter of a century hence this new machinery of which we be now so proud will similarly seem out of date but it be certainly serve its purpose well now the old french car have to be entirely discard we still have in use a few of the more modern but not most modern car which hold but twelve yard of earth they can be employ on certain line with sharp curve but the recent car hold from twenty five to thirty yard apiece and instead of the old clumsy method of unload they a steam plow be draw from end to end of the whole vestibuled train thus immensely economize labor in the rainy season the steam shovel can do but little in dirt but they work steadily in rock and in the hard ground there be some twenty five at work during the time i be on the isthmus and their tremendous power and efficiency be most impressive
 as soon as the type of canal be decide this work begin in good earnest the rainy season will shortly be over and then there will be an immense increase in the amount take out but even during the last three month in the rainy season steady progress be show by the figure in august 242,000 cubic yard in september 291,000 cubic yard and in october 325,000 cubic yard in october new record be establish for the output of individual shovel as well as for the tonnage haul of individual locomotive i hope to see the growth of a healthy spirit of emulation between the different shovel and locomotive crew just such a spirit as have grow on our battle ship between the different gun crew in matter of marksmanship pass through the cut the amount of new work can be see at a glance in one place the entire side of a hill have be take out recently by twenty seven ton of dynamite which be explode at one blast at another place i be give a presidential salute of twenty one charge of dynamite on the top notch of the culebra cut the prism be now as wide as it will be all tell the canal bed at this point have now be sink about two hundred foot below what it originally be it will have to be sink about one hundred and thirty foot far throughout the cut the drilling blasting shoveling and hauling be go on with constantly increase energy the huge shovel be press up as if they be mountain howitzer into the most unlikely look place where they eat their way into the hillside
 the most advanced method not only in construction but in railroad management have be apply in the zone with corresponding economy in time and cost this have be show in the handling of the tonnage from ship into car and from car into ship on the panama railroad where thank largely to the efficiency of general manager bierd the saving in time and cost have be noteworthy my examination tend to show that some of the department have doubtless necessarily become overdeveloped and could now be reduce or subordinate without impairment of efficiency and with a saving of cost the chairman of the commission mr. shonts have all matter of this kind constantly in view and be now reorganize the government of the zone so as to make the form of administration both more flexible and less expensive subordinate everything to direct efficiency with a view to the work of the canal commission from time to time change of this kind will undoubtedly have to be make for it must be remember that in this giant work of construction it be continually necessary to develop department or bureau which be vital for the time being but which soon become useless just as it will be continually necessary to put up building and even to erect town which in ten year will once more give place to jungle or will then be at the bottom of the great lake at the end of the canal
 it be not only natural but inevitable that a work as gigantic as this which have be undertake on the isthmus should arouse every specie of hostility and criticism the condition be so new and so try and the work so vast that it would be absolutely out of the question that mistake should not be make check will occur unforeseen difficulty will arise from time to time seemingly well settle plan will have to be change at present twenty five thousand man be engage on the task after a while the number will be double in such a multitude it be inevitable that there should be here and there a scoundrel very many of the poor class of laborer lack the mental development to protect themselves against either the rascality of other or their own folly and it be not possible for human wisdom to devise a plan by which they can invariably be protect in a place which have be for age a by word for unhealthfulness and with so large a congregation of stranger suddenly put down and set to hard work there will now and then be outbreak of disease there will now and then be shortcoming in administration there will be unlooke for accident to delay the excavation of the cut or the building of the dam and lock each such incident will be entirely natural and even though serious no one of they will mean more than a little extra delay or trouble yet each when discover by sensation monger and retail to timid folk of little faith will serve as an excuse for the belief that the whole work be be badly manage experiment will continually be try in housing in hygiene in street repair in dredging and in dig earth and rock now and then an experiment will be a failure and among those who hear of it a certain proportion of doubt thomases will at once believe that the whole work be a failure doubtless here and there some minor rascality will be uncover but as to this i have to say that after the most painstaking inquiry i have be unable to find a single reputable person who have so much as hear of any serious accusation affect the honesty of the commission or of any responsible officer under it i append a letter deal with the most serious charge that of the ownership of lot in colon the charge be not advance by a reputable man and be utterly baseless it be not too much to say that the whole atmosphere of the commission breathe honesty as it breathe efficiency and energy above all the work have be keep absolutely clear of politic i have never hear even a suggestion of spoil politic in connection with it
 i have investigate every complaint bring to i for which there seem to be any shadow of foundation in two or three case all of which i have indicate in the course of this message i come to the conclusion that there be foundation for the complaint and that the method of the commission in the respect complain of could be better in the other instance the complaint prove absolutely baseless save in two or three instance where they refer to mistake which the commission have already itself find out and correct
 so much for honest criticism there remain an immense amount of as reckless slander as have ever be publish where the slanderer be of foreign origin i have no concern with they where they be americans i feel for they the heartiest contempt and indignation because in a spirit of wanton dishonesty and malice they be try to interfere with and hamper the execution of the great work of the kind ever attempt and be seek to bring to naught the effort of their countryman to put to the credit of america one of the giant feat of the age the outrageous accusation of these slanderer constitute a gross libel upon a body of public servant who for train intelligence expert ability high character and devotion to duty have never be excel anywhere there be not a man among those direct the work on the isthmus who have obtain his position on any other basis than merit alone and not one who have use his position in any way for his own personal or pecuniary advantage
 after most careful consideration we have decide to let out most of the work by contract if we can come to satisfactory term with the contractor the whole work be of a kind suit to the peculiar genius of our people and our people have develop the type of contractor well fit to grapple with it it be of course much well to do the work in large part by contract than to do it all by the government provide it be possible on the one hand to secure to the contractor a sufficient remuneration to make it worth while for responsible contractor of the good kind to undertake the work and provide on the other hand it can be do on term which will not give an excessive profit to the contractor at the expense of the government after much consideration the plan already promulgate by the secretary of war be adopt this plan in its essential feature be draft after careful and thorough study and consideration by the chief engineer mr. stevens who while in the employment of mr. hill the president of the great northern railroad have personal experience of this very type of contract mr. stevens then submit the plan to the chairman of the commission mr. shouts who go carefully over it with mr. rogers the legal adviser of the commission to see that all legal difficulty be meet he then submit copy of the plan to both secretary taft and myself secretary taft submit it to some of the good counsel at the new york bar and afterwards i go over it very carefully with mr. taft and mr. shouts and we lay the plan in its general feature before mr. root my conclusion be that it combine the maximum of advantage with the minimum of disadvantage under it a premium will be put upon the speedy and economical construction of the canal and a penalty impose on delay and waste the plan as promulgate be tentative doubtless it will have to be change in some respect before we can come to a satisfactory agreement with responsible contractor perhaps even after the bid have be receive and of course it be possible that we can not come to an agreement in which case the government will do the work itself meanwhile the work on the isthmus be progress steadily and without any let up
 a seven headed commission be of course a clumsy executive instrument we should have but one commissioner with such head of department and other officer under he as we may find necessary we should be expressly permit to employ the good engineer in the country as consult engineer
  i accompany this paper with a map show substantially what the canal will be like when it be finish when the culebra cut have be make and the dam build if they be build as at present propose there will then be at both the pacific and atlantic end of the canal two great fresh water lake connect by a broad channel run at the bottom of a ravine across the backbone of the western hemisphere those well inform believe that the work will be complete in about eight year but it be never save to prophesy about such a work as this especially in the tropics
 i be inform that the representative of the commercial club of four cities&mdash;boston chicago cincinnati and st. louis&mdash;the membership of which include most of the lead business man of those city expect to visit the isthmus for the purpose of examine the work of construction of the canal i be glad to hear it and i shall direct that every facility be give they to see all that be to be see in the work which the government be do such interest as a visit like this would indicate will have a good effect upon the man who be do the work on one hand while on the other hand it will offer as witness of the exact condition man whose experience as business man and whose impartiality will make the result of their observation of value to the country as a whole
 of the success of the enterprise i be as well convince as one can be of any enterprise that be human it be a stupendous work upon which our fellow countryman be engage down there on the isthmus and while we should hold they to a strict accountability for the way in which they perform it we should yet recognize with frank generosity the epic nature of the task on which they be engage and its world wide importance they be do something which will redound immeasurably to the credit of america which will benefit all the world and which will last for age to come under mr. shonts and mr. stevens and doctor gorgas this work have start with every omen of good fortune they and their worthy associate from the high to the low be entitle to the same credit that we would give to the pick man of a victorious army for this conquest of peace will in its great and far reach effect stand as among the great conquest whether of peace or of war which have ever be win by any of the people of mankind a badge be to be give to every american citizen who for a specify time have take part in this work for participation in it will hereafter be hold to reflect honor upon the man participate just as it reflect honor upon a soldier to have belong to a mighty army in a great war for righteousness our fellow countryman on the isthmus be work for our interest and for the national renown in the same spirit and with the same efficiency that the man of the army and navy work i n time of war it behoove we in our turn to do all we can to hold up their hand and to aid they in every way to bring their great work to a triumphant conclusion

to the senate
 in response to senate resolution of december 6 address to i and to the two senate resolution address to he the secretary of war have by my direction submit to i a report which i herewith send to the senate together with several document include a letter of general nettleton and memoranda as to precedent for the summary discharge or muster out of regiment or company some or all of the member of which have be guilty of misconduct
 i order the discharge of nearly all the member of companies b c and d of the twenty fifth infantry by name in the exercise of my constitutional power and in pursuance of what after full consideration i find to be my constitutional duty as commander in chief of the united states army i be glad to avail myself of the opportunity afford by these resolution to lay before the senate the follow fact as to the murderous conduct of certain member of the company in question and as to the conspiracy by which many of the other member of these company save the criminal from justice to the disgrace of the united states uniform
 i call your attention to the accompany report of maj augustus p. blocksom of lieut col leonard a. lovering and of brig gen. ernest a. garlington the inspector general of the united states army of their investigation into the conduct of the troop in question an effort have be make to discredit the fairness of the investigation into the conduct of these colored troop by point out that general garlington be a southerner precisely the same action would have be take have the troop be white indeed the discharge would probably have be make in more summary fashion general garlington be a native of south carolina lieutenant colonel lovering be a native of new hampshire major blocksore be a native of ohio as it happen the disclosure of the guilt of the troop be make in the report of the officer who come from ohio and the effort of the officer who come from south carolina be confine to the endeavor to shield the innocent man of the company in question if any such there be by secure information which would enable we adequately to punish the guilty but i wish it distinctly understand that the fact of the birthplace of either officer be one which i absolutely refuse to consider the standard of professional honor and of loyalty to the flag and the service be the same for all officer and all enlisted man of the united states army and i resent with the keen indignation any effort to draw any line among they base upon birthplace creed or any other consideration of the kind i should put the same entire faith in these report if it have happen that they be all make by man come from some one state whether in the south or the north the east or the west as i now do when as it happen they be make by officer bear in different states
 major blocksom&#39;s report be most careful be base upon the testimony of score of eye witness testimony which conflict only in non essential and which establish the essential fact beyond chance of successful contradiction not only have no successful effort be make to traverse his finding in any essential particular but as a matter of fact every trustworthy report from outsider amply corroborate they by far the good of these outside report be that of gen. a. b. nettleton make in a letter to the secretary of war which i herewith append general nettleton be an ex union soldier a consistent friend of the colored man throughout his life a lifelong republican a citizen of illinois and assistant secretary of the treasury under president harrison
 it appear that in brownsville the city immediately beside which fort brown be situate there have be considerable feeling between the citizen and the colored troop of the garrison company difficulty have occur there be a conflict of evidence as to whether the citizen or the colored troop be to blame my impression be that as a matter of fact in these difficulty there be blame attach to both side but this be a wholly unimportant matter for our present purpose as nothing that occur offer in any shape or way an excuse or justification for the atrocious conduct of the troop when in lawless and murderous spirit and under cover of the night they make their attack upon the citizen
 the attack be make near midnight on august 13 the following fact as to this attack be make clear by major blocksom&#39;s investigation and have not be and in my judgment can not be successfully controvert from 9 to 15 or 20 of the colored soldier take part in the attack they leap over the wall from the barrack and hurry through the town they shoot at whomever they see move and they shoot into house where they see light in some of these house there be woman and child as the would be murderer must have know in one house in which there be two woman and five child some ten shot go through at a height of about 4 1/2 foot above the floor one put out the lamp upon the table the lieutenant of police of the town hear the firing and ride toward it he meet the raider who as he state be about 15 colored soldier they instantly start fire upon he he turn and ride off and they continue fire upon he until they have kill his horse they shoot he in the right arm it be afterwards amputate above the elbow a number of shot be also fire at two other policeman the raider fire several time into a hotel some of the shot be aim at a guest sit by a window they shoot into a saloon kill the bartender and wound another man at the same time other raider fire into another house in which woman and child be sleep two of the shot go through the mosquito bar over the bed in which the mistress of the house and her two child be lie several other house be strike by bullet it be at night and the street of the town be poorly light so that none of the individual raider be recognize but the evidence of many witness of all class be conclusive to the effect that the raider be negro soldier the shattered bullet shell and clip of the government rifle which be find on the ground be merely corroborative so be the bullet hole in the house some of which it appear must from the direction have be fire from the fort just at the moment when the soldier leave it not a bullet hole appear in any of the structure of the fort
 the townspeople be completely surprised by the unprovoked and murderous savagery of the attack the soldier be the aggressor from start to finish they meet with no substantial resistance and one and all who take part in that raid stand as deliberate murderer who do murder one man who try to murder other and who try to murder woman and child the act be one of horrible atrocity and so far as i be aware unparalleled for infamy in the annal of the united states army
 the white officer of the company be completely take by surprise and at first evidently believe that the firing mean that the townspeople be attack the soldier it be not until 2 or 3 o&#39;clock in the morning that any of they become aware of the truth i have direct a careful investigation into the conduct of the officer to see if any of they be blameworthy and i have approve the recommendation of the war department that two be bring before a court martial
 as to the noncommissioned officer and enlisted man there can be no doubt whatever that many be necessarily privy after if not before the attack to the conduct of those who take actual part in this murderous riot i refer to major blocksom&#39;s report for proof of the fact that certainly some and probably all of the noncommissioned officer in charge of quarter who be responsible for the gun rack and have key thereto in their personal possession know what man be engage in the attack
 major penrose in command of the post in his letter include in the appendix give the reason why he be reluctantly convince that some of the man under he as he think from 7 to 10 -got their rifle slip out of quarter to do the shooting and return to the barrack without be discover the shooting all occur within two and a half short block of the barrack it be possible for the raider to go from the fort to the farth point of firing and return in less than ten minute for the distance do not exceed 350 yard
 such be the fact of this case general nettleton in his letter herewith append state that next door to where he be write in brownsville be a small cottage where a children&#39;s party have just break up before the house be riddle by united states bullet fire by united states troop from united states springfield rifle at close range with the purpose of kill or maim the inmate include the parent and child who be still in the well light house and whose escape from death under such circumstance be astonishing he state that on another street he daily look upon fresh bullet scar where a volley from similar government rifle be fire into the side and window of a hotel occupy at the time by sleep or frightened guest from abroad who could not possibly have give any offense to the assailant he write that the chief of the brownsville police be again on duty from hospital and carry an empty sleeve because be be shoot by federal soldier from the adjacent garrison in the course of their murderous foray and not far away be the fresh grave of an unoffending citizen of the place a boy in year who be wantonly shoot down by these united states soldier while unarmed and attempt to escape
 the effort to confute this testimony so far have consist in the assertion or implication that the townspeople shoot one another in order to discredit the soldier an absurdity too gross to need discussion and unsupported by a shred of evidence there be no question as to the murder and the attempt murder there be no question that some of the soldier be guilty thereof there be no question that many of their comrade privy to the deed have combine to shelter the criminal from justice these comrade of the murderer by their own action have render it necessary either to leave all the man include the murderer in the army or to turn they all out and under such circumstance there be no alternative for the usefulness of the army would be at an end be we to permit such an outrage to be commit with impunity
 in short the evidence prove conclusively that a number of the soldier engage in a deliberate and concerted attack as cold blooded as it be cowardly the purpose be to terrorize the community and to kill or injure man woman and child in their home and bed or on the street and this at an hour of the night when concerted or effective resistance or defense be out of the question and when detection by identification of the criminal in the united states uniform be well nigh impossible so much for the original crime a blacker never stain the annal of our army it have be supplement by another only less black in the shape of a successful conspiracy of silence for the purpose of shield those who take part in the original conspiracy of murder these soldier be not school boy on a frolic they be full grow man in the uniform of the united states army arm with deadly weapon swear to uphold the law of the united states and under every obligation of oath and honor not merely to refrain from criminality but with the sturdy rigor to hunt down criminality and the crime they commit or connive at be murder they pervert the power put into their hand to sustain the law into the most deadly violation of the law the noncommissioned officer be primarily responsible for the discipline and good conduct of the man they be appoint to their position for the very purpose of preserve this discipline and good conduct and of detect and secure the punishment of every enlisted man who do what be wrong they fill with reference to the discipline a part that the commission officer be of course unable to fill although the ultimate responsibility for the discipline can never be shift from the shoulder of the latter under any ordinary circumstance the first duty of the noncommissioned officer as of the commission officer be to train the private in the rank so that he may be an efficient fighting man against a foreign foe but there be an even high duty so obvious that it be not under ordinary circumstance necessary so much as to allude to it the duty of train the soldier so that he shall be a protection and not a menace to his peaceful fellow citizen and above all to the woman and child of the nation unless this duty be well perform the army become a mere dangerous mob and if conduct such as that of the murderer in question be not where possible punish and where this be not possible unless the chance of its repetition be guard against in the most thoroughgoing fashion it would be well that the entire army should be disband it be vital for the army to be imbue with the spirit which will make every man in it and above all the officer and non commission officer feel it a matter of high obligation to discover and punish and not to shield the criminal in uniform
 yet some of the noncommissioned officer and many of the man of the three company in question have band together in a conspiracy to protect the assassin and would be assassin who have disgrace their uniform by the conduct above relate many of these non commission officer and man must have know and all of they may have know circumstance which would have lead to the conviction of those engage in the murderous assault they have stolidly and as one man break their oath of enlistment and refuse to help discover the criminal
 by my direction every effort be make to persuade those innocent of murder among they to separate themselves from the guilty by help bring the criminal to justice they be warn that if they do not take advantage of the offer they would all be discharge from the service and forbid again to enter the employ of the government they refuse to profit by the warning i accordingly have they discharge if any organization of troop in the service white or black be guilty of similar conduct in the future i shall follow precisely the same course under no circumstance will i consent to keep in the service body of man whom the circumstance show to be a menace to the country incidentally i may add that the soldier of long service and high position who suffer because of the order so far from be those who deserve most sympathy deserve least for they be the very man upon whom we should be able especially to rely to prevent mutiny and murder
 people have speak as if this discharge from the service be a punishment i deny emphatically that such be the case because as punishment it be utterly inadequate the punishment meet for mutineer and murderer such as those guilty of the brownsville assault be death and a punishment only less severe ought to be mete out to those who have aid and abet mutiny and murder and treason by refuse to help in their detection i would that it be possible for i to have punish the guilty man i regret most keenly that i have not be able to do so
 be it remember always that these man be all in the service of the united states under contract of enlistment which by their term and by statute be terminable by my direction as commander in chief of the army it be my clear duty to terminate those contract when the public interest demand it and it would have be a betrayal of the public interest on my part not to terminate the contract which be keep in the service of the united states a body of mutineer and murderer
 any assertion that these man be deal with harshly because they be color man be utterly without foundation officer or enlisted man white man or colored man who be guilty of such conduct would have be treat in precisely the same way for there can be nothing more important than for the united states army in all its membership to understand that its arm can not be turn with impunity against the peace and order of the civil community
 there be plenty of precedent for the action take i call your attention to the memoranda herewith submit from the military secretary&#39;s office of the war department and a memorandum from the military secretary enclose a piece by ex corporal hesse now chief of division in the military secretary&#39;s office together with a letter from district attorney james wilkinson of new orleans the district attorney&#39;s letter recite several case in which white united states soldier be arrest for crime be try and every soldier and employee of the regiment or in the fort at which the soldier be station volunteer all they know both before and at the trial so as to secure justice in one case the soldier be acquit in another case the soldier be convict of murder the conviction result from the fact that every soldier from the command officer to the humblest private unite in secure all the evidence in their power about the crime in other case for less offense soldier be convict purely because their comrade in arm in a spirit of fine loyalty to the honor of the service at once tell the whole story of the trouble and decline to identify themselves with the criminal
 during the civil war numerous precedent for the action take by i occur in the shape of the summary discharge of regiment or company because of misconduct on the part of some or all of their member the sixtieth ohio be summarily discharge on the ground that the regiment be disorganize mutinous and worthless the eleventh new york be discharge by reason of general demoralization and numerous desertion three company of the fifth missouri cavalry and one company of the fourth missouri cavalry be muster out of the service of the united states without trial by court martial by reason of mutinous conduct and disaffection of the majority of the member of these company an almost exact parallel to my action another missouri regiment be muster out of service because it be in a state border closely on mutiny other example include new jersey maryland and other organization be give in the enclose paper
 i call your particular attention to the special field order of brig gen. u. s. grant issue from the headquarters of the thirteenth army corps on november 16 1862 in reference to the twentieth illinois member of this regiment have break into a store and take good to the value of some $ 1,240 and the rest of the regiment include especially two officer fail in the word of general grant to exercise their authority to ferret out the man guilty of the offense general grant accordingly muster out of the service of the united states the two officer in question and assess the sum of $ 1,240 against the say regiment as a whole officer and man to be assess pro rata on their pay in its essence this action be precisely similar to that i have take although the offense be of course trivial compare to the offense with which i have to deal
 ex corporal hesse recite what occur in a united states regular regiment in the spring of 1860 corporal hesse subsequently when the regiment be surrender to the confederates by general twiggs save the regimental color by wrap they about his body under his clothing and bring they north in safety receive a medal of honor for his action it appear that certain member of the regiment lynch a barkeeper who have kill one of the soldier be unable to discover the culprit col robert e. lee then in command of the department of texas order the company to be disband and the member transfer to other company and discharge at the end of their enlistment without honor owe to the outbreak of the civil war and the consequent loss of record and confusion it be not possible to say what finally become of this case
 when general lee be in command of the army of northern virginia as will appear from the inclose clipping from the charlotte observer he issue an order in october 1864 disband a certain battalion for cowardly conduct state at the time his regret that there be some officer and man belong to the organization who although not deserve it be oblige to share in the common disgrace because the good of the service demand it
 in addition to the discharge of organization which be of course infrequent there be continual case of the discharge of individual enlisted man without honor and without trial by court martial the official record show that during the fiscal year end june 30 last such discharge be issue by the war department without trial by court martial in the case of 352 enlisted man of the regular army 35 of they be on account of having become disqualify for service through own misconduct moreover in addition to the discharge without honor order by the war department there be a considerable number of discharge without honor issue by subordinate military authority under paragraph 148 of the army regulations where the service have not be honest and faithful that be where the service do not warrant reenlistment
 so much for the military side of the case but i wish to say something additional from the standpoint of the race question in my message at the opening of the congress i discuss the matter of lynch in it i give utterance to the abhorrence which all decent citizen should feel for the deed of the man in almost all case white man who take part in lynching and at the same time i condemn as all decent man of any color should condemn the action of those colored man who actively or passively shield the colored criminal from the law in the case of these company we have to deal with man who in the first place be guilty of what be practically the bad possible form of lynching for a lynching be in its essence lawless and murderous vengeance take by an armed mob for real or fancied wrong and who in the second place cover up the crime of lynch by stand with a vicious solidarity to protect the criminal
 it be of the utmost importance to all our people that we shall deal with each man on his merit as a man and not deal with he merely as a member of a give race that we shall judge each man by his conduct and not his color this be important for the white man and it be far more important for the colored man more evil and sinister counsel never be give to any people than that give to colored man by those adviser whether black or white who by apology and condonation encourage conduct such as that of the three company in question if the colored man elect to stand by criminal of their own race because they be of their own race they assuredly lie up for themselves the most dreadful day of reckoning every farsighte friend of the colored race in its effort to strive onward and upward should teach first as the most important lesson alike to the white man and the black the duty of treat the individual man strictly on his worth as he show it any conduct by colored people which tend to substitute for this rule the rule of stand by and shield an evil doer because he be a member of their race mean the inevitable degradation of the colored race it may and probably do mean damage to the white race but it mean ruin to the black race
 throughout my term of service in the presidency i have act on the principle thus advocate in the north as in the south i have appoint colored man of high character to office utterly disregard the protest of those who would have keep they out of office because they be color man so far as be in my power i have seek to secure for the colored people all their right under the law i have do all i could to secure they equal school training when young equal opportunity to earn their livelihood and achieve their happiness when old i have strive to break up peonage i have uphold the hand of those who like judge jones and judge speer have war against this peonage because i would hold myself unfit to be president if i do not feel the same revolt at wrong do a colored man as i feel at wrong do a white man i have condemn in unstinted term the crime of lynching perpetrate by white man and i should take instant advantage of any opportunity whereby i could bring to justice a mob of lyncher in precisely the same spirit i have now act with reference to these colored man who have be guilty of a black and dastardly crime in one policy as in the other i do not claim as a favor but i challenge as a right the support of every citizen of this country whatever his color provide only he have in he the spirit of genuine and farsighte patriotism

to the senate and house of representatives no nation have great resource than our and i think it can be truthfully say that the citizen of no nation possess great energy and industrial ability in no nation be the fundamental business condition sounder than in ours at this very moment and it be foolish when such be the case for people to hoard money instead of keep it in sound bank for it be such hoarding that be the immediate occasion of money stringency moreover as a rule the business of our people be conduct with honesty and probity and this apply alike to farm and factory to railroad and bank to all our legitimate commercial enterprise in any large body of man however there be certain to be some who be dishonest and if the condition be such that these man prosper or commit their misdeed with impunity their example be a very evil thing for the community where these man be business man of great sagacity and of temperament both unscrupulous and reckless and where the condition be such that they act without supervision or control and at first without effective check from public opinion they delude many innocent people into make investment or embark in kind of business that be really unsound when the misdeed of these successfully dishonest man be discover suffer come not only upon they but upon the innocent man whom they have mislead it be a painful awakening whenever it occur and naturally when it do occur those who suffer be apt to forget that the long it be defer the more painful it would be in the effort to punish the guilty it be both wise and proper to endeavor so far as possible to minimize the distress of those who have be mislead by the guilty yet it be not possible to refrain because of such distress from strive to put an end to the misdeed that be the ultimate cause of the suffering and as a means to this end where possible to punish those responsible for they there may be honest difference of opinion as to many governmental policy but surely there can be no such difference as to the need of unflinche perseverance in the war against successful dishonesty in my message to the congress on december 5 1905 i said:"if the folly of man mar the general well being then those who be innocent of the folly will have to pay part of the penalty incur by those who be guilty of the folly a panic bring on by the speculative folly of part of the business community would hurt the whole business community but such stoppage of welfare though it might be severe would not be last in the long run the one vital factor in the permanent prosperity of the country be the high individual character of the average american worker the average american citizen no matter whether his work be mental or manual whether he be farmer or wage worker business man or professional man "in our industrial and social system the interest of all man be so closely intertwine that in the immense majority of case a straight deal man who by his efficiency by his ingenuity and industry benefit himself must also benefit other normally the man of great productive capacity who become rich by guide the labor of many other man do so by enable they to produce more than they could produce without his guidance and both he and they share in the benefit which come also to the public at large the superficial fact that the sharing may be unequal must never blind we to the underlying fact that there be this sharing and that the benefit come in some degree to each man concern normally the wageworker the man of small mean and the average consumer as well as the average producer be all alike help by make condition such that the man of exceptional business ability receive an exceptional reward for his ability something can be do by legislation to help the general prosperity but no such help of a permanently beneficial character can be give to the less able and less fortunate save as the result of a policy which shall inure to the advantage of all industrious and efficient people who act decently and this be only another way of say that any benefit which come to the less able and less fortunate must of necessity come even more to the more able and more fortunate if therefore the less fortunate man be move by envy of his more fortunate brother to strike at the condition under which they have both though unequally prosper the result will assuredly be that while damage may come to the one strike at it will visit with an even heavy load the one who strike the blow take as a whole we must all go up or go down together "yet while not merely admit but insist upon this it be also true that where there be no governmental restraint or supervision some of the exceptional man use their energy not in way that be for the common good but in way which tell against this common good the fortune amass through corporate organization be now so large and vest such power in those that wield they as to make it a matter of necessity to give to the sovereign that be to the government which represent the people as a whole some effective power of supervision over their corporate use in order to insure a healthy social and industrial life every big corporation should be hold responsible by and be accountable to some sovereign strong enough to control its conduct i be in no sense hostile to corporation this be an age of combination and any effort to prevent all combination will be not only useless but in the end vicious because of the contempt for law which the failure to enforce law inevitably produce we should moreover recognize in cordial and ample fashion the immense good effect by corporate agency in a country such as ours and the wealth of intellect energy and fidelity devote to their service and therefore normally to the service of the public by their officer and director the corporation have come to stay just as the trade union have come to stay each can do and have do great good each should be favor so long as it do good but each should be sharply check where it act against law and justice "the maker of our national constitution provide especially that the regulation of interstate commerce should come within the sphere of the general government the argument in favor of their take this stand be even then overwhelming but they be far strong to day in view of the enormous development of great business agency usually corporate in form experience have show conclusively that it be useless to try to get any adequate regulation and supervision of these great corporation by state action such regulation and supervision can only be effectively exercise by a sovereign whose jurisdiction be coextensive with the field of work of the corporation that be by the national government i believe that this regulation and supervision can be obtain by the enactment of law by the congress our steady aim should be by legislation cautiously and carefully undertake but resolutely persevere in to assert the sovereignty of the national government by affirmative action "this be only in form an innovation in substance it be merely a restoration for from the early time such regulation of industrial activity have be recognize in the action of the lawmaking body and all that i propose be to meet the change condition in such manner as will prevent the commonwealth abdicate the power it have always possess not only in this country but also in england before and since this country become a separate nation "it have be a misfortune that the national law on this subject have hitherto be of a negative or prohibitive rather than an affirmative kind and still more that they have in part seek to prohibit what could not be effectively prohibit and have in part in their prohibition confound what should be allow and what should not be allow it be generally useless to try to prohibit all restraint on competition whether this restraint be reasonable or unreasonable and where it be not useless it be generally hurtful the successful prosecution of one device to evade the law immediately develop another device to accomplish the same purpose what be need be not sweep prohibition of every arrangement good or bad which may tend to restrict competition but such adequate supervision and regulation as will prevent any restriction of competition from be to the detriment of the public as well as such supervision and regulation as will prevent other abuse in no way connect with restriction of competition "i have call your attention in these quotation to what i have already say because i be satisfied that it be the duty of the national government to embody in action the principle thus express no small part of the trouble that we have come from carry to an extreme the national virtue of self reliance of independence in initiative and action it be wise to conserve this virtue and to provide for its full exercise compatible with see that liberty do not become a liberty to wrong other unfortunately this be the kind of liberty that the lack of all effective regulation inevitably breed founder of the constitution provide that the national government should have complete and sole control of interstate commerce there be then practically no interstate business save such as be conduct by water and this the national government at once proceed to regulate in thoroughgoe and effective fashion condition have now so wholly change that the interstate commerce by water be insignificant compare with the amount that go by land and almost all big business concern be now engage in interstate commerce as a result it can be but partially and imperfectly control or regulate by the action of any one of the several states such action inevitably tend to be either too drastic or else too lax and in either case ineffective for purpose of justice only the national government can in thoroughgoe fashion exercise the need control this do not mean that there should be any extension of federal authority for such authority already exist under the constitution in amplest and most far reach form but it do mean that there should be an extension of federal activity this be not advocate centralization it be merely look fact in the face and realize that centralization in business have already come and can not be avoid or undo and that the public at large can only protect itself from certain evil effect of this business centralization by provide well method for the exercise of control through the authority already centralize in the national government by the constitution itself there must be no ball in the healthy constructive course of action which this nation have elect to pursue and have steadily pursue during the last six year as show both in the legislation of the congress and the administration of the law by the department of justice the most vital need be in connection with the railroad as to these in my judgment there should now be either a national incorporation act or a law licensing railway company to engage in interstate commerce upon certain condition the law should be so frame as to give to the interstate commerce commission power to pass upon the future issue of security while ample mean should be provide to enable the commission whenever in its judgment it be necessary to make a physical valuation of any railroad as i state in my message to the congress a year ago railroad should be give power to enter into agreement subject to these argreement be make public in minute detail and to the consent of the interstate commerce commission be first obtain until the national government assume proper control of interstate commerce in the exercise of the authority it already possess it will be impossible either to give to or to get from the railroad full justice the railroad and all other great corporation will do well to recognize that this control must come the only question be as to what governmental body can most wisely exercise it the court will determine the limit within which the federal authority can exercise it and there will still remain ample work within each state for the railway commission of that state and the national interstate commerce commission will work in harmony with the several state commission each within its own province to achieve the desire end moreover in my judgment there should be additional legislation look to the proper control of the great business concern engage in interstate business this control to be exercise for their own benefit and prosperity no less than for the protection of investor and of the general public as i have repeatedly say in message to the congress and elsewhere experience have definitely show not merely the unwisdom but the futility of endeavor to put a stop to all business combination modern industrial condition be such that combination be not only necessary but inevitable it be so in the world of business just as it be so in the world of labor and it be as idle to desire to put an end to all corporation to all big combination of capital as to desire to put an end to combination of labor corporation and labor union alike have come to stay each if properly manage be a source of good and not evil whenever in either there be evil it should be promptly hold to account but it should receive hearty encouragement so long as it be properly manage it be profoundly grain enter into interstate and foreign commerce as a remedy for the present evil the conservation of our natural resource and their proper use constitute the fundamental problem which underlie almost arbitration fail to comply with the award render "it be far agree that arbitration here contemplate shall be in conformity as to procedure with chapter iii of the convention for the pacific settlement of international disputes adopt at the hague and that it shall determine in so far as there shall be no agreement between the party the justice and the amount of the debt the time and mode of payment thereof "such a provision would have prevent much injustice and extortion in the past and i can not doubt that its effect in the future will be most salutary a third advance have be make in amend and relation between the united states and germany involve an inquiry into certain of our method of administration which have be the cause of much complaint on the part of german exporter in this inquiry i become satisfied that certain vicious and unjustifiable practice have grow up in our custom administration notably the practice of determine value of import upon detective report never disclose to the person whose interest be affect the use of detective though often necessary tend towards abuse and should be carefully guard under our practice as i find it to exist in this case the abuse have become gross and discreditable under it instead of seek information as to the market value of merchandise from the well know and respected member of the commercial community in the country of its production secret statement be obtain from informer and discharged employee and business rival and upon this kind of secret evidence the value of import good be frequently raise and heavy penalty be frequently impose upon importer who be never permit to know what the evidence be and who never have an opportunity to meet it it be quite probable that this system tend towards an increase of the duty collect upon import good but i conceive it to be a violation of law to exact more duty than the law provide just as it be a violation to admit good upon the payment of less than the legal rate of duty this practice be repugnant to the spirit of american law and to american sense of justice in the judgment of the most competent expert of the treasury department and the department of commerce and labor it be wholly unnecessary for the due collection of the custom revenue and the attempt to defend it merely illustrate the demoralization which naturally follow from a long continued course of reliance upon such method i accordingly cause the regulation govern this branch of the custom service to be modify so that value be determine upon a hearing in which all the party interested have an opportunity to be hear and to know the evidence against they moreover our treasury agent be accredit to the government of the country in which they seek information and in germany receive the assistance of the quasi official chamber of commerce in determine the actual market value of good in accordance with what i be advise to be the true construction of the law these change of regulation be adapt to the removal of such manifest abuse that i have not feel that they ought to be confine to our relation with germany and i have extend their operation to all other country which have express a desire to enter into similar administrative relation i ask for authority to reform the agreement with china under which the indemnity of 1900 be fix by remit and cancel the obligation of china for
