to the senate and house of representatives
 i withhold from my annual message a discussion of need legislation under the authority which congress have to regulate commerce between the states and with foreign country and say that i would bring this subject matter to your attention later in the session accordingly i beg to submit to you certain recommendation as to the amendment to the interstate commerce law and certain consideration arise out of the operation of the antitrust law suggest the wisdom of federal incorporation of industrial company
 interstate commerce law
 in the annual report of the interstate commerce commission for the year 1908 attention be call to the fact that between july 1 1908 and the close of that year sixteen suit have be begin to set aside order of the commission besides one commence before that date and that few order of much consequence have be permit to go without protest that the question present by these various suit be fundamental as the constitutionality of the act itself be in issue and the right of congress to delegate to any tribunal authority to establish an interstate rate be deny but that perhaps the most serious practical question raise concerned the extent of the right of the court to review the order of the commission and it be point out that if the contention of the carrier in this latter respect alone be sustain but little progress have be make in the hepburn act toward the effective regulation of interstate transportation charge in twelve of the case refer to it be state preliminary injunction be pray for be grant in six and refuse in six
 it have from the first be well understand say the commission that the success of the present act as a regulating measure depend largely upon the facility with which temporary injunction could be obtain if a railroad company by mere allegation in its bill of complaint support by ex parte affidavit can overturn the result of day of patient investigation no very satisfactory result can be expect the railroad lose nothing by these proceeding since if they fail it can only be require to establish the rate and to pay to shipper the difference between the high rate collect and the rate which be finally hold to be reasonable in point of fact it usually profit because it can seldom be require to return more than a fraction of the excess charge collect
 in its report for the year 1909 the commission show that of the seventeen case refer to in its 1908 report only one have be decide in the supreme court of the united states although five other case have be argue and submit to that tribunal in october 1909
 of course every carrier affect by an order of the commission have a constitutional right to appeal to a federal court to protect it from the enforcement of an order which it may show to be prima facie confiscatory or unjustly discriminatory in its effect and as this application may be make to a court in any district of the united states not only do delay result in the enforcement of the order but great uncertainty be cause by contrariety of decision the question present by these application be too often technical in their character and require a knowledge of the business and the mastery of a great volume of conflicting evidence which be tedious to examine and troublesome to comprehend it would not be proper to attempt to deprive any corporation of the right to the review by a court of any order or decree which if undisturbed would rob it of a reasonable return upon its investment or would subject it to burden which would unjustly discriminate against it and in favor of other carrier similarly situate what be however of supreme importance be that the decision of such question shall be as speedy as the nature of the circumstance will admit and that a uniformity of decision be secure so as to bring about an effective systematic and scientific enforcement of the commerce law rather than conflict decision and uncertainty of final result
 for this purpose i recommend the establishment of a court of the united states compose of five judge designate for such purpose from among the circuit judge of the united states to be know as the united states court of commerce which court shall be clothe with exclusive original jurisdiction over the following class of case
 1 all case for the enforcement otherwise than by adjudication and collection of a forfeiture or penalty or by infliction of criminal punishment of any order of the interstate commerce commission other than for the payment of money
 2 all case bring to enjoin set aside annul or suspend any order or requirement of the interstate commerce commission
 3 all such case as under section 3 of the act of february 19 1903 know as the elkins act be authorize to be maintain in a circuit court of the united states
 4 all such mandamus proceeding as under the provision of section 20 or section 23 of the interstate commerce law be authorize to be maintain in a circuit court of the united states
 reason precisely analogous to those which induce the congress to create the court of customs appeals by the provision in the tariff act of august 5 1909 may be urge in support of the creation of the commerce court
 in order to provide a sufficient number of judge to enable this court to be constitute it will be necessary to authorize the appointment of five additional circuit judge who for the purpose of appointment might be distribute to those circuit where there be at the present time the large volume of business such as the second third fourth seventh and eighth circuit the act should empower the chief justice at any time when the business of the court of commerce do not require the service of all the judge to reassign the judge designate to that court to the circuit to which they respectively belong and it should also provide for payment to such judge while sit by assignment in the court of commerce of such additional amount as be necessary to bring their annual compensation up to $ 10,000
 the regular session of such court should be hold at the capital but it should be empower to hold session in different part of the united states if find desirable and its order and judgment should be make final subject only to review by the supreme court of the united states with the provision that the operation of the decree appeal from shall not be stay unless the supreme court shall so order the commerce court should be empower in its discretion to restrain or suspend the operation of an order of the interstate commerce commission under review pende the final hearing and determination of the proceeding but no such restraining order should be make except upon notice and after hearing unless in case where irreparable damage would otherwise ensue to the petitioner a judge of that court might be empower to allow a stay of the commission&#39; order for a period of not more than sixty day but pende application to the court for its order or injunction then only where his order shall contain a specific finding base upon evidence submit to the judge make the order and identify by reference thereto that such irreparable damage would result to the petitioner specify the nature of the damage
 under the exist law the interstate commerce commission itself initiate and defend litigation in the court for the enforcement or in the defense of its order and decree and for this purpose it employ attorney who while subject to the control of the attorney general act upon the initiative and under the instruction of the commission this blending of administrative legislative and judicial function tend in my opinion to impair the efficiency of the commission by clothe it with partisan characteristic and rob it of the impartial judicial attitude it should occupy in pass upon question submit to it in my opinion all litigation affect the government should be under the direct control of the department of justice and i therefore recommend that all proceeding affect order and decree of the interstate commerce commission be bring by or against the united states eo nomine and be place in charge of an assistant attorney general act under the direction of the attorney general
 the subject of agreement between carrier with respect to rate have be often discuss in congress pool arrangement and agreement be condemn by the general sentiment of the people and under the sherman antitrust law any agreement between carrier operate in restraint of interstate or international trade or commerce would be unlawful the republican platform of 1908 express the belief that the interstate commerce law should be far amend so as to give the railroad the right to make and publish traffic agreement subject to the approval of the commission but maintain always the principle of competition between naturally compete line and avoid the common control of such line by any mean whatsoever in view of the complete control over rate making and other practice of interstate carrier establish by the act of congress and as recommend in this communication i see no reason why agreement between carrier subject to the act specify the classification of freight and the rate fare and charge for transportation of passenger and freight which they may agree to establish should not be permit provide copy of such agreement be promptly file with the commission but subject to all the provision of the interstate commerce act subject to the right of any party to such agreement to cancel it as to all or any of the agree rate fare charge or classification by thirty days&#39 notice in write to the other party and to the commission
 much complaint be make by shipper over the state of the law under which they be hold bind to know the legal rate applicable to any propose shipment without as a matter of fact have any certain mean of actually ascertain such rate it have be suggest that to meet this grievance carrier should be require upon application by a shipper to quote the legal rate in writing and that the shipper should be protect in act upon the rate thus quote but the objection to this suggestion be that it would afford a much too easy method of give to favor shipper unreasonable preference and rebate i think that the law should provide that a carrier upon write request by an intend shipper should quote in write the rate or charge applicable to the propose shipment under any schedule or tariff to which such carrier be a party and that if the party make such request shall suffer damage in consequence of either refusal or omission to quote the proper rate or in consequence of a misstatement of the rate the carrier shall be liable to a penalty in some reasonable amount say two hundred and fifty dollar to accrue to the united states and to be recover in a civil action bring by the appropriate district attorney such a penalty would compel the agent of the carrier to exercise due diligence in quote the applicable legal rate and would thus afford the shipper a real measure of protection while not open the way to collusion and the giving of rebate or other unfair discrimination
 under the exist law the commission can only act with respect to an alleged excessive rate or unduly discriminatory practice by a carrier on a complaint make by some individual affect thereby i see no reason why the commission should not be authorize to act on its own initiative as well as upon the complaint of an individual in investigate the fairness of any exist rate or practice and i recommend the amendment of the law to so provide and also that the commission shall be fully empower beyond any question to pass upon the classification of commodity for purpose of fix rate in like manner as it may now do with respect to the maximum rate applicable to any transportation
 under the exist law the commission may not investigate an increase in rate until after it shall have become effective and although one or more carrier may file with the commission a propose increase in rate or change in classification or other alteration of the exist rate or classification to become effective at the expiration of thirty day from such filing no proceeding can be take to investigate the reasonableness of such propose change until after it become operative on the other hand if the commission shall make an order find that an exist rate be excessive and direct it to be reduce the carrier affect may by proceeding in the court stay the operation of such order of reduction for month and even year it have therefore be suggest that the commission should be empower whenever a propose increase in rate be file at once to enter upon an investigation of the reasonableness of the increase and to make an order postpone the effective date of such increase until after such investigation shall be complete to this much objection have be make on the part of carrier they contend that this would be in effect to take from the owner of the railroad the management of their property and to clothe the interstate commerce commission with the original rate make power a policy which be much discuss at the time of the passage of the hepburn act in 1905 6 and which be then and have always be distinctly reject and in reply to the suggestion that they be able by resort to the court to stay the take effect of the order of the commission until its reasonableness shall have be investigate by the court whereas the people be deprive of any such remedy with respect to action by the carrier they point to the provision of the interstate commerce act provide for restitution to the shipper by carrier of excessive rate charge in case where the order of the commission reduce such rate be affirm it may be doubt how effective this remedy really be experience have show that many perhaps most shipper do not resort to proceeding to recover the excessive rate which they may have be require to pay for the simple reason that they have add the rate pay to the cost of the good and thus enhance the price thereof to their customer and that the public have in effect pay the bill on the other hand the enormous volume of transportation charge the great number of separate tariff file annually with the interstate commerce commission amount to almost 200,000 and the impossibility of any commission supervise the making of tariff in advance of their become effective on every transportation line within the united states to the extent that would be necessary if their active concurrence be require in the making of every tariff have satisfy i that this power if grant should be confer in a very limited and restricted form i therefore recommend that the interstate commerce commission be empower whenever any propose increase of rate be file at once either on complaint or of its own motion to enter upon an investigation into the reasonableness of such change and that it be far empower in its discretion to postpone the effective date of such propose increase for a period not exceed sixty day beyond the date when such rate would take effect if within this time it shall determine that such increase be unreasonable it may then by its order either forbid the increase at all or fix the maximum beyond which it shall not be make if on the other hand at the expiration of this time the commission shall not have complete its investigation then the rate shall take effect precisely as it would under the exist law and the commission may continue its investigation with such result as might be realize under the law as it now stand
 the claim be very earnestly advanced by some large association of shipper that shipper of freight should be empower to direct the route over which their shipment should pass to destination and in this connection it have be urge that the provision of section 15 of the interstate commerce act which now empower the commission after hear on complaint to establish through route and maximum joint rate to be charge etc when no reasonable or satisfactory through route shall have be already establish be amend so as to empower the commission to take such action even when one exist reasonable and satisfactory route already exist if it be possible to establish additional route this seem to i to be a reasonable provision i know of no reason why a shipper should not have the right to elect between two or more establish through route to which the initial carrier may be a party and to require his shipment to be transport to destination over such of such route as he may designate for that purpose subject however in the exercise of this right to such reasonable regulation as the interstate commerce commission may prescribe
 the republican platform of 1908 declare in favor of amend the interstate commerce law but so as always to maintain the principle of competition between naturally compete line and avoid the common control of such line by any mean whatsover one of the most potent mean of exercise such control have be through the holding of stock of one railroad company by another company own a compete line this condition have grow up under express legislative power confer by the law of many states and to attempt now to suddenly reverse that policy so far as it affect the ownership of stock heretofore so acquire would be to inflict a grievous injury not only upon the corporation affect but upon a large body of the investment hold public i however recommend that the law shall be amend so as to provide that from and after the date of its passage no railroad company subject to the interstate commerce act shall directly or indirectly acquire any interest of any kind in capital stock or purchase or lease any railroad of any other corporation which compete with it respect business to which the interstate commerce act apply but especially for the protection of the minority stockholder in securing to they the good market for their stock i recommend that such prohibition be couple with a proviso that it shall not operate to prevent any corporation which at the date of the passage of such act shall own not less than one half of the entire issue and outstanding capital stock of any other railroad company from acquire all or the remainder of such stock nor to prohibit any railroad company which at the date of the enactment of the law be operate a railroad of any other corporation under lease execute for a term of not less than twenty five year from acquire the reversionary ownership of the demise railroad but that such provision shall not operate to authorize or validate the acquisition through stock ownership or otherwise of a compete line or interest therein in violation of the antitrust or any other law
 the republican platform of 1908 far declare in favor of such national legislation and supervision as will prevent the future over issue of stock and bond by interstate carrier and in order to carry out its provision i recommend the enactment of a law provide that no railroad corporation subject to the interstate commerce act shall hereafter for any purpose connect with or relate to any part of its business govern by say act issue any capital stock without previous or simultaneous payment to it of not less than the par value of such stock or any bond or other obligation except note mature not more than one year from the date of their issue without the previous or simultaneous payment to such corporation of not less than the par value of such bond or other obligation or if issue at less than their par value then not without such payment of the reasonable market value of such bond or obligation as ascertain by the interstate commerce commission and that no property service or other thing than money shall be take in payment to such carrier corporation of the par or other require price of such stock bond or other obligation except at the fair value of such property service or other thing as ascertain by the commission and that such act shall also contain provision to prevent the abuse by the improvident or improper issue of note mature at a period not exceed twelve month from date in such manner as to commit the commission to the approval of a large amount of stock or bond in order to retire such note than should legitimately have be require
 such act should also provide for the approval by the interstate commerce commission of the amount of stock and bond to be issue by any railroad company subject to this act upon any reorganization pursuant to judicial sale or other legal proceeding in order to prevent the issue of stock and bond to an amount in excess of the fair value of the property which be the subject of such reorganization
 i believe these suggest modification in and amendment to the interstate commerce act would make it a complete and effective measure for secure reasonableness of rate and fairness of practice in the operation of interstate railroad line without undue preference to any individual or class over any other and would prevent the recurrence of many of the practice which have give rise in the past to so much public inconvenience and loss
 by my direction the attorney general have draft a bill to carry out these recommendation which will be furnish upon request to the appropriate committee whenever it may be desire
 in addition to the foregoing amendment of the interstate commerce law the interstate commerce commission should be give the power after a hearing to determine upon the uniform construction of those appliance such as sill step ladder roof hand hold running board and hand brake on freight car engage in interstate commerce use by the train man in the operation of train the defect and lack of uniformity in which be apt to produce accident and injury to railway train man the wonderful reform effect in the number of switchman and train man injure by couple accident due to the enforce introduction of safety coupler be a demonstration of what can be do if railroad be compel to adopt proper safety appliance
 the question have arise in the operation of the interstate commerce employer&#39;s liability act as to whether suit can be bring against the employer company in any place other than that of its home office the right to bring the suit under this act should be as easy of enforcement as the right of a private person not in the company&#39; employ to sue on an ordinary claim and process in such suit should be sufficiently serve if upon the station agent of the company upon whom service be authorize to be make to bind the company in ordinary action arise under state law bill for both the forego purpose have be consider by the house of representatives and have be pass and be now before the interstate commerce committee of the senate i earnestly urge that they be enact into law
 antitrust law and federal incorporation
 there have be a marked tendency in business in this country for forty year last past toward combination of capital and plant in manufacture sale and transportation the move cause have be several first it have render possible great economy second by a union of former competitor it have reduce the probability of excessive competition and third if the combination have be extensive enough and certain method in the treatment of competitor and customer have be adopt the combiner have secure a monopoly and complete control of price or rate
 a combination successful in achieve complete control over a particular line of manufacture have frequently be call a trust i presume that the derivation of the word be to be explain by the fact that a usual method of carry out the plan of the combination have be to put the capital and plant of various individual firm or corporation engage in the same business under the control of trustee
 the increase in the capital of a business for the purpose of reduce the cost of production and effecting economy in the management have become as essential in modern progress as the change from the hand tool to the machine when therefore we come to construe the object of congress in adopt the so call sherman anti trust act in 1890 whereby in the first section every contract combination in the form of a trust or otherwise or conspiracy in restraint of interstate or foreign trade or commerce be condemn as unlawful and make subject to indictment and restraint by injunction and whereby in the second section every monopoly or attempt to monopolize and every combination or conspiracy with other person to monopolize any part of interstate trade or commerce be denounce as illegal and make subject to similar punishment or restraint we must infer that the evil aim at be not the mere bigness of the enterprise but it be the aggregation of capital and plant with the express or imply intent to restrain interstate or foreign commerce or to monopolize it in whole or in part
 monopoly destroy competition utterly and restraint of the full and free operation of competition have a tendency to restrain commerce and trade a combination of person formerly engage in trade as partnership or corporation or otherwise of course eliminate the competition that exist between they but the incidental ending of that competition be not to be regard as necessarily a direct restraint of trade unless of such an all embrace character that the intention and effect to restrain trade be apparent from the circumstance or be expressly declare to be the object of the combination a mere incidental restraint of trade and competition be not within the inhibition of the act but it be where the combination or conspiracy or contract be inevitably and directly a substantial restraint of competition and so a restraint of trade that the statute be violate
 the second section of the act be a supplement to the first a direct restraint of trade such as be condemn in the first section if successful and use to suppress competition be one of the commonest method of secure a trade monopoly condemn in the second section
 it be possible for the owner of a business of manufacturing and sell useful article of merchandise so to conduct their business as not to violate the inhibition of the antitrust law and yet to secure to themselves the benefit of the economy of management and of production due to the concentration under one control of large capital and many plant if they use no other inducement than the constant low price of their product and its good quality to attract custom and their business be a profitable one they violate no law if their actual competitor be small in comparison with the total capital invest the prospect of new investment of capital by other in such a profitable business be sufficiently near and potential to restrain they in the price at which they sell their product but if they attempt by a use of their preponderate capital and by a sale of their good temporarily at unduly low price to drive out of business their competitor or if they attempt by exclusive contract with their patron and threat of nondeale except upon such contract or by other method of a similar character to use the largeness of their resource and the extent of their output compare with the total output as a means of compelling custom and frightening off competition then they disclose a purpose to restrain trade and to establish a monopoly and violate the act
 the object of the antitrust law be to suppress the abuse of business of the kind describe it be not to interfere with a great volume of capital which concentrate under one organization reduce the cost of production and make its profit thereby and take no advantage of its size by method akin to duress to stifle competition with it
 i wish to make this distinction as emphatic as possible because i conceive that nothing could happen more destructive to the prosperity of this country than the loss of that great economy in production which have be and will be effect in all manufacturing line by the employment of large capital under one management i do not mean to say that there be not a limit beyond which the economy of management by the enlargement of plant cease and where this happen and combination continue beyond this point the very fact show intent to monopolize and not to economize
 the original purpose of many combination of capital in this country be not confine to the legitimate and proper object of reduce the cost of production on the contrary the history of most trade will show at time a feverish desire to unite by purchase combination or otherwise all plant in the country engage in the manufacture of a particular line of good the idea be rife that thereby a monopoly could be effect and a control of price bring about which would inure to the profit of those engage in the combination the path of commerce be strew with failure of such combination their projector find that the union of all the plant do not prevent competition especially where proper economy have not be pursue in the purchase and in the conduct of the business after the aggregation be complete there be enough however of such successful combination to arouse the fear of good patriotic man as to the result of a continuance of this movement toward the concentration in the hand of a few of the absolute control of the price of all manufacture product
 the antitrust statute be pass in 1890 and prosecution be soon begin under it in the case of the united states v knight know as the sugar trust case because of the narrow scope of the pleading the combination seek to be enjoin be hold not to be include within the prohibition of the act because the averment do not go beyond the mere acquisition of manufacture plant for the refining of sugar and do not include that of a direct and intended restraint upon trade and commerce in the sale and delivery of sugar across state boundary and in foreign trade the result of the sugar trust case be not happy in that it give other company and combination seek a similar method of make profit by establish an absolute control and monopoly in a particular line of manufacture a sense of immunity against prosecution in the federal jurisdiction and where that jurisdiction be bar in respect to a business which be necessarily commensurate with the boundary of the country no state prosecution be able to supply the need machinery for adequate restraint or punishment
 follow the sugar trust decision however there have come along in the slow but certain course of judicial disposition case involve a construction of the antitrust statute and its application until now they seem to embrace every phase of that law which can be practically present to the american public and to the government for action they show that the antitrust act have a wide scope and apply to many combination in actual operation render they unlawful and subject to indictment and restraint
 the supreme court in several of its decision have decline to read into the statute the word unreasonable before restraint of trade on the ground that the statute apply to all restraint and do not intend to leave to the court the discretion to determine what be a reasonable restraint of trade the expression restraint of trade come from the common law and at common law there be certain covenant incidental to the carrying out of a main or principal contract which be say to be covenant in partial restraint of trade and be hold to be enforcible because reasonably adapt to the performance of the main or principal contract and under the general language use by the supreme court in several case it would seem that even such incidental covenant in restraint of interstate trade be within the inhibition of the statute and must be condemn in order to avoid such a result i have think and say that it might be well to amend the statute so as to exclude such covenant from its condemnation a close examination of the later decision of the court however show quite clearly in case present the exact question that such incidental restraint of trade be hold not to be within the law and be exclude by the general statement that to be within the statute the effect of the restraint upon the trade must be direct and not merely incidental or indirect the necessity therefore for an amendment of the statute so as to exclude these incidental and beneficial covenant in restraint of trade hold at common law to be reasonable do not exist
 in some of the opinion of the federal circuit judge there have be intimation have the effect if sound to weaken the force of the statute by include within it absurdly unimportant combination and arrangement and suggest therefore the wisdom of change its language by limit its application to serious combination with intent to restrain competition or control price a reading of the opinion of the supreme court however make the change unnecessary for they exclude from the operation of the act contract affect interstate trade in but a small and incidental way and apply the statute only to the real evil aim at by congress
 the statute have be on the statute book now for two decade and the supreme court in more than a dozen opinion have construe it in application to various phase of business combination and in reference to various subject matter it have apply it to the union under one control of two compete interstate railroad to joint traffic arrangement between several interstate railroad to private manufacturer engage in a plain attempt to control price and suppress competition in a part of the country include a dozen states and to many other combination affect interstate trade the value of a statute which be render more and more certain in its meaning by a series of decision of the supreme court furnish a strong reason for leave the act as it be to accomplish its useful purpose even though if it be be newly enact useful suggestion as to change of phrase might be make
 it be the duty and the purpose of the executive to direct an investigation by the department of justice through the grand jury or otherwise into the history organization and purpose of all the industrial company with respect to which there be any reasonable ground for suspicion that they have be organize for a purpose and be conduct business on a plan which be in violation of the antitrust law the work be a heavy one but it be not beyond the power of the department of justice if sufficient fund be furnish to carry on the investigation and to pay the counsel engage in the work but such an investigation and possible prosecution of corporation whose prosperity or destruction affect the comfort not only of stockholder but of million of wage earner employee and associate tradesman must necessarily tend to disturb the confidence of the business community to dry up the now flow source of capital from its place of hoarding and produce a halt in our present prosperity that will cause suffering and strained circumstance among the innocent many for the fault of the guilty few the question which i wish in this message to bring clearly to the consideration and discussion of congress be whether in order to avoid such a possible business danger something can not be do by which these business combination may be offer a mean without great financial disturbance of change the character organization and extent of their business into one within the line of the law under federal control and supervision secure compliance with the antitrust statute
 generally in the industrial combination call trust the principal business be the sale of good in many state and in foreign market in other word the interstate and foreign business far exceed the business do in any one state this fact will justify the federal government in grant a federal charter to such a combination to make and sell in interstate and foreign commerce the product of useful manufacture under such limitation as will secure a compliance with the antitrust law it be possible so to frame a statute that while it offer protection to a federal company against harmful vexatious and unnecessary invasion by the states it shall subject it to reasonable taxation and control by the states with respect to its purely local business
 many people conduct great business have cherish a hope and a belief that in some way or other a line may be draw between good trust and bad trust and that it be possible by amendment to the antitrust law to make a distinction under which good combination may be permit to organize suppress competition control price and do it all legally if only they do not abuse the power by take too great profit out of the business they point with force to certain notorious trust as having grow into power through criminal method by the use of illegal rebate and plain cheating and by various act utterly violative of business honesty or morality and urge the establishment of some legal line of separation by which criminal trust of this kind can be punish and they on the other hand be permit under the law to carry on their business now the public and especially the business public ought to rid themselves of the idea that such a distinction be practicable or can be introduce into the statute certainly under the present antitrust law no such distinction exist it have be propose however that the word reasonable should be make a part of the statute and then that it should be leave to the court to say what be a reasonable restraint of trade what be a reasonable suppression of competition what be a reasonable monopoly i venture to think that this be to put into the hand of the court a power impossible to exercise on any consistent principle which will insure the uniformity of decision essential to just judgment it be to thrust upon the court a burden that they have no precedent to enable they to carry and to give they a power approach the arbitrary the abuse of which might involve our whole judicial system in disaster
 in consider violation of the antitrust law we ought of course not to forget that that law make unlawful method of carry on business which before its passage be regard as evidence of business sagacity and success and that they be denounce in this act not because of their intrinsic immorality but because of the dangerous result toward which they tend the concentration of industrial power in the hand of the few lead to oppression and injustice in deal therefore with many of the man who have use the method condemn by the statute for the purpose of maintain a profitable business we may well facilitate a change by they in the method of do business and enable they to bring it back into the zone of lawfulness without lose to the country the economy of management by which in our domestic trade the cost of production have be materially lessen and in competition with foreign manufacturer our foreign trade have be greatly increase
 through all our consideration of this grave question however we must insist that the suppression of competition the controlling of price and the monopoly or attempt to monopolize in interstate commerce and business be not only unlawful but contrary to the public good and that they must be restrain and punish until end
 i therefore recommend the enactment by congress of a general law provide for the formation of corporation to engage in trade and commerce among the states and with foreign nation protect they from undue interference by the states and regulate their activity so as to prevent the recurrence under national auspex of those abuse which have arise under state control such a law should provide for the issue of stock of such corporation to an amount equal only to the cash pay in on the stock and if the stock be issue for property then at a fair valuation ascertain under approval and supervision of federal authority after a full and complete disclosure of all the fact pertain to the value of such property and the interest therein of the person to whom it be propose to issue stock in payment of such property it should subject the real and personal property only of such corporation to the same taxation as be impose by the states within which it may be situate upon other similar property locate therein and it should require such corporation to file full and complete report of their operation with the department of commerce and labor at regular interval corporation organize under this act should be prohibit from acquire and hold stock in other corporation except for special reason upon approval by the proper federal authority thus avoid the creation under national auspex of the hold company with subordinate corporation in different states which have be such an effective agency in the creation of the great trust and monopoly
 if the prohibition of the antitrust act against combination in restraint of trade be to be effectively enforce it be essential that the national government shall provide for the creation of national corporation to carry on a legitimate business throughout the united states the conflict law of the different states of the union with respect to foreign corporation make it difficult if not impossible for one corporation to comply with their requirement so as to carry on business in a number of different states
 to the suggestion that this proposal of federal incorporation for industrial combination be intend to furnish they a refuge in which to continue industrial abuse under federal protection it should be say that the measure contemplate do not repeal the sherman antitrust law and be not to be frame so as to permit the doing of the wrong which it be the purpose of that law to prevent but only to foster a continuance and advance of the high industrial efficiency without permit industrial abuse
 such a national incorporation law will be oppose first by those who believe that trust should be completely break up and their property destroy it will be oppose second by those who doubt the constitutionality of such federal incorporation and even if it be valid object to it as too great federal centralization it will be opposed third by those who will insist that a mere voluntary incorporation like this will not attract to its acceptance the bad of the offender against the antitrust statute and who will therefore propose instead of it a system of compulsory license for all federal corporation engage in interstate business
 let we consider these objection in their order the government be now try to dissolve some of these combination and it be not the intention of the government to desist in the least degree in its effort to end those combination which be to day monopolize the commerce of this country that where it appear that the acquisition and concentration of property go to the extent of create a monopoly or of substantially and directly restrain interstate commerce it be not the intention of the government to permit this monopoly to exist under federal incorporation or to transfer to the protect wing of the federal government a state corporation now violate the sherman act but it be not and should not be the policy of the government to prevent reasonable concentration of capital which be necessary to the economic development of manufacture trade and commerce this country have show a power of economical production that have astonish the world and have enable we to compete with foreign manufacture in many market it should be the care of the government to permit such concentration of capital while keep open the avenue of individual enterprise and the opportunity for a man or corporation with reasonable capital to engage in business if we would maintain our present business supremacy we should give to industrial concern an opportunity to reorganize and to concentrate their legitimate capital in a federal corporation and to carry on their large business within the line of the law
 second there be those who doubt the constitutionality of such federal incorporation the regulation of interstate and foreign commerce be certainly confer in the full measure upon congress and if for the purpose of securing in the most thorough manner that kind of regulation congress shall insist that it may provide and authorize certain agency to carry on that commerce it would seem to be within its power this have be distinctly affirm with respect to railroad company do an interstate business and interstate bridge the power of incorporation have be exercise by congress and uphold by the supreme court in this regard why then with respect to any other form of interstate commerce like the sale of good across state boundary and into foreign commerce may the same power not be assert indeed it be the very fact that they carry on interstate commerce that make these great industrial concern subject to federal prosecution and control how far as incidental to the carrying on of that commerce it may be within the power of the federal government to authorize the manufacture of good be perhaps more open to discussion though a recent decision of the supreme court would seem to answer that question in the affirmative
 even those who be willing to concede that the supreme court may sustain such federal incorporation be inclined to oppose it on the ground of its tendency to the enlargement of the federal power at the expense of the power of the states it be a sufficient answer to this argument to say that no other method can be suggest which offer federal protection on the one hand and close federal supervision on the other of these great organization that be in fact federal because they be as wide as the country and be entirely unlimited in their business by state line nor be the centralization of federal power under this act likely to be excessive only the large corporation would avail themselves of such a law because the burden of complete federal supervision and control that must certainly be impose to accomplish the purpose of the incorporation would not be accept by an ordinary business concern
 the third objection that the bad offender will not accept federal incorporation be easily answer the decree of injunction recently adopt in prosecution under the antitrust law be so thorough and sweeping that the corporation affect by they have but three course before they
 first they must resolve themselves into their component part in the different states with a consequent loss to themselves of capital and effective organization and to the country of concentrated energy and enterprise or
 second in defiance of law and under some secret trust they must attempt to continue their business in violation of the federal statute and thus incur the penalty of contempt and bring on an inevitable criminal prosecution of the individual name in the decree and their associate or
 third they must reorganize and accept in good faith the federal charter i suggest
 a federal compulsory license law urge as a substitute for a federal incorporation law be unnecessary except to reach that kind of corporation which by virtue of the consideration already advance will take advantage voluntarily of an incorporation law while the other state corporation do an interstate business do not need the supervision or the regulation of a federal license and would only be unnecessarily burden thereby
 the attorney general at my suggestion have draft a federal incorporation bill embody the view i have attempt to set forth and it will be at the disposition of the appropriate committee of congress

to the senate and house of representatives
 in my annual message i reserve the subject of the conservation of our national resource for discussion in a special message as follow
 in several department there be present the necessity for legislation look to the further conservation of our national resource and the subject be one of such importance as to require a more detailed and extended discussion than can be enter upon in this communication for that reason i shall take an early opportunity to send a special message to congress on the subject of the improvement of our waterway upon the reclamation and irrigation of arid semiarid and swamp land upon the preservation of our forest and the reforesting of suitable area upon the reclassification of the public domain with a view of separate from agricultural settlement mineral coal and phosphate land and site belong to the government border on stream suitable for the utilization of water power
 in 1860 we have a public domain of 1,055,911,288 acre we have now 731,354,081 acre confine largely to the mountain range and the arid and semiarid plain we have in addition 368,035,975 acre of land in alaska
 the public land be during the early administration treat as a national asset for the liquidation of the public debt and as a source of reward for our soldier and sailor later on they be donate in large amount in aid of the construction of wagon road and railway in order to open up region in the west then almost inaccessible all the principal land statute be enact more than a quarter of a century ago the homestead act the preemption and timber culture act the coal land and the mining act be among these the rapid disposition of the public land under the early statute and the lax method of distribution prevail due i think to the belief that these land should rapidly pass into private ownership give rise to the impression that the public domain be legitimate prey for the unscrupulous and that it be not contrary to good moral to circumvent the land law this prodigal manner of disposition result in the passing of large area of valuable land and many of our national resource into the hand of person who feel little or no responsibility for promote the national welfare through their development the truth be that title to million of acre of public land be fraudulently obtain and that the right to recover a large part of such land for the government long since cease by reason of statute of limitation
 there have develop in recent year a deep concern in the public mind respect the preservation and proper use of our national resource this have be particularly direct toward the conservation of the resource of the public domain the problem be how to save and how to utilize how to conserve and still develop for no sane person can contend that it be for the common good that nature&#39;s blessing be only for unborn generation
 among the most noteworthy reform initiate by my distinguished predecessor be the vigorous prosecution of land fraud and the bringing to public attention of the necessity for preserve the remain public domain from further spoliation for the maintenance and extension of our forest resource and for the enactment of law amend the obsolete statute so as to retain governmental control over that part of the public domain in which there be valuable deposit of coal of oil and of phosphate and in addition thereto to preserve control under condition favorable to the public of the land along the stream in which the fall of water can be make to generate power to be transmit in the form of electricity many mile to the point of its use know as water power site
 the investigation into violation of the public land law and the prosecution of land fraud have be vigorously continue under my administration as have be the withdrawal of coal land for classification and valuation and the temporary withholding of power site
 since march 4 1909 temporary withdrawal of power site have be make on 102 stream and these withdrawal therefore cover 229 per cent more stream than be cover by the withdrawal make prior to that date
 the present statute except so far as they dispose of the precious metal and the purely agricultural land be not adapt to carry out the modern view of the good disposition of public land to private ownership under condition offer on the one hand sufficient inducement to private capital to take they over for proper development with restrictive condition on the other which shall secure to the public that character of control which will prevent a monopoly or misuse of the land or their product the power of the secretary of the interior to withdraw from the operation of exist statute tract of land the disposition of which under such statute would be detrimental to the public interest be not clear or satisfactory this power have be exercise in the interest of the public with the hope that congress might affirm the action of the executive by law adapt to the new condition unfortunately congress have not thus far fully act on the recommendation of the executive and the question as to what the executive be to do be under the circumstance full of difficulty it seem to i that it be the duty of congress now by a statute to validate the withdrawal which have be make by the secretary of the interior and the president and to authorize the secretary of the interior temporarily to withdraw land pende submission to congress of recommendation as to legislation to meet condition or emergency as they arise
 one of the most pressing need in the matter of public land reform be that land should be classify accord to their principal value or use this ought to be do by that department whose force be well adapt to that work it should be do by the interior department through the geological survey much of the confusion fraud and contention which have exist in the past have arise from the lack of an official and determinative classification of the public land and their content
 it be now propose to dispose of agricultural land as such and at the same time to reserve for other disposition the treasure of coal oil asphaltum natural gas and phosphate contain therein this may be well accomplish by separate the right to mine from the title to the surface give the necessary use of so much of the latter as may be require for the extraction of the deposit the surface might be dispose of as agricultural land under the general agricultural statute while the coal or other mineral could be dispose of by lease on a royalty basis with provision require a certain amount of development each year and in order to prevent the use and cession of such land with other of similar character so as to constitute a monopoly forbid by law the lease should contain suitable provision subject to forfeiture the interest of person participate in such monopoly such law should apply to alaska as well as to the united states
 it be exceedingly difficult to frame a statute to retain government control over a property to be develop by private capital in such manner as to secure the governmental purpose and at the same time not to frighten away the investment of the necessary capital hence it may be necessary by law that be really only experimental to determine from their practical operation what be the good method of secure the result aim at
 the extent of the value of phosphate be hardly realize and with the need that there will be for it as the year roll on and the necessity for fertilize the land shall become more acute this will be a product which will probably attract the greed of monopolist
 with respect to the public land which lie along the stream offer opportunity to convert water power into transmissible electricity another important phase of the public land question be present there be valuable water power site through all the public land states the opinion be hold that the transfer of sovereignty from the federal government to the territorial government as they become states include the water power in the river except so far as that own by riparian proprietor i do not think it necessary to go into a discussion of this somewhat moot question of law it seem to i sufficient to say that the man who own and control the land along the stream from which the power be to be convert and transmit own land which be indispensable to the conversion and use of that power i can not conceive how the power in stream flow through public land can be make available at all except by use the land itself as the site for the construction of the plant by which the power be generate and convert and secure a right of way thereover for transmission line under these condition if the government own the adjacent land indeed if the government be the riparian owner it may control the use of the water power by impose proper condition on the disposition of land necessary in the creation and utilization of the water power
 the development in electrical appliance for the conversion of the water power into electricity to be transmit long distance have progress so far that it be no long problematical but it be a certain inference that in the future the power of the water fall in the stream to a large extent will take the place of natural fuel in the disposition of that domain already grant many water power site have come under absolute ownership and may drift into one ownership so that all the water power under private ownership shall be a monopoly if however the water power site now own by the government and there be enough of they shall be dispose of to private person for the investment of their capital in such a way as to prevent their union for purpose of monopoly with other waterpower site and under condition that shall limit the right of use to not exceed fifty year with proper mean for determine a reasonable graduate rental and with some equitable provision for fix term of renewal it would seem entirely possible to prevent the absorption of these most useful land by a power monopoly as long as the government retain control and can prevent their improper union with other plant competition must be maintain and price keep reasonable
 in consider the conservation of the natural resource of the country the feature that transcend all other include wood water mineral be the soil of the country it be incumbent upon the government to foster by all available mean the resource of the country that produce the food of the people to this end the conservation of the soil of the country should be care for with all mean at the government&#39;s disposal their productive power should have the attention of our scientist that we may conserve the new soil improve the old soil drain wet soil ditch swamp soil levee river overflow soil grow tree on thin soil pasture hillside soil rotate crop on all soil discover method for crop dry land soil find grass and legume for all soil feed grain and mill feed on the farm where they originate that the soil from which they come may be enrich
 a work of the utmost importance to inform and instruct the public on this chief branch of the conservation of our resource be be carry on successfully in the department of agriculture but it ought not to escape public attention that state action in addition to that of the department of agriculture as for instance in the drainage of swamp land be essential to the good treatment of the soil in the manner above indicate
 the act by which in semiarid part of the public domain the area of the homestead have be enlarge from 160 to 320 acre have result most beneficially in the extension of dry farming and in the demonstration which have be make of the possibility through a variation in the character and mode of culture of raise substantial crop without the presence of such a supply of water as heretofore have be think to be necessary for agriculture
 but there be million of acre of completely arid land in the public domain which by the establishment of reservoir for the storing of water and the irrigation of the land may be make much more fruitful and productive than the good land in a climate where the moisture come from the cloud congress recognize the importance of this method of artificial distribution of water on the arid land by the passage of the reclamation act the proceed of the public land create the fund to build the work need to store and furnish the necessary water and it be leave to the secretary of the interior to determine what project should be select among those suggest and to direct the reclamation service with the fund at hand and through the engineer in its employ to construct the work
 no one can visit the far west and the country of arid and semiarid land without be convince that this be one of the most important method of the conservation of our natural resource that the government have enter upon it would appear that over 30 project have be undertake and that a few of these be likely to be unsuccessful because of lack of water or for other reason but generally the work which have be do have be well do and many important engineering problem have be meet and solve
 one of the difficulty which have arise be that too many project in view of the available fund have be set on foot the fund available under the reclamation statute be inadequate to complete these project within a reasonable time and yet the project have be begin settler have be invite to take up and in many instance have take up the public land within the project rely upon their prompt completion the failure to complete the project for their benefit be in effect a breach of faith and leave they in a most distressed condition i urge that the nation ought to afford the mean to lift they out of the very desperate condition in which they now be this condition do not indicate any excessive waste or any corruption on the part of the reclamation service it only indicate an overzealous desire to extend the benefit of reclamation to as many acre and as many states as possible i recommend therefore that authority be give to issue not exceed $ 30,000,000 of bond from time to time as the secretary of the interior shall find it necessary the proceed to be apply to the completion of the project already begin and their proper extension and the bond run ten year or more to be take up by the proceed of return to the reclamation fund which return as the year go on will increase rapidly in amount
 there be no doubt at all that if these bond be to be allow to run ten year the proceed from the public land together with the rental for water furnish through the complete enterprise would quickly create a sink fund large enough to retire the bond within the time specify i hope that while the statute shall provide that these bond be to be pay out of the reclamation fund it will be draw in such a way as to secure interest at the low rate and that the credit of the united states will be pledge for their redemption
 i urge consideration of the recommendation of the secretary of the interior in his annual report for amendment of the reclamation act propose other relief for settler on these project
 respect the comparatively small timbere area on the public domain not include in national forest because of their isolation or their special value for agricultural or mineral purpose it be apparent from the evil result by virtue of the imperfection of exist law for the disposition of timber land that the act of june 3 1878 should be repeal and a law enact for the disposition of the timber at public sale the land after the removal of the timber to be subject to appropriation under the agricultural or mineral land law
 what i have say be really an epitome of the recommendation of the secretary of the interior in respect to the future conservation of the public domain in his present annual report he have give close attention to the problem of disposition of these land under such condition as to invite the private capital necessary to their development on the one hand and the maintenance of the restriction necessary to prevent monopoly and abuse from absolute ownership on the other these recommendation be incorporate in bill he have prepare and they be at the disposition of the congress i earnestly recommend that all the suggestion which he have make with respect to these land shall be embody in statute and especially that the withdrawal already make shall be validate so far as necessary and that the authority of the secretary of the interior to withdraw land for the purpose of submit recommendation as to future disposition of they where new legislation be need shall be make complete and unquestione
 the forest reserve of the united states some 190,000,000 acre in extent be under the control of the department of agriculture with authority adequate to preserve they and to extend their growth so far as that may be practicable the importance of the maintenance of our forest can not be exaggerated the possibility of a scientific treatment of forest so that they shall be make to yield a large return in timber without really reduce the supply have be demonstrate in other country and we should work toward the standard set by they as far as their method be applicable to our condition
 upwards of 400,000,000 acre of forest land in this country be in private ownership but only 3 per cent of it be be treat scientifically and with a view to the maintenance of the forest the part play by the forest in the equalization of the supply of water on watershed be a matter of discussion and dispute but the general benefit to be derive by the public from the extension of forest land on watershed and the promotion of the growth of tree in place that be now denude and that once have great flourishing forest go without say the control to be exercise over private owner in their treatment of the forest which they own be a matter for state and not national regulation because there be nothing in the constitution that authorize the federal government to exercise any control over forest within a state unless the forest be own in a proprietary way by the federal government
 it have be propose and a bill for the purpose pass the lower house in the last congress that the national government appropriate a certain amount each year out of the receipt from the forestry business of the government to institute reforestation at the source of certain navigable stream to be select by the geological survey with a view to determine the practicability of thus improve and protect the stream for federal purpose i think a moderate expenditure for each year for this purpose for a period of five or ten year would be of the utmost benefit in the development of our forestry system
 i come now to the improvement of the inland waterway he would be blind indeed who do not realize that the people of the entire west and especially those of the mississippi valley have be arouse to the need there be for the improvement of our inland waterway the mississippi river with the missouri on the one hand and the ohio on the other would seem to offer a great natural mean of interstate transportation and traffic how far if properly improve they would relieve the railroad or supplement they in respect to the bulky and cheap commodity be a matter of conjecture no enterprise ought to be undertake the cost of which be not definitely ascertain and the benefit and advantage of which be not know and assure by competent engineer and other authority when however a project of a definite character for the improvement of a waterway have be develop so that the plan have be draw the cost definitely estimate and the traffic which will be accommodate be reasonably probable i think it be the duty of congress to undertake the project and make provision therefor in the proper appropriation bill
 one of the project which answer the description i have give be that of introduce dam into the ohio river from pittsburg to cairo so as to maintain at all season of the year by slack water a depth of 9 foot upward of seven of these dam have already be construct and six be under construction while the total require be fifty four the remain cost be know to be $ 63,000,000
 it seem to i that in the development of our inland waterway it would be wise to begin with this particular project and carry it through as rapidly as may be i assume from reliable information that it can be construct economically in twelve year
 what have be say of the ohio river be true in a less complete way of the improvement of the upper mississippi from st. paul to st. louis to a constant depth of 6 foot and of the missouri from kansas city to st. louis to a constant depth of 6 foot and from st. louis to cairo to a depth of 8 foot these project have be pronounce practical by competent board of army engineer their cost have be estimate and there be business which will follow the improvement
 i recommend therefore that the present congress in the river and harbor bill make provision for continue contract to complete these improvement
 as these improvement be be make and the traffic encourage by they show itself of sufficient importance the improvement of the mississippi beyond cairo down to the gulf which be now go on with the maintenance of a depth of 9 foot everywhere may be change to another and great depth if the necessity for it shall appear to arise out of the traffic which can be deliver on the river at cairo
 i be inform that the investigation by the waterway commission in europe show that the existence of a waterway by no means assure traffic unless there be traffic adapt to water carriage at cheap rate at one end or the other of the stream it also appear in europe that the depth of the non tidal stream be rarely more than 6 foot and never more than 10 but it be certain that enormous quantity of merchandise be transport over the river and canal in germany and france and england and it be also certain that the existence of such method of traffic materially affect the rate which the railroad charge and it be the good regulator of those rate that we have not even except the governmental regulation through the interstate commerce commission for this reason i hope that this congress will take such step that it may be call the inaugurator of the new system of inland waterway
 for reason which it be not necessary here to state congress have see fit to order an investigation into the interior department and the forest service of the agricultural department the result of that investigation be not need to determine the value of and the necessity for the new legislation which i have recommend in respect to the public land and in respect to reclamation i earnestly urge that the measure recommend be take up and dispose of promptly without await the investigation which have be determine upon

declaration by the party which be responsible for it that a custom bill should be a tariff for the protection of home industry the measure of the protection to be the difference between the cost of produce the import article abroad and the cost of produce it at home together with such addition to that difference as might give a reasonable profit to the home producer the chief criticism of this tariff be a charge that in respect to a number of the schedule the declare measure be not follow but a high difference retain or insert by way of undue discrimination in favor of certain industry and manufacture little if any of the criticism of the tariff have be direct against the protective principle above state tariff board the time in which the tariff be prepare undoubtedly be so short as to the .purpose of more nearly conform to the party promise congress at its last session make provision at my request for the continuance of a board create under the authority of the maximum and minimum knowledge the halt in business and the shock to business due to the announcement that a new tariff bill be to be prepare and put in operation will be avoid by treat the schedule one by one as occasion plan of course involve the full cooperation of congress in limit the consideration in tariff matter to one schedule at a time because if a propose amendment to a tariff bill be to involve a complete consideration of all the schedule and another revision then we shall only repeat the evil from which the business of this country have in time past suffer most grievously by stagnation and uncertainty pende a resettlement of a law affect all business directly or indirectly i can not too much emphasize the importance and benefit of the plan above propose for the treatment of the tariff it facilitate the canal will be complete well within the time fix by colonel goethals to wit january 1 1915 and within the estimate of cost $ 375,000,000.press report have reach the united states from time to time give account of slide of earth of very large yardage in the culebra cut and elsewhere along the line from which it might be infer that the work have be much retarded and that the time of completion have be necessarily postpone the report of doctor hayes of the geological survey whom i send within the last month to the isthmus to make an investigation show that this section of the canal zone be compose of sedimentary rock of rather weak structure and subject to almost immediate disintegration when expose to the air subsequent to the deposition of these sediment igneous rock hard and more durable have be thrust into they and be cold at the time of their intrusion united but indifferently with the sedimentary rock at the contact the result of these condition be that as the cut be deepen cause unbalanced pressure slide from the side of the cut have occur these be in part due to the flowing of surface soil and decomposed sedimentary rock upon incline surface of the underlie undecomposed rock and in part by the crushing of structurally weak bed under excessive pressure these slide occur on one side or the other of the cut through a distance of 4 or 5 mile and now that their character be understand allowance have be make in the calculation of yardage for the amount of slide which will have to be remove and the great slope that will have to be give to the bank in many place in order to prevent their recurrence such allowance do not exceed ten million of yard consider that the number of yard remove from this cut on an average of each month through the year be 1,300,000 and that the total remain to be excavate include slide be about 30,000,000 yard it be see that this addition to the excavation do not offer any great reason for delay while this feature of the material to be excavate in the cut will not seriously delay or obstruct the construction of a canal of the lock type the increase of excavation due to such slide in the cut make 85 foot deep for a sea level canal would certainly have be so great as to delay its completion to a time beyond the patience of the american people fortify the canal among question arise for present solution be whether the canal shall be fortify i have already state to the congress that i strongly favor fortification and i now reiterate this opinion and ask your consideration of the subject in the light of the report already before you make by a competent board if in our discretion we believe modern fortification to be necessary to the adequate protection and policing of the canal then it be our duty to construct they we have build the canal it be our property by convention we have indicate our desire for and indeed undertake its universal and equal use it be also well know that one of the chief object in the construction of the canal have be to increase the military effectiveness of our navy failure to fortify the canal would make the attainment of both these aim depend upon the mere moral obligation of the whole international public obligation which we would be powerless to enforce and which could never in any other way be absolutely safeguard against a desperate and irresponsible enemy canal toll another question which arise for consideration and possible legislation be the question of toll in the canal this question be necessarily affect by the probable tonnage which will go through the canal it be all a matter of estimate but one of the government commission in 1900 investigate the question and make a report he conclude that the total tonnage of the vessel employ in commerce that could use the isthmian canal in 1914 would amount to 6,843,805 ton net register and that this traffic would increase 25.1 per cent per decade that it be not probable that all the commerce include in the total would at once abandon the route at present follow and make use of the new canal and that it might take some time perhaps two year to readjust trade with reference to the new condition which the canal would establish he do not include moreover the tonnage of war vessel although it be to be infer that such vessel would make considerable use of the canal in the matter of toll he reach the conclusion that a dollar a net ton would not drive business away from the canal but that a high rate would do so in determine what the toll should be we certainly ought not to insist that they should at once amount to enough to pay the interest on the investment of $ 400,000,000 which the united states have make in the construction of the canal we ought not to do this first because the benefit to be derive by the united states from this expenditure be not to be measure solely by a return upon the investment if it be then the construction might well have be leave to private enterprise it be because an adequate return upon the money invest could not be expect immediately or in the near future and because there be peculiar political advantage to be derive from the construction of the canal that it fall to the government to advance the money and perform the work in addition to the benefit to our naval strength the canal greatly increase the trade facility of the
