 international prize court

 fur seal treaty

 the fur seal controversy which for nearly twenty five year have be the source of serious friction between the united states and the power border upon the north pacific ocean whose subject have be permit to engage in pelagic sealing against the fur seal herd have their breeding ground within the jurisdiction of the united states have at last be satisfactorily adjust by the conclusion of the north pacific sealing convention enter into between the united states great britain japan and russia on the 7th of july last this convention be a conservation measure of very great importance and if it be carry out in the spirit of reciprocal concession and advantage upon which it be base there be every reason to believe that not only will it result in preserve the furseal herd of the north pacific ocean and restore they to their former value for the purpose of commerce but also that it will afford a permanently satisfactory settlement of a question the only other solution of which seem to be the total destruction of the fur seal in another aspect also this convention be of importance in that it furnish an illustration of the feasibility of secure a general international game law for the protection of other mammal of the sea the preservation of which be of importance to all the nation of the world

 international opium commission

 in a special message transmit to the congress on the 11th of january 19ii in which i concur in the recommendation make by the secretary of state in regard to certain needful legislation for the control of our interstate and foreign traffic in opium and other menacing drug i quote from my annual message of december 7 1909 in which i announce that the result of the international opium commission hold at shanghai in february 1909 at the invitation of the united states have be lay before this government that the report of that commission show that china be make remarkable progress and admirable effort toward the eradication of the opium evil that the interested government have not permit their commercial interest to prevent their cooperation in this reform and as a result of collateral investigation of the opium question in this country i recommend that the manufacture sale and use of opium in the united states should be more rigorously control by legislation

 prior to that time and in continuation of the policy of this government to secure the cooperation of the interested nation the united states propose an international opium conference with full power for the purpose of clothing with the force of international law the resolution adopt by the above mention commission together with their essential corollary the other power concern cordially respond to the proposal of this government and i be glad to be able to announce representative of all the power assemble in conference at the hague on the first of this month

 since the passage of the opium exclusion act more than twenty states have be animate to modify their pharmacy law and bring they in accord with the spirit of that act thus stamp out to a measure the intrastate traffic in opium and other habit form drug but although i have urge on the congress the passage of certain measure for federal control of the interstate and foreign traffic in these drug no action have yet be take in view of the fact that there be now sit at the hague so important a conference which have under review the municipal law of the different nation for the mitigation of their opium and other allied evil a conference which will certainly deal with the international aspect of these evil it seem to i most essential that the congress should take immediate action on the anti narcotic legislation to which i have already call attention by a special message

 the four important convention sign at the fourth pan american conference at buenos aires provide for the regulation of trademark patent and copyright and for the arbitration of pecuniary claim have with the advice and consent of the senate be ratify on the part of the united states and the ratification have be deposit with the government of the argentine republic in accordance with the requirement of the convention i be not advise that similiar action have be take by any other of the signatory government

 international arrangement to suppress obscene publication

 one of the notable advance in international morality accomplish in recent year be an arrangement enter into on april 13th of the present year between the united states and other power for the repression of the circulation of obscene publication

 foreign trade relation of tyte united states

 in my last annual message i refer to the tariff negotiation of the department of state with foreign country in connection with the application by a series of proclamation of the minimum tariff of the united states to importation from the several country and i state that in its general operation section 2 of the new tariff law have prove a guaranty of continue commercial peace although there be unfortunately instance where foreign government deal arbitrarily with american interest within their jurisdiction in a manner injurious and inequitable during the past year some instance of discriminatory treatment have be remove but i regret to say that there remain a few case of differential treatment adverse to the commerce of the united states while none of these instance now appear to amount to undue discrimination in the sense of section 2 of the tariff law of august 5 1909 they be all exception to that complete degree of equality of tariff treatment that the department of state have consistently seek to obtain for american commerce abroad

 while the double tariff feature of the tariff law of 1909 have be amply justify by the result achieve in remove former and prevent new undue discrimination against american commerce it be believe that the time have come for the amendment of this feature of the law in such way as to provide a graduated mean of meet vary degree of discriminatory treatment of american commerce in foreign country as well as to protect the financial interest abroad of american citizen against arbitrary and injurious treatment on the part of foreign government through either legislative or administrative measure

 it would seem desirable that the maximum tariff of the united states should embrace within its purview the free list which be not the case at the present time in order that it might have reasonable significance to the government of those country from which the importation into the united states be confine virtually to article on the free list

 record of highest amount of foreign trade

 the fiscal year end june 30 1911 show great progress in the development of american trade it be noteworthy as mark the high record of export of american product to foreign country the valuation be in excess of $ 2,000,000,000 these export show a gain over the precede year of more than $ 300,000,000

 facility for foreign trade furnished by joint action of department of state and of commerce and labor

 there be widespread appreciation express by the business interest of the country as regard the practical value of the facility now offer by the department of state and the department of commerce and labor for the furtherance of american commerce conference with their officer at washington who have an expert knowledge of trade condition in foreign country and with consular officer and commercial agent of the department of commerce and labor who while on leave of absence visit the principal industrial center of the united states have be find of great value these trade conference be regard as a particularly promising method of governmental aid in foreign trade promotion the department of commerce and labor have arrange to give publicity to the expect arrival and the itinerary of consular officer and commercial agent while on leave in the united states in order that trade organization may arrange for conference with they

 as i have indicate it be increasingly clear that to obtain and maintain that equity and substantial equality of treatment essential to the flourish foreign trade which become year by year more important to the industrial and commercial welfare of the united states we should have a flexibility of tariff sufficient for the give and take of negotiation by the department of state on behalf of our commerce and industry

 crying need for american merchant marine

 i need hardly reiterate the conviction that there should speedily be build up an american merchant marine this be necessary to assure favorable transportation facility to our great ocean bear commerce as well as to supplement the navy with an adequate reserve of ship and man it would have the economic advantage of keep at home part of the vast sum now pay foreign shipping for carry american good all the great commercial nation pay heavy subsidy to their merchant marine so that it be obvious that without some wise aid from the congress the united states must lag behind in the matter of merchant marine in its present anomalous position

 extension of american banking to foreign country

 legislation to facilitate the extension of american bank to foreign country be another matter in which our foreign trade need assistance

 chamber of foreign commerce suggest

 the interest of our foreign commerce be nonpartisan and as a factor in prosperity be as broad as the land in the dissemination of useful information and in the coordination of effort certain unofficial association have do good work toward the promotion of foreign commerce it be cause for regret however that the great number of such association and the comparative lack of cooperation between they fail to secure an efficiency commensurate with the public interest through the agency of the department of commerce and labor and in some case directly the department of state transmit to reputable business interest information of commercial opportunity supplement the regular publish consular report some central organization in touch with association and chamber of commerce throughout the country and able to keep purely american interest in close touch with different phase of commercial affair would i believe be of great value such organization might be manage by a committee compose of a small number of those now actively carry on the work of some of the large association and there might be add to the committee as member ex officio one or two official of the department of state and one or two official from the department of commerce and labor and representative of the appropriate committee of congress the authority and success of such an organization would evidently be enhance if the congress should see fit to prescribe its scope and organization through legislation which would give to it some such official standing as that for example of the national red cross

 with these factor and the continuance of the foreign service establishment departmental diplomatic and consular upon the high plane where it have be place by the recent reorganization this government would be abreast of the time in foster the interest of its foreign trade and the rest must be leave to the energy and enterprise of our business man

 improvement of the foreign service

 the entire foreign service organization be be improve and develop with especial regard to the requirement of the commercial interest of the country the rapid growth of our foreign trade make it of the utmost importance that governmental agency through which that trade be to be aid and protect should possess a high degree of efficiency not only should the foreign representative be maintain upon a generous scale in so far as salary and establishment be concern but the selection and advancement of officer should be definitely and permanently regulate by law so that the service shall not fail to attract man of high character and ability the experience of the past few year with a partial application of civil service rule to the diplomatic and consular service leave no doubt in my mind of the wisdom of a wide and more permanent extension of those principle to both branch of the foreign service the man select for appointment by mean of the exist executive regulation have be of a far high average of intelligence and ability than the man appoint before the regulation be promulgate moreover the feeling that under the exist rule there be reasonable hope for permanence of tenure during good behavior and for promotion for meritorious service have serve to bring about a zealous activity in the interest of the country which never before exist or could exist it be my earnest conviction that the enactment into law of the general principle of the exist regulation can not fail to effect further improvement in both branch of the foreign service by provide great inducement for young man of character and ability to seek a career abroad in the service of the government and an incentive to those already in the service to put forth great effort to attain the high standard which the successful conduct of our international relation and commerce require

 i therefore again commend to the favorable action of the congress the enactment of a law apply to the diplomatic and consular service the principle embody in section 1753 of the revised statutes of the united states in the civil service act of january 16 1883 and the executive order of june 27 1906 and of november 26 1909 in its consideration of this important subject i desire to recall to the attention of the congress the very favorable report make on the lowden bill for the improvement of the foreign service by the foreign affairs committee of the house of representatives available statistic show the strictness with which the merit system have be apply to the foreign service during recent year and the absolute nonpartisan selection of consul and diplomatic service secretary who indeed far from be select with any view to political consideration have actually be choose to a disproportionate extent from states which would have be unrepresente in the foreign service under the system which it be to be hope be now permanently obsolete some legislation for the perpetuation of the present system of examination and promotion upon merit and efficiency would be of great value to our commerical and international interest

 part iii

 the white house december 20 1911

 to the senate and house of representatives

 in my annual message to congress december 1909 i state that under section 2 of the act of august 5 1909 i have appoint a tariff board of three member to cooperate with the state department in the administration of the maximum and minimum clause of that act to make a glossary or encyclopedia of the exist tariff so as to render its term intelligible to the ordinary reader and then to investigate industrial condition and cost of production at home and abroad with a view to determine to what extent exist tariff rate actually exemplify the protective principle viz that duty should be make adequate and only adequate to equalize the difference in cost of production at home and abroad

 i far state that i believe these investigation would be of great value as a basis for accurate legislation and that i should from time to time recommend to congress the revision of certain schedule in accordance with the finding of the board

 in the last session of the sixty first congress a bill create a permanent tariff board of five member of whom not more than three should be of the same political party pass each house but fail of enactment because of slight difference on which agreement be not reach before adjournment an appropriation act provide that the permanent tariff board if create by statute should report to congress on schedule k in december 1911

 therefore to carry out so far as lie within my power the purpose of this bill for a permanent tariff board i appoint in march 19li a board of five add two member of such party affiliation as would have fulfil the statutory requirement and direct they to make a report to i on schedule k of the tariff act in december of this year

 in my message of august 17 1911 accompany the veto of the wool bill i say that in my judgment schedule k should be revise and the rate reduce my veto be base on the ground that since the tariff board would make in december a detailed report on wool and wool manufacture with special reference to the relation of the exist rate of duty to relative cost here and abroad public policy and a fair regard to the interest of the producer and the manufacturer on the one hand and of the consumer on the other demand that legislation should not be hastily enact in the absence of such information that i be not myself possess at that time of adequate knowledge of the fact to determine whether or not the propose act be in accord with my pledge to support a fair and reasonable protective policy that such legislation might prove only temporary and inflict upon a great industry the evil of continued uncertainty

 i now herewith submit a report of the tariff board on schedule k. the board be unanimous in its finding on the basis of these finding i now recommend that the congress proceed to a consideration of this schedule with a view to its revision and a general reduction of its rate

 the report show that the present method of assess the duty on raw wool this be by a specific rate on the grease pound i. e. unscoured -operate to exclude wool of high shrinkage in scour but fine quality from the american market and thereby lessen the range of wool available to the domestic manufacturer that the duty on scour wool of 33 cent per pound be prohibitory and operate to exclude the importation of clean low price foreign wool of inferior grade which be nevertheless valuable material for manufacturing and which can not be import in the grease because of their heavy shrinkage such wool if import might be use to displace the cheap substitute now in use

 to make the precede paragraph a little plainer take the instance of a hundred pound of first class wool import under the present duty which be 11 11 cent a pound that would make the duty on the hundred pound $ 11 the merchantable part of the wool thus import be the weight of the wool of this hundred pound after scour if the wool shrink 80 per cent as some wool do then the duty in such a case would amount to $ 11 $ 11 on 20 pound of scour wool this of course would be prohibitory if the wool shrink only 50 per cent it would be $ 11 on 50 pound of wool and this be near to the average of the great bulk of wool that be import from australia which be the principal source of our import wool

 these discrimination could be overcome by assess a duty in ad valorem term but this method be open to the objection first that it increase administrative difficulty and tend to decrease revenue through undervaluation and second that as price advance the ad valorem rate increase the duty per pound at the time when the consumer most need relief and the producer can well stand competition while if price decline the duty be decrease at the time when the consumer be least burden by the price and the producer most need protection

 another method of meet the difficulty of tax the grease pound be to assess a specific duty on grease wool in term of its scour content this obviate the chief evil of the present system namely the discrimination due to different shrinkage and thereby tend greatly to equalize the duty the board report that this method be feasible in practice and could be administer without great expense the scour content of the wool be the basis on which user of wool make their calculation and a duty of this kind would fit the usage of the trade one effect of this method of assessment would be that regardless of the rate of duty there would be an increase in the supply and variety of wool by make available to the american market wool of both low and fine quality now exclude

 the report show in detail the difficulty involve in attempt to state in categorical term the cost of wool production and the great difference in cost as between different region and different type of wool it be find however that take all variety in account the average cost of production for the whole american clip be high than the cost in the chief compete country by an amount somewhat less than the present duty

 the report show that the duty on noil wool waste and shoddy which be adjust to the rate of 33 cent on scour wool be prohibitory in the same measure that the duty on scour wool be prohibitory in general they be assess at rate as high as or high than the duty pay on the clean content of wool actually import they should be reduce and so adjusted to the rate on wool as to bear their proper proportion to the real rate levy on the actual wool import

 the duty on many class of wool manufacture be prohibitory and greatly in excess of the difference in cost of production here and abroad

 this be true of top of yarn with the exception of worsted yarn of a very high grade and of low and medium grade cloth of heavy weight

 on top up to 52 cent a pound in value and on yarn of 65 cent in value the rate be 100 per cent with correspondingly high rate for low value on cheap and medium grade cloth the exist rate frequently run to 150 per cent and on some cheap good to over 200 per cent this be largely due to that part of the duty which be levy ostensibly to compensate the manufacturer for the enhance cost of his raw material due to the duty on wool as a matter of fact this compensatory duty for numerous class of good be much in excess of the amount need for strict compensation

 on the other hand the finding show that the duty which run to such high ad valorem equivalent be prohibitory since the good be not import but that the price of domestic fabric be not raise by the full amount of duty on a set of 1 yard sample of 16 english fabric which be completely exclude by the present tariff rate it be find that the total foreign value be $ 41.84 the duty which would have be assess have these fabric be import $ 76.90 the foreign value plus the amount of the duty $ 118.74 or a nominal duty of 183 per cent in fact however practically identical fabric of domestic make sell at the same time at $ 69.75 show an enhance price over the foreign market value of but 67 per cent

 although these duty do not increase price of domestic good by anything like their full amount it be none the less true that such prohibitive duty eliminate the possibility of foreign competition even in time of scarcity that they form a temptation to monopoly and conspiracie to control domestic price that they be much in excess of the difference in cost of production here and abroad and that they should be reduce to a point which accord with this principle

 the finding of the board show that in this industry the actual manufacturing cost aside from the question of the price of material be much high in this country than it be abroad that in the making of yarn and cloth the domestic woolen or worsted manufacturer have in general no advantage in the form of superior machinery or more efficient labor to offset the high wage pay in this country the finding show that the cost of turn wool into yarn in this country be about double that in the lead compete country and that the cost of turn yarn into cloth be somewhat more than double under the protective policy a great industry involve the welfare of hundred of thousand of people have be establish despite these handicap

 in recommend revision and reduction i therefore urge that action be take with these fact in mind to the end that an important and established industry may not be jeopardize

 the tariff board report that no equitable method have be find to levy purely specific duty on woolen and worst fabric and that except for a compensatory duty the rate must be ad valorem on such manufacture it be important to realize however that no flat ad valorem rate on such fabric can be make to work fairly and effectively any single rate which be high enough to equalize the difference in manufacturing cost at home and abroad on highly finish good involve such labor would be prohibitory on cheap good in which the labor cost be a small proportion of the total value conversely a rate only adequate to equalize this difference on cheap good would remove protection from the fine good manufacture the increase in which have be one of the striking feature of the trade 's development in recent year i therefore recommend that in any revision the importance of a graduated scale of ad valorem duty on cloth be carefully consider and apply

 i venture to say that no legislative -body have ever have present to it a more complete and exhaustive report than this on so difficult and complicated a subject as the relative cost of wool and woolens the world over it be a monument to the thoroughness industry impartiality and accuracy of the man engage in its making they be choose from both political party but have allow no partisan spirit to prompt or control their inquiry they be unanimous in their finding i feel sure that after the report have be print and study the value of such a compendium of exact knowledge in respect to this schedule of the tariff will convince all of the wisdom of make such a board permanent in order that it may treat each schedule of the tariff as it have treat this and then keep its bureau of information up to date with current change in the economic world

 it be no part of the function of the tariff board to propose rate of duty their function be merely to present finding of fact on which rate of duty may be fairly determined in the light of adequate knowledge in accord with the economic policy to be follow this be what the present report do

 the finding of fact by the board show ample reason for the revision downward of schedule k in accord with the protective principle and present the datum as to relative cost and price from which may be determine what rate will fairly equalize the difference in production cost i recommend that such revision be proceed with at once

 part iv

 on the financial condition of the treasury need banking and currency reform and departmental question

 the white house december 21 1911

 to the senate and house of representatives

 the financial condition of the government as show at the close of the last fiscal year june 30 1911 be very satisfactory the ordinary receipt into the general fund exclude postal revenue amount to $ 701,372,374.99 and the disbursement from the general fund for current expense and capital outlay exclude postal and panama canal disbursement include the interest on the public debt amount to $ 654,137,907 89 leave a surplus of $ 47,234,377.10

 the postal revenue receipt amount to $ 237,879,823,60 while the payment make for the postal service from the postal revenue amount to $ 237,660,705.48 which leave a surplus of postal receipt over disbursement of $ 219,118.12 the first time in 27 year in which a surplus occur

 the interest bear debt of the united states june 30 1911 amount to $ 915,353,igo the debt on which interest have cease amount to $ 1,879,830.26 and the debt bear no interest include greenback national bank note to be redeem and fractional currency amount to $ 386,751,917 43 or a total of interest and noninterest bear debt amount to $ 1,303,984,937.69

 the actual disbursement exclusive of those for the panama canal and for the postal service for the year end june 30 1911 be $ 654,137,997.89 the actual disbursement for the year end june 30 1910 exclusive of the panama canal and the postal service disbursement be $ 659,705,391.08 make a decrease of $ 5,567,393.19 in yearly expenditure in the year 1911 under that of 1910 for the year end june 30 1912 the estimate receipt exclusive of the postal revenue be $ 666,000,000 while the total estimate exclusive of those for the panama canal and the postal expenditure payable from the postal revenue amount to $ 645,842,799.34 this be a decrease in the 1912 estimate from that of the 1911 estimate of $ 1,534,367 22

 for the year end june 30 1913 the estimate receipt exclusive of the postal revenue be $ 667,000,000 while the total estimate appropriation exclusive of the panama canal and postal disbursement payable from postal revenue will amount to $ 637,920,803.35 this be a decrease in the 1913 estimate from that of the 1912 estimate of $ 7,921,995.99

 as to the postal revenue the expansion of the business in that department the normal increase in the post office and the extension of the service will increase the outlay to the sum of $ 260,938,463 but as the department be self sustain this year the postmaster general be assure that next year the receipt will at least equal the expenditure and probably exceed they by more than the surplus of this year it be fair and equitable therefore in determine the economy with which the government have be run to exclude the transaction of a department like the post office department which rely for its support upon its receipt in calculation heretofore make for comparison of economy in each year it have be the proper custom only to include in the statement the deficit in the post office department which be pay out of the treasury

 a calculation of the actual increase in the expense of government arise from the increase in the population and the general expansion of governmental function except those of the post office for a number of year show a normal increase of about 4 per cent a year by direct the exercise of great care to keep down the expense and the estimate we have succeed in reduce the total disbursement each year

 the credit of the united states

 the credit of this government be show to be well than that of any other government by the sale of the panama canal 3 per cent bond these bond do not give their owner the privilege of use they as a basis for bank note circulation nor be there any other privilege extend to they which would affect their general market value their sale therefore measure the credit of the government the premium which be realize upon the bond make the actual interest rate of the transaction 2.909 per cent

 efficiency and economy in the treasury department

 i in the treasury department the efficiency and economy work have be keep steadily up provision be make for the elimination of 134 position during the come year two hundred and sixty seven statutory position be eliminate during the last year in the office of the treasury in washington and 141 position in the year 1910 make an elimination of 542 statutory position since march 4 1909 and this have be do without the discharge of anybody because the normal resignation and death have be equal to the elimination of the place a system of transfer having take care of the person whose position be drop out in the field service if the department too 1,259 position have be eliminate down to the present time make a total net reduction of all treasury position to the number of 1,801 meantime the efficiency of the work of the departmeat have increase

 monetary reform

 a matter of first importance that will come before congress for action at this session be monetary reform the congress have itself arrange an early introduction of this great question through the report of its monetary commission this commission be appoint to recommend a solution of the banking and currency problem so long confront the nation and to furnish the fact and datum necessary to enable the congress to take action the commission be appoint when an impressive and urgent popular demand for legislative relief suddenly arise out of the distressing situation of the people cause by the deplorable panic of 1907 the congress decide that while it could not give immediately the relief require it would provide a commission to furnish the mean for prompt action at a later date

 in order to do its work with thoroughness and precision this commission have take some time to make its report the country be undoubtedly hope for as prompt action on the report as the convenience of the congress can permit the recognition of the gross imperfection and mark inadequacy of our banking and currency system even in our most quiet financial period be of long standing and later there have mature a recognition of the fact that our system be responsible for the extraordinary devastation waste and business paralysis of our recur period of panic though the member of the monetary commission have for a considerable time be work in the open and while large number of the people have be openly work with they and while the press have largely note and discuss this work as it have proceed so that the report of the commission promise to represent a national movement the detail of the report be still be consider i can not therefore do much more at this time than commend the immense importance of monetary reform urge prompt consideration and action when the commission 's report be receive and express my satisfaction that the plan to be propose promise to embrace main feature that having meet the approval of a great preponderance of the practical and professional opinion of the country be likely to meet equal approval in congress

 it be exceedingly fortunate that the wise and undisputed policy of maintain unchanged the main feature of our banking system render it at once impossible to introduce a central bank for a central bank would certainly have be resist and a plan into which it could have be introduce would probably have be defeat but as a central bank could not be a part of the only plan discuss or consider that troublesome question be eliminate and ingenious and novel as the propose national reserve association appear it simply be a logical outgrowth of what be good in our present system and be in fact the fulfillment of that system

 exactly how the management of that association should be organize be a question still open it seem to be desirable that the bank which would own the association should in the main manage it it will be an agency of the bank to act for they and they can be trust well than anybody else chiefly to conduct it it be mainly banker work but there must be some form of government supervision and ultimate control and i favor a reasonable representation of the government in the management i entertain no fear of the introduction of politic or of any undesirable influence from a properly measure government representation

 i trust that all bank of the country possess the requisite standard will be place upon a footing of perfect equality of opportunity both the national system and the state system should be fairly recognize leave they eventually to coalesce if that shall prove to be their tendency but such evolution can not develop impartially if the bank of one system be give or permit any advantage of opportunity over those of the other system and i trust also that the new legislation will carefully and completely protect and assure the individuality and the independence of each bank to the end that any tendency there may ever be toward a consolidation of the money or banking power of the nation shall be defeat

 it will always be possible of course to correct any feature of the new law which may in practice prove to be unwise so that while this law be sure to be enact under condition of unusual knowledge and authority it also will include it be well to remember the possibility of future amendment

 with the present prospect of this long await reform encourage we it would be singularly unfortunate if this monetary question should by any chance become a party issue and i sincerely hope it will not the exceeding amount of consideration it have receive from the people of the nation have be wholly nonpartisan and the congress set its nonpartisan seal upon it when the monetary commission be appoint in commend the question to the favorable consideration of congress i speak for and in the spirit of the great number of my fellow citizen who without any thought of party or partisanship feel with remarkable earnestness that this reform be necessary to the interest of all the people

 the war department

 there be now before congress a dill the purpose of which be to increase the efficiency and decrease the expense of the army it contain four principal feature first a consolidation of the general staff with the adjutant general 's and the inspector general 's departments second a consolidation of the quartermaster 's department with the subsistence and the pay departments third the creation of an army service corps and fourth an extension of the enlistment period from three to five year

 with the establishment of an army service corps as propose in the bill i be thoroughly in accord and be convinced that the establishment of such a corps will result in a material economy and a very great increase of efficiency in the army it have repeatedly be recommend by i and my predecessor i also believe that a consolidation of the staff corps can be make with a result increase in efficiency and economy but not along the line provide in the bill under consideration

 i be oppose to any plan the result of which would be to break up or interfere with the essential principle of the detail system in the staff corps establish by the act of february 2 1901 and i be oppose to any plan the result of which would be to give to the officer select as chief of staff or to any other member of the general staff corps great permanency of office than he now have under the exist law neither the chief of staff nor any other member of the general staff corps can remain in office for a period of more than four year and there must be an interval of two year between successive tour of duty

 the bill refer to provide that certain person shall become permanent member of the general staff corps and that certain other be subject to redetail without an interval of two year such provision be fraught with danger to the welfare of the army and

 would practically nullify the main purpose of the law create the

 in make the consolidation no reduction should be make in the total number of officer of the army of whom there be now too few to perform the duty impose by law i have in the past recommend an increase in the number of officer by 6oo in order to provide sufficient officer to perform all class of staff duty and tc reduce the number of line officer detach from their command congress at the last session increase the total number of officer by 2oo but this be not enough promotion in the line of the army be too slow officer do not attain command rank at an age early enough properly to exercise it it would be a mistake far to retard this already slow promotion by throw back into the line of the arm a number of high rank officer to be absorb as be rovide in the

 another feature of the bill which i believe to be a mistake be the propose increase in the term of enlistment from three to five ear i believe it would be well to enlist man for six year release they at the end of three year from active service and put they in reserve for the remain three year reenlistment should be largely confine to the noncommissioned officer and other enlisted man in the skilled grade this plan by the payment of a comparatively small compensation during the three year of reserve would keep a large bodv of man at the call of the government train and ready for

 the army of the united states be in good condition it show itself able to meet an emergency in the successful mobilization of an army division of from i5,ooo to 2o ooo man which take place along the border of mexico during the recent disturbance in that country the marvelous freedom from the ordinary camp disease of typhoid fever and measle be refer to in the report of the secretary of war and show such an effectiveness in the sanitary regulation and treatment of the medical corps and in the discipline of the army itself as to invoke the high commendation

 memorial amphitheater at arlington

 i beg to renew my recommendation of last year that the congress appropriate for a memorial amphitheater at arlington va. the fund require to construct it upon the plan already approve

 the panama canal

 the very satisfactory progress make on the panama canal last year have continue and there be every reason to believe that the canal

 will be complete as early as the 1st of july 1913 unless something unforeseen occur this be about 18 month before the time promise by the engineer

 we be now near enough the completion of the canal to make it imperatively necessary that legislation should be enact to fix the method by which the canal shall be maintain and control and the zone govern the fact be that to day there be no statutory law by authority of which the president be maintain the government of the zone such authority be give in an amendment to the spooner act which expire by the term of its own limitation some year ago since that time the government have continue under the advice of the attorney general that in the absence of action by congress there be necessarily an imply authority on the part of the executive to maintain a government in a territory in which he have to see that the law be execute the fact that we have be able thus to get along during the important day of construction without legislation expressly formulate the government of the zone or delegate the creation of it to the president be not a reason for suppose that we may continue the same kind of a government after the construction be finish the imply authority of the president to maintain a civil government in the zone may be derive from the mandatory direction give he in the original spooner act by which he be command to build the canal but certainly now that the canal be about to be complete and to be put under a permanent management there ought to be specific statutory authority for its regulation and control and for the government of the zone which we hold for the chief and main purpose of operate the canal

 i fully concur with the secretary of war that the problem be simply the management of a great public work and not the government of a local republic that every provision must be direct toward the successful maintenance of the canal as an avenue of commerce and that all provision for the government of those who live within the zone should be subordinate to the main purpose

 the zone be 40 mile long and 10 mile wide now it have a population of 50,000 or 60,000 but as soon as the work of construction be complete the town which make up this population will be desert and only comparatively few native will continue their residence there the control of they ought to approximate a military government one judge and two justice of the peace will be sufficient to attend to all the judicial and litigated business there be with a few fundamental law of congress the zone should be govern by the order of the president issue through the war department as it be today provision can be make for the guaranty of life liberty and property but beyond those the government should be that of a military reservation manage in connection with this great highway of trade

 furnish supply and repairs

 in my last annual message i discuss at length the reason for the government 's assume the task of furnish to all ship that use the canal whether our own naval vessel or other the supply of coal and oil and other necessity with which they must be replenish either before or after pass through the canal together with the dock facility and repair of every character this it be think wise to do through the government because the government must establish for itself for its own naval vessel large depot and dry dock and warehouse and these may easily be enlarge so as to secure to the world public use the canal reasonable price and a certainty that there will be no discrimination between those who wish to avail themselves of such facility

 toll

 i renew my recommendation with respect to the toll of the canal that within limit which shall seem wise to congress the power of fix toll be give to the president in order to arrive at a proper conclusion there must be some experiment and this can not be do if congress do not delegate the power to one who can act expeditiously

 power exists to relieve american shipping

 i be very confident that the united states have the power to relieve from the payment of toll any part of our shipping that congress deem wise we own the canal it be our money that build it we have the right to charge toll for its use those toll must be the same to everyone but when we be deal with our own ship the practice of many government of subsidize their own merchant vessel be so well establish in general that a subsidy equal to the toll an equivalent remission of toll can not be hold to be a discrimination in the use of the canal the practice in the suez canal make this clear the experiment in toll to be make by the president would doubtless disclose how great a burden of toll the coastwise trade between the atlantic and the pacific coast could bear without prevent its usefulness in competition with the transcontinental railroad one of the chief reason for build the canal be to set up this competition and to bring the two shore close together as a practical trade problem it may be that the toll will have to be wholly remit i do not think this be the good principle because i believe that the cost of such a government work as the panama canal ought to be impose gradually but certainly upon the trade which it create and make possible so far as we can consistent with the development of the world 's trade through the canal and the benefit which it be intend to secure to the east and west coastwise trade we ought to labor to secure from the canal toll a sufficient amount ultimately to meet the debt which we have assume and to pay the interest

 the philippine islands

 in respect to the philippines i urgently join in the recommendation of the secretary of war that the act of february 6 1905 limit the indebtedness that may be incur by the philippine government for the construction of public work be increase from $ 5,000,000 to $ 15,ooo ooo the finance of that government be in excellent condition the maximum sum mention be quite low as compare with the amount of indebtedness of other government with similar resource and the success which have attend the expenditure of the $ 5,000,000 in the useful improvement of the harbor and other place in the islands justifie and require additional expenditure for like purpose

 naturalization

 friar land

 pende an investigation by congress at its last session through one of its committee into the disposition of the friar land secretary dickinson direct that the friar land should not be sell in excess of the limit fix for the public land until congress should pass upon the subject or should have conclude its investigation this order have be an obstruction to the disposition of the land and i expect to direct the secretary of war to return to the practice under the opinion of the attorney general which will enable we to dispose of the land much more promptly and to prepare a sink fund with which to meet the $ 7,000,000 of bond issue for the purchase of the land i have no doubt whatever that the attorney general 's construction be a proper one and that it be in the interest of everyone that the land shall be promptly dispose of the danger of create a monopoly of ownership in land under the statute as construe be nothing there be only two tract of 60,000 acre each unimproved and in remote province that be likely to be dispose of in bulk and the rest of the land be subject to the limitation that they shall be first offer to the present tenant and lessor who hold they in small tract

 the estimate for the river and harbor improvement reach $ 32,000,000 for the come year i wish to urge that whenever a project have be adopt by congress as one to be complete the more money which can be economically expend in its construction in each year the great the ultimate economy this have especial application to the improvement of the mississippi river and its large branch it seem to i that an increase in the amount- of money now be annually expend in the improvement of the ohio river which have be formally adopt by congress would be in the interest of the public a similar change ought to be make during the present congress in the amount to be appropriate for the missouri river the engineer say that the cost of the improvement of the missouri river from kansas city to st. louis in order to secure 6 foot as a permanent channel will reach $ 20,000,000 there have be at least three recommendation from the chief of engineers that if the improvement be adopt $ 2,000,000 should be expend upon it annually this particular improvement be especially entitle to the attention of congress because a company have be organize in kansas city with a capital of $ 1,000,000 which have build steamer and barge and be actually use the river for transportation in order to show what can be do in the way of affect rate between kansas city and st. louis and in order to manifest their good faith and confidence in respect of the improvement i urgently recommend that the appropriation for this improvement be increase from $ 600,000 as recommend now in the completion of a contract to $ 2,000,000 annually so that the work may be do in 10 year

 waterway from the lakes to the gulf

 the project for a navigable waterway from lake michigan to the mouth of the illinois river and thence via the mississippi to the gulf of mexico be one of national importance in view of the work already accomplish by the sanitary district of chicago an agency of the state of illinois which have construct the most difficult and costly stretch of this waterway and make it an asset of the nation and in view of the fact that the people of illinois have authorize the expenditure of $ 20,000,000 to carry this waterway 62 mile far to utica i feel that it be fitting that this work should be supplement by the government and that the expenditure recommend by the special board of engineer on the waterway from utica to the mouth of the illinois river be make upon line which while provide a waterway for the nation should otherwise benefit that state to the full extent i recommend that the term of service of say special board of engineer be continue and that it be empower to reopen the question of the treatment of the low illinois river and to negotiate with a properly constitute commission represent the state of illinois and to agree upon a plan for the improvement of the low illinois river and upon the extent to which the united states may properly cooperate with the state of illinois in secure the construction of a navigable waterway from lockport to the mouth of the illinois river in conjunction with the development of water power by that state between lockport and utica

 the department of justice

 removal of clerk of federal court

 the report of the attorney general show that he have subject to close examination the account of the clerk of the federal court that he have find a good many which disclose irregularity or dishonesty but that he have have considerable difficulty in secure an effective prosecution or removal of the clerk thus derelict i be certainly not unduly prejudiced against the federal court but the fact be that the long and confidential relation which grow out of the tenure for life on the part of the judge and the practical tenure for life on the part of the clerk be not calculate to secure the strictness of deal by the judge with the clerk in respect to his fee and account which assure in the clerk 's conduct a freedom from overcharge and carelessness the relationship between the judge and the clerk make it ungracious for member of the bar to complain of the clerk or for department examiner to make charge against he to be hear by the court and an order of removal of a clerk and a judgment for the recovery of fee be in some case reluctantly enter by the judge for this reason i recommend an amendment to the law whereby the president shall be give power to remove the clerk for cause this provision need not interfere with the right of the judge to appoint his clerk or to remove he

 e mployer liability and workmen 's compensation commission

 the limitation of the liability of the master to his servant for personal injury to such as be occasion by his fault have be abandon in most civilized country and provision make whereby the employee injure in the course of his employment be compensate for his loss of working ability irrespective of negligence the principle upon which such provision proceed be that accidental injury to workman in modern industry with its vast complexity and inherent danger arise from complicated machinery and the use of the great force of steam and electricity should be regard as risk of the industry and the loss bear in some equitable proportion by those who for their own profit engage therein in recognition of this the last congress authorize the appointment of a commission to investigate the subject of employer liability and workman 's compensation and to report the result of their investigation through the president to congress this commission be appoint and have be at work hold hearing gather datum and consider the subject and it be expect will be able to report by the first of the year in accordance with the provision of the law it be hope and expect that the commission will suggest legislation which will enable we to put in the place of the present wasteful and sometimes unjust system of employer liability a plan of compensation which will afford some certain and definite relief to all employee who be injure in the course of their employment in those industry which be subject to the regulating power of congress

 measures to prevent delay and unnecessary cost of litigation

 in promotion of the movement for the prevention of delay and unnecessary cost in litigation i be glad to say that the supreme court have take step to reform the present equity rule of the federal court and that we may in the near future expect a revision of they which will be a long step in the right direction

 the american bar association have recommend to congress several bill expedite procedure one of which have already pass the house unanimously february 6 1911 this direct that no judgment should be set aside or reverse or new trial grant unless it appear to the court after an examination of the entire cause that the error complain of have injuriously affect the substantial right of the party and also provide for the submission of issue of fact to a jury reserve question of law for subsequent argument and decision i hope this bill will pass the senate and become law for it will simplify the procedure at law

 another bill to amend chapter ii of the judicial code in order to avoid error in plead be present by the same association and one enlarge the jurisdiction of the supreme court so as to permit that court to examine upon a writ of error all case in which any right or title be claim under the constitution or any statute or treaty of the united states whether the decision in the court below have be against the right or title or in its favor both these measure be in the interest of justice and should be pass

 post office

 at the beginning of the present administration in 1909 the postal service be in arrear to the extent of $ 17,479,770.47 it be very much the large deficit on record in the brief space of two year this have be turn into a surplus of $ 220,000 which have be accomplish without curtailment of the postal facility as may be see by the fact that there have be establish 3,744 new post office delivery by carrier have be add to the service in 186 city 2,516 new rural route have be establish cover 60,000 mile the force of postal employee have be increase in these two year by more than 8,000 and their average annual salary have have a substantial increase

 postal savings system

 on january 3 1911 postal saving depository be establish experimentally in 48 states and territories after three month successful operation the system be extend as rapidly as feasible to the 7,500 post office of the first second and third class constitute the presidential grade by the end of the year practically all of these will have be designate and then the system will be extend to all fourth class post office do a money order business

 in select post office for depository consideration be give to the efficiency of the postmaster and only those office where the rating be satisfactory to the department have be designate withhold designation from postmaster with unsatisfactory rating have have a salutary effect on the service

 the deposit have keep pace with the extension of the system amount to only $ 60,652 at the end of the first month 's operation in the experimental office they increase to $ 679,310 by july and now after 11 month of operation have reach a total of $ 11,000,000 this sum be distribute among 2,71o bank and protect tinder the law by bond deposit with the treasurer of the united states

 under the method adopt for the conduct of the system certificate be issue as evidence of deposit and account with depositor be keep by the post office instead of by the department compare with the practice in other country of enter deposit in pass book and keep at the central office a ledger account with each depositor the use of the certificate have result in great economy of administration

 the depositor thus far number approximately 150,000 they include 40 nationality native americans largely predominate and english and italians come next

 the first conversion of deposit into united states bond bear interest at the rate of 2.5 per cent occur on july 1 1911 the amount of deposit exchange be $ 41,900 or a little more than 6 per cent of the total outstanding certificate of deposit on june 30 of this issue bond to the value of $ 6,120 be in coupon form and $ 35,780 in register form

 parcel post

 step should be take immediately for the establishment of a rural parcel post in the estimate of appropriation need for the maintenance of the postal service for the ensue fiscal year an item of $ 150,000 have be insert to cover the preliminary expense of establish a parcel post on rural mail route as well as to cover an investigation have for its object the final establishment of a general parcel post on all railway and steamboat transportation route the department believe that after the initial expense of establish the system be defray and the parcel post be in full operation on the rural route it will not only bring in sufficient revenue to meet its cost but also a surplus that can be utilize in pay the expense of a parcel post in the city delivery service

 it be hope that congress will authorize the immediate establishment of a limited parcel post on such rural route as may be select provide for the delivery along the route of parcel not exceed eleven pound which be the weight limit for the international parcel post or at the post office from which such route emanate or on another route emanating from the same office such preliminary service will prepare the way for the more thorough and comprehensive inquiry contemplate in ask for the appropriation mention enable the department to gain definite information concern the practical operation of a general system and at the same time extend the benefit of the service to a class of people who above all other be specially in need of it

 the suggestion that we have a general parcel post have awaken great opposition on the part of some who think that it will have the effect to destroy the business of the country storekeeper instead of do this i think the change will greatly increase business for the benefit of all the reduction in the cost of live it will bring about ought to make its come certain

 the navy department

 on the 2d of november last i review the fight fleet of battleship and other vessel assemble in new york harbor consist of 24 battleship 2 armored cruiser 2 cruiser 22 destroyer 12 torpedo boat 8 submarine and other attendant vessel make 98 vessel of all class of a tonnage of 576,634 ton those who see the fleet be strike with its preparedness and with its high military efficiency all americans should be proud of its personnel

 the fleet be deficient in the number of torpedo destroyer in cruiser and in collier as well as in large battleship cruiser which be now become a very important feature of foreign navy notably the british german and japanese

 the building plan for this year contemplate two battleship and two collier this be because the other and small vessel can be build much more rapidly in case of emergency than the battleship and we certainly ought to continue the policy of two battleship a year until after the panama canal be finish and until in our first line and in our reserve line we can number 40 available vessel of proper armament and size

 the reorganization of the navy and the appointment of four aid to the secretary have continue to demonstrate their usefulness it would be difficult now to administer the affair of the navy without the expert counsel and advice of these aid and i renew the recommendation which i make last year that the aid be recognize by statute

 it be certain that the navy with its present size should have admiral in active command high than rear admiral the recognize grade in order be admiral of the fleet admiral vice admiral and rear admiral our great battleship fleet be command by a rear admiral with four other rear admiral under his order this be not as it should be and when question of precedence arise between our naval officer and those of european navy the american rear admiral though in command of ten time the force of a foreign vice admiral must yield precedence to the latter such an absurdity ought not to prevail and it can be avoid by the creation of two or three position of flag rank above that of rear admiral

 i attend the opening of the new training school at north chicago ill. and be glad to note the opportunity which this give for draw upon young man of the country from the interior from farm store shop and office which insure a high average of intelligence and character among they and which they show in the very wonderful improvement in discipline and drill which only a few short week presence at the naval station have make

 i invite your attention to the consideration of the new system of detention and of punishment for army and navy enlist man which have obtain in great britain and which have make greatly for the well control of the man we should adopt a similar system here

 like the treasury department and the war department the navy department have give much attention to economy in administration and have cut down a number of unnecessary expense and reduce its estimate except for construction and the increase that that involve

 i urge upon congress the necessity for an immediate increase of 2,000 man in the enlisted strength of the navy provide for in the estimate four thousand more be now need to man all the available vessel

 there be in the service to day about 47,750 enlisted man of all rating

 careful computation show that in april 1912 49,166 man will be require for vessel in commission and 3,000 apprentice seaman should be keep under training at all time

 abolition of navy yards

 the secretary of the navy have recommend the abolition of certain of the small and unnecessary navy yard and in order to furnish a complete and comprehensive report have refer the question of all navy yard to the joint board of the army and navy this board will shortly make its report and the secretary of the navy advise i that his recommendation on the subject will be present early in the come year the measure of economy contain in a proper handling of this subject be so great and so important to the interest of the nation that i shall present it to congress as a separate subject apart from my annual message concentration of the necessary work for naval vessel in a few navy yard on each coast be a vital necessity if proper economy in government expenditure be to be attain

 amalgamation of staff corps in the navy

 the secretary of the navy be strive to unify the various corp of the navy to the extent possible and thereby stimulate a navy spirit as distinguish from a corps spirit in this he have my warm support

 all officer be to be naval officer first and specialist afterwards this mean that officer will take up at least one specialty such as ordnance construction or engineering this be practically what be do now only some of the specialist like the pay officer and naval constructor be not of the line it be propose to make they all of the line

 all combatant corp should obviously be of the line this necessitate amalgamate the pay officer and also those engage in the technical work of produce the finished ship this be at present the case with the single exception of the naval constructor whom it be now propose to amalgamate with the line

 council of national defense

 i urge again upon congress the desirability of establish the council of national defense the bill to establish this council be before congress last winter and it be hope that this legislation will pass during the present session the purpose of the council be to determine the general policy of national defense and to recommend to congress and to the president such measure relate to it as it shall deem necessary and expedient

 no such machinery be now provide by which the readiness of the army and navy may be improve and the program of military and naval requirement shall be coordinate and properly scrutinize with a view of the necessity of the whole nation rather than of separate department

 department of agriculture and commerce and labor

 for the consideration of matter which be pende or have be dispose of in the agricultural department and in the department of commerce and labor i refer to the very excellent report of the secretary of those department i shall not be able to submit to congress until after the christmas holiday the question of conservation of our resource arise in alaska and the west and the question of the rate for second class mail matter in the post office department

 commission on efficiency and economy

 the law do not require the submission of the report of the commission on economy and efficiency until the 31st of december i shall therefore not be able to submit a report of the work of that commission until the assembling of congress after the holiday

 civil retirement and contributory pension system

 i have already advocate in my last annual message the adoption of a civil service retirement system with a contributory feature to it so as to reduce to a minimum the cost to the government of the pension to be pay after considerable reflection i be very much opposed to a pension system that involve no contribution from the employee i think the experience of other government justify this view but the cry necessity for some such contributory system with possibly a preliminary governmental outlay in order to cover the initial cost and to set the system go at once while the contribution be accumulate be manifest on every side nothing will so much promote the economy and efficiency of the government as such a system

 elimination of all local offices from politics

 i wish to renew again my recommendation that all the local office throughout the country include collector of internal revenue collector of custom postmaster of all four class immigration commissioner and marshal should be by law cover into the classified service the necessity for confirmation by the senate be remove and the president and the other whose time be now take up in distribute this patronage under the custom that have prevail since the beginning of the government in accordance with the recommendation of the senators and congressman of the majority party should be relieve from this burden i be confident that such a change would greatly reduce the cost of administer the government and that it would add greatly to its efficiency it would take away the power to use the patronage of the government for political purpose when officer be recommend by senator and congressmen from political motive and for political service render it be impossible to expect that while in office the appointee will not regard their tenure as more or less dependent upon continue political service for their patron and no regulation however stiff or rigid will prevent this because such regulation in view of the method and motive for selection be plainly inconsistent and deem hardly worthy of respect

part 1 on our foreign relations to the senate and house of representatives the foreign relation of the united states actually and potentially affect the state of the union to a degree not widely realize and hardly surpass by any other factor in the welfare of the whole nation the position of the united states in the moral intellectual and material relation of the family of nation should be a matter of vital interest to every patriotic citizen the national prosperity and power impose upon us duty which we can not shirk if we be to be true to our ideal the tremendous growth of the export trade of the united states have already make that trade a very real factor in the industrial and commercial prosperity of the country with the development of our industry the foreign commerce of the united states must rapidly become a still more essential factor in its economic welfare whether we have a farseeing and wise diplomacy and be not recklessly plunge into unnecessary war and whether our foreign policy be base upon an intelligent grasp of present day world condition and a clear view of the potentiality of the future or be govern by a temporary and timid expediency or by narrow view befit an infant nation be question in the alternative consideration of which must convince any thoughtful citizen that no department of national polity offer great opportunity for promote the interest of the whole people on the one hand or great chance on the other of permanent national injury than that which deal with the foreign relation of the united states the fundamental foreign policy of the united states should be raise high above the conflict of partisanship and wholly dissociate from difference as to domestic policy in its foreign affair the united states should present to the world a united front the intellectual financial and industrial interest of the country and the publicist the wage earner the farmer and citizen of whatever occupation must cooperate in a spirit of high patriotism to promote that national solidarity which be indispensable to national efficiency and to the attainment of national ideal the relation of the united states with all foreign power remain upon a sound basis of peace harmony and friendship a great insistence upon justice to american citizen or interest wherever it may have be deny and a strong emphasis of the need of mutuality in clearly certain concrete policy which be the logical modern corollary of the undisputed and traditional fundamental of the foreign policy of the united states reorganization of the state department at the total estimate for 1913 of more than $ 5,000,000.the estimate for panama canal construction for 1914 be $ 17,000,000 less than for 1913our banking and currency system a time when panic seem far removed be the good time for we to prepare our financial system to withstand a storm the most cry need this country have be a proper banking and currency system the exist one be inadequate and everyone who have study the question admit it it be the business of the national government to provide a medium automatically contract and expand in volume to meet the need of trade our present system lack the indispensable quality of elasticity the only part of our monetary medium that have elasticity be the bank note currency the peculiar provision of the law require national bank to maintain reserve to meet the call of the depositor operate to increase the money stringency when it arise rather than to expand the supply of currency and relieve it it operate upon each bank and furnish a motive for the withdrawal of currency from the channel of trade by each bank to save itself and offer no inducement whatever for the use of the reserve to expand the supply of currency to meet the exceptional demand after the panic of 1907 congress realize that the present system be not adapt to the country 's need and that under it panic be possible that might properly be avoid by legislative provision accordingly a monetary commission be appoint which make a report in february 1912 the system which they recommend involve a national reserve association which be in certain of its faculty and function a bank and which be give through its governing authority the power by issue circulate note for approve commercial paper by fix discount and by other method of transfer of currency to expand the supply of the monetary medium where it be most need to prevent the export or hoarding of gold and generally to exercise such supervision over the supply of money in every part of the country as to prevent a stringency and a panic the stock in this association be to be distribute to the bank of the whole united states state and national in a mixed proportion to bank unit and to capital stock pay in the control of the association be vest in a board of director to be elect by representative of the bank except certain ex officio director three cabinet officer and the comptroller of the currency the president be to appoint the governor of the association from three person to be select by the director while the two deputy governor be to be elect by the board of director the detail of the plan be work out with great care and ability and the plan in general seem to i to furnish the basis for a proper solution of our present difficulty i feel that the government might very properly be give a great voice in the executive committee of the board of director without danger of inject politic into its management but i think the federation system of bank be a good one provide proper precaution be take to prevent bank of large capital from absorb power through ownership of stock in other bank the objection to a central bank it seem to i be obviate if the ownership of the reserve association be distribute among all the bank of a country in which banking be free the earning of the reserve association be limit in percentage tit a reasonable and fix amount and the profit over and above this be to be turn into the government treasury it be quite probable that still great security against control by money center may be work into the plan certain it be however that the objection which be make in the past history of this country to a central bank as furnish a monopoly of financial power to private individual would not apply to an association whose ownership and control be so widely distribute and be divide between all the bank of the country state and national on the one hand and the chief executive through three department head and his comptroller of the currency on the other the ancient hostility to a national bank with its branch in which be concentrate the privilege of do a banking business and carry on the financial transaction of the government have prevent the establishment of such a bank since it be abolish in the jackson administration our present national banking law have obviate objection grow out of the same cause by provide a free banking system in which any set of stockholder can establish a national bank if they comply with the condition of law it seem to i that the national reserve association meet the same objection in a similar way that be by give to each bank state and national in accordance with its size a certain share in the stock of the reserve association nontransferable and only to be hold by the bank while it perform its function as a partner in the reserve association the report of the commission recommend provision for the imposition of a graduate tax on the expand currency of such a character as to furnish a motive for reduce the issue of note whenever their presence in the money market be not require by the exigency of trade in other word the whole system have be work out with the great care theoretically it present a plan that ought to command support practically it may require modification in various of its provision in order to make the security against abuse by combination among the bank impossible but in the face of the crying necessity that there be for improvement in our present system i urgently invite the attention of congress to the propose plan and the report of the commission with the hope that an earnest consideration may suggest amendment and change within the general plan which will lead to its adoption for the benefit of the country there be no class in the community more interested in a safe and sane banking and currency system one which will prevent panic and automatically furnish in each trade center the currency need in the carrying on of the business at that center than the wage earner there be no class in the community whose experience well qualify they to make suggestion as to the sufficiency of a currency and banking system than the banker and business man ought we therefore to ignore their recommendation and reject their financial judgment as to the proper method of reform our financial system merely because of the suspicion which exist against they in the mind of many of our fellow citizen be it not the duty of congress to take up the plan suggest examine it from all standpoint give impartial consideration to the testimony of those whose experience ought to fit they to give the good advice on the subject and then to adopt some plan which will secure the benefit desired?a banking and currency system seem far away from the wage earner and the farmer but the fact be that they be vitally interested in a safe system of currency which shall graduate its volume to the amount need and which shall prevent time of artificial stringency that frighten capital stop employment prevent the meeting of the pay roll destroy local market and produce penury and want the tariff i have regard it as my duty in former message to the congress to urge the revision of the tariff upon principle of protection it be my judgment that the custom duty ought to be revise downward but that the reduction ought not to be below a rate which would represent the difference in the cost of production between the article in question at home and abroad and for this and other reason i veto several bill which be present to i in the last session of this congress now that a new congress have be elect on a platform of a tariff for revenue only rather than a protective tariff and be to revise the tariff on that basis it be
