immediately raise to full strength but our law have provide no mean by which this could be accomplish or by which the loss of the regiment when once send to the front could be repair in this respect we have neglect the lesson learn by other nation the new law provide that the soldier after serve four year with color shall pass into a reserve for three year at his option he may go into the reserve at the end of three year remain there for four year while in the reserve he can be call to active duty only in case of war or other national emergency and when so call and only in such case will receive a stated amount of pay for all of the period in which he have be a member of the reserve the legislation be imperfect in my opinion in certain particular but it be a most important step in the right direction and i earnestly hope that it will be carefully study and perfect by congress the national guard under exist law the national guard constitute after the regular army the first line of national defense its organization discipline training and equipment under recent legislation have be assimilate as far as possible to those of the regular army and its practical efficiency under the efficiency on the part of the national guard the organized militia to day can not be order outside of the limit of the united states and thus can not lawfully be use for general military purpose the officer and man be ambitious and eager to make themselves thus available and to become an efficient national reserve of citizen soldiery they be the only force of train man other than the regular army those adopt for the regular army be be formulate by the war college division of the general staff national volunteers the national guard consist of only about 110,000 man in any serious war in the volunteer there be at present no adequate provision of law for the raising of such a force there be now pende in congress however a bill which make such provision and which i believe be admirably war come the method therein direct be in accordance with the good military judgment as to what they ought to be and the act would prevent the necessity for a discussion of any legislation and the regulation of water power there be pende before congress a large number of bill propose to grant privilege of erect dam for the purpose of create water power in our navigable river the pendency of these bill have bring out an important defect in the exist general dam act that act do not in my opinion grant sufficient power to the federal government in deal with the construction of such dam to exact protective condition in the interest of navigation it do not permit the federal government as a condition of its permit to require that a part of the value thus create shall be apply to the further general improvement and protection of the stream i believe this to be one of the most important matter of internal improvement now confront the government most of the navigable river of this country be comparatively long and shallow in order that they may be make fully useful for navigation there have come into vogue a method of improvement know as canalization or the slack water method which consist in build a series of dam and lock each of which will create a long pool of deep navigable water at each of these dam there be usually create also water power of commercial value if the water power thus create can be make available for the further improvement of navigation in the stream it be manifest that the improvement will be much more quickly effect on the one hand and on the other that the burden on the general taxpayer of the country will be very much reduce private interest seek permit to build water power dam in navigable stream usually urge that they thus improve navigation and that if they do not impair navigation they should be allow to take for themselves the entire profit of the water power development whatever they may do by way of relieve the government of the expense of improve navigation should be give due consideration but it must be apparent that there may be a profit beyond a reasonably liberal return upon the private investment which be a potential asset of the government in carry out a comprehensive policy of waterway development it be no objection to the retention and use of such an asset by the government that a comprehensive waterway policy will include the protection and development of the other public use of water which can not and should not be ignore in make and execute plan for the protection and development of navigation it be also equally clear that inasmuch as the water power thus create be or may be an incident of a general scheme of waterway improvement within the constitutional jurisdiction of the federal government the regulation of such water power lie also within that jurisdiction in my opinion constructive statesmanship require that legislation should be enact which will permit the development of navigation in these great river to go hand in hand with the utilization of this by product of water power create in the course of the same improvement and that the general dam act should be so amend as to make this possible i deem it highly important that the nation should adopt a consistent and harmonious treatment of these water power project which will preserve for this purpose their value to the government whose right it be to grant the permit any other policy be equivalent to throw away a most valuable national asset the panama canal during the past year the work view of the great interest which have be manifest as to some slide in the culebra cut i be glad to say that the report of col goethals should allay any apprehension on this point it be gratify to note that none of the slide which occur during this year would have interfere with the passage of the ship have the canal in fact be in operation and when the slope pressure will have be finally adjust and the growth of vegetation will minimize erosion in the bank of the cut the slide problem will be practically solve and an ample stability assure for the culebra cut although the official date of the i be glad to bring to the attention of congress the fact that the supreme court have radically alter the equity rule govern the procedure on the equity side of all federal court and though as these jurisdiction with the federal court of first instance under the statute now in force the common law procedure in each federal court be make to conform to the procedure in the state in which the court  at last a vision have be vouchsafe we of our life as a whole we seethe bad with the good the debased and decadent with the sound and vital with this vision we approach new affair our duty be to cleanse to reconsider to restore to correct the evil without impair the good to purify andhumanize every process of our common life without weaken or sentimentalizingit there have be something crude and heartless and unfeele in our hasteto succeed and be great our thought have be let every man look out forhimself let every generation look out for itself while we rear giantmachinery which make it impossible that any but those who stand at thelever of control should have a chance to look out for themselves we hadnot forget our moral we remember well enough that we have set upa policy which be mean to serve the humblest as well as the most powerful with an eye single to the standard of justice and fair play and rememberedit with pride but we be very heedless and in a hurry to be great

mr. speaker mr. president gentlemen of the congress
 i be very glad indeed to have this opportunity to address the two houses directly and to verify for myself the impression that the president of the united states be a person not a mere department of the government hail congress from some isolated island of jealous power send message not speak naturally and with his own voice&mdash;that he be a human be try to cooperate with other human being in a common service after this pleasant experience i shall feel quite normal in all our dealing with one another
 i have call the congress together in extraordinary session because a duty be lay upon the party now in power at the recent election which it ought to perform promptly in order that the burden carry by the people under exist law may be lighten as soon as possible and in order also that the business interest of the country may not be keep too long in suspense as to what the fiscal change be to be to which they will be require to adjust themselves it be clear to the whole country that the tariff duty must be alter they must be change to meet the radical alteration in the condition of our economic life which the country have witness within the last generation while the whole face and method of our industrial and commercial life be be change beyond recognition the tariff schedule have remain what they be before the change begin or have move in the direction they be give when no large circumstance of our industrial development be what it be to day our task be to square they with the actual fact the soon that be do the soon we shall escape from suffer from the fact and the soon our man of business will be free to thrive by the law of nature the nature of free business instead of by the law of legislation and artificial arrangement
 we have see tariff legislation wander very far afield in our day&mdash;very far indeed from the field in which our prosperity might have have a normal growth and stimulation no one who look the fact squarely in the face or know anything that lie beneath the surface of action can fail to perceive the principle upon which recent tariff legislation have be base we long ago pass beyond the modest notion of protect the industry of the country and move boldly forward to the idea that they be entitle to the direct patronage of the government for a long time&mdash;a time so long that the man now active in public policy hardly remember the condition that precede it&mdash;we have seek in our tariff schedule to give each group of manufacturer or producer what they themselves think that they need in order to maintain a practically exclusive market as against the rest of the world consciously or unconsciously we have build up a set of privilege and exemption from competition behind which it be easy by any even the crude form of combination to organize monopoly until at last nothing be normal nothing be oblige to stand the test of efficiency and economy in our world of big business but everything thrive by concerted arrangement only new principle of action will save we from a final hard crystallization of monopoly and a complete loss of the influence that quicken enterprise and keep independent energy alive
 it be plain what those principle must be we must abolish everything that bear even the semblance of privilege or of any kind of artificial advantage and put our business man and producer under the stimulation of a constant necessity to be efficient economical and enterprising master of competitive supremacy well worker and merchant than any in the world aside from the duty lay upon article which we do not and probably can not produce therefore and the duty lay upon luxury and merely for the sake of the revenue they yield the object of the tariff duty henceforth lay must be effective competition the whetting of american wit by contest with the wit of the rest of the world
 it would be unwise to move toward this end headlong with reckless haste or with stroke that cut at the very root of what have grow up amongst we by long process and at our own invitation it do not alter a thing to upset it and break it and deprive it of a chance to change it destroy it we must make change in our fiscal law in our fiscal system whose object be development a more free and wholesome development not revolution or upset or confusion we must build up trade especially foreign trade we need the outlet and the enlarged field of energy more than we ever do before we must build up industry as well and must adopt freedom in the place of artificial stimulation only so far as it will build not pull down in deal with the tariff the method by which this may be do will be a matter of judgment exercise item by item to some not accustomed to the excitement and responsibility of great freedom our method may in some respect and at some point seem heroic but remedy may be heroic and yet be remedy it be our business to make sure that they be genuine remedy our object be clear if our motive be above just challenge and only an occasional error of judgment be chargeable against we we shall be fortunate
 we be call upon to render the country a great service in more matter than one our responsibility should be meet and our method should be thorough as thorough as moderate and well consider base upon the fact as they be and not work out as if we be beginner we be to deal with the fact of our own day with the fact of no other and to make law which square with those fact it be good indeed it be necessary to begin with the tariff i will urge nothing upon you now at the opening of your session which can obscure that first object or divert our energy from that clearly define duty at a later time i may take the liberty of call your attention to reform which should press close upon the heel of the tariff change if not accompany they of which the chief be the reform of our banking and currency law but just now i refrain for the present i put these matter on one side and think only of this one thing&mdash;of the change in our fiscal system which may well serve to open once more the free channel of prosperity to a great people whom we would serve to the utmost and throughout both rank and file
 i thank you for your courtesy

mr. speaker mr. president gentlemen of the congress
 it be under the compulsion of what seem to i a clear and imperative duty that i have a second time this session seek the privilege of address you in person i know of course that the heated season of the year be upon we that work in these chamber and in the committee room be likely to become a burden as the season lengthen and that every consideration of personal convenience and personal comfort perhaps in the case of some of we consideration of personal health even dictate an early conclusion of the deliberation of the session but there be occasion of public duty when these thing which touch we privately seem very small when the work to be do be so pressing and so fraught with big consequence that we know that we be not at liberty to weigh against it any point of personal sacrifice we be now in the presence of such an occasion it be absolutely imperative that we should give the business man of this country a banking and currency system by mean of which they can make use of the freedom of enterprise and of individual initiative which we be about to bestow upon they
 we be about to set they free we must not leave they without the tool of action when they be free we be about to set they free by remove the trammel of the protective tariff ever since the civil war they have wait for this emancipation and for the free opportunity it will bring with it it have be reserve for we to give it to they some fall in love indeed with the slothful security of their dependence upon the government some take advantage of the shelter of the nursery to set up a mimic mastery of their own within its wall now both the tonic and the discipline of liberty and maturity be to ensue there will be some readjustment of purpose and point of view there will follow a period of expansion and new enterprise freshly conceive it be for we to determine now whether it shall be rapid and facile and of easy accomplishment this it can not be unless the resourceful business man who be to deal with the new circumstance be to have at hand and ready for use the instrumentality and convenience of free enterprise which independent man need when act on their own initiative
 it be not enough to strike the shackle from business the duty of statesmanship be not negative merely it be constructive also we must show that we understand what business need and that we know how to supply it no man however casual and superficial his observation of the condition now prevail in the country can fail to see that one of the chief thing business need now and will need increasingly as it gain in scope and vigor in the year immediately ahead of we be the proper mean by which readily to vitalize its credit corporate and individual and its originative brain what will it profit we to be free if we be not to have the good and most accessible instrumentality of commerce and enterprise what will it profit we to be quit of one kind of monopoly if we be to remain in the grip of another and more effective kind how be we to gain and keep the confidence of the business community unless we show that we know how both to aid and to protect it what shall we say if we make fresh enterprise necessary and also make it very difficult by leave all else except the tariff just as we find it the tyranny of business big and little lie within the field of credit we know that shall we not act upon the knowledge do we not know how to act upon it if a man can not make his asset available at pleasure his asset of capacity and character and resource what satisfaction be it to he to see opportunity beckoning to he on every hand when other have the key of credit in their pocket and treat they as all but their own private possession it be perfectly clear that it be our duty to supply the new banking and currency system the country need and it will need it immediately more than it have ever need it before
 the only question be when shall we supply it&mdash;now or later after the demand shall have become reproach that we be so dull and so slow shall we hasten to change the tariff law and then be laggard about make it possible and easy for the country to take advantage of the change there can be only one answer to that question we must act now at whatever sacrifice to ourselves it be a duty which the circumstance forbid we to postpone i should be recreant to my deep conviction of public obligation do i not press it upon you with solemn and urgent insistence
 the principle upon which we should act be also clear the country have seek and see its path in this matter within the last few years&mdash;see it more clearly now than it ever see it before&mdash;much more clearly than when the last legislative proposal on the subject be make we must have a currency not rigid as now but readily elastically responsive to sound credit the expand and contracting credit of everyday transaction the normal ebb and flow of personal and corporate dealing our banking law must mobilize reserve must not permit the concentration anywhere in a few hand of the monetary resource of the country or their use for speculative purpose in such volume as to hinder or impede or stand in the way of other more legitimate more fruitful use and the control of the system of banking and of issue which our new law be to set up must be public not private must be vest in the government itself so that the bank may be the instrument not the master of business and of individual enterprise and initiative
 the committee of the congress to which legislation of this character be refer have devote careful and dispassionate study to the mean of accomplish these object they have honor i by consult i they be ready to suggest action i have come to you as the head of the government and the responsible leader of the party in power to urge action now while there be time to serve the country deliberately and as we should in a clear air of common counsel i appeal to you with a deep conviction of duty i believe that you share this conviction i therefore appeal to you with confidence i be at your service without reserve to play my part in any way you may call upon i to play it in this great enterprise of exigent reform which it will dignify and distinguish we to perform and discredit we to neglect

 in my report on the state of the union which i have the privilege of reading to you on the 2d of december last i venture to reserve for discussion at a later date the subject of additional legislation regard the very difficult and intricate matter of trust and monopoly the time now seem opportune to turn to that great question not only because the currency legislation which absorb your attention and the attention of the country in december be now disposed of but also because opinion seem to be clear about we with singular rapidity in this other great field of action in the matter of the currency it clear suddenly and very happily after the much debate act be pass in respect of the monopoly which have multiply about we and in regard to the various mean by which they have be organize and maintain it seem to be come to a clear and all but universal agreement in anticipation of our action as if by way of preparation make the way easy to see and easy to set out upon with confidence and without confusion of counsel

 the great business man who organize and finance monopoly and those who administer it in actual everyday transaction have year after year until now either deny its existence or justify it as necessary for the effective maintenance and development of the vast business process of the country in the modern circumstance of trade and manufacture and finance but all the while opinion have make head against they the average business man be convince that the way of liberty be also the way of peace and the way of success as well and at last the master of business on the great scale have begin to yield their preference and purpose perhaps their judgment also in honorable surrender

 what we be purpose to do therefore be happily not to hamper or interfere with business as enlightened business man prefer to do it or in any sense to put it under the ban the antagonism between business and government be over we be now about to give expression to the good business judgment of america to what we know to be the business conscience and honor of the land the government and business man be ready to meet each other half way in a common effort to square business method with both public opinion and the law the well inform man of the business world condemn the method and process and consequence of monopoly as we condemn they and the instinctive judgment of the vast majority of business man everywhere go with they we shall now be their spokesman that be the strength of our position and the sure prophecy of what will ensue when our reasonable work be do

 when serious contest end when man unite in opinion and purpose those who be to change their way of business join with those who ask for the change it be possible to effect it in the way in which prudent and thoughtful and patriotic man would wish to see it bring about with as few as slight as easy and simple business readjustment as possible in the circumstance nothing essential disturb nothing tear up by the root no part rent asunder which can be leave in wholesome combination fortunately no measure of sweeping or novel change be necessary it will be understand that our object be not to unsettle business or anywhere seriously to break its establish course athwart on the contrary we desire the law we be now about to pass to be the bulwark and safeguard of industry against the force that have disturb it what we have to do can be do in a new spirit in thoughtful moderation without revolution of any untoward kind

 we be all agree that private monopoly be indefensible and intolerable and our program be found upon that conviction it will be a comprehensive but not a radical or unacceptable program and these be its item the change which opinion deliberately sanction and for which business wait

 it wait with acquiescence in the first place for law which will effectually prohibit and prevent such interlocking of the personnel of the directorate of great corporations?bank and railroad industrial commercial and public service bodies?as in effect result in make those who borrow and those who lend practically one and the same those who sell and those who buy but the same person trade with one another under different name and in different combination and those who affect to compete in fact partner and master of some whole field of business sufficient time should be allow of course in which to effect these change of organization without inconvenience or confusion

 such a prohibition will work much more than a mere negative good by correct the serious evil which have arise because for example the man who have be the direct spirit of the great investment bank have usurp the place which belong to independent industrial management work in its own behoof it will bring new man new energy a new spirit of initiative new blood into the management of our great business enterprise it will open the field of industrial development and origination to score of man who have be oblige to serve when their ability entitle they to direct it will immensely hearten the young man come on and will greatly enrich the business activity of the whole country

 in the second place business man as well as those who direct public affair now recognize and recognize with painful clearness the great harm and injustice which have be do to many if not all of the great railroad system of the country by the way in which they have be finance and their own distinctive interest subordinate to the interest of the man who finance they and of other business enterprise which those man wish to promote the country be ready therefore to accept and accept with relief as well as approval a law which will confer upon the interstate commerce commission the power to superintend and regulate the financial operation by which the railroad be henceforth to be supply with the money they need for their proper development to meet the rapidly grow requirement of the country for increase and improved facility of transportation we can not postpone action in this matter without leave the railroad expose to many serious handicap and hazard and the prosperity of the railroad and the prosperity of the country be inseparably connect upon this question those who be chiefly responsible for the actual management and operation of the railroad have speak very plainly and very earnestly with a purpose we ought to be quick to accept it will be one step and a very important one toward the necessary separation of the business of production from the business of transportation

 the business of the country await also have long await and have suffer because it could not obtain far and more explicit legislative definition of the policy and meaning of the exist antitrust law nothing hamper business like uncertainty nothing daunt or discourage it like the necessity to take chance to run the risk of fall under the condemnation of the law before it can make sure just what the law be surely we be sufficiently familiar with the actual process and method of monopoly and of the many hurtful restraint of trade to make definition possible at any rate up to the limit of what experience have disclose these practice be now abundantly disclose can be explicitly and item by item forbid by statute in such term as will practically eliminate uncertainty the law itself and the penalty be make equally plain

 and the business man of the country desire something more than that the menace of legal process in these matter be make explicit and intelligible they desire the advice the definite guidance and information which can be supply by an administrative body an interstate trade commission

 the opinion of the country would instantly approve of such a commission it would not wish to see it empower to make term with monopoly or in any sort to assume control of business as if the government make itself responsible it demand such a commission only as an indispensable instrument of information and publicity as a clearing house for the fact by which both the public mind and the manager of great business undertaking should be guide and as an instrumentality for do justice to business where the process of the court or the natural force of correction outside the court be inadequate to adjust the remedy to the wrong in a way that will meet all the equity and circumstance of the case

 produce industry for example which have pass the point up to which combination may be consistent with the public interest and the freedom of trade can not always be dissect into their component unit as readily as railroad company or similar organization can be their dissolution by ordinary legal process may oftentime involve financial consequence likely to overwhelm the security market and bring upon it breakdown and confusion there ought to be an administrative commission capable of direct and shape such corrective process not only in aid of the court but also by independent suggestion if necessary

 inasmuch as our object and the spirit of our action in these matter be to meet business half way in its process of self correction and disturb its legitimate course as little as possible we ought to see to it and the judgment of practical and sagacious man of affair everywhere would applaud we if we do see to it that penalty and punishment should fall not upon business itself to its confusion and interruption but upon the individual who use the instrumentality of business to do thing which public policy and sound business practice condemn every act of business be do at the command or upon the initiative of some ascertainable person or group of person these should be hold individually responsible and the punishment should fall upon they not upon the business organization of which they make illegal use it should be one of the main object of our legislation to divest such person of their corporate cloak and deal with they as with those who do not represent their corporation but merely by deliberate intention break the law business man the country through would i be sure applaud we if we be to take effectual step to see that the officer and director of great business body be prevent from bring they and the business of the country into disrepute and danger

gentleman of the congress
 it be my duty to call your attention to a situation which have arise in our dealing with general victoriano huerta at mexico city which call for action and to ask your advice and cooperation in act upon it
 on the 9th of april a paymaster of the u.s.s. dolphin land at the iturbide bridge landing at tampico with a whaleboat and boat&#39;s crew to take off certain supply need by his ship and while engage in load the boat be arrest by an officer and squad of man of the army of general huerta neither the paymaster nor anyone of the boat&#39;s crew be arm two of the man be in the boat when the arrest take place and be oblige to leave it and submit to be take into custody notwithstanding the fact that the boat carry both at her bow and at her stern the flag of the united states the officer who make the arrest be proceed up one of the street of the town with his prisoner when meet by an officer of high authority who order he to return to the landing and await order and within an hour and a half from the time of the arrest order be receive from the commander of the huertista force at tampico for the release of the paymaster and his man the release be follow by apology from the commander and later by an expression of regret by general huerta himself general huerta urge that martial law obtain at the time at tampico that order have be issue that no one should be allow to land at the iturbide bridge and that our sailor have no right to land there our naval commander at the port have not be notify of any such prohibition and even if they have be the only justifiable course open to the local authority would have be to request the paymaster and his crew to withdraw and to lodge a protest with the command officer of the fleet admiral mayo regard the arrest as so serious an affront that he be not satisfied with the apology offer but demand that the flag of the united states be salute with special ceremony by the military commander of the port
 the incident can not be regard as a trivial one especially as two of the man arrest be take from the boat itself&mdash;that be to say from the territory of the united states&mdash;but have it stand by itself it might have be attribute to the ignorance or arrogance of a single officer unfortunately it be not an isolated case a series of incident have recently occur which can not but create the impression that the representative of general huerta be willing to go out of their way to show disregard for the dignity and right of this government and feel perfectly safe in do what they please make free to show in many way their irritation and contempt a few day after the incident at tampico an orderly from the u.s.s. minnesota be arrest at vera cruz while ashore in uniform to obtain the ship&#39;s mail and be for a time throw into jail an official dispatch from this government to its embassy at mexico city be withhold by the authority of the telegraphic service until peremptorily demand by our charge d&#39;affaire in person so far as i can learn such wrong and annoyance have be suffer to occur only against representative of the united states i have hear of no complaint from other government of similar treatment subsequent explanation and formal apology do not and could not alter the popular impression which it be possible it have be the object of the huertista authority to create that the government of the united states be be single out and might be single out with impunity for slight and affront in retaliation for its refusal to recognize the pretension of general huerta to be regard as the constitutional provisional president of the republic of mexico
 the manifest danger of such a situation be that such offense might grow from bad to bad until something happen of so gross and intolerable a sort as to lead directly and inevitably to armed conflict it be necessary that the apology of general huerta and his representative should go much far that they should be such as to attract the attention of the whole population to their significance and such as to impress upon general huerta himself the necessity of see to it that no further occasion for explanation and profess regret should arise i therefore feel it my duty to sustain admiral mayo in the whole of his demand and to insist that the flag of the united states should be salute in such a way as to indicate a new spirit and attitude on the part of the huertistas
 such a salute general huerta have refuse and i have come to ask your approval and support in the course i now purpose to pursue
 this government can i earnestly hope in no circumstance be force into war with the people of mexico mexico be tear by civil strife if we be to accept the test of its own constitution it have no government general huerta have set his power up in the city of mexico such as it be without right and by method for which there can be no justification only part of the country be under his control if armed conflict should unhappily come as a result of his attitude of personal resentment toward this government we should be fight only general huerta and those who adhere to he and give he their support and our object would be only to restore to the people of the distracted republic the opportunity to set up again their own law and their own government
 but i earnestly hope that war be not now in question i believe that i speak for the american people when i say that we do not desire to control in any degree the affair of our sister republic our feeling for the people of mexico be one of deep and genuine friendship and everything that we have so far do or refrain from do have proceed from our desire to help they not to hinder or embarrass they we would not wish even to exercise the good office of friendship without their welcome and consent the people of mexico be entitle to settle their own domestic affair in their own way and we sincerely desire to respect their right the present situation need have none of the grave implication of interference if we deal with it promptly firmly and wisely
 no doubt i could do what be necessary in the circumstance to enforce respect for our government without recourse to the congress and yet not exceed my constitutional power as president but i do not wish to act in a matter possibly of so grave consequence except in close conference and cooperation with both the senate and house i therefore come to ask your approval that i should use the armed force of the united states in such way and to such an extent as may be necessary to obtain from general huerta and his adherent the full recognition of the right and dignity of the united states even amidst the distressing condition now unhappily obtain in mexico
 there can in what we do be no thought of aggression or of selfish aggrandizement we seek to maintain the dignity and authority of the united states only because we wish always to keep our great influence unimpaire for the use of liberty both in the united states and wherever else it may be employ for the benefit of mankind

mr. chairman and fellow citizens
 we be assemble to celebrate the one hundred and thirty eighth anniversary of the birth of the united states i suppose that we can more vividly realize the circumstance of that birth stand on this historic spot than it would be possible to realize they anywhere else the declaration of independence be write in philadelphia it be adopt in this historic building by which we stand i have just have the privilege of sit in the chair of the great man who preside over the deliberation of those who give the declaration to the world my hand rest at this moment upon the table upon which the declaration be sign we can feel that we be almost in the visible and tangible presence of a great historic transaction
 have you ever read the declaration of independence or attend with close comprehension to the real character of it when you have hear it read if you have you will know that it be not a fourth of july oration the declaration of independence be a document preliminary to war it be a vital piece of practical business not a piece of rhetoric and if you will pass beyond those preliminary passage which we be accustom to quote about the right of man and read into the heart of the document you will see that it be very express and detail that it consist of a series of definite specification concern actual public business of the day not the business of our day for the matter with which it deal be past but the business of that first revolution by which the nation be set up the business of 1776 its general statement its general declaration can not mean anything to we unless we append to it a similar specific body of particular as to what we consider the essential business of our own day

 it be patriotic also to learn what the fact of our national life be and to face they with candor i have hear a great many fact state about the present business condition of this country for example&mdash;a great many allegation of fact at any rate but the allegation do not tally with one another and yet i know that truth always match with truth and when i find some insist that everything be go wrong and other insist that everything be go right and when i know from a wide observation of the general circumstance of the country take as a whole that thing be go extremely well i wonder what those who be cry out that thing be wrong be try to do be they try to serve the country or be they try to serve something small than the country be they try to put hope into the heart of the man who work and toil every day or be they try to plant discouragement and despair in those heart and why do they cry that everything be wrong and yet do nothing to set it right if they love america and anything be wrong amongst we it be their business to put their hand with our to the task of set it right when the fact be know and acknowledge the duty of all patriotic man be to accept they in candor and to address themselves hopefully and confidently to the common counsel which be necessary to act upon they wisely and in universal concert

my fellow countryman

 i suppose that every thoughtful man in america have ask himself during these last troubled week what influence the european war may exert upon the united states and i take the liberty of address a few word to you in order to point out that it be entirely within our own choice what its effect upon we will be and to urge very earnestly upon you the sort of speech and conduct which will well safeguard the nation against distress and disaster

 the effect of the war upon the united states will depend upon what american citizen say and do every man who really love america will act and speak in the true spirit of neutrality which be the spirit of impartiality and fairness and friendliness to all concern the spirit of the nation in this critical matter will be determine largely by what individual and society and those gather in public meeting do and say upon what newspaper and magazine contain upon what minister utter in their pulpit and man proclaim as their opinion on the street

 the people of the united states be draw from many nation and chiefly from the nation now at war it be natural and inevitable that there should be the utmost variety of sympathy and desire among they with regard to the issue and circumstance of the conflict some will wish one nation other another to succeed in the momentous struggle it will be easy to excite passion and difficult to allay it those responsible for exciting it will assume a heavy responsibility responsibility for no less a thing than that the people of the united states whose love of their country and whose loyalty to its government should unite they as americans all bind in honor and affection to think first of she and her interest may be divide in camp of hostile opinion hot against each other involve in the war itself in impulse and opinion if not in action

 such division among we would be fatal to our peace of mind and might seriously stand in the way of the proper performance of our duty as the one great nation at peace the one people hold itself ready to play a part of impartial mediation and speak the counsel of peace and accommodation not as a partisan but as a friend

 i venture therefore my fellow countryman to speak a solemn word of warning to you against that deepest most subtle most essential breach of neutrality which may spring out of partisanship out of passionately take side the united states must be neutral in fact as well as in name during these day that be to try man 's soul we must be impartial in thought as well as in action must put a curb upon our sentiment as well as upon every transaction that might be construe as a preference of one party to the struggle before another

 my thought be of america i be speak i feel sure the earnest wish and purpose of every thoughtful american that this great country of our which be of course the first in our thought and in our heart should show herself in this time of peculiar trial a nation fit beyond other to exhibit the fine poise of undisturbed judgment the dignity of self control the efficiency of dispassionate action a nation that neither sit in judgment upon other nor be disturb in her own counsel and which keep herself fit and free to do what be honest and disinterested and truly serviceable for the peace of the world

 shall we not resolve to put upon ourselves the restraint which will bring to our people the happiness and the great and lasting influence for peace we covet for they

mr. president gentlemen of the american bar association

 i be very deeply gratified by the greeting that your president have give i and by your response to it my only strength lie in your confidence

 we stand now in a peculiar case our first thought i suppose as lawyer be of international law of those bond of right and principle which draw the nation together and hold the community of the world to some standard of action we know that we see in international law as it be the moral process by which law itself come into existence i know that as a lawyer i have myself at time feel that there be no real comparison between the law of a nation and the law of nation because the latter lack the sanction that give the former strength and validity and yet if you look into the matter more closely you will find that the two have the same foundation and that those foundation be more evident and conspicuous in our day than they have ever be before

 the opinion of the world be the mistress of the world and the process of international law be the slow process by which opinion work its will what impress i be the constant thought that that be the tribunal at the bar of which we all sit i would call your attention incidentally to the circumstance that it do not observe the ordinary rule of evidence which have sometimes suggest to i that the ordinary rule of evidence have show some sign of grow antique everything rumor include be hear in this court and the standard of judgment be not so much the character of the testimony as the character of the witness the motive be disclose the purpose be conjecture and that opinion be finally accept which seem to be not the good found in law perhaps but the good found in integrity of character and of moral that be the process which be slowly work its will upon the world and what we should be watchful of be not so much jealous interest as sound principle of action the disinterested course be always the big course to pursue not only but it be in the long run the most profitable course to pursue if you can establish your character you can establish your credit

 what i want to suggest to this association in bid they very hearty welcome to the city be whether we sufficiently apply these same idea to the body of municipal law which we seek to administer citation seem to play so much large a role now than principle there be a time when the thoughtful eye of the judge rest upon the change of social circumstance and almost palpably see the law arise out of human life have we get to a time when the only way to change law be by statute the change of law by statute seem to i like mend a garment with a patch whereas law should grow by the life that be in it not by the life that be outside of it

 i once say to a lawyer with whom i be discuss some question of precedent and in whose presence i be venture to doubt the rational validity at any rate of the particular precedent he cite after all isn&#39;t our object justice and he say god forbid we should be very much confused if we make that our standard our standard be to find out what the rule have be and how the rule that have be applie to the case that be i should hate to think that the law be base entirely upon have been i should hate to think that the law do not derive its impulse from look forward rather than from look backward or rather that it do not derive its instruction from look about and see what the circumstance of man actually be and what the impulse of justice necessarily be

 understand i gentleman i be not venture in this presence to impeach the law for the present by the force of circumstance i be in part the embodiment of the law and it would be very awkward to disavow myself but i do wish to make this intimation that in this time of world change in this time when we be go to find out just how in what particular and to what extent the real fact of human life and the real moral judgment of mankind prevail it be worth while look inside our municipal law and see whether the judgment of the law be make square with the moral judgment of mankind for i believe that we be custodian not of command but of a spirit we be custodian of the spirit of righteousness of the spirit of equal handed justice of the spirit of hope which believe in the perfectibility of the law with the perfectibility of human life itself

 public life like private life would be very dull and dry if it be not for this belief in the essential beauty of the human spirit and the belief that the human spirit could be translate into action and into ordinance not entire you can not go any fast than you can advance the average moral judgment of the mass but you can go at least as fast as that and you can see to it that you do not lag behind the average moral judgment of the mass i have in my life deal with all sort and condition of man and i have find that the flame of moral judgment burn just as bright in the man of humble life and limited experience as in the scholar and the man of affair and i would like his voice always to be hear not as a witness not as speak in his own case but as if he be the voice of man in general in our court of justice as well as the voice of the lawyer remember what the law have be my hope be that be stir to the depth by the extraordinary circumstance of the time in which we live we may recover from those depth something of a renewal of that vision of the law with which man may be suppose to have start out in the old day of the oracle who commune with the intimation of divinity

to the house of representatives
 it be with unaffected regret that i find myself constrain by clear conviction to return this bill h.r. 6060 an act to regulate the immigration of alien to and the residence of alien in the united states without my signature not only do i feel it to be a very serious matter to exercise the power of veto in any case because it involve oppose the single judgment of the president to the judgment of a majority of both the houses of the congress a step which no man who realize his own liability to error can take without great hesitation but also because this particular bill be in so many important respect admirable well conceive and desirable its enactment into law would undoubtedly enhance the efficiency and improve the method of handle the important branch of the public service to which it relate but candor and a sense of duty with regard to the responsibility so clearly impose upon i by the constitution in matter of legislation leave i no choice but to dissent
 in two particular of vital consequence this bill embody a radical departure from the traditional and long establish policy of this country a policy in which our people have conceive the very character of their government to be express the very mission and spirit of the nation in respect of its relation to the people of the world outside their border it seek to all but close entirely the gate of asylum which have always be open to those who could find nowhere else the right and opportunity of constitutional agitation for what they conceive to be the natural and inalienable right of man and it exclude those to whom the opportunity of elementary education have be deny without regard to their character their purpose or their natural capacity
 restriction like these adopt early in our history as a nation would very materially have alter the course and cool the humane ardor of our politic the right of political asylum have bring to this country many a man of noble character and elevated purpose who be mark as an outlaw in his own less fortunate land and who have yet become an ornament to our citizenship and to our public council the child and the compatriot of these illustrious americans must stand amazed to see the representative of their nation now resolve in the fullness of our national strength and at the maturity of our great institution to risk turn such man back from our shore without test of quality or purpose it be difficult for i to believe that the full effect of this feature of the bill be realize when it be frame and adopt and it be impossible for i to assent to it in the form in which it be here cast
 the literacy test and the test and restriction which accompany it constitute an even more radical change in the policy of the nation hitherto we have generously keep our door open to all who be not unfit by reason of disease or incapacity for self support or such personal record and antecedent as be likely to make they a menace to our peace and order or to the wholesome and essential relationship of life in this bill it be propose to turn away from test of character and of quality and impose test which exclude and restrict for the new test here embody be not test of quality or of character or of personal fitness but test of opportunity those who come seek opportunity be not to be admit unless they have already have one of the chief of the opportunity they seek the opportunity of education the object of such provision be restriction not selection
 if the people of this country have make up their mind to limit the number of immigrant by arbitrary test and so reverse the policy of all the generation of americans that have go before they it be their right to do so i be their servant and have no license to stand in their way but i do not believe that they have i respectfully submit that no one can quote their mandate to that effect have any political party ever avow a policy of restriction in this fundamental matter go to the country on it and be commission to control its legislation do this bill rest upon the conscious and universal assent and desire of the american people i doubt it it be because i doubt it that i make bold to dissent from it i be willing to abide by the verdict but not until it have be render let the platform of party speak out upon this policy and the people pronounce their wish the matter be too fundamental to be settle otherwise

gentleman of the congress
 a situation have arise in the foreign relation of the country of which it be my plain duty to inform you very frankly
 it will be recall that in february 1915 the imperial german government announce its intention to treat the water surround great britain and ireland as embrace within the seat of war and to destroy all merchant ship own by its enemy that might be find within any part of that portion of the high sea and that it warn all vessel of neutral as well as of belligerent ownership to keep out of the water it have thus proscribe or else enter they at their peril the government of the united states earnestly protest it take the position that such a policy could not be pursue without the practical certainty of gross and palpable violation of the law of nation particularly if submarine craft be to be employ as its instrument inasmuch as the rule prescribe by that law rule found upon principle of humanity and establish for the protection of the life of non combatant at sea could not in the nature of the case be observe by such vessel it base its protest on the ground that person of neutral nationality and vessel of neutral ownership would be expose to extreme and intolerable risk and that no right to close any part of the high sea against their use or to expose they to such risk could lawfully be assert by any belligerent government the law of nation in these matter upon which the government of the united states base its protest be not of recent origin or found upon merely arbitrary principle set up by convention it be base on the contrary upon manifest and imperative principle of humanity and have long be establish with the approval and by the express assent of all civilized nation
 notwithstanding the earnest protest of our government the imperial german government at once proceed to carry out the policy it have announce it express the hope that the danger involve at any rate the danger to neutral vessel would be reduce to a minimum by the instruction which it have issue to its submarine commander and assure the government of the united states that it would take every possible precaution both to respect the right of neutral and to safeguard the life of non combatant
 what have actually happen in the year which have since elapse have show that those hope be not justify those assurance insusceptible of be fulfil in pursuance of the policy of submarine warfare against the commerce of its adversary thus announce and enter upon by the imperial german government in despite of the solemn protest of this government the commander of german undersea vessel have attack merchant ship with great and great activity not only upon the high sea surround great britain and ireland but wherever they could encounter they in a way that have grow more and more ruthless more and more indiscriminate as the month have go by less and less observant of restraint of any kind and have deliver their attack without compunction against vessel of every nationality and bind upon every sort of errand vessel of neutral ownership even vessel of neutral ownership bind from neutral port to neutral port have be destroy along with vessel of belligerent ownership in constantly increase number sometimes the merchantman attack have be warn and summon to surrender before be fire on or torpedo sometimes passenger or crew have be vouchsafe the poor security of be allow to take to the ship&#39;s boat before she be send to the bottom but again and again no warning have be give no escape even to the ship&#39; boat allow to those on board what this government foresaw must happen have happen tragedy have follow tragedy on the sea in such fashion with such attendant circumstance as to make it grossly evident that warfare of such a sort if warfare it be can not be carry on without the most palpable violation of the dictate alike of right and of humanity whatever the disposition and intention of the imperial german government it have manifestly prove impossible for it to keep such method of attack upon the commerce of its enemy within the bound set by either the reason or the heart of mankind
 in february of the present year the imperial german government inform this government and the other neutral government of the world that it have reason to believe that the government of great britain have arm all merchant vessel of british ownership and have give they secret order to attack any submarine of the enemy they might encounter upon the sea and that the imperial german government feel justify in the circumstance in treat all armed merchantman of belligerent ownership as auxiliary vessel of war which it would have the right to destroy without warn the law of nation have long recognize the right of merchantman to carry arm for protection and to use they to repel attack though to use they in such circumstance at their own risk but the imperial german government claim the right to set these understanding aside in circumstance which it deem extraordinary even the term in which it announce its purpose thus still far to relax the restraint it have previously profess its willingness and desire to put upon the operation of its submarine carry the plain implication that at least vessel which be not armed would still be exempt from destruction without warn and that personal safety would be accord their passenger and crew but even that limitation if it be ever practicable to observe it have in fact constitute no check at all upon the destruction of ship of every sort
 again and again the imperial german government have give this government its solemn assurance that at least passenger ship would not be thus deal with and yet it have again and again permit its undersea commander to disregard those assurance with entire impunity great liner like the lusitania and the arabic and mere ferryboat like the sussex have be attack without a moment&#39;s warning sometimes before they have even become aware that they be in the presence of an armed vessel of the enemy and the life of non combatant passenger and crew have be sacrifice wholesale in a manner which the government of the united states can not but regard as wanton and without the slight color of justification no limit of any kind have in fact be set to the indiscriminate pursuit and destruction of merchantman of all kind and nationality within the water constantly extend in area where these operation have be carry on and the roll of americans who have lose their life on ship thus attack and destroy have grow month by month until the ominous toll have mount into the hundred
 one of the late and most shocking instance of this method of warfare be that of the destruction of the french cross channel steam sussex it must stand forth as the sinking of the steamer lusitania do as so singularly tragical and unjustifiable as to constitute a truly terrible example of the inhumanity of submarine warfare as the commander of german vessel have for the past twelvemonth been conduct it if this instance stand alone some explanation some disavowal by the german government some evidence of criminal mistake or wilful disobedience on the part of the commander of the vessel that fire the torpedo might be seek or entertain but unhappily it do not stand alone recent event make the conclusion inevitable that it be only one instance even though it be one of the most extreme and distressing instance of the spirit and method of warfare which the imperial german government have mistakenly adopt and which from the first expose that government to the reproach of thrust all neutral right aside in pursuit of its immediate object
 the government of the united states have be very patient at every stage of this distressing experience of tragedy after tragedy in which its own citizen be involve it have seek to be restrain from any extreme course of action or of protest by a thoughtful consideration of the extraordinary circumstance of this unprecedented war and actuate in all that it say or do by the sentiment of genuine friendship which the people of the united states have always entertain and continue to entertain towards the german nation it have of course accept the successive explanation and assurance of the imperial german government as give in entire sincerity and good faith and have hope even against hope that it would prove to be possible for the german government so to order and control the act of its naval commander as to square its policy with the principle of humanity as embody in the law of nation it have be willing to wait until the significance of the fact become absolutely unmistakable and susceptible of but one interpretation
 that point have now unhappily be reach the fact be susceptible of but one interpretation the imperial german government have be unable to put any limit or restraint upon its warfare against either freight or passenger ship it have therefore become painfully evident that the position which this government take at the very outset be inevitable namely that the use of submarine for the destruction of an enemy&#39;s commerce be of necessity because of the very character of the vessel employ and the very method of attack which their employment of course involve incompatible with the principle of humanity the long established and incontrovertible right of neutral and the sacred immunity of non combatant
 i have deem it my duty therefore to say to the imperial german government that if it be still its purpose to prosecute relentless and indiscriminate warfare against vessel of commerce by the use of submarine notwithstanding the now demonstrate impossibility of conduct that warfare in accordance with what the government of the united states must consider the sacred and indisputable rule of international law and the universally recognize dictate of humanity the government of the united states be at last force to the conclusion that there be but one course it can pursue and that unless the imperial german government should now immediately declare and effect an abandonment of its present method of warfare against passenger and freight carry vessel this government can have no choice but to sever diplomatic relation with the government of the german empire altogether
 this decision i have arrive at with the keen regret the possibility of the action contemplate i be sure all thoughtful americans will look forward to with unaffected reluctance but we can not forget that we be in some sort and by the force of circumstance the responsible spokesman of the right of humanity and that we can not remain silent while those right seem in process of be sweep utterly away in the maelstrom of this terrible war we owe it to a due regard for our own right as a nation to our sense of duty as a representative of the right of neutral the world over and to a just conception of the right of mankind to take this stand now with the utmost solemnity and firmness
 i have take it and take it in the confidence that it will meet with your approval and support all sober minded man must unite in hope that the imperial german government which have in other circumstance stand as the champion of all that we be now contend for in the interest of humanity may recognize the justice of our demand and meet they in the spirit in which they be make

 for it be their emancipation that they be seeking,?blindly it may be and as yet ineffectually but with profound and passionate purpose and within their unquestionable right apply what true american principle you will,?any principle that an american would publicly avow the people of mexico have not be suffer to own their own country or direct their own institution outsider man out of other nation and with interest too often alien to their own have dictate what their privilege and opportunity should be and who should control their land their life and their resources,?some of they americans press for thing they could never have get in their own country the mexican people be entitle to attempt their liberty from such influence and so long as i have anything to do with the action of our great government i shall do everything in my power to prevent anyone stand in their way i know that this be hard for some person to understand but it be not hard for the plain people of the united states to understand it be hard doctrine only for those who wish to get something for themselves out of mexico there be man and noble woman too not a few of our own people thank god whose fortune be invest in great property in mexico who yet see the case with true vision and assess its issue with true american feeling the rest can be leave for the present out of the reckoning until this enslave people have have its day of struggle towards the light i have hear no one who be free from such influence propose interference by the united states with the internal affair of mexico certainly no friend of the mexican people have propose it

 the people of the united states be capable of great sympathy and a noble pity in deal with problem of this kind as their spokesman and representative i have try to act in the spirit they would wish i show the people of mexico be strive for the right that be fundamental to life and happiness,?15,000,000 oppress man overburden woman and pitiful child in virtual bondage in their own home of fertile land and inexhaustible treasure some of the leader of the revolution may often have be mistaken and violent and selfish but the revolution itself be inevitable and be right the unspeakable huerta betray the very comrade he serve traitorously overthrow the government of which he be a trusted part impudently speak for the very force that have drive his people to the rebellion with which he have pretend to sympathize the man who overcome he and drive he out represent at least the fierce passion of reconstruction which lie at the very heart of liberty and so long as they represent however imperfectly such a struggle for deliverance i be ready to serve their end when i can so long as the power of recognition rest with i the government of the united states will refuse to extend the hand of welcome to any one who obtain power in a sister republic by treachery and violence no permanency can be give the affair of any republic by a title base upon intrigue and assassination i declare that to be the policy of this administration within three week after i assume the presidency i here again vow it i be more interested in the fortune of oppressed man and pitiful woman and child than in any property right whatever mistake i have no doubt make in this perplexing business but not in purpose or object

 more be involve than the immediate destiny of mexico and the relation of the united states with a distressed and distracted people all america look on test be now be make of we whether we be sincere lover of popular liberty or not and be indeed to be trust to respect national sovereignty among our weak neighbor we have undertake these many year to play big brother to the republic of this hemisphere this be the day of our test whether we mean or have ever mean to play that part for our own benefit wholly or also for theirs upon the outcome of that test its outcome in their mind not in ours depend every relationship of the united states with latin america whether in politic or in commerce and enterprise these be great issue and lie at the heart of the grave task of the future task both economic and political and very intimately inwrought with many of the most vital of the new issue of the politic of the world the republic of america have in the last three year be draw together in a new spirit of accommodation mutual understanding and cordial cooperation much of the politic of the world in the year to come will depend upon their relationship with one another it be a barren and provincial statesmanship that lose sight of such thing

 the future the immediate future will bring we squarely face to face with many great and exact problem which will search we through and through whether we be able and ready to play the part in the world that we mean to play it will not bring we into their presence slowly gently with ceremonious introduction but suddenly and at once the moment the war in europe be over they will be new problem most of they many will be old problem in a new setting and with new element which we have never deal with or reckon the force and meaning of before they will require for their solution new thinking fresh courage and resourcefulness and in some matter radical reconsideration of policy we must be ready to mobilize our resource alike of brain and of material

 it be not a future to be afraid of it be rather a future to stimulate and excite we to the display of the good power that be in we we may enter it with confidence when we be sure that we understand it,?and we have provide ourselves already with the mean of understand it

 look first at what it will be necessary that the nation of the world should do to make the day to come tolerable and fit to live and work in and then look at our part in what be to follow and our own duty of preparation for we must be prepare both in resource and in policy

 there must be a just and settle peace and we here in america must contribute the full force of our enthusiasm and of our authority as a nation to the organization of that peace upon world wide foundation that can not easily be shake no nation should be force to take side in any quarrel in which its own honor and integrity and the fortune of its own people be not involve but no nation can any long remain neutral as against any wilful disturbance of the peace of the world the effect of war can no long be confine to the area of battle no nation stand wholly apart in interest when the life and interest of all nation be throw into confusion and peril if hopeful and generous enterprise be to be renew if the healing and helpful art of life be indeed to be revive when peace come again a new atmosphere of justice and friendship must be generate by mean the world have never try before the nation of the world must unite in joint guarantee that whatever be do to disturb the whole world&#39;s life must first be test in the court of the whole world&#39;s opinion before it be attempt

 these be the new foundation the world must build for itself and we must play our part in the reconstruction generously and without too much thought of our separate interest we must make ourselves ready to play it intelligently vigorously and well

 one of the contribution we must make to the world&#39;s peace be this we must see to it that the people in our insular possession be treat in their own land as we would treat they here and make the rule of the united states mean the same thing everywhere,?the same justice the same consideration for the essential right of man

 besides contribute our ungrudge moral and practical support to the establishment of peace throughout the world we must actively and intelligently prepare ourselves to do our full service in the trade and industry which be to sustain and develop the life of the nation in the day to come

 we have already be provident in this great matter and supply ourselves with the instrumentality of prompt adjustment we have create in the federal trade commission a means of inquiry and of accommodation in the field of commerce which ought both to coordinate the enterprise of our trader and manufacturer and to remove the barrier of misunderstanding and of a too technical interpretation of the law in the new tariff commission we have add another instrumentality of observation and adjustment which promise to be immediately serviceable the trade commission substitute counsel and accommodation for the harsh process of legal restraint and the tariff commission ought to substitute fact for prejudice and theory our exporter have for some time have the advantage of work in the new light throw upon foreign market and opportunity of trade by the intelligent inquiry and activity of the bureau of foreign and domestic commerce which the democratic congress so wisely create in 1912 the tariff commission complete the machinery by which we shall be enable to open up our legislative policy to the fact as they develop

 we can no long indulge our traditional provincialism we be to play a lead part in the world drama whether we wish it or not we shall lend not borrow act for ourselves not imitate or follow organize and initiate not peep about merely to see where we may get in

 we have already formulate and agree upon a policy of law which will explicitly remove the ban now suppose to rest upon cooperation amongst our exporter in seek and secure their proper place in the market of the world the field will be free the instrumentality at hand it will only remain for the master of enterprise amongst we to act in energetic concert and for the government of the united states to insist upon the maintenance throughout the world of those condition of fairness and of even hand justice in the commercial dealing of the nation with one another upon which after all in the last analysis the peace and order life of the world must ultimately depend

 at home also we must see to it that the man who plan and develop and direct our business enterprise shall enjoy definite and settle condition of law a policy accommodate to the free progress we have set the just and necessary limit we have put all kind of unfair competition under the ban and penalty of the law we have bar monopoly these fatal and ugly thing be exclude we must now quicken action and facilitate enterprise by every just mean within our choice there will be peace in the business world and with peace revive confidence and life

 we ought both to husband and to develop our natural resource our mine our forest our water power i wish we could have make more progress than we have make in this vital matter and i call once more with the deep earnestness and solicitude upon the advocate of a careful and provident conservation on the one hand and the advocate of a free and invite field for private capital on the other to get together in a spirit of genuine accommodation and agreement and set this great policy forward at once

 we must hearten and quicken the spirit and efficiency of labor throughout our whole industrial system by everywhere and in all occupation do justice to the laborer not only by pay a living wage but also by make all the condition that surround labor what they ought to be and we must do more than justice we must safeguard life and promote health and safety in every occupation in which they be threaten or imperille that be more than justice and well because it be humanity and economy

 we must coordinate the railway system of the country for national use and must facilitate and promote their development with a view to that coordination and to their well adaptation as a whole to the life and trade and defense of the nation the life and industry of the country can be free and unhampere only if these artery be open efficient and complete

 thus shall we stand ready to meet the future as circumstance and international policy effect their unfolding whether the change come slowly or come fast and without preface

 i have not speak explicitly gentlemen of the platform adopt at st. louis but it have be implicit in all that i have say i have seek to interpret its spirit and meaning the people of the united states do not need to be assure now that that platform be a definite pledge a practical program we have prove to they that our promise be make to be keep

 we hold very definite ideal we believe that the energy and initiative of our people have be too narrowly coach and superintend that they should be set free as we have set they free to disperse themselves throughout the nation that they should not be concentrate in the hand of a few powerful guide and guardian as our opponent have again and again in effect if not in purpose seek to concentrate they we believe moreover,?who that look about he now with comprehending eye can fail to believe??that the day of little americanism with its narrow horizon when method of protection and industrial nursing be the chief study of our provincial statesman be past and go and that a day of enterprise have at last dawn for the united states whose field be the wide world

 we hope to see the stimulus of that new day draw all america the republic of both continent on to a new life and energy and initiative in the great affair of peace we be americans for big america and rejoice to look forward to the day in which america shall strive to stir the world without irritate it or draw it on to new antagonism when the nation with which we deal shall at last come to see upon what deep foundation of humanity and justice our passion for peace rest and when all mankind shall look upon our great people with a new sentiment of admiration friendly rivalry and real affection as upon a people who though keen to succeed seek always to be at once generous and just and to whom humanity be dear than profit or selfish power

 upon this record and in the faith of this purpose we go to the country
