 i can not accept the leadership and responsibility which the national democratic convention have again in such generous fashion ask i to accept without first express my profound gratitude to the party for the trust it repose in i after four year of fiery trial in the midst of affair of unprecedented difficulty and the keen sense of add responsibility with which this honor fill i have almost say burden i as i think of the great issue of national life and policy involve in the present and immediate future conduct of our government i shall seek as i have always seek to justify the extraordinary confidence thus repose in i by strive to purge my heart and purpose of every personal and of every misleading party motive and devote every energy i have to the service of the nation as a whole pray that i may continue to have the counsel and support of all forward look man at every turn of the difficult business
 for i do not doubt that the people of the united states will wish the democratic party to continue in control of the government they be not in the habit of reject those who have actually serve they for those who be make doubtful and conjectural promise of service least of all be they likely to substitute those who promise to render they particular service and prove false to that promise for those who have actually render those very service

 so thing stand when the democratic party come into power how do they stand now alike in the domestic field and in the wide field of the commerce of the world american business and life and industry have be set free to move as they never move before
 the tariff have be revise not on the principle of repel foreign trade but upon the principle of encourage it upon something like a footing of equality with our own in respect of the term of competition and a tariff board have be create whose function it will be to keep the relation of american with foreign business and industry under constant observation for the guidance alike of our business man and of our congress american energy be now direct towards the market of the world
 the law against trust have be clarify by definition with a view to make it plain that they be not direct against big business but only against unfair business and the pretense of competition where there be none and a trade commission have be create with power of guidance and accommodation which have relieve business man of unfounded fear and set they upon the road of hopeful and confident enterprise
 by the federal reserve act the supply of currency at the disposal of active business have be render elastic take its volume not from a fix body of investment security but from the liquid asset of daily trade and these asset be assess and accept not by distant group of banker in control of unavailable reserve but by banker at the many center of local exchange who be in touch with local condition everywhere
 effective measure have be take for the re creation of an american merchant marine and the revival of the american carry trade indispensable to our emancipation from the control which foreigner have so long exercise over the opportunity the route and the method of our commerce with other country
 the interstate commerce commission be about to be reorganize to enable it to perform its great and important function more promptly and more efficiently we have create extend and improve the service of the parcel post
 so much we have do for business what other party have understand the task so well or execute it so intelligently and energetically what other party have attempt it at all the republican leader apparently know of no mean of assist business but protection how to stimulate it and put it upon a new footing of energy and enterprise they have not suggest
 for the farmer of the country we have virtually create commercial credit by mean of the federal reserve act and the rural credits act they now have the standing of other business man in the money market we have successfully regulate speculation in future and establish standard in the marketing of grain by an intelligent warehouse act we have assist to make the standard crop available as never before both for systematic marketing and as a security for loan from the bank we have greatly add to the work of neighborhood demonstration on the farm itself of improved method of cultivation and through the intelligent extension of the function of the department of agriculture have make it possible for the farmer to learn systematically where his good market be and how to get at they
 the workingman of america have be give a veritable emancipation by the legal recognition of a man&#39;s labor as part of his life and not a mere marketable commodity by exempt labor organization from process of the court which treat their member like fractional part of mob and not like accessible and responsible individual by release our seaman from involuntary servitude by make adequate provision for compensation for industrial accident by provide suitable machinery for mediation and conciliation in industrial dispute and by put the federal department of labor at the disposal of the workingman when in search of work
 we have effect the emancipation of the child of the country by release they from hurtful labor we have institute a system of national aid in the building of highroad such as the country have be feel after for a century we have seek to equalize taxation by mean of an equitable income tax we have take the step that ought to have be take at the outset to open up the resource of alaska we have provide for national defense upon a scale never before seriously propose upon the responsibility of an entire political party we have drive the tariff lobby from cover and oblige it to substitute solid argument for private influence

 we have be neutral not only because it be the fixed and traditional policy of the united states to stand aloof from the politic of europe and because we have have no part either of action or of policy in the influence which bring on the present war but also because it be manifestly our duty to prevent if it be possible the indefinite extension of the fire of hate and desolation kindle by that terrible conflict and seek to serve mankind by reserve cur strength and our resource for the anxious and difficult day of restoration and healing which must follow when peace will have to build its house anew
 the right of our own citizen of course become involve that be inevitable where they do this be our guide principle that property right can be vindicate by claim for damage and no modern nation can decline to arbitrate such claim but the fundamental right of humanity can not be the loss of life be irreparable neither can direct violation of a nation&#39;s sovereignty await vindication in suit for damage the nation that violate these essential right must expect to be check and call to account by direct challenge and resistance it at once make the quarrel in part our own these be plain principle and we have never lose sight of they or depart from they whatever the stress or the perplexity of circumstance or the provocation to hasty resentment the record be clear and consistent throughout and stand distinct and definite for anyone to judge who wish to know the truth about it

 we ought both to husband and to develop our natural resource our mine our forest our water power i wish we could have make more progress than we have make in this vital matter and i call once more with the deep earnestness and solicitude upon the advocate of a careful and provident conservation on the one hand and the advocate of a free and invite field for private capital on the other to get together in a spirit of genuine accommodation and agreement and set this great policy forward at once
 we must hearten and quicken the spirit and efficiency of labor throughout our whole industrial system by everywhere and in all occupation do justice to the laborer not only by pay a living wage but also by make all the condition that surround labor what they ought to be and we must do more than justice we must safeguard life and promote health and safety in every occupation in which they be threaten or imperille that be more than justice and well because it be humanity and economy
 we must coordinate the railway system of the country for national use and must facilitate and promote their development with a view to that coordination and to their well adaptation as a whole to the life and trade and defense of the nation the life and industry of the country can be free and unhampere only if these artery be open efficient and complete

 we hope to see the stimulus of that new day draw all america the republic of both continent on to a new life and energy and initiative in the great affair of peace we be americans for big america and rejoice to look forward to the day in which america shall strive to stir the world without irritate it or draw it on to new antagonism when the nation with which we deal shall at last come to see upon what deep foundation of humanity and justice our passion for peace rest and when all mankind shall look upon our great people with a new sentiment of admiration friendly rivalry and real affection as upon a people who though keen to succeed seek always to be at once generous and just and to whom humanity be dear than profit or selfish power
 upon this record and in the faith of this purpose we go to the country

gentleman of the senate

 on the eighteenth of december last i address an identic note to the government of the nation now at war request they to state more definitely than they have yet be state by either group of belligerent the term upon which they would deem it possible to make peace i speak on behalf of humanity and of the right of all neutral nation like our own many of whose most vital interest the war put in constant jeopardy

 the central powers unite in a reply which state merely that they be ready to meet their antagonist in conference to discuss term of peace

 the entente powers have reply much more definitely and have state in general term indeed but with sufficient definiteness to imply detail the arrangement guarantee and act of reparation which they deem to be the indispensable condition of a satisfactory settlement

 we be that much near a definite discussion of the peace which shall end the present war we be that much near the discussion of the international concert which must thereafter hold the world at peace

 in every discussion of the peace that must end this war it be take for grant that that peace must be follow by some definite concert of power which will make it virtually impossible that any such catastrophe should ever overwhelm we again every lover of mankind every sane and thoughtful man must take that for grant

 i have seek this opportunity to address you because i think that i owe it to you as the council associate with i in the final determination of our international obligation to disclose to you without reserve the thought and purpose that have be take form in my mind in regard to the duty of our government in the day to come when it will be necessary to lay afresh and upon a new plan the foundation of peace among the nation

 it be inconceivable that the people of the united states should play no part in that great enterprise to take part in such a service will be the opportunity for which they have seek to prepare themselves by the very principle and purpose of their polity and the approve practice of their government ever since the day when they set up a new nation in the high and honorable hope that it might in all that it be and do show mankind the way to liberty

 they can not in honor withhold the service to which they be now about to be challenge they do not wish to withhold it but they owe it to themselves and to the other nation of the world to state the condition under which they will feel free to render it that service be nothing less than this to add their authority and their power to the authority and force of other nation to guarantee peace and justice throughout the world such a settlement can not now be long postpone it be right that before it come this government should frankly formulate the condition upon which it would feel justified in ask our people to approve its formal and solemn adherence to a league for peace i be here to attempt to state those condition

 the present war must first be end but we owe it to candor and to a just regard for the opinion of mankind to say that so far as our participation in guarantee of future peace be concern it make a great deal of difference in what way and upon what term it be end the treaty and agreement which bring it to an end must embody term which will create a peace that be worth guarantee and preserving a peace that will win the approval of mankind not merely a peace that will serve the several interest and immediate aim of the nation engage

 we shall have no voice in determine what those term shall be but we shall i feel sure have a voice in determine whether they shall be make lasting or not by the guarantee of a universal covenant and our judgment upon what be fundamental and essential as a condition precedent to permanency should be speak now not afterwards when it may be too late

 no covenant of cooperative peace that do not include the people of the new world can suffice to keep the future safe against war and yet there be only one sort of peace that the people of america could join in guarantee

 the element of that peace must be element that engage the confidence and satisfy the principle of the american government element consistent with their political faith and with the practical conviction which the people of america have once for all embrace and undertake to defend

 i do not mean to say that any american government would throw any obstacle in the way of any term of peace the government now at war might agree upon or seek to upset they when make whatever they might be i only take it for grant that mere term of peace between the belligerent will not satisfy even the belligerent themselves

 mere agreement may not make peace secure it will be absolutely necessary that a force be create as a guarantor of the permanency of the settlement so much great than the force of any nation now engage or any alliance hitherto form or project that no nation no probable combination of nation could face or withstand it

 if the peace presently to be make be to endure it must be a peace make secure by the organized major force of mankind

 the term of the immediate peace agree upon will determine whether it be a peace for which such a guarantee can be secure the question upon which the whole future peace and policy of the world depend be this

 be the present war a struggle for a just and secure peace or only for a new balance of power if it be only a struggle for a new balance of power who will guarantee who can guarantee the stable equilibrium of the new arrangement

 only a tranquil europe can be a stable europe there must be not a balance of power but a community of power not organized rivalry but an organized common peace

 fortunately we have receive very explicit assurance on this point the statesman of both of the group of nation now array against one another have say in term that could not be misinterpret that it be no part of the purpose they have in mind to crush their antagonist but the implication of these assurance may not be equally clear to all?may not be the same on both side of the water i think it will be serviceable if i attempt to set forth what we understand they to be

 they imply first of all that it must be a peace without victory it be not pleasant to say this i beg that i may be permit to put my own interpretation upon it and that it may be understand that no other interpretation be in my thought

 i be seek only to face reality and to face they without soft concealment victory would mean peace force upon the loser a victor&#39;s term impose upon the vanquished it would be accept in humiliation under duress at an intolerable sacrifice and would leave a sting a resentment a bitter memory upon which term of peace would rest not permanently but only as upon quicksand

 only a peace between equal can last only a peace the very principle of which be equality and a common participation in a common benefit the right state of mind the right feeling between nation be as necessary for a last peace as be the just settlement of vex question of territory or of racial and national allegiance

 the equality of nation upon which peace must be found if it be to last must be an equality of right the guarantee exchange must neither recognize nor imply a difference between big nation and small between those that be powerful and those that be weak

 right must be base upon the common strength not upon the individual strength of the nation upon whose concert peace will depend

 equality of territory or of resource there of course can not be nor any other sort of equality not gain in the ordinary peaceful and legitimate development of the people themselves but no one ask or expect anything more than an equality of right mankind be look now for freedom of life not for equipoise of power

 and there be a deep thing involve than even equality of right among organize nation no peace can last or ought to last which do not recognize and accept the principle that government derive all their just power from the consent of the govern and that no right anywhere exist to hand people about from sovereignty to sovereignty as if they be property

 i take it for grant for instance if i may venture upon a single example that statesman everywhere be agree that there should be a united independent and autonomous poland and that henceforth inviolable security of life of worship and of industrial and social development should be guarantee to all people who have live hitherto under the power of government devote to a faith and purpose hostile to their own

 i speak of this not because of any desire to exalt an abstract political principle which have always be hold very dear by those who have seek to build up liberty in america but for the same reason that i have speak of the other condition of peace which seem to i clearly indispensable,?because i wish frankly to uncover reality

 any peace which do not recognize and accept this principle will inevitably be upset it will not rest upon the affection or the conviction of mankind the ferment of spirit of whole population will fight subtly and constantly against it and all the world will sympathize the world can be at peace only if its life be stable and there can be no stability where the will be in rebellion where there be not tranquillity of spirit and a sense of justice of freedom and of right

 so far as practicable moreover every great people now struggle towards a full development of its resource and of its power should be assure a direct outlet to the great highway of the sea where this can not be do by the cession of territory it can no doubt be do by the neutralization of direct right of way under the general guarantee which will assure the peace itself with a right comity of arrangement no nation need be shut away from free access to the open path of the world&#39;s commerce

 and the path of the sea must alike in law and in fact be free the freedom of the sea be the sine qua non of peace equality and cooperation

 no doubt a somewhat radical reconsideration of many of the rule of international practice hitherto think to be establish may be necessary in order to make the sea indeed free and common in practically all circumstance for the use of mankind but the motive for such change be convincing and compelling there can be no trust or intimacy between the people of the world without they

 the free constant unthreatened intercourse of nation be an essential part of the process of peace and of development it need not be difficult either to define or to secure the freedom of the sea if the government of the world sincerely desire to come to an agreement concern it

 it be a problem closely connect with the limitation of naval armament and the cooperation of the navy of the world in keep the sea at once free and safe and the question of limit naval armament open the wide and perhaps more difficult question of the limitation of army and of all program of military preparation

 difficult and delicate as these question be they must be face with the utmost candor and decide in a spirit of real accommodation if peace be to come with healing in its wing and come to stay peace can not be have without concession and sacrifice there can be no sense of safety and equality among the nation if great preponderate armament be henceforth to continue here and there to be build up and maintain

 the statesman of the world must plan for peace and nation must adjust and accommodate their policy to it as they have plan for war and make ready for pitiless contest and rivalry the question of armament whether on land or sea be the most immediately and intensely practical question connect with the future fortune of nation and of mankind

 i have speak upon these great matter without reserve and with the utmost explicitness because it have seem to i to be necessary if the world&#39;s yearn desire for peace be anywhere to find free voice and utterance perhaps i be the only person in high authority amongst all the people of the world who be at liberty to speak and hold nothing back

 i be speak as an individual and yet i be speak also of course as the responsible head of a great government and i feel confident that i have say what the people of the united states would wish i to say may i not add that i hope and believe that i be in effect speak for liberal and friend of humanity in every nation and of every program of liberty

 i would fain believe that i be speak for the silent mass of mankind everywhere who have as yet have no place or opportunity to speak their real heart out concern the death and ruin they see to have come already upon the person and the home they hold most dear

 and in hold out the expectation that the people and government of the united states will join the other civilized nation of the world in guarantee the permanence of peace upon such term as i have name i speak with the great boldness and confidence because it be clear to every man who can think that there be in this promise no breach in either our tradition or our policy as a nation but a fulfilment rather of all that we have profess or striven for

 i be propose as it be that the nation should with one accord adopt the doctrine of president monroe as the doctrine of the world that no nation should seek to extend its polity over any other nation or people but that every people should be leave free to determine its own polity its own way of development unhindered unthreatened unafraid the little along with the great and powerful

 i be propose that all nation henceforth avoid entangle alliance which would draw they into competition of power catch they in a net of intrigue and selfish rivalry and disturb their own affair with influence intrude from without there be no entangle alliance in a concert of power when all unite to act in the same sense and with the same purpose all act in the common interest and be free to live their own life under a common protection

 i be propose government by the consent of the govern that freedom of the sea which in international conference after conference representative of the united states have urge with the eloquence of those who be the convinced disciple of liberty and that moderation of armament which make of army and navie a power for order merely not an instrument of aggression or of selfish violence

 these be american principle american policy we could stand for no other and they be also the principle and policy of forward look man and woman everywhere of every modern nation of every enlighten community they be the principle of mankind and must prevail
gentleman of the congress
 the imperial german government on the thirty first of january announce to this government and to the government of the other neutral nation that on and after the first day of february the present month it would adopt a policy with regard to the use of submarine against all shipping seek to pass through certain designate area of the high sea to which it be clearly my duty to call your attention
 let i remind the congress that on the eighteenth of april last in view of the sinking on the twenty fourth of march of the cross channel passenger steam sussex by a german submarine without summon or warning and the consequent loss of the life of several citizen of the united states who be passenger aboard she this government address a note to the imperial german government in which it make the follow declaration
 if it be still the purpose of the imperial government to prosecute relentless and indiscriminate warfare against vessel of commerce by the use of submarine without regard to what the government of the united states must consider the sacred and indisputable rule of international law and the universally recognize dictate of humanity the government of the united states be at last force to the conclusion that there be but one course it can pursue unless the imperial government should now immediately declare and effect an abandonment of its present method of submarine warfare against passenger and freight carry vessel the government of the united states can have no choice but to sever diplomatic relation with the german empire altogether
 in reply to this declaration the imperial german government give this government the follow assurance
 the german government be prepared to do its utmost to confine the operation of war for the rest of its duration to the fight force of the belligerent thereby also insure the freedom of the sea a principle upon which the german government believe now as before to be in agreement with the government of the united states
 the german government guide by this idea notify the government of the united states that the german naval force have receive the follow order
 in accordance with the general principle of visit and search and destruction of merchant vessel recognize by international law such vessel both within and without the area declare as naval war zone shall not be sink without warn and without save human life unless these ship attempt to escape or offer resistance
 but it add neutral can not expect that germany force to fight for her existence shall for the sake of neutral interest restrict the use of an effective weapon if her enemy be permit to continue to apply at will method of warfare violate the rule of international law such a demand would be incompatible with the character of neutrality and the german government be convince that the government of the united states do not think of make such a demand know that the government of the united states have repeatedly declare that it be determined to restore the principle of the freedom of the sea from whatever quarter it have be violate
 to this the government of the united states reply on the eighth of may accept of course the assurance give but add
 the government of the united states feel it necessary to state that it take it for grant that the imperial german government do not intend to imply that the maintenance of its newly announce policy be in any way contingent upon the course or result of diplomatic negotiation between the government of the united states and any other belligerent government notwithstanding the fact that certain passage in the imperial government&#39;s note of the fourth instant might appear to be susceptible of that construction in order however to avoid any possible misunderstanding the government of the united states notify the imperial government that it can not for a moment entertain much less discuss a suggestion that respect by german naval authority for the right of citizen of the united states upon the high sea should in any way or in the slight degree be make contingent upon the conduct of any other government affect the right of neutral and non combatant responsibility in such matter be single not joint absolute not relative
 to this note of the eighth of may the imperial german government make no reply
 on the thirty first of january the wednesday of the present week the german ambassador hand to the secretary of state along with a formal note a memorandum which contain the follow statement
 the imperial government therefore do not doubt that the government of the united states will understand the situation thus force upon germany by the entente allies&#39 brutal method of war and by their determination to destroy the central powers and that the government of the united states will far realize that the now openly disclose intention of the entente allies give back to germany the freedom of action which she reserve in her note address to the government of the united states on may 4 1916
 under these circumstance germany will meet the illegal measure of her enemy by forcibly prevent after february 1 1917 in a zone around great britain france italy and in the eastern mediterranean all navigation that of neutral include from and to england and from and to france etc etc all ship meet within the zone will be sink
 i think that you will agree with i that in view of this declaration which suddenly and without prior intimation of any kind deliberately withdraw the solemn assurance give in the imperial government&#39;s note of the fourth of may 1916 this government have no alternative consistent with the dignity and honor of the united states but to take the course which in its note of the eighteenth of april 1916 it announce that it would take in the event that the german government do not declare and effect an abandonment of the method of submarine warfare which it be then employ and to which it now purpose again to resort
 i have therefore direct the secretary of state to announce to his excellency the german ambassador that all diplomatic relation between the united states and the german empire be sever and that the american ambassador at berlin will immediately be withdraw and in accordance with this decision to hand to his excellency his passport
 notwithstanding this unexpected action of the german government this sudden and deeply deplorable renunciation of its assurance give this government at one of the most critical moment of tension in the relation of the two government i refuse to believe that it be the intention of the german authority to do in fact what they have warn we they will feel at liberty to do i can not bring myself to believe that they will indeed pay no regard to the ancient friendship between their people and our own or to the solemn obligation which have be exchange between they and destroy american ship and take the life of american citizen in the willful prosecution of the ruthless naval program they have announce their intention to adopt
 only actual overt act on their part can make i believe it even now
 if this inveterate confidence on my part in the sobriety and prudent foresight of their purpose should unhappily prove unfounded if american ship and american life should in fact be sacrifice by their naval commander in heedless contravention of the just and reasonable understanding of international law and the obvious dictate of humanity i shall take the liberty of come again before the congress to ask that authority be give i to use any mean that may be necessary for the protection of our seaman and our people in the prosecution of their peaceful and legitimate errand on the high sea i can do nothing less i take it for grant that all neutral government will take the same course
 we do not desire any hostile conflict with the imperial german government we be the sincere friend of the german people and earnestly desire to remain at peace with the government which speak for they we shall not believe that they be hostile to we unless and until we be oblige to believe it and we purpose nothing more than the reasonable defense of the undoubted right of our people we wish to serve no selfish end we seek merely to stand true alike in thought and in action to the immemorial principle of our people which i seek to express in my address to the senate only two week ago,&mdash;seek merely to vindicate our right to liberty and justice and an unmolested life these be the basis of peace not war god grant we may not be challenge to defend they by act of wilful injustice on the part of the government of germany

gentleman of the congress
 i have again ask the privilege of address you because we be move through critical time during which it seem to i to be my duty to keep in close touch with the houses of congress so that neither counsel nor action shall run at cross purpose between we
 on the third of february i officially inform you of the sudden and unexpected action of the imperial german government in declare its intention to disregard the promise it have make to this government in april last and undertake immediate submarine operation against all commerce whether of belligerent or of neutral that should seek to approach great britain and ireland the atlantic coast of europe or the harbor of the eastern mediterranean and to conduct those operation without regard to the establish restriction of international practice without regard to any consideration of humanity even which might interfere with their object that policy be forthwith put into practice it have now be in active execution for nearly four week
 its practical result be not yet fully disclose the commerce of other neutral nation be suffer severely but not perhaps very much more severely than it be already suffer before the first of february when the new policy of the imperial government be put into operation we have ask the cooperation of the other neutral government to prevent these depredation but so far none of they have think it wise to join we in any common course of action our own commerce have suffer be suffer rather in apprehension than in fact rather because so many of our ship be timidly keep to their home port than because american ship have be sink
 two american vessel have be sink the housatonic and the lyman m. law the case of the housatonic which be carry food stuff consign to a london firm be essentially like the case of the fry in which it will be recall the german government admit its liability for damage and the life of the crew as in the case of the fry be safeguard with reasonable care the case of the law which be carry lemon box stave to palermo disclose a ruthlessness of method which deserve grave condemnation but be accompany by no circumstance which might not have be expect at any time in connection with the use of the submarine against merchantman as the german government have use it
 in sum therefore the situation we find ourselves in with regard to the actual conduct of the german submarine warfare against commerce and its effect upon our own ship and people be substantially the same that it be when i address you on the third of february except for the tying up of our shipping in our own port because of the unwillingness of our shipowner to risk their vessel at sea without insurance or adequate protection and the very serious congestion of our commerce which have result a congestion which be grow rapidly more and more serious every day this in itself might presently accomplish in effect what the new german submarine order be mean to accomplish so far as we be concern we can only say therefore that the overt act which i have venture to hope the german commander would in fact avoid have not occur
 but while this be happily true it must be admit that there have be certain additional indication and expression of purpose on the part of the german press and the german authority which have increase rather than lessen the impression that if our ship and our people be spare it will be because of fortunate circumstance or because the commander of the german submarine which they may happen to encounter exercise an unexpected discretion and restraint rather than because of the instruction under which those commander be act it would be foolish to deny that the situation be fraught with the grave possibility and danger no thoughtful man can fail to see that the necessity for definite action may come at any time if we be in fact and not in word merely to defend our elementary right as a neutral nation it would be most imprudent to be unprepared
 i can not in such circumstance be unmindful of the fact that the expiration of the term of the present congress be immediately at hand by constitutional limitation and that it would in all likelihood require an unusual length of time to assemble and organize the congress which be to succeed it i feel that i ought in view of that fact to obtain from you full and immediate assurance of the authority which i may need at any moment to exercise no doubt i already possess that authority without special warrant of law by the plain implication of my constitutional duty and power but i prefer in the present circumstance not to act upon general implication i wish to feel that the authority and the power of the congress be behind i in whatever it may become necessary for i to do we be jointly the servant of the people and must act together and in their spirit so far as we can divine and interpret it
 no one doubt what it be our duty to do we must defend our commerce and the life of our people in the midst of the present trying circumstance with discretion but with clear and steadfast purpose only the method and the extent remain to be choose upon the occasion if occasion should indeed arise since it have unhappily prove impossible to safeguard our neutral right by diplomatic mean against the unwarranted infringement they be suffer at the hand of germany there may be no recourse but to armed neutrality which we shall know how to maintain and for which there be abundant american precedent
 it be devoutly to be hope that it will not be necessary to put armed force anywhere into action the american people do not desire it and our desire be not different from theirs i be sure that they will understand the spirit in which i be now act the purpose i hold near my heart and would wish to exhibit in everything i do i be anxious that the people of the nation at war also should understand and not mistrust we i hope that i need give no further proof and assurance than i have already give throughout nearly three year of anxious patience that i be the friend of peace and mean to preserve it for america so long as i be able i be not now propose or contemplate war or any step that need lead to it i merely request that you will accord i by your own vote and definite bestowal the mean and the authority to safeguard in practice the right of a great people who be at peace and who be desirous of exercise none but the right of peace to follow the pursuit of peace in quietness and good will,&mdash;right recognize time out of mind by all the civilized nation of the world no course of my choosing or of theirs will lead to war war can come only by the wilful act and aggression of other
 you will understand why i can make no definite proposal or forecast of action now and must ask for your support authority in the most general term the form in which action may become necessary can not yet be foresee i believe that the people will be willing to trust i to act with restraint with prudence and in the true spirit of amity and good faith that they have themselves display throughout these try month and it be in that belief that i request that you will authorize i to supply our merchant ship with defensive arm should that become necessary and with the mean of use they and to employ any other instrumentality or method that may be necessary and adequate to protect our ship and our people in their legitimate and peaceful pursuit on the sea i request also that you will grant i at the same time along with the power i ask a sufficient credit to enable i to provide adequate mean of protection where they be lack include adequate insurance against the present war risk
 i have speak of our commerce and of the legitimate errand of our people on the sea but you will not be mislead as to my main thought the thought that lie beneath these phrase and give they dignity and weight it be not of material interest merely that we be think it be rather of fundamental human right chief of all the right of life itself i be think not only of the right of americans to go and come about their proper business by way of the sea but also of something much deep much more fundamental than that i be think of those right of humanity without which there be no civilization my theme be of those great principle of compassion and of protection which mankind have seek to throw about human life the life of non combatant the life of man who be peacefully at work keep the industrial process of the world quick and vital the life of woman and child and of those who supply the labor which minister to their sustenance we be speak of no selfish material right but of right which our heart support and whose foundation be that righteous passion for justice upon which all law all structure alike of family of state and of mankind must rest as upon the ultimate base of our existence and our liberty i can not imagine any man with american principle at his heart hesitate to defend these thing

my fellow citizens

 the four year which have elapse since last i stand in this place havebeen crowd with counsel and action of the most vital interest and consequence perhaps no equal period in our history have be so fruitful of importantreform in our economic and industrial life or so full of significant changesin the spirit and purpose of our political action we have seek verythoughtfully to set our house in order correct the gross error andabuse of our industrial life liberate and quicken the process of ournational genius and energy and lift our politic to a broad view ofthe people&#39; essential interest

 and yet all the while we have be conscious that we be not part ofit in that consciousness despite many division we have draw closertogether we have be deeply wrong upon the sea but we have not wishedto wrong or injure in return have retain throughout the consciousnessof stand in some sort apart intent upon an interest that transcendedthe immediate issue of the war itself

 there be many thing still to be do at home to clarify our own politicsand add new vitality to the industrial process of our own life and weshall do they as time and opportunity serve but we realize that the greatestthing that remain to be do must be do with the whole world for stageand in cooperation with the wide and universal force of mankind and weare make our spirit ready for those thing

force into it because there be no other mean of defend our right it will be all the easy for we to conduct ourselves as belligerent in a high spirit of right and fairness because we act without animus humanity and of right and be run amuck we be let i say again the sincere friend of the german people and shall desire nothing so much as the early reestablishment of intimate relation of mutual advantage between we however hard it may be for they for the time be to believe that this be speak from our heart we have bear with their present government through all these bitter month because of that friendship exercise a patience and forbearance which would otherwise have be impossible we shall happily still have an opportunity to prove that friendship in our daily attitude and action toward the million of man and woman of german birth and native sympathy who live among we and share our life and we shall be proud to prove it toward all who be in fact loyal to their neighbor and to the government in the hour of test they be most of they as true and loyal americans as if they have never know any other fealty or allegiance they will be prompt to stand with we in rebuke and restrain the few who may be of a different mind and purpose if there should be disloyalty it will be deal with with a firm hand of stern repression but if it lift its head at all it will lift it only here and there and without countenance except from a lawless and malignant few it be a distressing and oppressive duty gentleman of the congress which i have perform in thus address you there be it may be many month of fiery trial and sacrifice ahead of we it be a fearful thing to lead this great peaceful people into war into the most terrible and disastrous of all war civilization itself seem to be in the balance but the right be more precious than peace and we shall fight for the thing which we have always carry near our heart for democracy for the right of those who submit to authority to have a voice in their own government for the right and liberty of small nation for a universal dominion of right by such a concert of free people as shall bring peace and safety to all nation and make the world itself at last free to such a task we can dedicate our life and our fortune everything that we be and everything that we have with the pride of those who know that the day have come when america be privileged to spend her blood and her might for the principle that give her birth and happiness and the peace which she have treasure god help she she can do no other
my countryman the surpass war of all time have involve we and find we utterly unprepared in either a mental or military sense the republic must awaken the people must understand our safety lie in full realization the fate of the nation and the safety of the world will be decide on the western battlefront of europe

 primarily the american republic have enter the war in defense of its national right if we do not defend we could not hope to endure other big issue be involve but the maintain right and defend honor of a righteous nation include they all cherish the national right the father fight to establish and love freedom and civilization we should have violate every tradition and sacrifice every inheritance if we have long hold aloof from the armed conflict which be to make the world safe for civilization more we be commit to sacrifice in battle in order to make america safe for americans and establish their security on every lawful mission on the high sea or under the shine sun

 we be test popular government 's capacity for self defense we be resolve to liberate the soul of american life and prove ourselves an american people in fact spirit and purpose and consecrate ourselves anew and everlastingly to human freedom and humanity 's justice realize our new relationship with the world we want to make it fit to live in and with might and fright and ruthlessness and barbarity crush by the conscience of a real civilization ours be a small concern about the kind of government any people may choose but we do mean to outlaw the nation which violate the sacred compact of international relationship

 the decision be to be final if the russian failure should become the tragic impotency of nation if italy should yield to the pressure of military might if heroic france should be martyr on her flaming altar of liberty and justice and only the soul of heroism remain if england should starve and her sacrifice and resolute warfare should prove in vain if all these improbable disaster should attend even then we should fight on and on make the world 's cause our cause

 a republic worth live in be worth fight for and sacrifice for and die for in the fire of this conflict we shall wipe out the disloyalty of those who wear american garb without the faith and establish a new concord of citizenship and a new devotion so that we should have make a safe america the home and hope of a people who be truly american in heart and soul

whereas the congress of the united states in the exercise of the constitutional authority vest in they have resolve by joint resolution of the senate and house of representatives bear date this day that the state of war between the united states and the imperial german government which have be thrust upon the united states be hereby formally declare

 whereas it be provide by section 4067 of the revised statutes as follow

 whenever there be declare a war between the united states and any foreign nation or government or any invasion or predatory incursion be perpetrate attempt or threaten against the territory of the united states by any foreign nation or government and the president make public proclamation of the event all native citizen denizen or subject of a hostile nation or government be male of the age of fourteen year and upwards who shall be within the united states and not actually naturalize shall be liable to be apprehend restrain secure and remove as alien enemy the president be authorize in any such event by his proclamation thereof or other public act to direct the conduct to be observe on the part of the united states toward the alien who become so liable the manner and degree of the restraint to which they shall be subject and in what case and upon what security their residence shall be permit and to provide for the removal of those who not be permit to reside within the united states refuse or neglect to depart therefrom and to establish any such regulation which be find necessary in the premise and for the public safety

 whereas by section 4068 4069 and 4070 of the revised statutes further provision be make relative to alien enemy

 now therefore i woodrow wilson president of the united states of america do hereby proclaim to all whom it may concern that a state of war exist between the united states and the imperial german government and i do specially direct all officer civil or military of the united states that they exercise vigilance and zeal in the discharge of the duty incident to such a state of war and i do moreover earnestly appeal to all american citizen that they in loyal devotion to their country dedicate from its foundation to the principle of liberty and justice uphold the law of the land and give undivided and willing support to those measure which may be adopt by the constitutional authority in prosecute the war to a successful issue and in obtain a secure and just peace

 and act under and by virtue of the authority vest in i by the constitution of the united states and the say section of the revised statutes i do hereby further proclaim and direct that the conduct to be observe on the part of the united states toward all native citizen denizen or subject of germany be male of the age of fourteen year and upwards who shall be within the united states and not actually naturalize who for the purpose of this proclamation and under such section of the revised statutes be term alien enemy shall be as follow

 all alien enemy be enjoin to preserve the peace towards the united states and to refrain from crime against the public safety and from violate the law of the united states and of the states and territories thereof and to refrain from actual hostility or give information aid or comfort to the enemy of the united states and to comply strictly with the regulation which be hereby or which may be from time to time promulgate by the president and so long as they shall conduct themselves in accordance with law they shall be undisturbed in the peaceful pursuit of their life and occupation and be accord the consideration due to all peaceful and law abide person except so far as restriction may be necessary for their own protection and for the safety of the united states and towards such alien enemy as conduct themselves in accordance with law all citizen of the united states be enjoin to preserve the peace and to treat they with all such friendliness as may be compatible with loyalty and allegiance to the united states

 and all alien enemy who fail to conduct themselves as so enjoin in addition to all other penalty prescribe by law shall be liable to restraint or to give security or to remove and depart from the united states in the manner prescribe by section 4069 and 4070 of the revised statutes and as prescribe in the regulation duly promulgate by the president

 and pursuant to the authority vest in i i hereby declare and establish the following regulation which i find necessary in the premise and for the public safety

 first an alien enemy shall not have in his possession at any time or place any fire arm weapon or implement of war or component part thereof ammunition maxim or other silencer bomb or explosive or material use in the manufacture of explosive

 second an alien enemy shall not have in his possession at any time or place or use or operate any aircraft or wireless apparatus or any form of signal device or any form of cipher code or any paper document or book write or print in cipher or in which there may be invisible writing

 third all property find in the possession of an alien enemy in violation of the foregoing regulation shall be subject to seizure by the united states

 fourth an alien enemy shall not approach or be find within one half of a mile of any federal or state fort camp arsenal aircraft station government or naval vessel navy yard factory or workshop for the manufacture of munition of war or of any product for the use of the army or navy

 fifth an alien enemy shall not write print or publish any attack or threat against the government or congress of the united states or either branch thereof or against the measure or policy of the united states or against the person or property of any person in the military naval or civil service of the united states or of the states or territories or of the district of columbia or of the municipal government therein

 sixth an alien enemy shall not commit or abet any hostile act against the united states or give information aid or comfort to its enemy

 seventh an alien enemy shall not reside in or continue to reside in to remain in or enter any locality which the president may from time to time designate by executive order as a prohibit area in which residence by an alien enemy shall be find by he to constitute a danger to the public peace and safety of the united states except by permit from the president and except under such limitation or restriction as the president may prescribe

 eighth an alien enemy whom the president shall have reasonable cause to believe to be aid or about to aid the enemy or to be at large to the danger of the public peace or safety of the united states or to have violate or to be about to violate any of these regulation shall remove to any location designate by the president by executive order and shall not remove therefrom without a permit or shall depart from the united states if so require by the president

 ninth no alien enemy shall depart from the united states until he shall have receive such permit as the president shall prescribe or except under order of a court judge or justice under section 4069 and 4070 of the revised statutes

 tenth no alien enemy shall land in or enter the united states except under such restriction and at such place as the president may prescribe

 eleventh if necessary to prevent violation of the regulation all alien enemy will be oblige to register

 twelfth an alien enemy whom there may be reasonable cause to believe to be aid or about to aid the enemy or who may be at large to the danger of the public peace or safety or who violate or attempt to violate or of whom there be reasonable ground to believe that he be about to violate any regulation duly promulgate by the president or any criminal law of the united states or of the states or territories thereof will be subject to summary arrest by the united states marshal or his deputy or such other officer as the president shall designate and to confinement in such penitentiary prison jail military camp or other place of detention as may be direct by the president

 this proclamation and the regulation herein contain shall extend and apply to all land and water continental or insular in any way within the jurisdiction of the united states

 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix

 do at the city of washington this 6th day of april in the year of our lord one thousand nine hundred and seventeen and of the independence of the united states of america the one hundred and forty first
my fellow countrymen
 the entrance of our own beloved country into the grim and terrible war for democracy and human right which have shake the world create so many problem of national life and action which call for immediate consideration and settlement that i hope you will permit i to address to you a few word of earnest counsel and appeal with regard to they
 we be rapidly put our navy upon an effective war footing and be about to create and equip a great army but these be the simple part of the great task to which we have address ourselves there be not a single selfish element so far as i can see in the cause we be fight for we be fight for what we believe and wish to be the right of mankind and for the future peace and security of the world to do this great thing worthily and successfully we must devote ourselves to the service without regard to profit or material advantage and with an energy and intelligence that will rise to the level of the enterprise itself we must realize to the full how great the task be and how many thing how many kind and element of capacity and service and self sacrifice it involve
 these then be the thing we must do and do well besides fight the thing without which mere fighting would be fruitless
 we must supply abundant food for ourselves and for our army and our seaman not only but also for a large part of the nation with whom we have now make common cause in whose support and by whose side we shall be fight
 we must supply ship by the hundred out of our shipyard to carry to the other side of the sea submarine or no submarine what will every day be need there and abundant material out of our field and our mine and our factory with which not only to clothe and equip our own force on land and sea but also to clothe and support our people for whom the gallant fellow under arm can no long work to help clothe and equip the army with which we be coordinate in europe and to keep the loom and manufactory there in raw material coal to keep the fire go in ship at sea and in the furnace of hundred of factory across the sea steel out of which to make arm and ammunition both here and there rail for wear out railway back of the fighting front locomotive and roll stock to take the place of those every day go to piece mule horse cattle for labor and for military service everything with which the people of england and france and italy and russia have usually supply themselves but can not now afford the man the material or the machinery to make
 it be evident to every thinking man that our industry on the farm in the shipyard in the mine in the factory must be make more prolific and more efficient than ever and that they must be more economically manage and well adapt to the particular requirement of our task than they have be and what i want to say be that the man and the woman who devote their thought and their energy to these thing will be serve the country and conduct the fight for peace and freedom just as truly and just as effectively as the man on the battlefield or in the trench the industrial force of the country man and woman alike will be a great national a great international service army a notable and honored host engage in the service of the nation and the world the efficient friend and savior of free man everywhere thousand nay hundred of thousand of man otherwise liable to military service will of right and of necessity be excuse from that service and assign to the fundamental sustain work of the field and factory and mine and they will be as much part of the great patriotic force of the nation as the man under fire
 i take the liberty therefore of address this word to the farmer of the country and to all who work on the farm the supreme need of our own nation and of the nation with which we be coordinate be an abundance of supply and especially of food stuff the importance of an adequate food supply especially for the present year be superlative without abundant food alike for the army and the people now at war the whole great enterprise upon which we have embark will break down and fail the world&#39;s food reserve be low not only during the present emergency but for some time after peace shall have come both our own people and a large proportion of the people of europe must rely upon the harvest in america upon the farmer of this country therefore in large measure rest the fate of the war and the fate of the nation may the nation not count upon they to omit no step that will increase the production of their land or that will bring about the most effectual coordination in the sale and distribution of their product the time be short it be of the most imperative importance that everything possible be do and do immediately to make sure of large harvest i call upon young man and old alike and upon the able bodied boy of the land to accept and act upon this duty to turn in host to the farm and make certain that no pain and no labor be lack in this great matter
 i particularly appeal to the farmer of the south to plant abundant food stuff as well as cotton they can show their patriotism in no well or more convincing way than by resist the great temptation of the present price of cotton and help help upon a great scale to feed the nation and the people everywhere who be fight for their liberty and for our own the variety of their crop will be the visible measure of their comprehension of their national duty
 the government of the united states and the government of the several states stand ready to coordinate they will do everything possible to assist farmer in secure an adequate supply of seed an adequate force of laborer when they be most need at harvest time and the mean of expedite shipment of fertilizer and farm machinery as well as of the crop themselves when harvest the course of trade shall be as unhampere as it be possible to make it and there shall be no unwarranted manipulation of the nation&#39;s food supply by those who handle it on its way to the consumer this be our opportunity to demonstrate the efficiency of a great democracy and we shall not fall short of it
 this let i say to the middleman of every sort whether they be handle our food stuff or our raw material of manufacture or the product of our mill and factory the eye of the country will be especially upon you this be your opportunity for signal service efficient and disintereste the country expect you as it expect all other to forego unusual profit to organize and expedite shipment of supply of every kind but especially of food with an eye to the service you be render and in the spirit of those who enlist in the rank for their people not for themselves i shall confidently expect you to deserve and win the confidence of people of every sort and station
 to the man who run the railway of the country whether they be manager or operative employee let i say that the railway be the artery of the nation&#39;s life and that upon they rest the immense responsibility of see to it that those artery suffer no obstruction of any kind no inefficiency or slackened power to the merchant let i suggest the motto small profit and quick service and to the shipbuilder the thought that the life of the war depend upon he the food and the war supply must be carry across the sea no matter how many ship be send to the bottom the place of those that go down must be supply and supply at once to the miner let i say that he stand where the farmer do the work of the world wait on he if he slacken or fail army and statesman be helpless he also be enlist in the great service army the manufacturer do not need to be tell i hope that the nation look to he to speed and perfect every process and i want only to remind his employee that their service be absolutely indispensable and be count on by every man who love the country and its liberty
 let i suggest also that everyone who create or cultivate a garden help and help greatly to solve the problem of the feeding of the nation and that every housewife who practice strict economy put herself in the rank of those who serve the nation this be the time for america to correct her unpardonable fault of wastefulness and extravagance let every man and every woman assume the duty of careful provident use and expenditure as a public duty as a dictate of patriotism which no one can now expect ever to be excuse or forgive for ignore
 in the hope that this statement of the need of the nation and of the world in this hour of supreme crisis may stimulate those to whom it come and remind all who need reminder of the solemn duty of a time such as the world have never see before i beg that all editor and publisher everywhere will give as prominent publication and as wide circulation as possible to this appeal i venture to suggest also to all advertising agency that they would perhaps render a very substantial and timely service to the country if they would give it widespread repetition and i hope that clergyman will not think the theme of it an unworthy or inappropriate subject of comment and homily from their pulpit
 the supreme test of the nation have come we must all speak act and serve together

by the president of the united states of america

 section 5 that all male person between the age of twenty one and thirty both inclusive shall be subject to registration in accordance with regulation to be prescribe by the president and upon proclamation by the president or other public notice give by he or by his direction state the time and place of such registration it shall be the duty of all person of the designate age except officer and enlisted man of the regular army the navy and the national guard and naval militia while in the service of the united states to present themselves for and submit to registration under the provision of this act

 the penalty for failure

 provide that in the call of the docket preference shall be give in court try the same to the trial of criminal proceeding under this act
 provide far that person shall be subject to registration as herein provide who shall have attain their twenty first birthday and who shall not have attain their thirty first birthday on or before the day set for the registration and all person so register shall be and remain subject to draft into the force hereby authorize unless exempt or excuse therefrom as in this act provide
 provide far that in the case of temporary absence from actual place of legal residence of any person liable to registration as provide herein such registration may be make by mail under regulation to be prescribe by the president
 the work of registration

 neglect of duty and fraud
 any person charge as herein provide with the duty of carry into effect any of the provision of this act or the regulation make or direction give thereunder who shall fail or neglect to perform such duty and any person charge with such duty or have and exercise any authority under say act regulation or direction who shall knowingly make or be a party to the making of any false or incorrect registration physical examination exemption enlistment enrolment or muster
 and any person who shall make or be a party to the making of any false statement or certificate as to the fitness or liability of himself or any other person for service under the provision of this act or regulation make by the president thereunder or otherwise evade or aid another to evade the requirement of this act or of say regulation or who in any manner shall fail or neglect fully to perform any duty require of he in the execution of this act shall if not subject to military law be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction in the district court of the united states have jurisdiction thereof be punish by imprisonment for not more than one year or if subject to military law shall be try by court martial and suffer such punishment as a court martial may direct

 registration by mail
 and i do hereby charge those who through sickness shall be unable to present themselves for registration that they apply on or before the day of registration to the county clerk of the county where they may be for instruction as to how they may be register by agent
 those who expect to be absent on the day name from the county in which they have their permanent home may register by mail but their mail registration card must reach the place in which they have their permanent home by the day name herein they should apply as soon as practicable to the county clerk of the county wherein they may be for instruction as to how they may accomplish their registration by mail
 in case such person as through sickness or absence may be unable to present themselves personally for registration shall be sojourn in city of over 30,000 population they shall apply to the city clerk of the city wherein they may be sojourn rather than to the clerk of the county
 the clerks of county and of city of over 30,000 population in which numerous application from the sick and from non resident be expect be authorize to establish such sub agency and to employ and deputize such clerical force as may be necessary to accommodate these application
 the whole nation an army
 the power against which we be array have seek to impose its will upon the world by force to this end it have increase armament until it have change the face of war in the sense in which we have be will not to think of army there be no army in this struggle there be entire nation arm
 thus the man who remain to till the soil and man the factory be no less a part of the army that be in france than the man beneath the battle flag
 it must be so with we it be not an army that we must shape and train for war it be a nation to this end our people must draw close in one compact front against a common foe but this can not be if each man pursue a private purpose all must pursue one purpose the nation need all man but it need each man not in the field that will most pleasure he but in the endeavor that will well serve the common good
 thus though a sharpshooter please to operate a trip hammer for the forging of great gun and an expert machinist desire to march with the flag the nation be be serve only when the sharpshooter marche and the machinist remain at his lever the whole nation must be a team in which each man shall play the part for which he be well fit
 not a draft of the unwilling
 to this end congress have provide that the nation shall be organize for war by selection that each man shall be classify for service in the place to which it shall well serve the general good to call he
 the significance of this can not be overstate it be a new thing in our history and a landmark in our progress it be a new manner of accept and vitalize our duty to give ourselves with thoughtful devotion to the common purpose of we all it be in no sense a conscription of the unwilling it be rather selection from a nation which have volunteer in mass
 it be no more a choosing of those who shall march with the color than it be a selection of those who shall serve an equally necessary and devoted purpose in the industry that lie behind the battle line
 the day here name be the time upon which all shall present themselves for assignment to their task it be for that reason destine to be remember as one of the most conspicuous moment in our history it be nothing less than the day upon which the manhood of the country shall step forward in one solid rank in defense of the ideal to which this nation be consecrate it be important to those ideal no less than to the pride of this generation in manifest its devotion to they that there be no gap in the rank
 day of patriotic devotion
 it be essential that the day be approach in thoughtful apprehension of its significance and that we accord to it the honor and the meaning that it deserve our industrial need prescribe that it be not make a technical holiday but the stern sacrifice that be before we urge that it be carry in all our heart as a great day of patriotic devotion and obligation when the duty shall lie upon every man whether he be himself to be register or not to see to it that the name of every male person of the designate age be write on these list of honor
